All guides have a range of languages and ours also was doing musical history at university so had extra stories and insights into the building, performances etc. It was value for money and easily organized by visiting the Opera House or looking it up online.

Exquisite inside!. A tour is a must; the inside holds so much splendor. You have to pay for the tour which is overpriced. However you cannot walk around otherwise, unless you buy tickets for a performance.

Fascinating building - interesting history. The Hungarians are rightly proud of this building. It is not as grand as others in Europe for political reasons but what they managed to do within those restrictions is remarkable. The carpentry is wonderful as is makes the most out of oak and not more exotic timbers. The tour was in English which was a bonus and the guide knowledgeable and engaging.
Beautiful architecture!. A gem of a building,beautiful architecture. We did the guided tour which was so very well presented. The Opera House is one of the top 10 landmarks to visit in Budapest.

The diva of opera houses☺. I’m still floating on a soprano cloud. This museum-like opera house opened in 1884—the year after NY’s Brooklyn Bridge and 35 years after Chain Bridge—the gilded glory era. It’s been restored and most of the fixtures are original. There are continual tours grouped by language, which gather on the grand staircases. The tour moves through ante-rooms into the grand hall. I entered an upper-level loge, stage left. Spectacular chandeliers grace the ceiling, and the 1,200 (compared to Vienna’s 2,000) wooden seats are the originals, from 1884, though the red velvet has been replaced a number of times. There are five levels of seating/boxes, and the floor has metal grates for heat or ventilation under each seat.Although the complete tour package is expensive for the limited time allowed, that includes a mini-opera at the end. The diva in the accompanying photo performed two arias. Wow, what a voice! And no microphone or amplification. There’s an additional charge to take pix, but unless using advanced photographic equipment the photos in low lighting are poor quality, as evidenced by my accompanying pathetic attempts. I highly recommend a tour of this phenomenal edifice. Travel in time to the gilded era of grandness, something that is rarely found in the States.

Charming and historical . Ancient charming theater for the historicity structure and intact furnishings and decorations! We watch a lyrical stupendous work, with a lot of Hungarian people and manicured and tourists all characters and attentive to the arts and culture (very important and fundamental in this city and citizens)

Very Fancy!. My boyfriend and I went to watch a musical in the State Opera House and it was a whole other experience for us! We decided to get tickets because they were literally three pounds each and we thought for that price we couldnt go wrong. When we got there the man asked us if we wanted to be upgraded for free and put us in one of the front rows! We didnt actually enjoy the opera itself (I think because we are not cultured enough!) but we loved seeing the inside of the Opera building which was absolutely incredible! I would recommend a visit to anyone!

Very Enjoyable . We visited this Opera House and the knowledgeable guide showed us a lot including allowing us to sit in one of the boxes while she continued her talk. The tour covered several areas and was just the right length. There were many tour groups that day so we had to move rooms a couple of times but that was fine as I think we saw more. It was beautiful on the inside. They were preparing for a show so we even saw them change lighting and viewed a stage set. Easy to get to and I would recommend this attraction. One note, if you plan to take photos you need to buy a pass to do so.
Great Opera House. Worth a visit, a lot of history, a great experience, we saw it as part of a guided tour and placed we did.

Another lovely looking building . Walked by this several times on our trip. a really busy place as everytime we walked by there was loads of people with cameras etc almost waiting for people to arrive.
Def worth walking by.

Nice but pricey! . Good information and an excellent tour guide, didn't get to see as much as I have done on other opera house tours (eg didn't see any stage or scenery.) A mini concert is available for a few extra forints, we didn't go to this so I can't comment on if it's worth it. The whole experience was just a bit expensive for what it is. Beautiful building though!
Surprisingly interesting . The guided tour is well worth it as it not only because of the explanations on the architecture but also because it correlates it to Hungarian history.

Beautiful Building. Did a tour. Tour guides were very knowledgeable and presented in an entertaining way. The entertainment, opera singing (favourites eg Toreador etc) on the stairs was the highlight of the tour.

Cultural Icon. The Hungarian Opera House (Magyar Allami Operahaz) was unveiled in 1884 by thewell known architect Ybl Miklos, another focal point of the city`s boulevard, the Andrassy Street.The iterior of the opera house impresses visitors with marble, gold, and wroght iron works, and statues featuring prominent composers, where Gustav Mahler has been the musical director.The opera house is located on Andrassy Boulevard named after Count Gyula Andrassy; strolling alongside pre-show restaurants, rolling street food stalls, grand-terrasse coffee houses, and posh shops for contemporary fashion with footprints of the country´s past; you will also pass the House of Terror telling Budapests dark history.On the left side of Heroe`s Square you find the Museum of fine arts with art works ofVenecian, Dutch and Spanish masters; on the other side there is the Hall of Arts focusing on contemporary exhibitions.The Hungarian State Opera House featuring its unique cultural identiy and should be perhaps on your visiting itinerary whilst staying in Budapest.

Very well organized tour with impressive young guides. We did the tour with the mini concert (which was sitting on the steps in the staircase and not in the main theater) but that was still worth the extra 2 dollars if you are with kids who can't sit through a full opera but you want to appreciate the up-close talents of an opera singer. I preferred the stairs venue because we were so close to the singer and could see the work and finesse she put into her singing. The guide we had in English was very good and knew an extensive amount of stories and information about the building. It was a very worthwhile tour overall.

Could have skipped. We took the English tour for 2990 HUF and opted to not add the 'mini-concert.' Access was limited while the guide was very good. All in all, I have attended real performances in as ornate old venues. So, paying a fee just to tour, we should have skipped the tour.

Take a tour inside and have a concert, opera or ballet. They have 2 tours both 3 and 4 o clock everyday. We have taken 4 o clock one .It is about an hour in English, French, German, Italian and Japanese. You can have a concert if you pay additional fee. Concert has 2 aria songs and takes place on the stairs (strange) instead of the real stage. We have paid to take photos but many didn’t and still took photos. Nice building similar (but smaller) with the one in Vienna. During the tour you can visit several areas , main hall,bar, royal stairs and rooms,hawses etc. I think it is better to have a concert, opera or ballet to feel the atmosphere. Opera Cafe is also nice for a coffee while waiting.
Dress up and Enjoy!. This is a beautiful setting for any performance. Although all are welcome, enhance your experience by dressing up! My only negative comment is that the seats are VERY hard.
Had a tour. Had a tour of the opera house, complete with a mini concert at the end. What a stunning place. The tour guide was great. This is a must for all classical music lovers.

Expected level of Wow. Beautiful and grand as expected of a European royal state opera house as far as art, architecture, and interior design are concerned. Attending a concert there would be more meaningful than the guided tour if you get the opportunity and ticket prices are reasonable.

Overpriced and disappointing. Felt like sheep being herded into different nationalities at the start then a fairly lack lustre tour. The saving grace was watching Billy Elliott rehearsal in the auditorium! The mini opera (which costs extra) was done on the entrance stairs and had started before our tour ended - the man who does the 'Go Compare' advert on UK TV was better.All in all, the visit was below what I expected for the cost.

Magnifivent theatre. We booked the 2pm tour with mini concert (it IS 'mini'): well worth it. If you love theatre/opera/classical music or just admiring beautiful buildings then do it. So much history and so many great names associated with the building. Not to be missed.

Lovely visit. Beautiful building, no shows in july, though they do a mini concert, at end of tour if you pay for it, i say mini its 2 songs from an opera singer and you sit on stairs, careful sit at the front you may have to dance with the singer, we paid to take photos but many didnt and still took photos i guess if you didnt want to pay nobody would stop you.

Beautiful building. A really beautiful building with a lovely interior and great history. Sitting on the grand staircase listening to one of the professional singers perform a couple of well known arias was the icing on the cake.

Good to know. It is a bit expensive. I joined Japanese tour, cause English groups was huge. It looked more 50 people. Japanese was 5. But Otter Participants were old rady and I felt uncomfortable. But your guide was quite nice. He is Hungarian but he learns Japanese himself. His Japanese is no problem

Beautiful place, do a guided tour.. It a very beautiful and old place, very nice guided tour that can be made at 15:00 and 16:00. if you pay extra 2.5 EUR you will have the chance to sea 5 min of an Opera singing.

An interesting tour and mini performance. The tour offered an interesting glimpse into the patronage of the Opera and the associated decision making process in designing the resplendent spaces. Also where costs were cut to make the project happen.Inside the place is a real gem and well worth a look around.

On a private tour we were treated like royalty. Our tour company arranged a private tour that took us to the stage, we sat in the privileged boxes and even had a solo by two of the leads in a surprise performance. It does not get any better.
Amazing. We were able to take a guided tour of the Opera House, & take in a mini concert. The theater is breath taking with all the gold.

Magnificent building. . Walked by the opera house and went inside to try and organise a tour. Tours run hourly and are in English. They also seem to include a mini concert. I didn't end up going but the building was beautiful.

Rich & Opulent. State Opera House, Budapest is a must for any music-lover and a lover of history. It is richly decorated and furnished, its opulent interiors are a treat. Conducted tours in many different languages that give you a very good idea about the history of this marvel, are highly recommended. Interestingly, the opera house will be hosting its first non-classical modern musical performance for the first time in its history.

Not worth the money. 3000 Forint, tours in English are at 2, 3 and 4pm. They want you to pay an extra 2 Euro if you want to take pictures. The group size was 35(x4) in English. Tour started 15 minutes after scheduled time, annoying waiting time in a crowd.The building itself its nice but for this money you get to see way more in other cities and places. The tour ended after less than 40 minutes. Would not recommend. Mostly squeezing money out of tourists.

A beautiful old building.. A beautiful old building. I like to walk by at morning when there is no cafe tables there. Try to walk around the Opera House. The only one bad thing about it is that the area is not very clean, especially behind the Opera House.

Must get tour with opera performance. I am not an opera fan, but I loved seeing the opera house. You need to pay for a tour if you want to view the inside (not expensive though). You can pay extra to take photos and/or to hear opera singer at the end of the tour. I paid for the music and it was worth the extra 660 forint. It was the best part of the tour! Amazing! The house, though, is breathtaking and the tour will only take you about 40 minutes. Do it! The walk to get to opera house from District V is quick--about 15 minutes--and it's pretty too!
Magnificent building. . Beautiful architecture and interior. We did not attend a performance but believe it would be special. Nice area for a stroll and bear St Stephens basilica.
A Must For Music Afficienadoes. We attended an afternoon tour and had a fantastic time. Great guide and a gorgeous setting, very ornate. We even had a brief opera performance at the end.

Beautiful . Not only is the Opera House beautiful, the location puts you in the heart of great restaurants and shopping. Our family took the tour and arrived early enough to hear the mini concert sung prior to our visit. The Opera House tour is informative and interesting. Definitely worth the price!

Fantastic and Beautiful. The tour and cost are well worth the time and price. The tours are by language preference. Get tickets early. Groups are small. It is worth getting the extra part of the music / singing portion of the tour. It is a slight extra cost but worth hearing the beautiful singer. The building is exquisite.

Beautiful Opera House. We took a 45-minute guided tour of the interior of the opera house. The tour guide was informative and her English was very good. We opted for the 10 minute "mini-concert" at the end, which was fun. This will cost you a few dollars, but if you enjoy old and opulent, give this a visit.

don' t miss the guided tours!. It is really one of the best/most exciting experience, you can have in Budapest. The tickets are relatively cheap compared to other Opera Houses in Europe. Book online well in advance! Guided tours are also available. However it will be closed down for reconstruction starting from Spring/summer of 2017 until May 2018. Erkel Ferenc theater an other, yet less impressive building, close to Blaha Lujza ter will carry on with ballett performances/Opera shows. If you are a classical music/music fan then MÜPA next to the Danube is also a must see spot!
A nice stop . It's a nice place to stop by if you are in the city center. I walked around the building and had a look inside the alley but the hall is only accessible through guided tours.
Historical and great acoustics. Enjoyed the opera Queen of Spades while in Budapest. The building was phenomenal and with everyone dressed to the nines an unique experience.

A must stop in Budapest. Beautiful architecture inside and out. English tour runs out fast and only in the afternoon, so we booked the day before. I'm so glad we booked the tour with the mini concert since we couldn't get a show ticket during our time of visit. You won't be disappointed with the a bit extra paid for the mini concert.
Worth. Good cultural show glimpse of Hungarian dances & great costumes,singing etc.45 minutes show & after 10 minutes interval again 45 minutes show,worth to watch if interested in local folks

Beautiful building. We stopped in for an impromptu tour after our fabulous bike tour with yellow zebra (their shop is just behind the Opera House). We took a tour in English with Mini Opera Concert add on. I wish the tour was more informative regarding the art work and artifacts inside. There was a brief discussion of the engineering of the building and its "cooling system" which was interesting. The mini concert was 5 minutes long and performed on the entry stairway rather than in the hall itself I thought it was wonderful. My husband, not an opera fan, thought the length was just right.

The best opera house I've visited. As of now, I have visited Barcelona's, this and Vienna's opera houses and I can say that this is the most beautiful. Every detail was done with care and the tour also talks about the "side stories" like what else it was used for besides the obvious opera performances. A must-see for thorough visitors.

Very beautiful building. The building is superb, with walls and ceilings covered in beautiful, ornate art. Take the tour of the Opera House (and you can get a mini-mini opera performance at the end).Well worth the visit!

Simply beautiful!. Not much to add to what others have already written. The Opera House is a gorgeous building that rivals any other in the world. Our tour guide was great. She knew her subject extremely well and let us dictate the pace of the tour. It is worth the visit.

Beautiful lobby. Even if you don't take the tour, find time to visit the Opera House lobby, which is free to do. Conveniently located on the nicest part of Andrussy Ut. The lobby is superb, with walls and ceilings covered in beautiful, ornate art. Well worth the visit.

Interesting tour worth a visit with a mini opera show at end!. Although there were many people on the tour which is difficult to manage, we really enjoyed the experience; it's nice to be shown the various sites with background information, very sweet tour guide. We paid a little extra for the mini opera performance at the end which was a bonus and highly recommended
Worth a visit -Budapest Opera house. You will be amazed by the beautiful interior of this opera house. It truly rivals the one in Vienna. I would recommend purchasing the option to take pictures.

Highlight of Budapest Visit. We did a tour of the Opera House and our guide gave us little details about its acoustic and construction which made us appreciate the place more.It is Opulent with such fine detailing in the wood work and also marble. the grand staircase with its balustrade is a designers delight. The distinction between the original works and later renovations is evident to see.I highly recommend a conducted tour of this place to appreciate the effort and workmanship of this beautiful heritage.

Beautiful building. When you just judge the building than it is one of most wonderful best opera houses of the world. When it come to a performence - you must be very lucky if you have a good one. The best singers of HUngary all are abroad, and the rest is just avarage or poor. We had already some expreience, when tourists, who have heard about the Budapest Opera House went to a parformance, and after the first or second intemission they left. By the way the seats are in terrible condition and the noise what they make sometimes even lauder than the music.

Quick walk bu. Came across the opera house while walking down Andrássy Street. We viewed from the outside and went in as far as they would let us without buying a ticket. Like many buildings here, the ceilings architecture is lovely. Given the number of churches and other architectural marvels we chose to skip the paid tour. Hence my 3 star rating.
Beautiful but. A phenomenal structure to behold -- first class acoustics and some top level talentAlas subtitles unlike in Vienna are not offered in English --

Go see it!. We bought a ticket to the opera, cheapest of tickets, right up in the Gods. The building is fantastic, well worth the trip just to see that. We didn't stay for the entire opera, I got a real pain in my neck trying to see, but that was beside the point.

Interesting tour. Beautiful building and get themini concert to get a taste of what the opera audiences hear. One tip--go when they are doing performances as the air conditioning is on. Our guide was delightful!

Nice tour, beautiful building. The tour was interesting, although crowded, and the building is beautiful.The mini concert in the end is recommended in my opinion (although it costs more).In the summer time when there are no shows the building is not air-conditioned and gets very hot - beware if it bothers you.

Epic tour of a wonderful building. After spending two years here we finally decided to go on the Opera House tour.It is an elegant building with so much architectural features from wall and ceiling paintings to tons of gleaming marble.The inside is extremely well maintained and lovely. The tour guides split the groups by language which is good and details some of the basic features. At the end of the 3pm and 4pm tours you are treated to two songs by an opera singer which finishes of the tour on a high.Well worth the money and effort.

a little bit of culture. well worth a visit, although tours are only in the afternoon. Added bonus you can pay extra for a mini concert at the end. Not ideal for someone with walking issues as there are a lot of steps

Magnificent Architecture and Decor. We purchased a guided tour with an optional mini-opera performance at the end at the ticket office. We were not given any tickets but only given a receipt and armbands for the optional performance. 20 minutes later as we tried to enter, we were told that we needed tickets. After a brief exchange and their review of our receipt we were permitted to enter. When the tour began, we were told that we could not take any photos unless we had purchased an additional photo armband. This was not an option that the lady at the ticket office offered to us and it was too late to add it. The tour was very crowded and we could not understand half of what the guide said - partly due to her accent and partly due to tours going on in adjacent spaces in other languages. It's really too bad because it is a gorgeous facility. I only wish we could have understood what we were seeing and had a few photos for memories.

Take the tour!. The inside of the opera house is stunning. On the tour you will see many beautiful frescoes, the Presidential box (no other way to see it other than being invited by the President!), the inside of the opera and the buffet/food area. The tour itself is full of interesting anecdotes about the history of the opera. It takes about 45 minutes. You could purchase a right to take photos for HUF 500 and for another small fee, you could listen to a short 5-6 minute mini concert with 2 opera songs.

Good site to view. This opera house is a little off the main city Centre. It's small and well kept. We purchased tkts for a guided tour and it had a 2 min performance at the end. The interior is quite beautiful.There is a small cafe and gift shop attached to it.

Be sure to take the tour. We book the tour with the mini concert after. I would recommend this to anyone even if your not a big opera buff. The concert includes two partial songs and ends the tour on a high note.

This Opera House i even more lovely than their "bigger brother" in Vienna!. We have been to the magnificent Vienna State Opera House many times. With reference to the history of the Austrian-Hungarian empire during the centuries we were convinced that Vienna's opera house would be the most impressive of the two. However, we were wrong! The Hungarian Opera House was really a Beauty! See for yourselves! We joined a visit tour and was very much impressed.
Beautiful place. This a relatively small opera house with beautiful design and decoration. We did a group tour in the afternoon that took about 45 minutes. They offer tours in six languages.
Beautiful. This opera house is an amazing piece of history that thankfully has been kept in Budapest We enjoyed our visit and the performance we received A wonderful visitn

A lifetime experience!. A piece of art is in the middle of one of the most famouw streets in Budapest. The building is amazing from the inside and outside, it's deffinately worth it to do the tour and if you love opera you shouls buy tickets for a performance.In my opinion it's the most beautiful opera house in Europe!!

Wonderful. We took a fascinating tour of the Opera House on our trip to Budapest. We learned a lot about Hungarian culture on the tour, as well as the opera house itself. We also paid a little extra to watch a mini opera performance. It was my first experience with opera and it was wonderful!

Great Experience. We saw the jazzy performance of The Fairy Queen here. Great value row 12 tickets purchased online for just about $100 for two. Great visuals and acoustics. If you can catch a performance I recommend you do so. Nice dining options nearby too.

Tours cancelled at short notice.. Having checked the website the day before we arrived to find the usual English language tours cancelled, by the look of things in favour of cruise ship parties. Major disappointment.

For the love of Opera. A small version of the Paris Opera, even if you are not interested in Opera, a visit will not disappoint. Artists are of world class, as well as the orchestra. Operas are performed in 'Seasons', so best to check for programs beforehand. Pre book tickets on line.

take the tour - enjoy it all. The opera house is a classic looking building in the heart of Budapest. We signed up for a tour with a mini opera which is a short but well worth it 5 mini opera. The tour started sitting in the opera house listening to a guide go over the history followed by a waling tour and finally the "mini-opera" performance.

Stunning opera house fantastic value tickets. We went to see Madame butterfly on a Sunday morning at 11am! The opera was full with all ages from children to very elderly. It was fantastic to see it so well supported. Beautiful old building with stunning ornate areas. Don't miss on a visit to Budapest.
So royal!. Was lovely to see the inside of the opera house. We had a guided tour and the tour guide was lovely and made it all very interesting!

Great mini opera at the Opera House. We did a walking tour of the opera house and included in our ticket was a mini opera in one of the main stair cases. It really was something. The building and the opera singer were so enjoyable!

small but beautiful. you should attend one of the excursions with a mini-concert: such a nice atmosphere in such a "cosy" theatre. It is the opposite of Opera Garnier in Paris, but it breathes culture and refinement

Beautiful. We went to the Opera House and as many of the building in Budapest, it's simply a chef d'oeuvre of architecture!
We walk inside a bit, but we didn't think it was worth it to pay to visit inside, better book a real show in my humble opinion.

See the opera. We got tickets for the Opera while we were in Budapest, rather than paying for a tour. 1st row, balcony seats at about $20 each was well worth it. We had an excellent view. We saw an English opera, and they had subtitles across the top in English and Hungarian (not sure what languages they do with the Italian operas).
very beautiful. a gorgeous piece of architecture. The statues on top are marvelous and it's worth visiting. If you also catch some Opera there it's even better!
Beautiful. Buy a ticket for the five minute opera as one of the cast sings for you at the end of your of the opera house, just beautiful experience

Maybe not for German opera.... We bought last minute tickets to the passion of the Christ over the easter weekend. Tickets were very reasonable and easy to come by last minute. The theatre is stunning, and well worth the visit. Wardrobe is a mix of casual and dressy - caters to all. All that said, German opera is unique, so perhaps stick to Italian or French productions if you're an opera newbie.

Impressive building. I would have loved to have been able to have done one of the tours of this opera house, sadly because of all the other places we were visiting we could never get back at the right time, tours were available in English during the afternoon and seemed good value for money. From what we could see in the entrance the internal painted ceilings must be beautiful. If we go back we will def make sure we do catch one of the daily tours

Wonderful architecture. This place is worth to be seen, wonderful architecture and a piece of history. The guidance was really bad. Very big groups and hard to hear anything. And due to rehearsals in the main area it was hardly impossible to see anything or hear the guides whispering voice in the darkness. Wonderful place and definitely worth a visit for the architecture but don't expect to much from the guiding service.
Beautiful Opera House!. Very typical European traditional opera house - the little show was excellent! I wish I could attend one show - I did not have time

Opera House on Andrassy Ave. Not the largest, and in places a little worn, but really worth a look inside. English language tours in the afternoon; pay a little extra for the opera "mini concert" of about 5min duration.
See it if you can. I had a tour and it was interesting to see it and hear about the lifestyle in those times. We had a surprise performance of a male and female opera singers.

Excellent Experience. As we were staying in the hotel next to the Opera House (K&K Opera) we bought tickets directly from the Opera House at 6480 HUF (approx. £17.50) for the two of us. Please note that there is a small charge of 500 HUF to allow you to take pictures inside the Opera House (£1.35 approx.). There are tours in English at 2, 3 & 4 o'clock for around an hour. There is an option to take in a mini concert at the end of the tour for an additional charge, but we did not do this as we just wanted to see the Opera House. The Opera House is beautiful and the tour guide was excellent, offering to answer questions on each part of the building we toured and was at a good pace. We toured the auditorium, the royal box and the tour guide was informative without being overloaded and kept my attention for the whole tour. The architecture is stunning and it is definitely worth a visit!

Cheap but surprisingly good!. 1. Tickets are very easily available.2. The price of the said tickets is very democratic.3. Opera house itself is very nice and the public is polite and engaged - not a beer bottle in sight!All in all, we enjoyed our impromptu visit - watched "Die Fledermaus" ("The Bat"), an operetta.If you have a spare evening in Budapest - I definitely recommend to experience Hungarian Opera!

An absolute must!. My furstvtrip to Budapest I didn't get to see anything at the opera house and was disappointed so on return I booked tickets and went back I. May to see Onegin. I was not disappointed. Being an avid fan of the ROH in London, the state opera house in Budapest had a lot to live up to and it met with my expectations. Not only was the ballet performance wonderful, the auditorium, although smaller than the ROH but, like the ROH is breathtaking. Going back to Budapest for a long weekend to see the ballet and state opera house was a top decision and I would definitely return for a long weekend again just for this purpose. Highly recommended.

Nice But Not Fantastic. I guess we just expected more. It was beautiful but we keep getting the feeling that we were being herded quickly through the facility. Never had a feeling of being relaxed enough to truly enjoy this visit. Hard to complain but relatively speaking the entrance price was high was high for what you get...

Purcell's Fairy Queen. The building and interior decoration of the Hungarian Opera House is simply stunning! If you cannot afford a performance there are guided tours which are well worth the cost! We enjoyed Purcell's music and the Scenes presented. The subtitles were in English and Hungarian. It is not really an opera, just individual scenes with musical interludes. The costumes were all in black and white but very imaginative and the singing was beautiful. There was even a car on the stage and the different scenes appeared either from above or on a moving circular arrangement.

Take the tour, get a mini concert!. As part of a tour, the tour of the opera house was included and I'm really happy it was. The inside is lovely and the guides really give you an appreciation of how important music is the the Hungarian people. The concerts are often very reasonably priced if your timing is such that they are performing and not in rehearsals. At the end of the tour they perform a mini concert at the foot of the grand staircase (where you're sitting), which was very entertaining and the singing was really impressive. Make sure to pay the extra money to be able to take photos inside if you think you might enjoy the photos, you must be wearing a wristband to use you camera.
very nice. It was a very nice tour with the surprise and the end ! you get a song from one of the opera singers. It gives you just the taste of wanting more. Next time I will go for a concert!!

Very disappointing.. The best way to describe this place is – a rip off. Entry is by paid tour only. Their are only one or two tours per day (in the late afternoon). The tour is not specific to one language – so you spend a large amount of time listening to the same story in a variety of different languages. If you want to take photos as a memento of your visit – you have to pay extra. Why? Either they don't want you to take photos, because it might cause problems to the décor or paintings, or they don't mind. They only want to gouge more cash out of the visitors.All in all a very disappointing place to visit
Interesting Tour. Beautiful building from the late 19th century and the half hour tour was sufficient in an afternoon to appreciate the classical style.

Tours Available at 2:00, 3:00, and 4:00 PM. We took the 3:00 PM guided tour, in English, and it was a great experience. We were escorted into the auditorium itself, as well as other ornate spaces of the Opera House, which was built 1875-1884. The auditorium and seats use a lot of wood to enhance the audio qualities. At the time we went, "The Fairy Queen" was about to premier. At the end of the tour we were treated to a "mini Concert" by an opera singer.

Interesting . Our Hotel was right next to the Opera House and we also did a guided tour. Obviously it was built with the intention of not being superior to Vienna's Opera House but still a beautiful and unique building. Interesting that the original seats were wooden and very uncomfortable. I was disappointed to see that they had a huge billboard advertising an upcoming event covering up most of the front facade of the Opera House which ruins a photograph of such an amazing piece of architecture.

Exquisite. Went during the day on the weekend - worth going as it will take your breath away.
The frescos on the inside are incredible - and so well preserved. Very beautiful late 19th century building.

Beautiful building but ............ We paid for a tour of the Opera House, and also paid for one of us to be able to take photos. On top of that we paid for a mini concert. The tour was interesting and it was good to have photo opportunities but ........ the mini concert was a rip off. I don't know if this is normal but the "concert" was held in a marble stairway (beautiful, mind you). The main part of the Opera House was being set up for an opera. We came out from the tour and saw a whole crowd of people sitting on the stairs, and we were guided to join them. An opera singer came out to the bottom of the stairs, sang two partial pieces, bowed and left. The acoustics were horrible and literally painful to the ear, so I was glad it didn't last long. Ask where the mini concert is being held before you pay or save your money!

Ordered Opera tix here, actually at another, drab theater . Gorgeous opera house but no opera here.I ordered tickets to a Verdi opera but arrived to find it was actually at another thresher across town that was drab. Decent opera, it felt like a bait and switch since I was interested in seeing an opera in this famed house.

Great tour and fun mini concert. We wanted to attend an opera but didn't have the right clothing so we did the tour instead. The building is beautiful, the tour well done, and the optional mini concert well worth it.
Stunning building.. Such an impressive building. Really beautiful. We didn't get to go inside unfortunately. But the building is so pretty from the outside anyway. Well worth seeing.

Wonderful building. Visit or attend a performance!. An impressive building with the statues of Franz Liszt and Ferenc Erkel in front. It's considered to be one of the best opera houses in the world because of great quality on acoustics and beauty! If you are unlucky like us and there are no performances you can take a tour and see a mini concert for an additional 690 fiorins or about 2,5 euros.

really pretty!!. It's located in the middle of Andrassy street, right infront of the Opera station! I had a chance to enjoy ballet performance, Manon. It was great performance; all of the performers were really talented. The Interior is gorgeous and can also take really pretty photos inside too!

Does not get old. I live in Hungary so I've visited this place many times (this time with my parents) but it is simply beautiful and doesn't get boring. We joined guided tour in Japanese (Mondays, Thursdays, and Saturdays if I'm not mistaken, at 15 and 16 o'clock) and it took about 40 mins. The guide was Hungarian but she spoke it fluently. You need to purchase an additional wristband if you'd like to take pictures inside or join mini concert after the tour. They provide tour in French, Spanish, Italian, English, Russian, Japanese, and Hungarian. Go see opera if you get the chance. She said the Opera is run by government and even the most expensive ticket is about 80-100 USD ish. You can check the schedule on Internet.
Beautiful and impressive building. Beautiful and impressive building. Can take a guided toor of 40 minutes, or going to see a show (Opera or Ballet).
great dissapointing. we tryed to visit inside but there are visiting hours during day time and only with a guide. Don't like this. And entrance fee.

Tour with opera singer. Beautiful building and the guide gives interesting information about the building itself and its visitors. On our tour an opera singer sang some well known parts from operas. Great ambiance.
Fantastic tour. Having just taken the Vienna Opera House tour, I must say that the Hungarian Opera house should not be missed! Amazingly decorated. Smaller than Vienna, but very opulent.

Hungarian State Opera House. A friend and I decided on a bit of culture one evening in Budapest and the only thing available was 'Lear' at the State Opera House. It was worth the visit for the building alone which is absolutely stunning as you might expect but this modern opera based on Shakespeare's King Lear was pretty way out and not very enjoyable only to be made worse by the seats!! They were fold down cinema seats with no upholstery at all, just plain wood with a single layer of covering material. Tough going for two and a half hours but we stuck it out. My colleague said it added to the purgatory of the story! I can't recommend a visit here unless you are an opera buff at any cost.

impressive!. We visited in the summer, no opera in season. But we did have a wonderful tour of a majestic opera house, and for a small fee were treated to a mini concert by a talented opera singer. Don't miss this beautiful place.

Beautiful inside, interesting tour. We went on the English tour of the opera house which runs 1-3 times a day. We didn't need book as we were advised it rarely gets booked up. Went around the auditorium, the aristocrats bar and some of the Royal rooms which are very beautiful. Also has a mini opera concert at be end which gave a good flavour of the shows without the price tag!
It has character. A lot of detail. Well worth a visit.. Enjoyed the tour inside and I hope to go see a show one day, am sure it will be spectacular.. Put it on your list!!

Wow!. Great building. Great acoustics. Great city. Great location. Great music. Great people...What's not to like? Situated right in the hub of this deceptively huge and varied city, restaurants, coffee bars, dive bars, designer shops, lovely, airy, stylish streets and folk all around..... I think I'm a little bit in love with Budapest.

Interesting building. We did not go inside this building however we walked by it on our way up Andrassy Avenue to Hosok Ter. The building is nice looking and worth a walk by; cannot say anything about the interior.

Two large groups. Nice building. Fast speaking guide. . Twenty five of us toured the opera house, it is well worth seeing with lots of gold leaf and due to the weight artificial marble. Mini concert for our group was well sung.

Opulent opera. Great afternoon of grandeur in the opera house with a lovely guide. Well worth a visit and the mini performance at the end of the tour was a nice touch. Everything is extra, taking photos and the mini concert, not really worth paying extra for. Front of house only though, no back stage tour and quite s large group of 40 in our English speaking tour.

Opulent venue for an awe inspiring opera. We visited the Opera House to see The Queen of Hearts. The venue itself is worth a visit even if you do not see an opera. Such decadent and opulent surroundings are well worth exploring during the intervals and you can even go out on the balcony to enjoy a drink.

Buy the ticket that includes the free mini concert on the stairs. The Opera House is beautiful. Filled with gold leaf baroque style interiors and elegant paintings it is definitely worth taking the tour. We were asked not to take pictures because we didn't have the right corner of wrist bands. But there was no enforcement for the large group, so picture taking resumed. I think only people with large cameras were targeted. Also be sure to buy the ticket that includes the 10 minutes mini concert on the staircase after the tour. The stairway acoustics are great and the singer was excellent. It cost extra. Our guide spoke good English but was quiet. Other nearby guides were louder, so if you have a choice get the guide with the dominant voice. We walked up and bought tickets. Tour times vary. Not all tours include the casual concert.

Very Disappointing. Three levels of tickets...basic tour paper ticket. Add-on is permission to take photos inside with a red wrist band and to listen to a mini-concert with blue wrist band. Several hundred people lined up, with the majority seeking English. The tour did not start on time. The group was far too large and had to be divided. Thus, there were at least four large groups being moved from one location to another like a herd of cattle. I found it extremely difficult to listen because of the noise from other guides yelling to their groups. It became almost impossible to discern what was being said. Also, plenty of people without the red wrist band were taking pictures without penalty. Instead of letting us sit in the theater and listen to one of the opera singers perform, we were herded to a large staircase and told to sit on the floor! The opera singer was good but by this point I was too disgusted by this waste of time and money. It appeared the tours were hindered because of rehearsals. It would seem someone in authority would have rehearsals at one time and tours at another.

Wow. This is the only word I can think of to describe this stunningly beautiful building. The tour was fantastic,the young lady conducting the tour spoke very good English,me and my wife were most impressed. Listening the the soprano was a great touch.A simply beautiful place to visit.
Beautiful building. Inside is very ornate. Worth a look. If I ever go back I'll make sure to see a show here. Even the gift shop was super fancy.

Gorgeous Opera House. Excellent visit , English speaking guide, only young girl (early 20's I'd say), Great communication skills and knowledge of the workings of the building and conveyed great enthusiasm for Hungary and the Opera

A delicate opera house. It is inevitable to compare the opera house in budapest with the one in Vienna. Undoubtedly the one in Vienna was bigger, but decorations of this opera house seemed more appealing to me. Some of the wooden artefacts were nicely made, while the main opera hall was a nice place to stay in.We went for an opera house tour which cost £5 for students on its own. May need to buy a photo pass and a mini concert ticket separately. Just buy tickets before the tour in the opera house and will be fine.
beautiful opera house. this opera house is a must for visiting.the building , the halls and the theater and gorgeous and worth visiting.Also worth seeing an opera of ballet if you like it.
Opera House. This point was covered during the city sight seeing tour of Budapest from outside only. We did not stop here.
Amazing. Wonderful place to visit if you are on your own get a guide or tour so they can explain the history and current going ons if this wonderful place
Really better than Viennas!. It may look smaller on the outside but on the inside the beauty far outweighs Vienna's. The box seats are most interesting. A surprise performance enhances the visit.

Make sure to get good seats.. We went here to see an opera and took two seats on the second floor and on the second row of the balcony. We asked if it was still good seats, if we would be able to see good - and got the answer that we would.A complete lie.We didnt see enough at all - if we stood up we could see half of the stage, and the whole balcony probably just saw half of the english surtitles. Not worth it. Why lie? Why not be honest and say that it's actually BAD seats? In my opinion they shouldn't even sell tickets to the second row of the second floor, everyone we say at these seats stood up to be able to see something.2 out of 5, because it's a beautiful buildning and I still enjoyed the music.

Marvelous Building. Due to time constraints we could not go for the tour and any of the concerts. But the Opera House itself is very attractive and we simply enjoyed architectural beauty of the building.

Extraordinary building. . Went to see Anna karenina. The building is beautiful. The ballet was an experience. I would recommend paying a little extra for better seats though. Pay for what you can afford.
Beautiful and good music. We went to see the Budapest symphonic orchestra, and were not disappointed. However seats need to be booked quite in advance.

Opera tour . Actually we interested in the mini concert only and doesn't wanna join the opera tour, but it is not allow to buy the only mini concert ticket. Finally we decided to join both tour and mini concert. The tour is quite interesting (history of the building, architect, and design), but I am very disappointed the mini concert cause it held at the main staircase. We have to sat on the steps. The single sang only 2 songs.

Beautiful architecture. We took the tour and enjoyed it but be advised that the groups for tours in English can be very large (over 50 people) and the tour guides do not use amplification. Since English is spoken by many as a second language if a tour isn't available in their primary language, those who understand English will join an English tour. (Parliament tours are amplified and group numbers are limited.) We did opt for the tour with "mini concert" which was basically a singer in costume performing at the base of the main staircase. The singer was good but as someone who goes to the Metropolitan Opera in NY 5-6 times per year, I would probably not opt for the "mini concert" again.
Impressive structure!. Impressive structure! Does get stuffy inside during summer. Get good tickets for better view of the show!

A Joy to Visit!. During the summer, English Tours are at 2 in addition to the 3 and 4pm tours which allow (for an additional price) a five minute performance. I opted for the 2pm (no performance) as it better fit my schedule. (I'd double check.) The young woman leading our tour spoke excellent English and knew her subject well. Not only did she convey her love for the building, but easily answered many questions-and managed to keep us on time! The Building is absolutely glorious inside and so worth the 45 minutes of your time. A highlight is getting to stand inside the Royal Box, and enjoy the prime view! As a classical musician, let me just add that this House had some real heavy weights in the Classical World as both conductors and performers. It's much more than just a beautiful building.And as for having to pay for photos, although not the norm in some countries, it's certainly not all that unusual either. It's really not that much in either dollars or euros, certainly not in pounds, for your personal memories long after you've left. I'm so glad I paid. Go and enjoy!

Stunning architecture, great acoustics.. This is a late 19th-century building filled with frescos and gold trim. Well worth seeing, but best seen when you are attending an opera or concert. The acoustics are exquisite.

take the ten minutes to walk in and have your camera ready. One regret from our stay was we only got to go inside and not do the tour. Even going inside was phenomenal, it is opulent in the way an opera house should be inside.

Interesting tour. We were lucky enough to join an official tour of the Opera House at 4pm. The guide introduced us to the architectural and historical details of the Opera House which we savoured with great interests. The interiors of the Opera House were lavishly decorated and in my opinion, on par with the Paris Opera House. We also paid an extra 60 FT for the mini-concert, which was essentially an ad-hoc performance by a prima donna on the main staircase. It was short but fun. A recommendation for all who visit Budapest.

oh my Goth. Striking architecture, gloomy shadows, and deep recessed windows take you back to an older time and place. Although I did not experience a show, I appreciated the building and its effusive personality immediately.

Never thought Opera House can be fun and exciting. Overall, the experience was truly enjoyable. My wife and I had some free time so we decided to visit the Opera House. It's not as big as the Vienna Opera House but the tour made it a very memorable experienceFirst getting to the opera house was a breeze. There is a train stop just outside the opera house. The schedule was also very accommodating as it had two 3PM and 4PM if I remember correctly. The guides were extremely organized, splitting a large group into English, Spanish, German sub tours. They were able to organize this in no time. The tour allowed us to experience the opera house a guest and as a royalty with Cece watching over us.Lastly we capped off the tour with an amazing performance to give us a glimpse. I would've loved to watch a opera but we didn't have time. I recommend this tour to any one visiting Budapest.

We attended a short one hour tour.. Our tour took us through the opera house. At the conclusion a tenor came out and sang to us for about five minutes. I know nothing about opera, but like music. I was completely blown away by the power and beauty of his voice. I have been at an opera performance, but never this close to a performer. It was very impressive.

Beautiful venue. Such a magical experience. I was so impressed with the gorgeous performance and the elegance of the Hungarian people in the audience. I saw "Sleeping Beauty" and the talent of the musicians, the grace of the dansers were matched only by the example of the lovely and cultured families present with their well-dressed and adorable young daughters. Pure pleasure!
Opera. Although the show we experienced was not to our usual taste the opera house was absolutely stunning and well worth a visit.

Excellent guided tour of one of the best opera houses in Europe with a 'taster' solo performance at end.. Guided tour, in English, of one of the most beautiful opera houses in Europe.For a very reasonable additional cost we also listened to solo 'mini' performance of two popular arias. Although not all of us were opera fans, we all thought it was a very worthwhile visit.

Impressive building. Me and my boyfriend took a walk from St. Stephan Basilic to our hotel and suddenly this amazing building was infront of us. Beautiful at night. The next day the tour guide from the St. Matthias Church recommended us to book a tour inside but we did not had time unfortunately. I would like to go back and experience an opera show.

Memorable Evening. Definitely go to see an opera at the Hungarian State Opera House. It is a magical experience. If you can, get tickets in a box. The tickets are really not expensive and it's well worth it.

Great tour. This one hour tour is worth the effort. The interior of this theatre is exquisite. Although we didn't have the opportunity to see an opera, we thoroughly enjoyed learning about this venue.

Beautiful Opera House. You can visit the Opera House on most days with english tours being conducted at 2, 3, and 4 pm. Tickets must be purchased ahead of time. You have a choice of the guided tour only, or add on a mini-opera concert. The building is a beautiful structure with lots of interesting history. The main opera hall is beautiful. Worth seeing. We are not opera fans, but we still enjoyed our visit. If you have the time, do visit it. The M1 subway line station is just outside the Opera House entrance.
Beautiful building and wonderful performance. I attended several ballets and one opera at this venue and each were outstanding. Quite a beautiful exterior and interior.

Sumptuous surrounding and other worldly charm.. Treat yourself to a night at the Opera, Ballet or concert at this amazing venue. Excellent acoustic, second to La Scala, so you will not be disappointed. Daily tours of the building will give you a greater insight on it's history and how/when it was built. One of the jewels in Budapest's crown and a must see and hear for any lover of the performing arts. It also has a cafe, restaurant and shop to make your visit all the more enjoyable.

A Must-See/Do for Any Serious Opera Fan. I toured the Operahaz in 2014 and when I returned to Budapest last week I decided to book a ticket for Otello--for $55 US I got a seat in row 15, at the SF Opera that would easily be a $300 ticket, plus this house is about 100 times more fabulous. The seats were incredibly hard and uncomfortable, seemed to be totally original to the 1800s, but otherwise a typical opera experience.

Vienna in Budapest. I have been in the Opera House in Vienna, well this one is almost as good and a very good place to visit in the evening hours. I'm not really a clasiclover but on places like this you really have to see it.

Tour great. Mini performance was truly mini. Wonderful tour in up to 6 languages. Educational and entertaining. Tour takes about 30 minutes. The there is about 10 minutes where an opera singer stands on a Landing while you sit on the stairs and he/she sings 3 songs. The singing was fine but sitting on the steps not so. I think we all expected something longer and in the auditorium however it did add to the memory. Opera house is an easy 5-10 minute from the Oktagon transit stop

Taming a screw. We were a party of seven seated in 2 of the lounges. Unfortunately the once sitting in the lounge next to us was using the railing in front of them as a pillow making it very difficult for 3 from our party to see. This could have been avoided if they perhaps had, had some guidance..Other than that, then the building is one of the most beautiful I've ever been in. The show was superb! I hope I get to experience a full opera or ballet at that venue one day!I have already recommended it to all of my friends, and will absolutely continue to do so.

Beautiful building on Adrassay. The Opera is ornate both inside and out. I didn't go for a tour but you can still enter and explore the lobby which is rather impressive. I can only imagine how nice an opera here is.

Historical tour of a beautiful space!. We got there around 3:40 to get tickets for the 4pm tour. They offer separate guides for each language and even split the English group into several smaller tours which was nice. Our guide was very informative and we enjoyed learning about the history. The inside was stunning! We did not buy the ticket to take pictures, but we did pay extra for the mini concert by one of the opera's sopranos and enjoyed it! It was in the stairway instead of in the actual hall but it was still fun.
MAGICAL NIGHT. How to give up a night at the opera in Budapest?a delightful theater with a special atmosphere. have to go there

Opera House. Very beautiful building,` which was made by hungarian architect and all most from hungarian materials. I liked internal excursion and small concert.I recommend to buy tickets for events previously.

The opera worth a visit. We just passed it on the way to the City Park.
It is an old magnificent building from the outside - we did not have the time to go in.

Fascinating. We took a tour of the opera house. It is beautiful. They used as much wood as possible because it helps with the acoustics. They also did some other fascinating this to amplify the sound.

Spectacular. Went on a tour which was brief and the guide was oh so boring, but, the building is such a spectacular sight. They were setting up the stage for a performance and I was impressed by the organization.

A night to the Opera. Being in Budapest is very important a visit to the Beautiful Magyar Nemzeti Opera Hàz, constructed by the Architect Ybl for order of the Eperor Franz Jozef.
The level of the performances id very high, and sometimes there are important international guests like Ambrogio Maestri, Giuseppe Filianoti, Arturo Chacon Cruz and so on.

Marvellous grand operahouse with bags of atamosphere. Although I didn't actually go to an opera here (trip was too short) I went to an exhibition of toy theatres that was fascinating. Beautiful exhibits each one a work of art, all very nostalgic and well labelled. The café is in splendid surroundings and everything is very smartly presented, Worth going there just for a coffee! ACtually I have a goulash stew there with pasta and it was a jolly good , delicious square meal. I can't understand why burger-bars are springing up in Hungary when their traditional cuisine is so good, so hearty and so tasty.The decor includes paintings of many stars of the stage in past generations, which adds to the glamourous theatrical atmosphere.
small beautiful. Amazing history about the rivalry between Vienna and Budapest and for those who love the story of Sissi a very nice visit

Magnificent!. I have seen opera houses all over continental Europe but this one beats them all. The inside is practically jaw dropping and steeped in history of the Austro-Hungarian empire. Dust off your memory of movies about Empress Sissi before you go. A tour (for a fee) will re-introduce you to the history, you will be shown the box reserved for the Hapsburg Emperor and that of Sissi near the stage. You will be allowed to enter the box but not trying out the Emperor seats. The tour ends with a lovely demo by a local opera singer. Most tour attendees, including myself, came out jubilant and appreciative of the whole experience. This a must-see landmark if you visit Budapest. My appreciation of the Hungarian people and their sense of style went up several notches after seeing the Budapest Opera House, and the Parliament Building, which is the subject of the next review.
Simply Beautiful. A very beautiful and impressive Opera building, with many spectacular features, like the Imperial Box, the Bar or the Balcony and very beautiful rooms.
State Opera. The Sightseeing tour is fairly short and expensive. Try to get a ticket for a performance, costs are rather low.
Very good accoustics. We saw the performance of "The tempest" which was marvelous! Even the very inexpensive seats give you great sight and provide an unforgettable experience!,

Lovely building and very ornate inside.. We had a guided tour of the Opera House with Esther who was very knowledgeable. She told us the history and that Franz Joseph had said it must not be as big as Vienna's and must be all Hungarian. By all accounts it is smaller but more beautiful !!!We were able to sit in the boxes overlooking the main auditorium and saw the bar areas and smoking corridor. As we made our way downstairs again we were treated to a short recital by one of the female singers which was a lovely way to finish the visit.I am sure it would be great to see a full performance in this lovely building.
Beautiful building . After out Segway tour (behind the opera building) we toured the opera, though we really didn't get to see the opera hall itself. Nice architecture.
Fantastic inside. The inside of this building is amazing. We only saw the lobby, but that was enough--the ceiling and design of the building is a "must see" in my book.

Beautiful building, uncomfortable seats. We saw an opera during our trip to Budapest, which was a wonderful way to see this incredible building. The performance was great, but the seats have no padding and are very close together, making it a somewhat uncomfortable place to sit for three hours! Also a few things to be aware of: Yes, the seats in the top section are inexpensive, but you are literally sent in through the "servant's entrance" (yes, that's what the usher called it) and you have a very long climb ahead of you (no elevator that we could find), completely separate lounge area during the intermission, bathrooms, coat check, etc. Also: be prepared to pay to check your coat. Even if you're wearing it, they make you check it before you can enter the theatre. Still, even with that added cost, it was a less expensive way to see the building than paying for a tour, so it all depends on your ability to climb four flights of stairs and deal with uncomfortable seats! Overall, we enjoyed the performance, but I wish we'd known some of this ahead of time.

Out of this world. It's a must to see this Opera house when in Budapest so much history, take mini tour and make sure you ask for the mini opera performance at the end its great.You get to stand in the royal box (but not aloud to sit down in it) Good English speaking tour guide.
Magnificent building. Its magnificent from outside and I really wanted to go inside to have a look or see a show. Unfortunately the staff weren;t too helpful.

Amazing. We saw a ballet here during our recent stay in Budapest and it was amazing. The ballet itself was excellent but even if it hadn't been the building was super cool. We paid extra to be on the ground floor since most of the cheap seats have limited or no view of the stage (fine for an opera though), but it was still very affordable compared to other Opera Houses. Definitely worth walking around and checking out the lobby, etc. during intermission. It was all so beautiful. Coat check is mandatory but pretty cheap. Some people were dressed very nicely and others a bit more casual. I definitely felt more comfortable being a bit dressed up though.

nice premiere. One more visit to this nice little operahouse in budapest..Premiere at Thomas Ades the tempest...the quality of this operahouse is surprisingly good...most very good singers, and the orchestra plays well to.. the prices are extremely low compared to europe, and the house is a little beauty, only complain is the very hard woodden seats on the floor..in the breaks you can have drinks and food in the small restaurant, and enjoy it on the terrasse outside...

Talk about opulent.. Our guide, Barbara, said Franz Joseph only visited this opera house once, because although Vienna's opera house was bigger, this one was more beautiful, and you can't go showing up Vienna. The guide was very informative on the tour, but we didn't get a look back stage. However, we did get to enter the emperor's box and have a view from the absolutely best seats. Pay the extra fee to take photos. I am a little undecided about the extra mini concert that you can purchase for an extra fee. Although the singer was excellent, he only sang two arias and they were not performed in the auditorium, but rather on the main staircase. Getting up after sitting on those tiny stairs was not easy.
Beautiful. Lovely old opera house. Interiors are what one would expect of an ornate 19th century opera house. Very walkable from the center of the city.

Stunning Interior. We did the 40 minute tour of this wonderful building. The tours in English are frequent but when we arrived just before the 3pm tour it was full and we bought tickets for the 4pm tour. Worth the small extra charge for the mini opera performance. A singer sang two arias beautifully at the end. The building itself is glorious and the commentary was informative and amusing.

a must when in Budapest!. Fantastic! Budapest Opera House; what an amazing building to experience our first opera and the presentation of Madam Butterfly, spectacular.The only experience to better our evening would have to visited when people dressed for the opera, instead of having to share our experience with a load of nondescripts tourists in 'shell suits & trainers' but there we go!!!It certainly didn't detract from an experience we will always remember and looking forward to next time.

Charming and cheap. The opera house itself is a beautiful building located in one of the main streets of Budapest. The story of the building is amazing and it is worth a visit. In the surrounding areas you will find "House of Terror" and a number of old embassies. If you want to enjoy the opera inside prices starts at just a few euros.
Wonderful production of Cosi fan tutte. We visited the opera house to enjoy a super production of Cosi fan tutte. Fabulous evening in wonderful interior.

Majestic theatre . This is a truly majestic theatre at Budapest. We had a guided tour of the whole theatre. When the lights were switched on in the main theatre, one could appreciate the beauty. We had an impromptu opera show at the main foyer. Love to see an opera here one day.
Beautiful impressive building. The organised tour is very informative and can includes a taste of an aria or two from one of the professional members

Spectacular Opera House well worth a visit. We recently visited the Opera House and thoroughly enjoyed one of the afternoon English tours. The guide was engaging and quite knowledgeable. The building is exquisite. We also loved the short 10 minute opera performance held at the conclusion of the tour.

Beautiful but not sure about the tour. It's beautiful and many details to see in the building. The mini concert was interesting. However, the tour wasn't well organised at all. Too many groups in different languages at the same time, and you could not hear what the tour guide said all the time. It was also very limited of time for tourists to see the details or take pictures. Although the tour did not meet my expectation ( there are also much more people in English tour). In my opinion, it's still a place where you definitely need to visit in Budapest.
Opera House Tour. Interesting tour in English showing the Royal Boxes and the Auditorium but not backstage. Guide was very good but tour was a little on the short side.

Get yourself a cheap opera ticket to really appreciate the building. We paid just under £3.50 each to get tickets to see the opera whilst we were in Budapest (there were cheaper tickets but they apparently offered no view whatsoever) and had an incredible evening. The baroque-ness of the interior really comes alive when the place is filled with people and music. One tip though- you will stand out if you're wearing the clothes you just walked off the train from Belgrade in, not everyone else was wearing white gloves but a significant majority were...

Gorgeous building poor tour with excessive price. The Opera House is spectacular. Seating only 1200 and built primarily with Hungarian materials it is exquisite. The tour is really quite ghastly. You see the lobby, the bar and the auditorium. They charge for the tour, to take photos and then for a mini concert in the stairwell. I am trying to remember a worse tour anywhere and I cannot. At $25 all in it is just mediocre. However I then went to the final dress rehearsal and for $10-20 you can see everything and the performance. And you can take photos and not have to sit in the stairwell. So while the Opera house is spectacular avoid the tour and just buy a ticket to a performance.
beautiful old architecture. Tour guide took us to see the balconies from side to back views...interesting facts revealed. Needed to pay for a photo pass to take photographs which were worth it.

A superb Opera House with a great repertoire. The Hungarian State Opera House functions in a classical, 19th century building created in the mid-19th century exactly for this purpose. It is located in the central area of Pest, on a major thoroughfare and easy to reach by public transportation. Parking in the vicinity can be complicated, so better take a cab. The resident company is simply outstanding! The voices, the choreography, the sets, are all outstanding. As opposed to many US opera companies that barely present 7-8 operas per season, The Hungarian State Opera usually lists between 15 and 20 operas per season. And, it is not the only opera in town: there are two other places where you can enjoy opera in Budapest. The building itself is beautiful, inside and out. The performances compare very favorably to most European Opera companies, especially Vienna, Berlin, Paris, Milan and London. In addition, the tickets are much less expensive as in Western Europe or the US. Please note, you are more likely to see operas that are seldom or never performed in the West for a group of illustrious opera composers from central and Eastern Europe.

Amazing architecture, average tour. I'm no opera buff but the architecture is simply delicious. I was lucky enough to catch the last guided tour of the day at 4pm. The price is 2990F and add another 500F if taking photos. The tour ended earlier for me cos most paid extra for what was described as a short opera ... perhaps you get a couple of arias?! I wasn't aware of this option.The only gripe I have is that the tour was very rushed. I paid to take photos but every time I tried, I was hurried along to the next room. Tour was average, architecture was 5 stars.

Beautiful old building. This is a beautifully restored opera house with most of the interior original. There is an excellent guided tour and there are frequent nightly performances. Well worth a visit.

Take a look in detail. This is one of the most beautiful buildings in Budapest, it has a lot of detail that you can take some time to appreciate it. During my visit there weren't any performance. I don't have any doubt it would be amazing to assist to any opera.
opera house. absolutely gorgeous inside and outside. unfortunately, I was not able to see any presentation. but, it should be a must.

Tour spoilt by rude staff. The guide was excellent. Unfortunately, during the tour, catering staff were preparing for a performance later that day and were particularly noisy. A member of the group politely asked if they could reduced the noise and received a rude reply from a male member of staff who then proceeded to make more noise at a higher volume - the guide had to shout to be heard. The management should remind staff that they are all ambasadors for the opera house and time preparations around the tours. This unnecessary episode spolit what was otherwise an excellent tour.

Nice architecture. We walked along the opera a couple of times but did't manage to go in and take a look. One day there was a very big line and an other day it was close. Nevertheless this building right in the middle of center is great to look at.

beautiful building. I'd say it's better for you buy ticket and watch the performance, rather than taking the tour. The building itself is indeed beautiful. but the tour is quite pricey for a half hour tour.

More stunning that viennas opera house & pay for the short aria. Stunning architecture and gold leafing in this opera house. We paid extra to take pictures (otherwise you can't) but it's a small reasonable fee. We also paid an extra charge to hear an opera singer song 2 arias which was amazing and could be filmed. Great idea if you don't have time or money to book an opera show.

Beautiful building! . Booked in advance to go and see the opera. The performance was in English with Hungarian and English subtitles displayed on a screen above the stage. Opera was fab- even if we didn't really understand what was going on! Paid about £8 each for a ticket and got upgraded to amazing seats 2 rows from the front!! Could not complain for the price we paid.Only negative was the surprise compulsory cloakroom cost followed by a large queue at the end of the night to retrieve our coats! Otherwise a must see for the price!

We didn't go in but the exterior is beautiful . We did not go for an opera but passed by in front to admire the building which is very beautiful. The hop-on and hop-off bus passes by here you can take a look or step off

Restored and a stunning interior, with many forms of art there.. Opera is very expensive in Europe, but in Hungary Music with Orchestra, choirs and Operas are staged here with a very variable program. It is like going back 100 years inside, and has been wonderfully restored, reputed to be on of the finest Opera houses in Europe. A top Box seat here can be £20, with seats from £3. The Hungarians have always had access to art, music, dance, ballet, Opera almost as we see pop music. It is accessible to everyone at these prices, and a concert or performance of whatever you see very memorable and pleasant.I would highlight this as one of the most special venues to book and go to a convert when in the city, which can be booked on line or at the very helpful box office.People and many locals do dress smartly and formally here, so a smart casual at the very least for this high end cultural gem.

A must for everyone. Took my 11 year old to Budapest for the weekend to see Madame Butterfly as part of our stay. It was a wonderful experience and the opera house is stunning inside and out. The words were also written in English on the subtitle screen which made it easier. A once in a lifetime must do experience whether you are a fab of opera or not.

New Years Day concert. We attended a new years day Opera and it was lovely. A gorgeous building from the outside and when you step inside the beauty continues into the lobby up the main grand stair case. Inside the actual auditorium is beautifully decorated just like you imagine in an opera house. Painted ceiling, ornate lights, velvet covered chairs, box seats surrounding the stage. A true Opera experience!

Transcendent experience!. The State Opera House is incredible! We had the opportunity to watch the ballet "Onegin" and it was fantastic. The acoustics were great and while I am certainly no ballet expert (it was my first ballet) I found it to be thoroughly entertaining.
absolutly beautiful!. we saw a ballet preformance, it was beautifully done. the house itself is also quite breathtaking. I don't know if they offer tours.

The Opera House is delight. It is one of the most beautiful buildings in Budapest and you can go in and actually see what set or stage they are setting up for that evening. We were lucky and heard some actors practicing and singing.

My first Opera. When visiting Budapest for the weekend, Falstaff was performing at the Royal Opera House. I have been to the London Royal Opera House and it has nothing on this. the beauty of every single part of the building is breathtaking. worth going to just for that. the theatre stalls are pure gold, with hand painted ceilings, grand marble staircases and a beautiful bar and balcony overlooking the city streets.

Daily tour for Opera Visit quite worth it. We didn't plan for the tour in the first place. Was around that road at around 2something where they start to sell the tour ticket for 3pm tour. We decided to join since the interior inside looks amazing. With Budapest card, theres 20% discount so remember to flash the card. You will have to purchase the photo ticket for 500HUF per pax. There is an option to attend a mini concert after the tour with additional charge.The tour was roughly 40mins and the guide will share some of the history of the opera house. The interior was very nice and grand looking even though a little bit small in scale.

Beautiful inside the State Opera House!. I've been to the Johannes Passion around easter and bought the most cheapest ticket ever (5 euro's). I was on the balcony and could see everything, but you have a special (for the cheap tickets) entrance at the left side of the building with a long stairs going up. It's still worth wile to see the main entrance from the inside and off course the ceiling paintings! Love it!

The price is right. We visited the Opera house and looked at the upcoming performances. We chose one at 11:00 on the Saturday morning and, on buying tickets, were astonished to find that they were only about £2:20 each!!! It was quite a climb up to where we were seated but for the price we had an excellent view. The performance was a ballet, Onyegin, set to music by Tchaikovsky. It was a very enjoyable two hours of high quality ballet and received rapturous applause at the end. Generally the tickets for performances of all kinds of things seemed considerably lower that in the UK. It seemed strange to be attending this kind of event in the morning but it worked. The Opera house itself was probably once the rival of others in Europe. It probably needs a little more work now but as an experience it's well worth looking in to.

The daily tour is a must see event. The tours are well conducted and the architecture is stunning. A wonderful peice of history and a dazzling display of opulence and grandeur. The little performance of opera at the end of the tour is a nice touch. A very satisfactory visit.

Stunning opera house. We went to the opera house (as a last minute purchase) to watch the ballet (Oneygin....it's an excellent production).The opera house is a stunning building, internally and externally. Facilities inside are modern, and prices, for top quality alcohol at least, are relatively high, but not out of kilter with other similar opera houses around the world (as is the atmosphere...it's a mixture of serious fans and blatant tourists so there is a degree of tension between the two).As our purchase was last minute we purchased tickets on the top tier which has a restricted view (left side, row one, seats 9-14): you lose about a third of the stage but are comparatively close for the bits you can see vis a vis some of the other seats. Thankfully there is a wide screen TV close to the restricted view areas so you can view the part of the stage you can't see. Let me say this: these seats are cheap. Seriously cheap...£4.50 per person, so for the prices it's an excellent experience (if you're seeing the ballet just for the music alone!) so you egg what you pay for. That being said the seats overall even in the stalls aren't expensive: we worked out the most expensive seats are around £50-£60 per person (applying a liberal conversion rate) so approximately half the price of similar tickets at the ENO or similar, so it's worth getting some better seats if you are able. Tickets are easy to buy online and you print in advance. Word of warning though....if you buy the cheap seats you've got to walk up several flights of stairs to get to where you need to....not for the unfit or faint of heart!
