More Opulent Than Vienna. By emperor's decree the building could not be larger than that of Vienna. The Hungarians made up for it on the interior. Despite all of the gold and marble, the decor never crosses the line to gaudy.The steps are not steep so walking them is quite easy. The tour allows one to actually sit in box. The halls outside of the auditorium are gorgeous. How I'd love to see Otelloi on this stage.It was worth every minute spent there.

Lots of bad seats . An opulent interior graces what must have been a world class experience... For any seat with a view. This house lends the appearance of a somewhat run down jewel of the golden age in Eastern Europe. Unfortunately, many of the available seats in the upper deck barely qualify to be sold with "a view of the stage". The orchestra did well and the front of house services were as expected: a coat check for 200 Ft was perfectly reasonable. The drinks were overpriced, as usual for this type of venue... 1,580 Ft for a carefully limited pour of whisky. You would do better to get proper seats on the floor well in advance. Their website ticket vendor requires a leap of faith, but it surely beats sulking about your crappy no-view seats in the nosebleeds over an overpriced whiskey. Better yet take the tour for a quick look and spend an evening on the town instead!

Fleeced by Budapestopera-tickets.com. Beware of the site budapestopera-tickets com. Do not buy opera or concert tickets from them. They fleece you to the rate of 26% on the actual price of the tickets. It is best that you book at another site where you are also allowed to choose your tickets instead of them being imposed on you. This other site is In fact jegymester.hu where the tickets are sold at their actual price with a small charge of €1 for two tickets. After booking I realised that the site operators of budapestopera-tickets com got their tickets from jegymester and added a charge of €10 per ticket.

Very interesting history. My wife really wanted to see the opera house and your. The price was about 12 euro with additional fees for a mini concert or pictures inside. The tour was an hour long with many interpreters available. The mini opera was nice and covered two solos in the grand staircase. If you appreciate music and history you will be pleased.
Beautiful building. We only stopped in to see the inside and it was worth it!The ceilings are all gold and frescoes. A beautiful building a bit smaller than the one in Vienna.

Definitely a must visit. A trip to Budapest and not taking the opportunity to visit the Opera House is a huge mistake in judgement. This fall, we had an opportunity to visit both the Opera House in Vienna and in Budapest. Although smaller in size the Budapest Opera House makes up in opulence and character. Everything from the in floor ventilation under each seat to the gold accents is amazing to see first hand. The entrance and stair case used strictly by the Royals as well as their private Royal box is a sight to behold. During our visit, we were surprised when a male and female Opera signer came out in full dress and performed four songs while standing in the main staircase. Even there, the acoustics were second to none. What a special treat. Don't leave Budapest without taking a tour of the Opera House and better stil, if you can attend a live performance please jump at the opportunity. The prices are very, very reasonable.

Lovely. We entered this attraction during our walking tour. The inside is stunning. We were going to try and attend some small performance they put on later in the day for tourists, however never managed it. Although i hear they are worth a visit if you like opera.

NICE BUILDING. One of the most visited nice buildings in the BUDAPEST, this is on the Pest side and very close to Stephens Basilica. Nice architecture having stunning views in the evening when the lighting is on.
Lovely.. Good acoustics, very impressive building, and you can get reasonable priced tickets to see an opera. Definitely worthy a visit.

Beautifully decorated opera house. This opera house is not big but the decoration inside is very beautiful. Walls, staircases are all crafted from blocks of rose marble. The ceiling is lavisly painted with gold. We didn't attend any performaces as it was in the morning but we did enjoy a good half an hour sitting inside on confortable sofas to admire the interior. Afterwards we go across the street to have some good apple strudel at the renown Callas Cafe.

Magnificent opera house and every short concert. It was a rainy day perfect for an indoor activity . This is a magnificent building and it is essential to take a guided tour , albeit a rushed one in the afternoon (they had tours on the hour from 2-4 p.m.) we had a very knowledgeable guide . Unfortunately this is a very busy venue . It is also worth paying the extra to attend a very short concert where a soprano sang three songs on the staircase . I would recommend a visit .

Good Tour, Bit Busy. Wonderful building with a really interesting history.Our tour guide did the best job she could, however I've not been able to give 5/5 as on our visit the Opera House had scheduled loads of tour groups from bus tours to be in at the same time making our tour very very crowded and difficult to see things.

Money making tour. Could not get tickets to opera or ballet so did tour. Very quick and have to work around about 6 tours all going around at same time. Expensive for what it was and joke you have to pay extra to take photos don't bother just do it in large groups no one has an idea who will have paid. Also have to pay extra to stay at end and listen to an opera singer Sang two songs. Very moving but just on the stairway as you leave so just stay put and listen for free! Thought you would get to go backstage and see more of the place than you get to go.

Othello at the Hungarian State Opera House. We went to a modern production by the Hungarian State Opera Company of Othello by Guiseppe Verdi, sung in Italian with English and Hungarian subtitles (projected above the proscenium arch). We had booked several weeks in advance, which is probably necessary if you are visiting Budapest. The opera house building itself is magnificent, and well worth seeing. The staging was impressive, making excellent use of the revolving stage and a separate raising section of the stage. The orchestra was excellent, and the Soprano lead was good. However the Alto and Tenor leads were weak - the Alto particularly so as she was barely audible when singing in duet or with the chorus. The Bass lead was sound enough, without being strong. Overall, a good production, but not of the highest standard.

Otello at the Hungarian State Opera House. At the risk of appearing uncultured, I will have to admit that I don’t regularly attend the opera in my home town but I was excited to see the inside of the opera house in Budapest and to see an opera in Europe. Otello was playing and by the time I got around to buying tickets (two weeks before our vacation) not many seats were left. The only two seats together were in a box so I purchased them online from Jegymester.hu; you can print the tickets at home making it super easy. (I later bought tickets for the Parliament tour on the same website.) The Opera House is stunning. Unlike in the USA, the show did not start until thirty minutes after the time on the ticket. I wasn’t sure if that is normal but it seemed like it was. There is a nice area inside to buy food and drinks before the show. Boxes have 4 seats. Three in the front and one behind. Fortunately, a daughter and mother were the other (season) ticket holders and the daughter called and cancelled. We all sat in front. The boxes closer to the stage do not afford the best views but it was nice being able to watch the orchestra. We enjoyed ourselves and were glad we went. Hungarians do dress for the opera. Most women wore black dresses or dress pants. Most men wore ties although there were some people wearing open collared shirts, with or without jackets.

although smaller than Vienna. They offer great tours of the opera house and at the end, an opera singer performs for us. The opera house is based on the one in Vienna, but is much smaller and more accessible to the public.

Opera tour. There is a short tour of the opera house showing you the auditorium and the Royal reception areas etc, and to finish we were treated to a short performance by one of the opera singers who came out to the hallway and sang two songs for us. Well worth the visit.

Wonderful experience. Magnificent building. watched an outdoor performance of Othello. Would you ever see that in the Uk.? Absolutely brilliant and something I will always remember even though I am not an opera follower
Gorgeous and beautifully restored.. Tickets in advance very wise. Need tour in your language. Get your that end with brief concert. More beautiful than Milan or any place in the US.

Great visit, worth paying for the performance. Tour was very informative and professional. Buy tix 15-20 min in advance and arrive on time. Expect to wait a bit uncomfortably on the steps before guide arrives but its worth the wait. The five minute performance after the tour is extra but gives the real feel and is worth it.
Beautiful Opera House. This was by far my favorite experience in Budapest. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and engaging. Definitely worth a visit.

It deserves a long visit and and if possible, you must attend a performance there.. The building of the Hungarian State Opera House is the largest Budapest Opera House. Originally named the Hungarian Royal Opera, was financed by the governance of Budapest and by Emperor Franz Joseph I. The Opera House was designed and built in the post-Baroque and Neo-Renaissance architectural style by the architect Miklós Ybl and was inaugurated on 27 September year de1884.It is reputed to be one of the three best acoustics amongst similar Scala in Milan and the Paris Opera House. The interior is luxurious and beautiful, it deserves a long visit and, if possible, attend a performance of any operatic classic on display.

Only chance to see the Opera House. Unless you go to a performance this is the only way to see inside. It is crowded at first but they are six different languages offered. English being the most popular. Stay for the mini concert and stand on the steps to the right facing down. The opera singer comes out on that side.
Wonderful experience. Fabulous building but there were too many groups of tours going on at the same time, should be more spaced out. The Aria at the end though was well worth the visit.
We only walked around. We were too late to go on a formal tour of the Opera House but we did get to see the lobby area. WOW!!! This is a must do next time.

We really enjoyed this..... We were encouraged to go here by other members of our tour group and we werent disappointed. We arrived just as they wre gathering an English Tour group together and paid for the Tour, the ability to take photos and the mini-opera. The tour route is a little confusing but we thought the Tour guide was informative although she did struggle with one or two questions. You start in the auditorium and you have to keep to a schedule to end on the main staircase for the performance. This consists of 2 arias sung by a single Soprano. She entered into the spirit of the thing dancing with one group member!
saved the rainy day. we took a tour with a mini concert, and it was a great activity to do on a rainy day in budapest, easily found and accessible, well organized.

stunningly beautiful. a guided tour of the opera house is a must! the auditorium is stunning. tours are available in several languages and the guides are knowledgeable and interesting. A nice touch is the arias sung at the end of the tour.

Quality for a good price. Beautiful historical building with great reputation. All staff is very friendly and helpfull. Unfortunately, prices of drinks are very expensive, compared to nearby bistros and restaurants. The opera itself was good.

Culture at its best. Fantastic tour the building is a unique beautiful example of architecture, we were also able to book to see swan lake later in the week, it is just sublime and feel privileged to have watched a ballet in this marvellous building, the acoustics are fantastic. Don't miss the opera house next to the metro 1 line station opera and that metro line is an experience that must be tried.

Great 1 hour tour in Budapest. We went to the opera house in Budapest, where they offer a 2 hour tour (in English).It is a beautiful place and well worth the price. You have to pay extra to take photos but it was an inexpensive add on. The tour consists of details of the history of the opera house as well as a detailed background in all of the rooms.. If you have time in Budapest, it is worth the visit

Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful!. Rosie wanted to visit here. I am so glad that she did. Just magnificent. Can't fault it. The architecture, the acoustics, the staff. Just a great experience. Go here.

Beautiful Venue, Stellar Productions. I have attended the Hungarian State Opera twice in the past year; once for the Nutcracker, and once for Faust. The venue is magnificent from the moment you walk into the lobby. Value-wise, tickets are very inexpensive in the balconies and in the back rows of the floor. However, do NOT buy the cheapest tickets on the far right and left of the top balcony, as you physically cannot see more than half of the stage from there. The best place in my opinion is the back rows of the floor, as they are close, yet still inexpensive.

Hungarian State Opera House - Gorgeous Inside and Out!. My wife and I had the tremendous pleasure to visit the Hungarian State Opera House during our visit to Budapest! From the street, the remarkable architecture conveys to all that this building is a very special place! We bought tickets to the English language guided tour. There are a few offered each day - some include music. Unfortunately due to time constraints, ours did not include music. There is a premium priced ticket for patrons who want to take photos while on the tour. Every inch of the interior of the building including the reception rooms and stairways were fabulously decorated from the floor to the ceilings. Throughout the tour, my eyes were drawn to the gorgeous gold colored vaulted ceilings illuminated by sparkling chandeliers. There are many statues of famous composers, large and beautiful paintings of renowned opera singers and many pieces of historic opera memorabilia. Eventually we entered the concert hall and it is spectacular! Although this is a relatively small concert hall, it was spectacularly designed and built. According to the experts, the Hungarian State Opera House is acoustically junior to only Milan's La Scala! The concert hall chandelier and ceiling painting are breathtaking. There are dozens of private boxes, with the largest and best located box reserved for the king and queen. If you enjoy classical music, fine architecture, the arts and culture, you must visit this opera house in Budapest!

Magnifico. Beautiful, majestic and impressive.It's been a long time since i was here. Now i have the pleasure of travelling to Budapest again and also the pleasure of coming here which i thoroughly enjoy
Culture and beauty. What a beautiful building. Try one of the tours (they even have one that includes a small concert. Well worth a visti
Worth a peak but no more. We peeked inside the opera house so unless you love opera, this is worth seeing but nothing to spend much time. It reminded me of the New York Broadway theaters.

Overwhelming Frescos!. The play of the neo- classical arch work and the ceiling murals imparts a mood to this exceptional concert hall. The acoustics are said to be among the best in the world. The small ( only 1200 seat) auditorium makes every performance intimate.
Enjoy this building/landmark while enjoying a fantastic performance. A beautiful building and a performance here the true way to enjoy it. You can get really cheap tickets with short notice.
fabulous building and decor. Decor and acoustics are fabulous enjoyed a special evening. You need to dress up and lap up the atmosphere. Reccomend a opera or ballet as a way to see the inside.
Lovely experience . I recommend a guided tour with a mini concert (1800 HUF). Beautiful building. Great story. Very dedicated and interesting guide.

Dont miss a guided tour including a mini concert. The opera house is an amazing building.
You can have a guided tour around the house. And in the end there is a mini concert.

Go to the Operetta - more decadant and comfortable. Antiquated furniture especially when you compare it to the Operetta around the corner. Badly needs updating. The seats were hard, extremely worn and well past their sell by date.

A Show Would Probably be more Enjoyable. I was in Budapest at the end of August, as a result there were no shows playing here and I had to satisfy myself with the tour. And what stands out, about the facility itself, is that it is fairly extravagant, maybe sometimes more gaudy than elegant. And though I stayed around for the mini-concert, the tour doesn't really allow you to experience the acoustics, which I expect is the best part of the facility. If given a chance, a show would probably be more memorable than the tour.The tour, and our guide, provided a good overview of the building (including multiple overlaps with the Parliament) and who / how it has been used over the years. However, it could not compensate for the number of tours under way at one time. There were tours for 5 or so languages, with the English one being broken into three 15+ people groups. They all start at the same time and there just is not enough room to accommodate that many people. Add in those using up extra space for taking pictures (getting their money worth out of the photography pass) and I did not find the experience particularly enjoyable.

Crowded. This building is breathtakingly beautiful. I did the tour which was expensive and they charged extra to be allowed to take photos. It was hot and overcrowded with different nationalities vying to be heard on top of one another. However, it was all worth it to see this beautiful building and the mini concert on the staircase at the end was fabulous.

Opulent decor, rich history, and a passionate performance. The Opera House itself is quite beautiful in it's baroque decor and architecture. It is acoustically ranked 2nd in the world, which is quite a feat for such a small building. It is about 1/3 the size of the Vienna Opera House, but is a worthy contemporary.  We enjoyed a performance by the Philharmonic Orchestra one evening here. It was quite impressive. Price was very reasonable too. Make time for a performance if you can

Another jewel that must be seen in Budpaest. Far better than the Vienna Opera House, but a little smaller. This is a must visit. The staff is extremely knowledgeable about the history of the Opera House. Well worth the visit!

Skip the ticketed mini-opera performance. Beautiful opera house with good acoustics. If visiting during opera season see a performance from a box!
Otherwise, a guided tour gives access to visiting the box seats and rooms used by King Joseph and Queen Sisi. But skip the mini-operatic performance in the stairway…seriously. Besides, you can overhear it from the Opera House entry :-)
bring your own seat cushion. I went to the opera one night. The inside of the opera house is small, but beautifully decorated. The seats are hard wooden old seats. So, bring a cushion.

Whatever Vienna can do we can do as well. I have only given it very good because it was Sunday morning and we couldn't enter the auditorium but the Foyer and down to the Shop was magnificent. Can't wait to go back and see a production there one day.
Architecture!. A stunning building. We saw Cosi Fan Tutte here and the performance was excellent, with reasonably priced tickets.
Lovely building. Lovely building but restrictive hours of touring, limited to mid and late afternoon, meant that we were unable to view the interior.

Super little opera.... I once got a free ticket from a complete stranger who could only stay for half an opera... Small compared to the big houses but beautiful ....Very pretty and compact .. Fun part of town..Very happening now..

Stunning place!. This place located in Andrassy avenue. That area is simply amazing! To go for a tour inside it cost Money but worth to get and look. The architecture is very beautiful!! To go to a concert it can be just perfect.
Fabulous Opera House, hard seats!!. Magnificent opera house. This is what we expect of an opera house - opulence in abundance. However take a soft cushion as the seats are hard, hard, hard!

A top-10 place to visit!. We took the tour with the short performance and thoroughly enjoyed it. The building is a feast for the eyes and the short performance was great fun. The performer sang while walking down beautiful staircase and through the tour group…even waltzing with one member of our group. Absolutely worth the hour invested!

Go see an Opera too.. I cannot comment on the tour, but if you go see an Opera you get to see inside this wonderful old building as well as treating yourself to an Opera. The prices are fair and a lot cheaper than Vienna. The opera we saw was entertaining with top quality artists. Highly recommended.
Beautiful Building. Our hotel was across the street from the Opera House and we noticed it several times a day. It is a beautiful building with many interesting details. Stop for a look.

Tour "mini performance" was WORTG IT. The tour was well managed despite the large crowd. They divided us into groups by language and handled the tours very efficiently. The opera house is BEAUTIFUL and I was so thankful that we included the optional mini-performance with our package. Although it was only ten minutes or so, I had goosebumps the entire time. It was a splendid taste of opera. Highly recommend this stop!
Gorgeous. Lots of tours going on, so be sure to keep your eye on your guide and not just the luscious surroundings or you'll find yourself in another group in a second.

Beautiful. This is a beautiful building that must inspire the performers as much as the audience. The tour took us through the various luxury boxes and then to the floor where the common-folk sat. Interesting that the floor was scuffed/painted wood. Worth seeing. Take the guided tour.
be warned. A rip off. Get them in, get their money and get them out! That was the feeling that left me., be warned!

Check the schedule before you go. On the day we went, they were only offering tours at 2, 3, and 4 in the afternoon. The tours were good and they were offered in several languages. We paid for the mini-concert, which was only 2 songs and performed in the grand stairwell area not the theater, but it was worth it.
Nice interior . Opera house has a nice interior, the guided tour was very informative and the mini concert was good! If you have time pls watch their opera!

we were for a show. the building is stunning and beautiful, and you should enjoy the beautiful interior. the show we saw (Cosi fan tutte) was very good, but the seats were unbelievably bad (a second row in a box). so make sure you get seats you can actually see something from. we had to improvise

Beautiful worth seeing Opera House. wonderful old opera house! beautifully decorated! Has to be one of the best in Europe!the tour was excellent and covered a lot. Check for schedule of operas and language. The opera house is easy to get to and they handle their crowds easily.

Beautiful building. The visit in the opera building is very nice, you can see a opera building full of amazing art work, the seats is the same seat from the day of opening at the 19th century. There is an option with additional cost to hear an opera singer singing, worth to pay it

beautiful and unique!. We did the guided tour in French at 4pm, several other languages were available. With this visit we have seen many places that you will not see if you attend a representation. We even went in Sissi's place. The small concert at the end is very impressive. This is really a not-to-be-missed visit in Budapest even if you know nothing on operas. The building is so beautiful!

Don't Miss It. Well worth a visit. We paid for the guided visit with a mini concert after which is well worth the extra £2 it costs. you get to visit the bar area the stalls and the boxes lasted about 45 mins and we enjoyed every minute of it.

Not singing their praises.. Paid for the tour, which was conducted in a very amateurish way by possibly a student earning some extra money. It was chaos inside the entrance area to pay and then find out where the english speaking tour was meeting. If your prepared to weather the initial storm, you'll enjoy the interior.

Palace of music in Budapest. Beautiful building ina very center of the city, great people working there, and such a amazing musical experience that I had there... Absolutely adorable...So wishing to do it again!
beautiful!!. The guide i had spoke a little bit fast (Spanish), but the visit was worth it, is simply beautiful and very interesting to see the the opera from the inside.
Must do. This is a must, even if you are only in town for one night you should spend it here if you can. The ambience and the building are electrifying.

Magnificent inside. Plain outside. Wow. This is gorgeous on the inside. The outside didn't for much for us but we were pleasantly surprised that the inside is stunning.Wanted to see a concert here but none were playing for 3 days. Would have been awesome.

Beautiful building, but take care if you want to visit or book. You can always walk into the Opera building and have a look at the nice entry hall.45 Minute tours in English of the Opera House are available. However, we found on a website that tours were at 3pm and 4pm, and upon arrival it turned out the latest tour was 2:30pm. You best check with them (info@opera.hu) for the latest info in advance.We equally wanted to attend an opera performance on a specific evening, but the performance was not at the Opera House itself, but at another venue that is also run by the Opera. Have a good look at their website before you book.

Opera worth a visit. We didn't enter the building but admired it from the outside. It is truly one of the lovely buildings of Budepest and worth a look. Had we been able to see inside I'm sure it would be beautiful.

Old, beautiful building with amazing music!. I love the Opera House as a specific attraction and as a place for high quality classical music. Worth a visit in daytime for a guided tour and later for some joy for our ears and souls. :)

Interesting architecture and engineering. We went on the tour of the opera house and was impressed by the "air conditioning" and history lessons incorporated into the tour. The only distractor was the different languages for other tours that sometimes made it hard to hear. On the same note, it was also interesting to hear the tour in a different language. The Opera House is beautiful and should not be missed.

Stunning and amazing opera! . We saw the premiere of Othello here. It was amazing. Better than many performances I've seen in London. Plus, the building is just stunning. Really ornate ceilings and red carpeted stairs. If you can see an opera here, I'd thoroughly recommend it!
Opera House not to be missed. The building is beautiful both outside and inside. Loved the tour and the short recital at the end. Not to be missed if you are in Budapest.

Beautiful architecture, weird production!. This building is beautiful from the outside but it really is absolutely breathtaking on the inside. We bought tickets for a couple of pounds each to a production, which was actually cheaper than doing a tour! It was a great experience even though we weren't big fans of the 'alternative' and slightly odd production. It really is worth going inside because it is stunning.
Arias. The 45 minute tour of this beautiful Opera House was excellent and included a soprano singing two arias. It was built in 1884.

Interesting tour impacted by very large Groups. Very popular on a wet Friday with English speaking participants split into 5 groups up to 40, each competing with other groups and languages. Overall, we enjoyed the tour, including the live opera singing at the conclusion. Cost breakdown was HUF2900 admission, HUF600 for mini 'concert', and HUF500 to take photos.

Excellent but you can't book ahead so arrive 20 mins before and book tickets.. To see an actual performance you can book online and I would recommend this based on the performances I've seen in other countries. We came to Budapest in the week and there were no performances until the weekend so take this into account when you book dates.You can't book online for a tour and even if you go the day before they tell you to come back on the day about twenty minutes before a scheduled tour. Whilst we were here (Sept) there were tours at 2pm,3pm and 4pm although the actual tour at 3 started at 3:30 and it's advisable to buy your ticket at least 20 mins before as there were a lot of people there at that time. You will be asked if you want to listen to the 'mini concert' and I would recommend this. It's about £1.50 extra and for that one of the opera singers gives a short performance. Our singer was spectacular. Definitely recommended. The Opera itself is exquisite inside full of luxury and splendour. I did read beforehand that when the weather was hot a tour a tour was unbearable as there was no air conditioning but it was about 35C when we went to Budapest and the Opera was fine. They do now have air con. Don't miss.

waste of time. the put you in a big group, the guide doesn't speak English very well and you can hardly understand what she says!! let alone hearing her voice among 25 people who are standing behind her. they tell you that you need to pay extra money for taking pictures but nobody minds if you take pictures without paying, so don't waste your time.the couple of euros you pay extra for watching 10 minutes opera is also terrible as the show you get consists of only one opera singer and you dont watch this in the hall but rather on the stairs at the entrance hall.

Definately Worth the Visit. Beautiful representation of a unique epoch, it's gallant and amanzingly well preserved. Even the subway station in front of the Opera is another atraction that MUST be visited to get a grip in such wondergul architectural style!

Don't Miss This Opportunity. Fantastic tour with a 5 min solo presentation at the conclusion.what a great explanation of the building and more of an insight into life in Budapest in the 19C. A must do tour.
Great tour. Beautiful opera house,great tour with opera singer ,singing two arias what's there not to like,recommended

Very pretty building and interior but the tour was very much too crowded. This opera house is beautifully decorated as one would expect from a world class opera house. The tour was so crowded however that it made one almost claustraphobic. I would skip the tour unless you are a real opera buff.

Careful if you buy tickets for the opera!!!!!. I bought tickets for Carmen when I was there in September. I bought them from the homepage of the Opera House. The day of the opera we went there and found out that the performance wasn't there!! we met lots of tourists who were in our same situation and had to go by taxi to an auditorium called Erkel to see a ludicrous Carmen which, though in the musical area was great, was nontheless hard to look at, as they chose to do a "modern" interpretation and you could see CHEERLEADERS dancing to the sound of the chorus. As an opera lover, this was painful to see, we didn't leave because the orchestra and singers were so good and did their best to overcome such nonsense, not always with the best of success...If what you want is a visit, it's worthy to get in and see.

Highlight of Budapest visit. This beautiful builing and its stunning interior is a must see in Budapest.Tours well organised and for a little extra an opera singer comes out on the balcony and sings two familiar songs.Well worth visit.

Beautiful building, disappointing tour. The State Opera house is one of those wedding cake buildings filled with amazing decoration. Unless you go there for a performance, you can only visit on a guided tour, which we did. Unfortunately,our English language group had over 40 people, our guide, although knowledgeable, was not good at projecting her voice and was often barely audible. Also there were other groups with different languages, so a bit of a cacophony at times. The mini concert, of two arias by a beautiful singer, was very moving. Certainly worth doing, but one has no control over the size of the tour group or the voice projection of the guide.

Good to See. Tour is Meh.... Beautiful inside. Spectacular even.Tour is sort of lame. It's very quick, packed with people. They drain you of every cent too. Have to pay for the privilege of taking pictures. There are so many people and the tour is so quick, no time to get a shot without people in it. Have to pay for a 5 minute song from one opera singer.

Serenade me. Our apartment was right outside the Opera house and we learned there are free exhibitions given in front just about every day in the late morning. As we relaxed in our place we were serenaded and could look out the window onto the performance.We were not able to tour the inside.

A Definite Must See. This stop was part of our Vantage river cruise tour. This is an amazing building that can be seen on a guided tour...extremely worthwhile for both the history and the magnificent interior.

Great. Never been inside, but had a great pleasure enjoying an informal opera performance in front of the theater. It was a great experience, because the performers wore jeans and t-shirts and simply sang on a bare stage, but it was great.

Worth every penny..... We decided to immerse ourselves in a slightly different cultural experience to our usual cinema date nights...what better than the opera and a little of Mozarts Cosi fan Tutte?! In all honesty we only watched the first half because the seats were quite uncomfortable and we didn't get the best in the house by any means! I wasn't bothered though considering they only cost about £3 each! It was worth it to see the inside of the spectacular venue, you can do a tour but I think that's much more expensive.

Good to view but busy guided tours. Good to see inside, and learn about its history on a guided tour. Tour was a bit busy, as groups kept bumping into each other. Difficult to hear at times because of the tour sizes.

Beautiful place, tour a little disorganized. The place is beautiful, however, the tour was a little disorganized. It took awhile to get ready, and the place was under construction so it was hard to hear the guide at times. I recommend the place stops the loud repairs while tours are being held.

Take the tour - its amazing!. Do take the full tour around this amazing building. Our guide a young vivacious student who spoke perfect English was a perfect guide. The extra of having a tenor sing to us at the beginning of the tour was icing on the cake. Great!

Stunningly Beautiful: A Must See!. I only had the opportunity to walk around and visit the gift shop; sadly, we did not have the time to attend a performance here. Be sure to include this stop whether you access it via the Hop On-Hop Off bus or by walking or by taxi. It is a memorable place, and you will be glad that you took the time to step in and see it for yourself. MOST HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
Nice. Beautiful place with a nice history. Better to select a guided tour that ends up with a mini concert!

Every inch packed with beauty. This may be smaller than some of its international neighbours, but it is absolutely gorgeous. Overlooked on the outside by the ubiquitous statues of important men, inside every inch is beautiful decorated -- from ceiling to floor and everything in between. No show on when we passed by, but we were still able to walk in and spend some time looking at the foyer, staircases etc (and at no charge). Well worth a visit.
Amazing experience!. Small, intimate; gorgeous and ornate historic Opera House. See an opera there no matter what is showing!

Beautiful building. The Opera House is a beautiful building with a very interesting history. Guided tours are available and can be booked on site at a reasonable cost. It is located on a beautiful tree-lined avenue lined with expensive shops and is walking distance from major downtown hotels or the cruise boat docks. One small complaint is the large groups in the tours made for a rather impersonal experience.

Opera and architecture buffs. Gorgeous. Went on a Saturday and they were practicing an opera on the street corner with actors, stage managers and a small orchestra. The tour is well worth it. Book opera tickets well in advance.
Adventure Budapest. This is a gorgeous building to house the opera. Very convenient to get to. It is elaborate inside and out. It is worth visiting.

A little neglected on the outside, but beautiful on the inside. It needs a clean on the outside, but inside it is ornate and pristene. We've seen many opera houses and this is one of the best. Even with no show on the stage, you would be happy sitting in the theatre for an hour just taking in the beautiful baroque decorations all around - so much gold, scrolls and artwork.Some practical tips:1) You can only see the theatre by paying for a tour.2) There are English tours at 2,3,4pm daily in high season3) Don't be put off the 2pm tour because it doesn't include the option of a "miniconcert". What you are not told is that the miniconcert is NOT in the old main theatre, but in the more modern second theatre. Unless you want the concert for the concert's sake, forget it4) Street ticket sellers may offer you tickets to the opera in the opera house, but they may not be in the grand old theatre, but instead in the secondary more modern theatre in the building. Don't be fooled!
Worth a visit even if you are not an Opera Fan. Wonderful tour as well as a short presentation of a scene from a famous Opera. Beautiful ornamentation throughout and wide sweeping staircases.

Stunning, get the tour. This was one opera house whose tour was well worth while. It was informative, interesting, fun, humorous and full of interesting legends. We got a mini concert at the beginning which was delightful, the opera house itself is stunning, right up there with Vienna (same architect), woodwork was beautiful, marble was colorful, boxes were lush.

Lovely building and opera. Make sure you include the mini concert in your tour. Only about 5 - 10 mins long, but really sets the scene.The tour itself is very crowded, but everyone was given time to see everything and a chance to ask questions.However, there was noisy building work going on which, disappointingly, carried on during the tour / mini concert. Considering they only run 2 tours a day, you would have thought they might have stopped it for at least the music.Finally, don't bother paying extra for the photo permit - most people don't (or aren't even told about it) and there's certainly no checks.
Stunning Architecture. Very nice architecture, a pleasure to watch the opera in here. Do not be afraid to go in and ask about the tickets- they have cheap tickets for some performances too.
Really worth a visit. My tour here was organised by APT - we had a great guide, and champagne whilst a surprise opera singer entertained us from the balcony. Way to go!

A beautiful Opera house. One of the most beautiful opera houses in the world. If you can, go to an opera or a ballet, and in any case, take the guided tour to find out why the Emperor left with dismay in the opening night and never came back.

Book some tickets, it's worth it!. Visiting the Opera in most of Europe is an extremely expensive experience, luckily Budapest have kept their tickets well priced, so if you want to see inside this beautiful building, you can pick up some tickets for the same price as a guided tour. It's worth it, the space is amazing and the performances are really good.

Wien opera but smaller . If you have been in Wien Opera house, you might fill a little the same. Actually it is not surprising since the money for that building came partly from Austria. In case you never been in Wien, you must visit this site. Take the tour inside, don't pay extra for the license to take pictures since you can do it secretly but pay some extra money to see the small show.

Afternoon concert. We didn't get to visit the Opera itself, as we arrived there too late (the visiting times are few, at least in March) but we had already booked for a small afternoon chamber-music concert in the Bertalan Szekely Hall, the Royal Hall. It was a small, intimate venue, vith very few people, and we listend to some members of the Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra and a singer.Both my husband, who is into classical music more then I am, and I loved our time there.

Didn't get to see the inside.. Only open for tours at 2pm, 3pm and 4pm, so we didn't get to be there at those times. However, one morning as we were going to the Metro, we came across an open-air rehearsal of Figaro. Nice bonus.
A real beauty of a special era. excellent tour guides, nice stories of the competition with Viena and romantic stories about the Empress Sisi and a magnificent building out and inside

WOW. Completely amazing opera hall. We took the 3 PM tour in English + short opera performance. Although we were a large group, the guide was nice and patient. While we were there the stage was under construction so the opera demo was given in the main staircase - which was very good (probably not the same as on stage though...)The opera hall itself was incredible! Shockingly gorgeous.
Sightseeing. Truly an architectural jewel. Worth visiting - full of history. Strategically located in Andrassy Avenue.
Do not miss. The highlight of our trip was the mini concert! I will come back some day to attend a full opera. the opera house is stunning and I loved the history and romance of this opera house.

Take the Tour, Stay for the Simi-Concert. Beautiful building, good tour, a small concert at the end with a soprano performing at the top of the staircase, walking into the audience as she sang. A real treat, our second of the day. The first was as we approached the Opera House, and the cast of Otello was rehearsing outside on the corner in jeans and t-shirts. Residents and tourists alike were mesmerized. Our hotel concierge told us that this is not uncommon. I wish we had more accessibility to the opera in the US; perhaps a new generation would come to love it as we do!

Astonishing place. It's worth the visit even just to admire the building especially during the night. We saw La Boheme, it was a unique experience since we bought good seats tickets. There were subtitles only in magyar, although the opera house was quite loaded by tourists like me who i don't believe are familiar with that language.

Visit not recommended. HelloMe and my husband visited the opera house in Budapest on the 10th of Sep. we paid for a tour but it was so crowded (something like 50-60 people) and there was such a noise of tools and workers because of renovations, that we couldn't hear a thing, although the guide did her best, so we left in the middle .We went to complain to the manager but all she could say was " I am sorry".All I am saying is that during this works they shouldn't organize guided tours

Beautiful. As others have said, this is similar to other Opera Houses in Europe. But I would say this was one of the more beautiful ones. I would recommend using a real camera inside-- one in which you can compensate for low lighting and adjust your flash. We asked some strangers to take pictures of our family inside and got great pictures of us in the ornate setting. Most were using cell phone cameras and were disappointed that their cameras could not pick up the richness. Yes, there were some lights on inside, but not enough to create perfect cell phone camera shots.

What an experience. Had a wonderful night at the opera here. I don't even like opera but we saw Faust and it was amazing. The opera house is, I believe, the biggest in Hungary and in incredibly sumptuous in its decor. To go there is to go back in time to a glorious era when the wealthy had the best of everything, and to sit in that auditorium with the wonderful paintings everywhere, the huge chandelier above one and those plush, red curtains and seats....what decadent joy. It was fabulous and an occasion to remember.

Beautiful Opera House. Beautiful Opera House in idyllic surroundings. The architecture is truly amazing, we would highly recommend a visit due to it being one of Budapest's landmarks. We saw no show but had a quick look inside.

Opera house tour - worth while. Unfortunately the opera season was delayed due to refurbishments so we took the hour long tour and ended with an aria on the staircase, which was well worth the extra 600 forints. A fabulous venue and next time we visit we will make sure it is in the opera season.

Worth a visit and a guided tour - at least!. Beautiful building on the outside, very similar though to other Opera Houses in Europe... the minute you enter things change: magnificent, beautiful, rich, a real work of art!. And if you are lucky to get to watch a performance you realize Budapest and Hungary still are part of the "Great Arts Empire" in Europe.

A must see. Spent several hours with an expert guide viewing the inner workings of this theater. Recommend this a site not to be missed that said, given the amount of walking and stairs do it early. If you have the time stay for a performance

Glad we went!. We were unsure whether to tour the Budapest Opera House but were certainly glad we did! It is smaller but more opulent than the Viennese Opera House. The tour did not require a long wait, was affordable and was both informative and enjoyable.

Excellent site that deserves better tour opportunities. The building itself is wonderful. Our tour was a bit of trial, however, due to the hordes of people on simultaneous tours. It seemed like we were being herded from one place to another and the guide's English was not that clear, especially due to echoes and interfering noise/speech from other tour groups nearby. At the end of the tour,...


More

very nice architecture. Hungary has tradition with music. This building is very nice and I only regret that I was not also to a show inside but maybe next time, around New Year. Its location is good and it should be well kept and taken care of as it is a proof of the musical traditions of Hungary.

Pay a visit if you have spare time. Public tours start at 3pm and 4pm. Metro Stn right opposite so it's easily reached. Be prepared for a crowd at the start, but thankfully the tour itself is divided into manageable groups beforehand. IYou learn some interesting facts and figures about the building and the decor inside is quite a scene.

A photo of this place does not do it justice. Must see.. To some, this is an old building that really depicts the era it. Just being there, you could feel the history. It is unfortunate that the surrounding building were somewhat rundown.
You can have trips to visit it, we missed out on that due to lack of time. The whole street is full of history from start to finish (start...


More
Stunning building. Beautiful building and well worth the visit just a shame you can't book on-line you have to go to the Opera House to book and buy the tickets for later that day.
Ceiling is stunning. The Opera House was certainly built to last and it has been carefully looked after and has the most stunning ceiling.

A seat at the Opera (house).. Well-organized tour in multiple languages. Kept us far enough apart there was no "babble" effect. Beautiful and will compare to our new Center opening in Charleston, SC later this year.
Opulence at its best. Beautiful architecture and furnishings. The guide was excellent and gave us an informational history of the building, it's architect, and the royalty it served.
Become an instant opera fan.... The atmosphere, the history, the place and the tour are all grand, including the optional performance of a couple of arias. It was enchanting.
Beautiful!. Incredible opera house! We were disappointed that the opera was "off" the week we were there, but really enjoyed the tour of the building and hearing some of the history.

Hungarian State opera House. We visited the Opera House on one of the hottest days of the year. There is no air conditioning there. There are many groups being guided by your language of choice at the same time. So you are kept moving on a route, where you avoid the other groups until you get near the end, where you look down on a big staircase. All the groups converge there, with many sitting on the stairs and others standing four deep to hear two opera arias sung by one of the performers. On the day we were there, the heat was almost unbearable. So, if you are there on a day when the weather is in the 90 degree range, I would wait for a cooler day. You will be able to appreciate the opulence there on a cooler day.

Amazing opera house. This beautiful opera house is the prime example of 19th century architecture , very Renaissance like . The interior is marvelous with excellent acoustic. Well worth a tour and not to be missed when you visit Budapest.

Great Tour Guides here!. Best tour of our trip to Budapest. Be sure to stop by the Opera House early (by 11am I believe we did) to reserve tix for a tour that will take place later in the day, in the language you want.
Hungarian Opera. Excellent architecture. A building which someone must see even once. Prefer to travel in Budapest around Spring. The nature beauty and the flowers will bring you up another feeling.

One of the most Beautiful Opera Houses I have visited. There were no performances when my wife and I visited Budapest in August. So we had to settle for the guided tour. The building is impressive, the tour is very well organized and the mini concert (actually 2 arias) at the end is a must. I only wish I was able to catch the pulse of this place during an actual live performance.

worth a visit. Worth a visit and quite reasonably priced.
Art work amazing.
Guided tours really interesting. 1 hrs tour fro. 2pm, 3pm or 4pm

Beautiful building and nice tour. We were there in July when the opera is blacked out but was able to take a tour of the opera house. They do a nice job of separating groups into different language groups and then seeing different sections without bumping into each other. You can also buy a ticket to take pictures and also another ticket to experience a "mini opera", where you gather into a smaller room and listen to a singer perform a couple of songs. Even in that small room the acoustics were good. Just imagine how good they would be in the theater itself. Well done.

place is gorgeous, tour is terrible. the opera house is beautiful and the only way you can see it, beyond the lobby is an over priced tour. the groups were too large, and we couldn't get close enough to hear everything. often other groups were present in the same area so you had to listen over a competing guide in another language. when the tour was over it was pretty clear you had to leave or hang out in the lobby. it felt rushed and confused. we went at 4 pm on a Sunday perhaps the weekdays are better. the guide was nice and knowledgeable and tried her best but the odds were against her.
A confection of wonderful imperial excess.. It gets crowded - but the tour is worth the wait. The house is truly more beautiful than the one in Vienna, much to the Emperor's disgust.
Too busy. Quite interesting but as the Opera tour is on the standard cruise ship itinerary it was so busy as to not be enjoyable.

Never in the summer. Building is beautiful, but lack of AC made it unbearable. On top of that they were very disorganized at check in and during the tour. Too many people really spoiled it, as did a late start. Might be better in the low season.

Stunning Architecture. This is worth visiting the tour of the building. Definitely pay the extra for the 5 minute opera concert at the end of the tour. There were way too many people in our group and it was a bit disorganized but worth visiting nonetheless.
Take the Guided Tour. Would recommend taking the guided tour around the beautiful Opera House- very insightful guides and amazing interior. Be sure to stay for the mini-concert!

Pay a visit with the visitor tour!!. Visited the house in August with the visitor tour. The tour held everyday at 15:00 and 16:00 with ticket price around 2000Fr. You may buy the tickets in advance at the day you wish to visit. The tour had multi-language for us to choice, and the tour guide would take you all over the opera house and introduce everything to you. Overall the visitor tour is a really good and simple way to understand and enjoy this beautiful buildings.
Amazing. Overwhelmingly beautiful, so perfectly designed, every corner will amaze you with history, art and professional details. Must visit when in Budapest, you will remember it for lifetime...
Mute in the summer. Lovely building, but closed up for the summer. No chance for seeing a performance or a concert. Too bad.

A Worthwhile Visit to a Beautiful Opera House. The Opera House is quite spectacular and worth touring. They offer tours at 2,3, and 4 pm with the 3 and 4 pm tours including a mini Opera performed by a lovely lady.
The tour is about an hour and they have several guides in various languages. I think the cost was the equivilent of about $15 US.
Fantastic. This is a must see even if you don't like music. We were given a guided tour, the grandeur of the inside takes your breath away.

Very busy. The day we went, the place was packed with people all doing the tours, but worth the wait and the effort. An amazing place and I would have loved to have been to a real event here if it had been in season.

Well run busy tours but fantastic interiors and wonderful taster opera demonstration.. Took the English language tour and mini opera. The tour organisation is very efficient despite the large sizes of some groups. The building is stunning and the tour very interesting but its was the mini opera which made me resolve to come back to see a full opera there one day. Great fun if a little crowded.

Mini concert at the end is worth it. Beautiful opera house, worth a visit. Lots of different languages available for the guided tour. Nothing absolutely spectacular - however the 5 minute concert at the end was beautiful. The opera singer came down into the group and sang to us. It brought tears to my eyes.

Must-see. Beautiful so beautiful inside another must see in Budapest. charges though seemed unfair I thought. If you want to just tour it is one price, if you want to take photos its another price and if you want to see a 5 minute concert thats another price!!!!!!make sure you pay to get some photos inside as it is worth it.

A Real Touch of the Old World. If you want to experience "The Old World" we are talking about the time when Europe was at its peak. This is a wonderful experience. The beauty of the building itself, the avenue it is located on and to top it off, you can't imagine the glorious beauty inside. Do it.

Beautiful Opera House. This is one of the most beautiful buildings in Europe built in Neo-Classical architecture,made of marble & with frescoes by some of the best Hungarian artists of that era.The Opera house has the statue of Ferenc Erical & Frenec Liszt, the Hungarian composers.it quickly established itself as one of the most prestigious musical institution in Europe with good acoustics & an horse shoe shaped auditorium seating 1200 people.Did not see any opera but visited it only.
Overtour. Lovely building but tour was overpriced, oversold (too many people on the numerous tours taking place simultaneously) and over too quickly (not enough to see to fill the hour).

Worth a visit!. Did not take the tour short on time. However, the exterior of this building is breathless. The spectacular design and ornate architecture makes it worth it to take the tour and go inside this beautiful structure. Of the many buildings and attractions we saw in Budapest ranks as one of the best in terms of its architecture and history. If you get a chance to visit while in "pest" be sure to due it!

Opera in Budapest. Took a tour of the Opera House in August. No chance to see a full production since it was summer. Easy to get to the opera station on the Metro. Beautiful building. Student guide with excellent English. Had a chance to hear a mini concert with a solo opera singer. Bathrooms available for ticket holders only.

Another landmark. An opera house and major performing arts venue. The building is a fine example of the Neo-renaissance architectural style. the construction started in 1875 on the order of Emperor Franz Joseph of Austria-Hungary and it opened in 1844.

Stop. Look Up! If You have time Take the Tour!. So much to do. So little time. Simply put: If you are passing through Budapest, pass by. If you are around for a bit stop in for the tour. It is very rewarding.
Worth the visit. It was worth visiting this opera house. The details of the structure is amazing. It was a bonus to be able to watch a show here.
Poor Opera Tour (Expensive too!) Beautiful Building!. The opera house tour is waaaay overpriced and not at all worth the money to pay! Skip it all together and just take in the interiors on your own.
Beautiful, even if you don't like opera. Beautiful building inside and out that's worth checking out even if you don't plan on going to the opera or doing a tour.Pro tip: get a photo with the sphinx.

Bargain. We decided to get tickets for the ballet on a whim when in Budapest and managed to get seats up in the God for a crazy price of something like £2 each. The view was quite restricted but we were able to move to more preferable seats as people left during the interval. The production was great and the building pretty stunning so thoroughly recommended as an evening activity while in town.
Just Beautiful. We didn`t see much of it but we got pretty delightful with what we saw. I strongly recommend you to go there and to take a tour in the opera house.

Experience stylish artistic Pest. Go to a performance to experience the art and the building. You can feel the history even as you walk in to the building the atmosphere hits you.Don' t bother with the tour. When we went it was packed with too many groups and was chaos. The extra 'concert' could not have been briefer!

My fav. My favorite place to go when am at home. Ballet or opera, concert or contemporary dance show, doesn't matter. In the moment I enter the building I step back in time. The most beautiful opera house probably in the world, but in Europe for sure :)
Beautiful.. Absolutely beautiful and well worth a visit even if you are not a fan of the opera. Stunning decoration and a beautiful bar with a terrace to enjoy in the interval.
Beautiful building. We did the guided tour which was very good and informative. A beautiful Opera House. Also paid a little extra and had the short recital to finish.

Worth seeing. We took the tour and thoroughly enjoyed it. This is an amazing building full of history. You will learn why theaters have safety cutrains, where nobility sat, how lovers snuck away and just how many famous artists performed here. So many photo opportunities you will find yourself taking photo after photo.The optional "opera" performance lasts about ten minutes and is in a side room. Even though it is a little touristy we did enjoy it.

Impressive building. I didn't have time to take a tour. I was captivated just by seen the exterior. Once inside, you get trapped by the yellow, gold and red that frame the whole decoration. It is a really beautiful place, well preserved and centrally located.

A magnificent building not to miss. What a magnificent building, so much gold. We had a tour of the building which included champagne and a classical performance. The acoustics in the main performance area are the third best of any opera house in the world. The chandeliers are breath taking. Definitely worth a visit

If you're a musical aesthete, not to be missed.... Beautiful opera house, whether you're doing a tour or performance visit. You can book on line or line up before the show. Arrive early to give opportunity to browse. Just breathe in the culture as you revel in the performance. The metro stops right in front and it's no bother to take it back wherever you reside. The city is very walkable.

A treat for the eyes as well as the ears!. My favorite building on Andrassy Avenue is the neo-Renaissance Opera House. Completed in 1884, this is Hungary's largest opera house. The interior is decorated with beautiful frescos and sculptures. The huge Auditorium can seat around 1200 patrons and is decorated with gold. A massive chandelier weighing three tons hangs in the center of the auditorium. The Hapsburg Emperor allowed the construction of this Opera house on the condition that it should not be bigger than the one in the capital, Vienna. He forgot to add that it should not be more beautiful too. So when the building was completed the Emperor was so upset at it's beauty that he never visited again. His wife Elisabeth though visited it regularly but as she came without her husband she was not permitted to use the Royal Box. So she chose a box closer to the stage and the Royal Box stayed vacant. Touring groups and the Kasa National Opera and Theatrical Troupe performed here during the 19th century. These days the Budapest Opera Ball, an annual event, is held here.

Not to Be Missed. We walked past the Opera House on our first day in Budapest and were struck by its beauty. We were fortunate the next day to have the time to do an English speaking tour. The tour is very thorough and allows you to sit in one of the boxes as well as to sit on the main floor. There are various side rooms that are also visited and the background given by the guide is very useful in understanding the history of the building.

Pay for the opera, not the tour. The Opera house is worth seeing. The tour, not so much. The guide is totally scripted and does not engage the customer. It is too bad. The stories these walls could tell...

Stunning!. I visited in August. It is worth getting there at 11am when the doors open, and purchase a ticket for one of the tours later. The inside is stunning! To take photos, however, will cost you a little extra.
Tour short but worth it. Very impressive indeed. The tour itself I thought was too short, but what there was of it was informative and interesting.

Just fabulous. Situated on the Pest side. Beautiful building with historical musical figures on the roof. There is daily tours - 2.00pm, 3.00pm and 4.00pm. There is a charge for the tour, for photography taking, for a mini concert (two songs by a opera singer). It gets very crowded and very hot and sticky in August. I went on the 2.00pm tour. I had to go my hotel and had a shower after the visit. The interior is spectacular. It is a worthwhile visit even it is expensive.

Impressive building, especially at night. Situated on a road with designer shops, and near to Jewish quarter (food market place full of restaurants) very interesting as part of the evenings wandering up road.

Beautiful!. The tours are a must. They are in a variety of languages but are very busy.The interior of the building really is very special and the guides are well informed and make sure you get the best from this hour long tour.You can opt for an extra at the end of the tour which includes a 10 minute concert and this is well worth it-just beware of being selected for audience participation!!!
Take the time to stop and see this. We weren't able to go inside but the outside of the building is yet another reminder of the grandeur of the Austria-Hungarian Empire.
1 hour tour is recommended. The outside doesnt look so inviting but the inside is better. Worth to book a tour to know the history of the Opera with interesting details.

Amazing building. If you are walking on the nicest avenue in Hungary, very vlode to the downtown you will find the Opera house. GREAT building, you have an option to visit inside with guided tou as well.
Nice building but bad timing.. The schedule and opening time is quite restricted. But overall a very nice opera house with great design. The souvernir could have been better located.

Over the top (in a good way). Alert: 500 Florins for a camera-use fee. Payable in Florins or Euros.Outside, the building is topped with statues of 16 composers and the floor of the carriage entry (portico) side is parquet wood (so as to soften the clattering of horses' hooves).The senses are totally assaulted inside: built between 1875 and 1884, the cost of construction was 3 1/2 million GOLDEN Florins. Sounds like a lot.Our tour included about 7 or 8 stops for viewing and explanation and we had opportunities to sit in the theater balcony seats and opera boxes, admire the "Hungarian Painters Room", take in the auditorium, see behind-the-scenes places where performers changed costumes and snuck a smoke and a snuggle with an admirer, maneuver the grand staircases, and check out where the guests would have checked in their coats.The woods came from Slovenia and Croatia. Marble came from Hungary and Transylvania. Our guide reminded us that Hungary was 75% bigger at the time and the sources for these materials was readily avialable in their provinces.Back in the day of construction, there was a provision stating that all material AND workers MUST come from Hungary. That regulation is no longer in effect.How many kinds of marble colors? I lost count after 10. And almost every wall is clad in brocade coverings in various hues. In the main foyer room (used by only the elite), the ceiling depicts Bacchus who was not only the diety of wine but also the patron saint of the theater. I did not know that.The floors are exquisite: lots of parquet in various patterms, marble stairs, and carpeting here and there. The Opera box gives a great view of the chandelier which weighs 2.1 tons. 1,261 people can be seated and the cost per ticket is 45 Euros each. Assume here that some tickets will cost more or some less.In the Hungarian Painters room there is a portrait of the character "Carmen" (a cigar store girl about whom an opera was written) and, yes, she has a cigar in her hand. The staircases have huge mirrors on the walls. Mauve marble, brown marble, all colors of marble are on display and in use.The 3 cloakrooms are works of art in wood. Such detail in the carvings! If you decide to come, you will enjoy the visit more if you can hook up wth a tour. It isn't so easy as just waking around. It is helpful to have an expert make it more meaningful.
Musical delight. We went on the 3pm English tour which ended with a soprano rendition of 3 arias. Well worth booking this tour.

Spectacular building, awesome tour.. I am so impressed with how well the Opera House runs their daily tours. Almost seamlessly the friendly guides bring several different language groups around the Opera house without disruption. The guide was extremely knowledgable and visibly very enthusiastic about working for an establishment the Hungarians have such pride for. It is well worth paying. The additional fee to hear the singer perform two songs in an intimate, memorable setting. Unfortunately I do not agree with charging another additional fee for photographs as the entry price for the tour should cover this.

If you love classic music,u'll love this place.. Im the only person who love classical music in my family,I love the ballet,the orchestra and almost all clasical art(in any way). So,in this visit to budapest I decide to went to the hungarian state opera house. But,unfortunetly they don't have anyshow during summer and next show was in october. A little bit dissapointed but,I took the tour around the opera house,and it was magnificent. I love everything about that opera house. If you have a chance to watch the opera or the ballet or any show there,you should go.
Totally overloaded. There are some miniconcerts at specific times and when thats the case you dont find space in the actually very beautiful opera house. Awesome architecture

Great tour. The tour is excellent and the theatre is beautiful. Worth both a trip to see the opera or ballet but also in the off season the tours are very good with lots of information and beautiful rooms to look around. It also has a balcony!

Beautiful building, amazing music. Don't book a tour! Buy a ticket for the opera/Budapest State Philharmonic and have an amazing evening taking in the building, the bar and the some fantastic music. Cheapest tickets were the equivalent of about £4 and the most expensive (so great seats) only around £12/£13! Highlight of our trip.

Opera House worth a visit. Our Tauck Tour, The Blue Danube included a tour of this beautiful opera house. It concluded with a performance on the stairs. Tauck does not miss a thing. Learning more about Maria Christina and the Hapsburg dynasty was an added bonus.

Okay. We spent four days in Budapest and did everything we could manage. Of all the things we did, this was the one I would skip if short on time. Everything else had been reasonably priced, this seemed a little expensive and whilst it was interesting in parts it did not take you backstage. The interior however was beautiful.

Unbelievable experience - book the tour. Given that we were traveling with 2 teenagers we didnt think a night at the opera was a possibility - so instead we took a tour with a mini concert. The tour was amazing and we learned a lot about how the history of Budapest was part of the history of the building. After the tour - we stayed for a few arias by an amazing soprano. Even my children (ages 12 and 14) were amazed and delighted. Definitely a must do in Budapest.

be sure to catch a tour!. They had a film crew there with dancers, so we were not able to tour the opera theatre, but we were allowed to linger in the lobby to warm up and view the dancers and production crew. Call or check ahead for tour times. I'm sorry that we missed the interior.

jewellery-box of Europe. This building has been often mentioned by people of Budapest as the jewellery-box of Europe. It is indeed very beautiful and nicely decorated. I would compare to Opera Garnier of Paris. Central y located just at the Opera station of the millennial-subway, a visit is inevitable.
Amazing building. and inside...OMG. You defenately need to do the visit at the Opera house, the guids are so perfect, the building is amazig, free to tae photos...

A beautiful visit. Make sure you book your visit ahead of times, if you are interested in a guided tour. The visit consists of a guided tour in the language of your choice. Book your tour with a picture ticket if you want to use your camera inside. It is well worthed. The decoration and architecture is absolutely splendid and is influenced by the Garnier Opera in Paris. My only regret was that there was no show available at these premises in summertime. At the end of the visit, an opera singer did a five minutes performance,which was a pure delight.
Beautiful. Its like taking a step back in time, full of charm and very opulent. The guide was great, really interesting and well worth a visit.

Anyone for the Royal Box. When I visited Budapest the opera season was in recess for the summer so I did the next best thing and booked myself a tour of the interior, in English. Tickets with an allocated time can be purchased from the box office on the day. The building was constructed using exclusively Hungarian materials and is an absolute artistic treasure trove within. I was so disappointed that I was unable to attend a performance but was assured by our guide that from ' the royal box' where, these days, the head of state has replaced the royal person I would get not only a magnificent view of the central stage but a first class acoustic experience. Don't miss it.
Opulent decor. Takes you back in time imagining what it would be like to attend an opera in a bygone era. Very opulent. Tours can be taken to see behind the scenes.

Don't miss this treasure when in Budapest. What can one say?One of the most gorgeous old opera houses in the world.True old charm.Many brilliant productions, especially La Boheme - the oldest production in the world.highly recommend a visit!

A magnificent building.. They do tours of the inside in English and most other European languages. Unfortunately we missed the tours as our timing was wrong. A great shame. And do not forget that the Opera does not play in July and August.

DO NOT FORGET TO VISIT THE OPERA!. The opera is almost a copy of the opera of Wien.It is must for Sissi lovers. Make a guided tour in your own language. And have a coffee at the terrace next to the opera. An amazing concert hall, very good guides.

beautiful music. Having been to the Paris Opera and also the Vienna Opera house I put the Budapest Opera house in the middle not as beautiful or grand as Paris, and I know Vienna having been rebuilt after the war suffers from 1950s modernism budapest is smaller (decree by the emperor) no less important they have crazy good musicians singers and dancers and a beutiful backdrop. The tour was very good and went to several areas but dissapointed no backstage got a nice backstage tour in vienna

Stately and Ornate. Funded by the Head of State at a time with Hungary and Austria were one. The Head of State determined one opera house (that of Vienna) was enough. The people of Budapest petitioned the Head of State who reluctantly funded the project over a 6+ year time frame with one condition - it had to be smaller than the one in Vienna. It may be smaller in size but it exceeds in beauty and acoustics. A gem in Budapest. Enjoy!!!

Beautiful building. We took a tour of the building with a great guide who brought the place alive for us. Really interesting and some beautiful architecture. Unfortunately we went off-season so the stage was closed, but I'd still recommend it. They charge extra if you want to take pictures, but it was only £1 or so.

beautiful building and great tour guide. Glad we did the tour as the interior of the opera house was outstanding and tour guide very informative - we did give the mini concert a miss though as it was a bit extra and we aren't really opera fans - think it's a bit much though charging for taking your own photos no matter how little.
gorgeous opera house!. We enjoyed a guided tour of the opera house - it's incredibly ornate, and definitely worth a visit if you're in Budapest.

Exceptional talent in a wonderful setting. We caught Il Trovatore and it was a treat. Exceptionally talented singers, great production, and a wonderfully historic and beautiful venue. Much cheaper for comparable quality in other top venues. Definitely recommended!

Walked away impressed!. I'm not the kind of person who is a fan of opera or stage shows, however read that a visit to this place is a must... And it was worth it. The interior of the auditorium was simply fantastic, and up there with the most impressive buildings I have seen. You can only visit this building by guided tour, which are held at 2pm, 3pm and 4pm daily. The venue is also used for live shows. Worth a visit.

Beautiful Opera House, Great Performances!. This is a very impressive opera house and we really enjoyed seeing La Boheme. If you visit Budapest and are a fan of opera, you need to visit this opera house. Or if you don't, it still makes for great pictures inside.
Hungarian State Opera House. We enjoyed a guided tour of this most ornate and beautiful building, and at the end a short solo opera demo along with champagne!

Nice Place. We took a walking tour around the Opera House. There are inside tours available during the day for English speakers. Check the board outside the palace for times. It was very interesting to learn the history behind the opera house.

Come for the architecture, stay for a mini-concert. Very very cool building - the performance space is jaw dropping really. Do the tour that includes a mini-concert - it's a soloist doing a couple Arias (Ave Maria was one of them) and it will definitely move you.The mini-concert is NOT in the main theater, which is a touch disappointing, but felt like this was a great value.It was crowded and very hot inside (I went in July) so be prepared if you decide to go during the summer.Absolutely would go back for another mini-concert.

Great tour, enjoyable ballet...not so fond of the opera. It's hard for me to review this as an attraction, since I had very different experiences on different visits:First, I've been on the operahouse tour 4 times now, and enjoyed it very much every time. While the guides follow the same route and general narrative, they all provide different tidbits and I learned something new each time. It IS much more enjoyable during the off-season, when things are not so crowded, and it IS difficult to take photos (particularly good photos) under the conditions of the tour. I'm fairly serious about photography, so after I went on the tour once, I "preplanned" each time which shot I wanted to try for and focused on getting that, and was able to get some very nice photos. For me, this is worth the price, but I can understand why people might feel it's not good value for money. Extra "photo tickets" are pretty common in this region, and IMO an extra 500 HUF (~$1.80) is not a big deal, especially since they have always let me purchase one photo ticket to cover two people. I would give the tour 4.5 stars (****1/2). The architecture and history are beautiful and interesting, and the guides well-trained, but due to the size of the tours, fairly impersonal.Second, I saw a ballet (Anyegin) from the cheap upper seats which I enjoyed a lot. For about $5 US, I had a surprisingly good view (especially with binoculars) and as far as I can tell since I am not educated in ballet, quality classical ballet. I would give this experience 5 stars (*****). I wanted to see Swan Lake, but tickets sold out in about 5 seconds flat and it was the middle of the semester, so I didn't have time to go lurk around the box office hoping some would become available.Third, I saw two operas - Carmen, at the Erkel Színház location, and Ariadne auf Naxos, at the main operahouse. The former was enjoyable but underwhelming, but I won't review it here. The latter...was the first time I've ever considered walking out of a professional performance at intermission, but there was no intermission, so I was stuck. While it turns out I probably wouldn't care for that particular opera under any circumstances, I'm mystified as to why they decided to turn it into a bloodbath, systematically killing off all the characters in more and more gruesome ways. When it wasn't gross, it was boring, although the summary made it sound satirical (implying at least a modicum of dark humor).
