Since Carmen was also a "modern" staging," I'm now a little wary that the Hungarian State Opera goes for "modern" stagings as a matter of course - I'm not opposed to restaging and don't demand everything be staged traditionally, but I do think it's easy to go for shock value and poorly thought-out "updates". I would think very hard before trying another of their opera performances, especially when the Budapest Operetta Theatre stages such delightful operettas.I would give Ariadne auf Naxos 1 star (the singing was competent - the bare minimum I hope for, because if opera doesn't have competent singing, it's got nothing) and hope it's not representative.

Celebrating 130 Years. Budapest has endured invasions, occupations, destruction and reconstruction for centuries... this city isn't like a well preserved, time-honoured Prague. After WWII, 80% of Budapest buildings were either destroyed or damaged. Perhaps because of everything the city has gone through, it deserves to be named "the world's second best city" according to Condé Nast Traveler and ranked as the most liveable Central or Eastern European city on EIU's quality of life index. Buildings like the Hungarian State Opera House celebrating a 130 years is a wonderful reason to take a tour or see an opera or ballet performance. It is beautiful inside and there is still a history and stories to told here... it makes no difference that the building isn't 400 years old. We had a great tour guide who offered a lot interesting detail about the theatre and private rooms as well as fun trivia about people who have attended performances over the years. Definitely include the Opera House on itinerary!!

Great Architecture. Magnificent Building that is still been used to produce some great performances. Due to the high cost of the tour I opted just to admire all the exterior features and then had coffee in a cafe opposite to admire the view further.

Singing praises. I have my own travel blog and was interested in getting some rocking images for it. I was not sure whether it would be worth paying the admission fee and photographers fee (2400 HUF in total as a student) to simply view the opera house but I am very much glad I did. The tour is the right length of time, 40 minutes, I had a great guide who was both funny and informative. They take you around the entire theatre (except backstage) and many opportunities for photos of the ornate interiors. Incredible to be in a place and transported to another time simply by being in a building. I believe it was worth the visit and I was able to get some incredible photos of my tour.

Really enjoyable. Was absolutely wowed by the inside of this building, it's really stunning. We had a very good tour guide and learned a lot, which was also the perfect length of time and also paid the extra amount to take photos which was well worth it!Definitely a must see when visiting Budapest.

Great architecture but tour was disappointing.. The architecture is quite stunning and well worth seeing.However, I feel that the high cost of the tour, the extra charge to take pictures and an additional cost to listen to a very short recital is poor value. The number of visitors at any one time is massive and the tour process feels like "a money machine" in action.In spite of my severe reservations this is an interesting building to visit.

Stately and Grand. A true gem from the historical perspective and yet a currently operating Opera house. One can be enthralled by the ornate interior from a bygone era and yet appreciate the beautifully maintained building. Don't miss the opportunity to see this site.

Little disappointment. After the money we've paid - entrance, extra fee for taking photos and extra money for mini life concert - i can genuinely say that this experience is not good value for money.The English group as always is the most crowded one therefore is not easy to receive more personal tour from the guid who seem to be in the rush at all times. We saw Spanish or Japanese (smaller) groups being taken to first floor on the balconies as wall as on the outside balcony above the main entrance were pictures could be taken. Unfortunately our group was pushed forward and forward so pictures had to be taken so quickly that we didn't even have time to contemplate beauty of the interiors itself even though extra fee was paid for this privilege.The guide itself had good knowledge of the building with few interesting tips which can not be found in books.The biggest disappointment was the mini concert. We truly thought we would be able to experience someone singing on the main scene so we could hear how this magnificent voices sound on the real scale. Instead we were gathered in the official canteen room where opera singer came out behind the curtain and sang for 5 minutes and left. Great voice but so what. People sitting on the canteen floor is not what I would have paid for in the future.BOGUS!

WOW!. Beautiful Opera House. Very nice, comparable with the opera houses in Vienna & Milan. Build about 125 years ago it has excellent acoustics. Took the tour and the guide spoke American English! Had the opportunity to listen to Lady sign some operetta songs. Not sure if it was in Hungarian, French or Italian but was wonderful.
Great place to tour. I am not in the habit of touring opera houses, but this tour was very interesting. Always interesting to see buildings constructed to marry function with glamour.

Opera House Budapest. Wowed. We took the tour and it was excellent. Paid a little more a purchased a mini concert. Opera house is quite lovely. Tour takes you inside and you get to sit in the seats and visit throughout. The mini concert was about 5 minutes but well worth it. A soprano came out to perform. She sang two beautiful pieces. I taped it on my phone. Wowee.

Limited Tour. The tour was interesting but very limited. You can go through the building afterwards but it was so hot this summer in Budapest we just could not stand it any longer. IT was burning up hot in the building. They make you pay an EXTRA fee to be able to take photos inside! BOGUS!

Beautiful experience. We had a really lovely guided tour of the inside. The opera house is quite easy to get to by bus or subway. There were a few little shops selling little ballet shoes key rings, T-shirt, post cards and little girls' stuff.

Worthy sanctuary of opera in Budapest. The Hungarian State Opera House (Hungarian: Magyar Állami Operaház) is a neo-Renaissance opera house located in central Budapest, on Andrássy út. Originally known as the Hungarian Royal Opera House, it was designed by Miklós Ybl, a major figure of 19th century Hungarian architecture. Construction began in 1875, funded by the city of Budapest and by Emperor Franz Joseph of Austria-Hungary, and the new house opened to the public on the 27 September 1884. Before the closure of the "Népszínház" in Budapest, it was the second largest opera building in the city; today it is the largest opera house in Budapest and in Hungary.Touring groups had performed operas in the city from the early 19th century, but as Legány notes, "a new epoch began after 1835 when part of the Kasa National Opera and Theatrical Troupe arrived in Buda". They took over the Castle Theatre and, in 1835, were joined by another part of the troupe, after which performances of operas were given under conductor Ferenc Erkel. By 1837 they had established themselves at the Magyar Színház (Hungarian Theatre) and by 1840, it had become the "Nemzeti Színház" (National Theatre). Upon its completion, the opera section moved into the Hungarian Royal Opera House, with performances quickly gaining a reputation for excellence in a repertory of about 45 to 50 operas and about 130 annual performances. Today, the opera house is home to the Budapest Opera Ball, a society event dating back to 1886.
Opera House. The tour is very interesting. The opera house is a very beautiful place, you cannot miss this on your trip to Budapest!

Very limited tour in a beautifull building. The tour takes about 45 minutes and if you take the English one the groups a very large so we decided to take the German one, that was only 4 persons and we could understand the German speaking guide easily. Tour shows you the main places and you can not visit the royal box for example, which is possible in other opera houses in the world. Tour itself is not that interesting but getting around the building and see the interior was wortwhile.
Nice outside.... Didn't go round on one of the tours - felt would rather have tied this in with seeing a performance - but it seems very interesting.

Beautiful building. The tour of the Opera building was interesting and we appreciated the beautiful restoration work that has been done here. Also paid for the short concert but it didn't live up to expectations as we just stood around and listened - sitting would have been more authentic.

Opera buffs delight. Mrs G is the opera buff, so we had to visit the Opera house. The day we went there were lots of visitors on our tour, so sometimes it was difficult to hear the commentary of the guide. But the tour was very informative and we were able to see a production in rehearsal and at the end our own little mini concert in the bar. Sadly there were not any real operas on whilst we were in Budapest, looks like we'll be going back!

Hungarian Opera House. The opera house is really elegant and worth a visit, but only if you are willing to be in hot and overcrowded circumstances. When we visited there were just too many tours happening at once and in many different languages. At every turn we encountered other groups, so we had to wait to move into a room which made it hard to see all that the room entailed. Also we had only a brief time in the concert hall as too many tour groups. Also we were restricted from viewing the boxes as some kind of competition was also in progress.We did enjoy the mini concert at the end of the tour, it's just too bad that the regular season ends earlier in June so that we could not go to a concert there. If you can do that It would well be worth going.

Amazing place! Consider a concert (cheaper and better than a tour). We were lucky enough to see the last concert of the year before the summer shut down. This is a better and cheaper way to experience the opera house than an expensive tour. The place is nice outside, but during a concert it will blow you away and transport you back a hundred years where you can image what it must have been like at the turn of the century to see a performance.

informative and enjoyable. We chose an afternoon tour with mini concert and were surprised at how much there was too see there. Didn't get to sit down for the mini concert but we were impressed by the acoustics of the Buffet and the singing was wonderful!

Beautiful but crowded and a expensive for such a short tour. The opera house is beautiful and impressive. We enjoyed the tour but it was crowded. The best part of the tour was the mini concert at the end. It was worth the additional 600 HUF. If you can, I recommend buying tickets to a full performance instead of the tour and mini concert.

Good theater opportunity. I was surprised at the great theater and performance available in Budapest. The opera was hrs to understand because it was not in English and did not have English subtitles. But it was beautiful and we had a good time. And it was relatively cheap considering.
A must. A must if you are visiting Budapest it puts on all the best known classics without going all designer on you

Definitely worth the trip. This is an awesome tour - worth the wait and the lines, especially if you get to compare this state opera house with others in the region (Vienna, Bratislava) to see how the same ideas were expressed and maintained so differently, with different values and materials.

Opulent interiors, interesting history. We had a guided tour around the Opera house and learned about its history and when it was made. It was an interesting talk and the guide was very knowledgeable. The interior is very opulent and it is interesting that they have seats that are very cheap, so that everyone can afford it. We didn't actually see an opera.

Believe it or believe it not!!. When we tried to book on line before our holiday all the seats downstairs were full and only seats in 'the gods' were available at the side. We paid what was asked including a credit card charge. When we got our c.c. bill it showed we owed under £4 for the two of us!! We had a great time, the Vivaldi music was beautiful, the only draw back was that the storyline of 'Fernace' had been altered to include drug taking. (This is why we took off a star). We did have to climb lots of stairs up to the third level and our seats did not have a complete view of the stage. However, even though they showed full, there were lots of spaces we were able to move seats and get an excellent view. We so enjoyed our visit at virtually no cost. Thank you.

A Special Evening at the Hungarian State Opera House. Two friends and I attended a memorable production of 'La Traviata' here. Our seats on the ground floor were comfortable and two of us had good views of the stage. One of my companions is short and couldn't see over the person sitting in front of her. After the first act she explained her problem to the house manager, who immediately moved her to a better seat. There were supertitles of the libretto in 3 languages, Hungarian, Italian and English. The opera house itself is a fine example of elegant 19th century architecture. It is a combination of baroque-like and Renaissance Revival design with a ground floor, a mezzanine, and three balconies plus a lavish painted ceiling. There were many people dressed formally, which added to the elegance of the evening. One of the nicest surprises was the inexpensive cost of the tickets, making it affordable for just about anyone to enjoy a night at the opera.

A special treat. we had a local guide take us on a walking tour that included the Opera House. What a beautiful building with a rich and colorful history. As a special treat, our group,was privileged to a private concert by one of the female opera singers. A must see.!

A beautiful opera house. Situated on the Avenue Andrassy. Closed for performances for the summer but open for tourists to take a short tour which also included a mini-recital from a your opera singer.
Nice building. It's a nice building with great architectural aspects. We didn't go in to see an opera unfortunately.

Swan lake. Went to the ballet. Booked on line. Excellent experience would highly recommend. The performance was longer than we are used to and the ending not what we were expecting. Seats a little uncomfortable.

Beautiful building. The building is located very close to the city centre. easy to find and on the road to hero square.It is beautiful to see from outside, i guess it should be better when you walk inside. There were guided tours but their time was not convenient for our schedule. Plus 11euros for a tour didnt sound worthy.Do walk by and take pictures

Worth it, I suppose. Not quite what I expected. I had hoped we might see behind the scenes too. Lightning visit round the bar, boxes and stalls with what is a lovely building, though beware, the seats in the stalls are very hard!! The mini-concert that we bought into consisted of just two arias by a soprano, in the bar with canned music - not again what I expected.

Opulent Opera House. We went on a tour of the opera house. Our group was a bit large but the guide was informative and seemed to be having a lot of fun entertaining us with stories. The opera house itself is gorgeous! We paid a bit extra and were treated to a short 5 minute performance at the end of the tour. That little treat was well worth it!
Wish I could attend. Thank heavens this building suffered minimal damage during WWII. It was wonderful to see the original furnishings. The singer who provided the short concert was impressive.

Fantastic and accessible. This was enjoyed by tourists and locals of all levels of position in society. The opera was fantastic and the locals clearly go regularly and were really friendly to us new comers.
Not easy to get in.. Maybe it was only our problem, but we didnt get in. The staff didn't ant let us in. But it looks like a castle.
I wish i could see one. I was really hoping to see a musical on my holidays but unfortunately I didn't get a chance. The place looks beautiful

Absolute gem of an operahouse; tours are somewhat hit or miss. If you don't come during the opera season -- or aren't up to sitting through an opera -- make sure to tour the house, even if you are not an opera far. The architecture is just stunning. I'm an enormous fan of the Vienna Staatsoper, but have to confess this building is on a more human scale and is more charming. I have taken several visitors on tours between March and June, so have had a chance to compare how the tours are conducted. No surprise that you get a lot more for your money in the off season - you literally get to see a lot more and you get to spend longer everywhere. Also, groups are smaller. In the peak season, though, they do a genius job of seamlessly weaving the groups among each other, and first-time visitors have no idea they have missed anything. Be sure to spend the extra money for the "mini-concert." It's only tow arias but done with enormous verve and is a great way to round off the tour. And if you do come during the opera season -- tickets are inexpensive by Western standards and performances are of a very high standard.

Great old world building in the heart of the city. Budapest Opera House has performances most time of the year. Need to book early. Prices very competitive, much cheaper than average western prices. Most of the shows have no translation service.

Beautiful Architecture!. The building is a beautiful magestic old building with amazing architecture and decorations. We went on a guided tour which was well done and in English. Howver, in our ignorance we thought we would be able to just show up and join a tour being late winter and fewer crowds. This was not to be the case as we did have to book and also book an english guide and be prepared for a 3/4 hour time period. Fortunately, we were able to fit it in the next day and it was worth it. Its also near the Museum of Terror (which is excellent) and the famous Book Cafe (also worth a look but very busy , be prepared to wait in a queue for a table).

Nice Opera House. The tour guide was very good - clear and informative. The opera house itself is nice but not amazing. Tourists who have never visited other old European opera houses are lily to get more out the tour.

Worth a visit. The building is interesting and well worth a visit, and wish that we had had time to go on one of their guided tours, but had to settle for seats for a final rehearsal of Verdi's Furnace.We arrived in anticipation, and then had to climb innumerable stairs to reach the appropriate floor, which was no mean feat for the more elderly - apparently no lifts - the seats were very cramped - even more so than most older theatre's - and the opera, or the performance, was less than stimulating which, regrettably, tended to colour our appreciation of the building.Choose your opera with care, avoid the upper balconies/ circles and pay more for your seats, and then, no doubt, your experience will be significantly enhanced!

very nice building. I am not an opera fan but I can certainly appreciate the history and the architecture within. This is worth the time to visit and it is right across the street from one of the hop on hop off bus stops.

One of the best opera houses in Europe. Located in one of the most beautiful and famous streets of Budapest, on Andrassy Street. Just outside the Opera, there is the Metro station. The Opera is at 4 best in Europe! The State Opera in Budapest operating since 1884. It was built in order to compete with the opera houses of Paris, Vienna and Dresden. He was the life work of the great Hungarian architect Miklos Impl. The interior is decorated with works of Hungarian artists such as Lodz and Strobl. From that time until today the Opera has hosted some of the most famous composers, like Erkel, Gustav Mahler and Otto Klemperer. The central hall of the Opera is decorated with a bronze chandelier weighing 3,050 kg, which illuminates a wonderful fresco of Lodz with the gods of Olympus. Also the royal gallery is decorated with sculptures symbolizing the four voices of opera: alto, soprano, bass, tenor.

A must do. This is a beautiful place to visit. You can book to see a performance or, as we did, have a tour with a mini performance. Excellent organisation and the tour guide spoke very good English. The mini show was fabulous.
We want to return!. Unfortunately were unable to see a show so we simply visited the opera house and admired its architecture. The subway stop is right in front of the opera house.
an elegant place to visit. an elegant place to visit in the center of budapest in fashion street one the most important streets in budapest
Beautiful!. One of the most beautiful buildings in Budapest! An absolute must-see if you are visiting! Close to the city-centre and metro station

Beautiful. I am an opera fan and have seen Opera Houses and have heard operas in a lot of European operahouses. The Budapest Opera House is one of the most beautiful in Europe. If you are not interested to hear a whole opera, there is a fantastic possibility to visit the building see its beauty and hear its history. If you are an opera fun it is a great possibility to enjoy a good performance for a very good price for value.

What a fantastic building. We didn't do the tour and the Opera season had finished but visited the foyer with some lovely gifts in there. A most beautiful building and a definite must to return and visit an Opera here to see this beautiful building in it's full glory.
World's nicest opera house. I visited this opera house regularly since I was kid. I have never seen nicer opera house. All the gold and red velvet makes the place magical.

Another gem in a stunning city!!!. I finally got to be in this beautiful opera house! I bought tickets over the internet for "Jenufa" rather than take the tour of the opera house. I had been dying to visit as the previous and first time I was in Budapest the opera was out for the summer. The exterior looks old but that adds to it's charm and atmosphere. The interior is stunning!What can I say. It is the most beautiful opera house, ornate and plush. We had a box and it was great. We inspected the balcony with all the beautiful statues and alcoves, and all the beautiful stair cases, the interior. My jaw simply dropped open. The opera itself was wonderful! I ate my heart out that I did not get tickets for Swan Lake as well. So we tried the box office and there were just 2 tics left but expensive, and because we were tired from a long day of running around in this amazing city, we didn't take them and wisely so. My husband would have dropped off which would have been painful at 50 euros per ticket. As it turned out, we went to the wonderful Budapest Jazz Club, and sadly there I dropped off when it came to the jam session (free) past 11 p.m. which was absolutely smashing, but I was so tired and it was so late. It's better to buy tickets on the internet because you can see exactly where you sit and you do not have to go for the higher prices. Our tickets cost 17 or 19 euros each (don't remember) and were perfectly adequate. Another plus is you can plan your day accordingly. In my case it is imperative that my husband gets some rest before so he doesn't drop off (and he didn't).
Took the tour. I thought the Opera House was totally beautiful. Didn't get a chance to see an opera while there, but the gold and red decor just sparkled. LOVELY

Beautiful opera house, worth the visit. We had included the short performance of 2 arias which is worth paying for. The guided tour, despite the size of the groups, were well organized and very informative. Really enjoyed the experience

Very poor show. This 30 minute tour of the Opera House, with way too many people in the group, was very poor value for money. Total was approx 7000ft for two, for a guided tour, a five minute mini concert and permission to take photos. Because of the very large group it was often difficult to hear the guide. The interior, compared to the Vienna or Paris Opera houses, was extremely poor. Decor was shabby and neglected, statues or busts were mostly chipped and seemed to be made of plaster of Paris and not authentic. Fabrics, flooring and decor were not original but cheap copies. The five minute mini concert, for which we paid extra, was a disgrace...150 people cramped into a small room (not the main auditorium), were made to stand and listen to a singer that could not be seen by 90% of those present. Don't waste your money!

Beautiful architecture. Beautiful architecture, the area around it is lovely for a walk,. We were there on the weekend, so there were no tours inside. Walked down the street to a public park, where there are a number of embassies, and some interesting monuments. This is best done with a guide on a walking tour, or a self guided adio tour..much historical info.

Visit in the Opera house. We had no possibility to see some opera program because it was summertime. But they arranged guided tours for tourists to visit the Opera house with possibility to take photos if you pay an extra charge. This Opera house is very beautifu and we can recommend to visit it.

Feeling Medieval. Opera seems very small When you look outside. But inside it looks very huge. We went to German concerts. a bit painfully. 4-5 floor that they have in the opera. As an tourist you can visit. But a suggest you to listen concert. Famous Lıszt French statue outside. To summarize it was nice , I felt Medieval time when ı was there.

lovely experience. the guide was a cute girl you frowned with concentration, but did her job well. The inside of the building is lovely and well worth a visit. Should not be missed if you are in Budapest.

Beautiful Architechture. We did the guided tour of the Opera House. It is said to be more beautiful than the one in Vienna! The tour is about 45 minutes long and they do charge 500 Florint/group for taking pictures. Overall, it was a very good tour.

Stunning, another absolute must!!!. This building is just amazing, both inside and out. Stop and gaze at it, try to get inside just for a peek at the foyer area if you can't get any further. They do tours which you should consider if the timings are right.Of course it's as much about performances as appearances and this place doesn't disappoint on that score either, Hungarians take their opera very seriously.

Tourist rip off. Very expensive for a very short tour of this very beautiful place. The cost was more than a ticket to see an Opera but lasted 30 mins. The guide was robotic and spoken very quickly often difficult to understand. The english group had to be divided into three and each group comprised about 35-45. There was no back stage tour which in Vienna I found extremely interesting. By the way Vienna cost a third of this.Extra if you wanted to take photos, extra if you wanted a 5 min sample of an aria.On the whole very poor value. If you have a spare 15 euro to throw away then go for it.

Magnificent interior. went to see a performance of Swan Lake Ballet, I was able to get last minute seat in box sharing with a lovely couple from Vienna. A great and memorable visit to this beautiful building.

Elegant. We took one of the daily 2:00 English tours. If you want to take photos you have to pay a little extra. It was informative. The opera house is beautiful. The tour ends abruptly and I wish there were opportunities to ask questions but there weren't.

the opera house - don't go to the "official tour". the opera house is very similar to other like houses. but the organized tour is just a "money making machine". You are charged separately for the tour, for taking photos (if you want) and for 5 minutes demonstration of an opera singer (not compulsory, but not in the main hall). There are no limit to the number of people in the tours, and in this touristic season (July) there were too many of us and it was difficult to move, to look and to hear the guide.
Stunningly beautiful.. We didn't have time to attend a performance but the entry hall was worth a visit in itself. Like do many buildings in Budapest it was beautiful in a bling bling way.
English tours in afternoon. Don't miss this tour if you enjoy opera houses and listening to interesting trivia. Our guide was full of stories. Check their website for tour times.

Vivaldi's Farnace. The building is very ornate and well worth seeing.We saw Vivaldi's Farnace, and there were surtitles in both Hungarian and English.Great mid stalls seats for around £25. There is a tour during the day but so much better to see the building being used as intended. Located in a main street about 10 mins walk from the river, easy to find with lots of good places to eat nearby. A glass of fizz in the foyer was about £3. Even compared to Glasgow theatre prices this was very reasonable, for anyone used to London prices, it's a must.

the Interior. We had a tour in the theater. Its interiors and history are worth of your attention! Excellent onion soup in the cafe next door outside the theater. We enjoyed it while waiting for the tour.

Interesting history & architecture, even for people who aren't opera buffs. The guided tours are very well organized & interesting, and available in multiple languages. One can learn about some Budapest royals as well as the politics often involved in building these gems which display national pride, wealth and power. It was interesting to compare this 19th century opera house to the 20th century Sydney Australia gem. Well worth one's time and edification.

Must see inside. Very important building in Budapest, must see. Be informed and take a tour inside building, its worth it. Near by is a very nice Opera restaurant. If You are a Opera lover, maybe You will be lucky to get ticket. Hungarians are very fond of Opera and they are very proud of theirs. Its not spectacular like Opera house in Vienna but its worth to see
A must see. Lovely building and worth seeing. If there is anything on when you are visiting then make sure you get tickets.
Opera House. Avery beautiful building inside very photo shop did not get to experience a concert but enjoyed going inside if you have time just walk in enjoy

Worth while taking a guided tour as the building has a lot of history. We took a guided tour which was interesting. To get the guided tour with a mini opera, you must be there when tickets are sold at 11 a.m. Otherwise you can wander around without any explanations. When you buy the ticket, you are also supposed to buy a camera permit. The mini opera occurs at the end of the tour. A singer, male or female comes out (not on stage) and sings a couple of arias. It is fun. The opera house does not appear to have efficient a/c.

Awe inspiring!. Unfortunately there were no performances, but there are daily conducted tours. The building is beautiful and the tour goes very quickly, so you need to make the most of it while it lasts. The tours are very popular, so you do need to book prior to the tour.

Beautiful. We visited the Opera House whilst in Vienna, which was disappointing, but this was a gem by comparison. Well worth taking the afternoon tour which explains its history, and enables you to walk around all the areas

Fabulous Old Opera HOuse still has it. This is a lovely Opera hall. Built to rival Vienna it is in itself a terrific spot. The acoustics are very nice and the prices of the opera are very fair compared to what you pay in Paris, London, New York or especially Sicily and Germany.The seats are comfortable and sight lines excellent. the opera that I heard in September was also performed In New York but I enjoyed it more here as the house is a lot smaller and although the Orchestra was not as good as New York was more in the spirit of the piece. Very good spot to spend a pleasent evening and the refreshments are also fairly priced.
A def see. Lovely place to visit, there are various shows on as well, ask your hotelier or email them in advance and arrange directly.

Beautiful way to experience the Budapest culture!. We did not have the time to attend a full opera at the opera house while we were in Budapest, but we really wanted to see it from the inside. A tour is offered at 3 and at 4 pm. We took one of them and enjoyed it very much. The tour is offered in multiple languages, and although there were multiple groups touring at the same time, you did not feel it was crowded. The guides are knowledgable and always waited for all the people of the group to arrive at a spot of explanation before talking. At the end, you have an option of adding a few extra euros to hear a "mini" sample concert with one of the singers which was very cute. The opera house is amazing from the inside!
Superb building and history. A must see. Really great tour and an amazing building and history take the mini concert also. Tremendous Must visit place..

First Opera Experience. Went to my first opera with the girlfriend here. It didn't turn me into an Opera buff, but I am glad that I had the experience in this opera house. The inside is absolutely stunning. If you are going to try the opera, try it here.

Such an impressive building. You can understand why the Viennese were pissed off!. It's not as big as the Opera house in Vienna, because they weren't allowed to be so expansive. Instead, however, they decided to use every gorgeous type of stone/marble from all over the old Hungarian empire. So inside it's just totally amazing! No need to pay for a visit, either take in a performance (which can be amazingly cheap) or just admire from the foyer!

Grand Opera house. In my opinion this beautiful opera house does not match the grandeur of the Paris Opera, however this is a must see site. We opted for the mini recital - which is an optional - and it was worth the extra €5.

Budapest Opera house. We were lucky enough to have a tour and hear a short recital. Would have loved to hear an opera. A stunning building taking me back in time The story about the mirror at the top of the stairs isinteresting

Very pretty at night and during the day. Our hotel was right around the corner, they offer tours in many languages and I believe three English tours a day. We went to the 4 o'clock tour, I believe the others are at 2 and 3. The performances are pretty cheap too. Nice building on the inside and outside.

Great tour of the Opera House. Definitely worth a visit and the guide was wonderful. Recommend you purchase the photo option ticket too, otherwise you can't take pics of the beautiful interior. But it's also nice to just enjoy and NOT take photos!

It is too bad you cannot walk through on your own.. This is a magnificent building inside and out. The tours are in English daily at 2,3 & 4 and in 6 other languages daily at 3 & 4. This is a quickly paced, VERY crowded tour. We went on a Monday at 3:00 and there were about 25 people on our english tour...then there were about 15-20 people in each of the other tours as well. I do recommend it, just because the inside is exquisite but it is pretty expensive for what you get (2,900 HUF + 500 extra if you want to take pictures). It would be WONDERFUL if they allowed an option to walk through without the guide, but they do not. You learn a bit but it was very loud from competing with the other groups. The inside it very stunning but be ready to pay for a ticket to be rushed through quickly.

Beautiful building! Good Performance. We attended Verdi's Troubadour. It was a nice experience, actors were very skilled and the show was also quite spectacular. The building is small but has a unique interior design. One of the must sees of Budapest.

Short, but Worth It. The 45 minute tour of this beautiful building was the perfect length. None of us are Opera fans but we still found the tour very interesting. There are English tours at 2, 3, and 4 while there are tours in other languages at 3 and 4. We bought our tickets about 30 minutes before our tour and there was no trouble. The only downside was that tour group was huge and in some of the rooms some of the people struggled getting close enough to hear or see what the guide was talking about. Also the guides are a little bit or miss. We started our tour with a guide who seemed disinterested and bored, but for some reason part way through the tour we switched tour guides and our second guide was really engaging and passionate. There is also a fee if you want to take pictures during, but it was only around 2€ a person.
Worth a visit. Amazing build and the show was excellent as well. And all of this with a very reasonable price. Drink on a balcony is a good addition to the whole experience.

A comprehensive tour. The tour was extremely interesting and the guide was very knowledgeable. It provided an interesting insight into the activities and interests of Emperor Franz Joseph and his court, as well as the Empress Sissi, It is particularly noticeable that the major architectural features of the building are very much in the style of St Stephen's Cathedral and the Parliament building. An important observation: there were too many tours going round at the same time and it was very noisy. I suggest you try to book the first tour at 2 pm.

Underwhelming tour. I would have loved to go to a proper performance, but didn't have the time. So I settled for the tour and mini-concert. It was all rather pointless. I had no problem with the guide or the busyness (unlike some other reviewers), and the building is grand and attractively decorated. But worth paying good money to walk around without actually seeing an opera? Certainly not. (I paid only fractionally more than this to see Rigoletto in Vienna.)The silliest part was that they took us *out* of the auditorium to see the mini-concert in a reception room with appalling acoustics.

Exquisite. This is one of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen. Once I got past the scrum at the beginning and got into my smaller group of about 30 people, the building was eye-poppingly beautiful. The tour only takes about 30 minutes so be patient at the beginning. Once we were on the move, we got to see all the key things. There were a lot of parallel groups on the day I went but it didn't really impact the enjoyment of the visit.Lots of lovely little stories to give it life. Well worth a visit for 2900 forint.

Gorgeous opera house. The beautiful neo-renaissance decors makes it one of the most beautiful opera house. The acoustic was incredible. Sculptures and paintings were as impressive. I would definitely recommend a visit. Prices were surprisingly affordable.

Opulence and great acoustics. We are classical music and opera fans, and were not disappointed in the tour of this beautiful facility. Our guide was knowledgeable and we enjoyed the opportunity for a little backstage information. I would recommend, however, that if you are able to understand any other language (French, Spanish, Japanese, etc.) you book the tour in that language. The English groups were large and chaotic. The lobby is poorly designed for ticket purchases and the process is tedious. Definitely book a performance of any type when you are there. The acoustics are wonderful. The cheap seats ($10 in the upper balcony), provide great views and fine acoustics but are cramped and very uncomfortable. If you are in town and interested in any kind of performance, make this the first stop because most performances sell out well in advance. You might even want to book ahead online if you know your plans in advance.
One of the best in Europe. Went there and surprised by the size of the hall. The decoration is also one of the best opera houses I have seen in Europe.

Take the Tour!. Rather difficult to hear our English speaking guide who was in competition with several others in the same area. However this is a beautiful building and the high spot was a performance from a member of the cast! It was FANTASTIC!!!

Wonderful Opera House. Do take this tour... You will be told that because Budapest was part of the Austro-Hungarian empire, and was partially financed by Franz Joseph, that it could not be larger than the opera house in Vienna. Well it isn't, but due to a number of factors (WWII Bombing being one), this opera house, in my opinion, is grander that the Vienna Opera House. You will love the detail, and use of LOCAL materials. Outstanding....
Grand Opera House in Budapest. Magnificent Opera House - interior exceeds Vienna's, Good location on Andrassy Ut (Main boulevard in Pest). Near Metro, near embassies. Last tour at 4 p.m.
Biking thru the city. We rented bikes near the opera house and it was a great way to see the city. We was able to see 2-days walking attractions in 1 day on bike.

Great building but some seats shouldn't be used. Great building but some seats shouldn't be used. We didn't pay much for the tickets to the opera so we were not expecting great seats, but we were also not expecting that we would have a better view standing than actually seating. Some people from the same parts of the building (top tier on both sides) left half way as they couldn't see the stage. The building itself is amazing and worth a visit.

Guided tour is informative but crowded. My husband and I are both musicians, so we were looking forward to the guided tour of the beautiful State Opera House. Tours are offered in many languages; our English-speaking group was so large, it was split into two groups and it was still too big! Many people in the group were pushing forward and were quite rude in trying to get closer to the guide. The guide's English was very good, but she was a little hard to hear at times. The interior of the building is impressive and richly decorated. I purchased an extra ticket to be allowed to take pictures inside, but I saw others without the ticket taking photos on their phones and other devices. We also paid extra to hear a performance at the end of the tour. A gentleman came out in costume and sang three short arias and interacted with the crowd a bit. He was a great singer and we enjoyed his performance, but in hindsight, we should have just attended a performance there. We would probably have had less trouble with rude tourists and might have been able to take in the beauty of the building better at a performance. I do think it's worth it to spend the money to see the Opera House, but you may want to think about attending a performance instead.

YOU HAVE TO SEE IT !!. Thank goodness that this beautiful building was preserved and restored to it's present condition.. To be able to stand in the various rooms etc and let your mind wander to THOSE days decades ago with the grandeur etc.. The guides literally brought your body into those times so you seemed to actually experience the times.. A must for all visiting this beautiful city......The surprise was when one of the local cast presented us all with an impromptu performance.... WOW !!!

attend an Opera in this beautiful historic building!. On my bucket list was to attend an Opera and what better place to fulfill this wish than At the Hungarian State Opera House! We purchased tickets online about a month before our trip. We picked seats in row two of one of the opera boxes - not a good choice - get the first row of seats in the opera boxes because you cannot see the stage from the second row. Luckily, the first row people did not show so we were able to move up. We saw Vivaldi's Farnace. The orchestra and the opera singers were excellent! Although I had never attended an opera, I have been to countless symphanies, musicals, and other concert events. The artistic interpretation of this Vivaldi opera was very interesting and very different. Overall, we are very glad we attended an actual performance to see the glory of the building in use. One concern we had was the dress code for the opera. We were in Budapest when the temperature reached 96 degrees F. My husband had packed a suit jacket to wear, but it was just too hot. He wore a nice pair of dress slacks and a nice long sleeve dress shirt which was perfect for the occasion. I wore a pair of black slacks with a dressy blouse which also worked very well for the evening. Most people were dressed similar to us, There were some men in suits and ties, but most were in smart business casual. A nice dress or dress pants and blouse were typical for women. Definitely would recommend going to an actual opera performance and buying the tickets online before you go!

Opera house. Let me start by saying that I never actually went inside the building. We stopped by along the metro to see the architecture and details of the building. There were many bus tours out front and large buses parked along the road in front. It was frustrating even trying to get a photo.

Ornate building, good guides. We toured the building with a guide, which is essential to appreciate it unless you have expert background knowledge. The building is highly decorated and has history going back 120 years or so only. If you have the time and appreciate opera music it might be better to attend an actual opera - there are a wide range of ticket prices, and all are seated. We paid for the permit to take photos inside the building (roughly 2 euros) but most people did not and still snapped away happily with no problem. Excellent coffee and cakes at traditional old Coffee House almost immediately opposite. Top class Designer shops along the avenue where the Opera House is located are almost all shut on a Sunday now.

Have a glass of wine first. We stopped by in the morning and got tickets for an afternoon tour. The tour price does not include the ability to take pictures, which is extra. Then there is an optional mini concert at the end which is also extra. Viking Cruises showed up at our tour time (2pm I believe) and had a large number of people. They divided the English speaking tour into three groups, and I wasn't a fan of the guide we got. The place was amazing, but you spend about 5 minutes in the actual seating area of the theater, and the sheer number of people going in twenty directions with a guide that really wasn't calm, made the whole thing stressful. It was really neat, I learned a lot, and the concert was cool, so I'm happy I went. However, when it was over, I couldn't get out fast enough and the first thing I did after was get a glass of rosè. Maybe I should have done that first.

A tour of the opera house. This is a fantastic opera house,inlaid gold with complete original features,a very informative guide who took time and trouble to explain the main features,You may take photos but only if you prepay in advance,if you speak another language apart from english try to joint another tour as the tours in english are over subscribed,tickets for performances ate very cheap by british standards

Grand decor, sweeping stair cases and gold leaf. These very busy tours of the Opera House are reasonably priced and clearly very popular. The 3pm tour on the day we visited was packed to around 100 people and after being sorted into our various language groups the 45 minute tour covered all the grand salons and public areas, a sneaky peak into the Royal Box and a welcome sit down in the beautiful auditorium.

Guided tour and mini-opera. This visit really worths the price because it's a unique experience to walk in this building and understanding its history with the help of the smiling and well-prepared guides. Buy the mini-concert ticket and you'll have the opportunity to listen to a 5-minute opera singer composition.
Farnace - Contemporary Opera. Love goign to the Opera in Hungary, but this is a very contemporary opera and unfortunately had to leave following the disembowelment :-)
Amazing Decor inside the Opera House. This is a magnificent place to visit and actually the outside doesn't do the inside justice.You could almost miss this place while walking on the street.
Sumptuous Splendor. Don't miss it! Both the ornate exterior and even more ornate interior surround you with opulence. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable, and his English was excellent.
One of the great Imperial Opera Houses of Europe. Beautiful, historic building and the tour is very fun, informative and a perfect length. A memorable time and place.

Wonderful & the most gorgeous looking. this building can be recognised just by the look of it .Impressive ,& has a baroque style .since we didn't get time to see a show or take in a tour we just enjoyed looking & admiring the architecture from the outside .Our guide said that the statue to the left is the father in law of Andrew Lloyd Webber .
marvellous ceilings and auditorium. Almost every room visited on the tour of the Opera House had something good to look at, and the auditorium itself was very imposing
Gorgeous Opera House. We stayed in the box to listen to an opera. We were lucky to reserve the box just left to the middle box. Very good view and the performace was excellent.

Beautiful Building, Tour Disappointing - What? WHAT? Maybe Skip On Mondays. I don't think it's fair for a less than great review to be read in Trip Advisor without having shared my opinion with the location prior. Which I did before leaving the Opera House. We paid for an English speaking tour. A rather large group. Other language specific groups started their tours at the same time. So, imagine five different groups entering the grand seating hall and the tour guides, trying their best to yell loud enough for all to hear. Let's just say there was competition. I'd say it's important to hire guides with Maria Callas lungs if this is the situation. Oh, and have I mentioned there were actors/singers on the stage trying to have a rehearsal. They gave up while the groups were in the room. The large English group was split in two. Then as we toured the building, there were times where two groups were sharing a room (see earlier competing tour guides comments...), or passing in a hallway. So essentially, while we SAW a beautiful building, we HEARD less than 50% (being generous) about it.So, after the tour I went up to the lady who sold us tickets and expressed my concern. She invited me to share with her boss where my comments should be heard, and I was escorted to her. The young lady who escorted me said that Mondays are particularly crowded due to many tourist attractions being closed (so everyone goes there). Call me crazy but maybe management should staff for that? Maybe add some tours, or space them 10 minutes apart?The manager was respectful and courteous as I relayed my complaint. I believe she said the rehearsal was part of the problem - get the groups in and out so they can continue. I asked what normally happens? The groups are one at a time. She said the original guide should have explained all of this. But wait...many of us couldn't hear the guide.... I shared that I was pleased to see such a beautiful building, it's just that I couldn't tell her anything that I'd learned. She thanked me and hoped that I at least enjoyed the building. I did. It was beautiful. But, no offer of a refund, partial refund, or an invitation to come back on Tuesday when more tourist sites are open, and supposedly, no five different language groups navigating at the same time and guides speaking up, and up, so folks could hear. Go see this building, just make sure you can hear about it.

Fantastic experience and it won't break the bank)). The opera house in Budapest stands as one of the most beautiful Neo-Renaissance buildings in Europe.The Budapest Opera House is considered to be amongst the best opera houses in the world in terms of its acoustics, and has an auditorium that seats 1200 people.You can tour the Opera House during the day and learn about its gorgeous architecture as well as enjoy a world-class performance in the evening.A performance at the Budapest Opera is a fantastic experience and it won't break the bank. You can get quality tickets for as little as 5 €

Faust at the opera house. We went after 2pm to get tickets for that day. The building is wonderful inside and the opera was very impressive with a very large cast.it lasted over three and a half hours.. There is a reasonable bar which also sells interesting snacks and coffee.
Awesome Opera house.. Didn't see an opera, but still was good. We did a tour of the opera house which was good. They even had a 5 minute mini opera performance and the performer was very talented.

Awesome old world charm. Historic beauty, well priced, great repertoire. Looking at this building inside and out, you will have a hard time closing your mouth. It is awesome and highly recommended to visit or to go to one of the performances. Great times!

Fabulous building inside and out. A really magnificent building. The auditorium is lovely old world splendour. We took a guided tour which is certainly worthwhile, though ours was unnecessarily rushed. If you do this, do choose to include the mini operetta. It's only a few minutes, but lovely. Next time we will go to an opera if we can. No tickets available this time.

Even better if you can hear a opera. I had the pleasure of hearing Ariadne auf Naxos . Apart from the opera stat house quite beautiful ( but Buenos Aires opera house still my favorite). Good performance and the staging very interesting. Regretted no ticket for das rheingold !
Highly recommended.. very beautiful scenery. Rich and colorful interior. Expensive ticket for Opera performance!Worth a visit.

A lovely guided tour. Had a guided tour by an enthusiatic and knowledgable guide. Very nice enjoyed the visit - at the end you get to go in a private box for a seated view - there are plenty at the end of the tour to choose and take pictures from.
Most beauty full city an earth.. I been in lot of cities but like Budapest is only one on this planet.I love you BUDAPEST.God bless you.

Worth a visit. The guided tour, though crowded, was very well conducted. Different groups for different languages that tended to clash a little, but mostly organised so each group in a different area. The main opera theatre is magnificent, better than Vienna, and the whole place is beautiful. We paid for the extra mini- concert , only 2 songs from a tenor, but very cheap so worth the extra.
Music everywhere.... When you see the statues of all musicians played in the Operahouse, you feel awe and pride that you are there. Try an opera performance. You will be delighted!

Beautiful building.. Only viewed from the outside, but yet another example of the amazing Baroque buildings in Budapest. Can only imagine inside would have been even better. Worth the walk just to have a look.

Value the beutiful building. One of the nicest Opera Houses in Europe. But the is the surface. Unfortunately the seats are in terible condition, sometimes they make such a noise, that you can not here the music.You must be very lucky to have a good performance, the average is not so good. But the art works, the staircases, the lamps are really wonderful.
short tours and opera. The opera house offers short tours during the day followed by a short taste of opera for those who want to experience it.Well worth the hour or so it takes.

state opera house visit. it was a chance to see the inside without going to the opera,my partner isnt keen on opera and there was nothing i wanted to see during my stay.it is really beautiful inside,the last treat before the end of our trip.

Beautiful Building. Had a free evening and visited the opera house for an afternoon tour with tickets in the evening for Der Freischutz! Beautiful building with marvelous rooms, art work and ambience. had a wonderful time at both events and would visit again!

One of Europe best Opera houses. We were staying in an apartment in Lazar street, between the Basilica and the Opera house. We passed the Opera house several times during our 3-day stay. But we never went to a show.It is a Neo-Renaissance building commissioned by Emperor Franz Joseph, from Austria because the city was part of the Austro-Hungarian empire. The statue of Ferenc Erkel stands in front of the Opera House. He was the composer of the Hungarian national anthem and the first music director of the Opera. The other statue in front of the Budapest Opera is of Ferenc Liszt, the well-known Hungarian composer.

Bit of a letdown really. The tour lasted 45 mins .The guide new her stuff but you didnt get a lot of time to take pictures.Also you you had to pay exfra for the privilege of taking photos.It was only 600 huff extra, but why?Our group was of about 40.The others were smaller.We didnt get to go in the royal box or upper gallerys, the smaller groups did.Glad i went on the tour but wouldnt recommend it.
Beautiful architecture. The architecture and presentation of this opera house is beautiful. There were lots of groups there, especially school children, but no area was too crowded.

Beautiful, but too crowded. There's a charge a 45 minute tour. Ours had so many participants, that I couldn't hear or understand the heavily accented guide But the building is beautiful, and a fairly easy walk (about 20 minutes) from the Gresham Palace, where we stayed. Be sure to enjoy a coffee at the adjacent Calle coffee house and marvel at the yet-to-be-restored building across the street. (Our understanding is that the developers want to turn it into a five star hotel under the condition that the Hungarian authorities allow an underground parking facility. So far the Hungarian authorities aren't budging, perhaps a throwback to the days of Communism.)One thing to say for the Communist influence: My understanding that it's still possible to get very affordable seats for this still state-subsidized opera.

Tour of opera house disappointing. The opera house is truly grand, however in high tourist season , it was too crowded to enjoy. It was difficult to hear the guide because of competing guides talking. We did not get to see backstage or walk on to the stage. The best way to enjoy this house would have been to see an opera, but our schedule did not permit.
Fabulous building. Awesome building in beautiful location. Saw Das Rheingold performed live. Ghosts from a previous, glamorous era pervades... But eek....avoid the pre-theatre wine...

you don't need to enjoy opera to have a great day at this venue. this is a truly stately building with all the aplomb today that it must have had over the past 2 centuries. You can just feel the presence of all the greatest artists that walked the richly decorated halls

Great evening, if seats a bit hard. Saw Schumann's Faustus (not exactly lightweight) but enjoyed the incredible theatre and acoustics are top. Get ticket on line if you go during busy period. Perfect outdoor terrace during intermission. A chammpagne split was about $9.

the best!. Nabucco May 2015 was stunning in every aspect except French accents. Modern dress was inspired especially Walpergis Night scene (deliberately no detail so as not to spoil impact). Building completely lived up to expectations. Worth the entire trip just for this.Cafe opposite also excellent!

Something must be visited. I have been many times at opera and balett performances and every time I am amoused about the beauty and charm of this House!Hystorical and fashionable!Must see, not only the building and architecture, but also any magnificiant performances!

Lovely. Beautiful building, cameras or smart phone a must - another must see on any visit to Budapest. Lovely interior, great to just visit the building but if possible take in a performance if you have the time. You will be amazed.

Golden Age Glory. With only 12 hours in Budapest, I strategically chose The New York Café and the Hungarian State Opera House.It was the Spring Opera Festival, but chanced gaining a singleton ticket of the rarely performed Mephistofele (Boita). With acoustics touted as the 3rd best in the world, the grand basso, Mephistofele, and tenor, Faust, swept me into a time warp. Surrounded by a small guilded amphitheater and box seat, I was transported to neo-Classical era almost Baroque. Spectacular acoustics, aesthetics from a time long gone, and an excellent production. The seats were not as comfortable as I would have liked.

Opera , last night!. A beautiful elegant place to take in ballet, or symphony this summer. We saw last night of the season opera , Faust. A very nice modern interpretation. Drinks on the terrace overlooking Andrazzy is always fun!

Either go for Opera or Guided Tour. We went for opera and reached there bit in advance to enjoy the ambience... It was marvelous n grand... The overall experience was amazing.... Mostly shows are booked in advance so book it well in advance... But there is a guided tour as well just in case you dont want to see the opera.
Hungarian Opera House. Love visiting other countries and seeing all the historical buildings! This is a beauty and should be on your list to see!

Opera. Beautiful building. Guided tour in English 2:00pm, 3:00pm and 4:00pm each day free of charge. There are a lot of people but well worth the visit.
Eileen Leonard
An opera house. Nothing to write home about. Could only get in to see the outer hall of the building. You have to pay to get in any further. Wasn't interested enough for that

Beautiful and historical. This Opear House is well worth the visit. It's Baroque architecture is amazing. When you walk up the steps you feel like you are walking back into history to a time of monarchs. Make sure to take a tour to understand the theatre's history. The balcony on the top level offers wonderful views of the city.

Wonderful experience. The Hungarian State Opera house is a classical beauty. The opera company is top notch and the price makes it perhaps the best opera bargain in Europe. Totally enjoyed the experience. I hope to go again on my next visit to Budapest.

Beautiful, but not a must see. The Hungarian State Opera House is beautiful inside and out, but if you're limited on funds, I would definitely try to see an Opera instead. It's best to book one month out if possible. If you are visiting Budapest in off-season, then a tour of the Opera House makes sense, otherwise, I don't think it's a must if you're crunched for time.

Touring the Opera house. The opera house is absolutely gorgeous and taking a tour of it provided all its rich history.The disappointing aspect of the tour was that you have to pay extra if you want to take pictures.

Beautiful Building with exclusive access. There would never be a time when I could sit in a box but you get that opportunity to view what the Royals see on this tour. The building is beautiful. Well worth a visit.

Excellent tour. Beautiful interior and intricate designs and gold decor. Informative tour guide. Did not stay for mini-concert. Heard not worth the extra $$. Since it is more intimate if not more ornate than the Vienna Opera House, the acoustic should be great. Next time will schedule a opera at this HOuse.
JABOH (just another beautiful Opera House). OK, smaller than the Vienna OH but more beautiful (probably, I haven't seen it for a while). Put this lower down on your priorities.

Beautiful Opera Hall. We took the tour and paid a little extra for a five minute performance. The Opera House is a work of art to be admired. The opera singer was great. The only disappointment was that the performance was not in the theater. We had hoped to briefly experience the acoustics there. Instead it is in a side room used normally for concessions. Still, all in all I would highly recommend taking this tour.

They sometimes give tours in English, if so go!. Our tour guide of the city said they don't do it all the time, but we lucked out and there was one the day we were there. It was worth it. Very cool building, interior. Got to go up into the boxes for even a cooler prospective. Have to pay extra if you want to take photos inside
Tour Great. Amazing tour, very informative and interesting. Lots of opportunities to take pictures and reasonably priced.

Syliva! Go see it!. If you can get a ticket to the Hungarian National Opera house's summer production of the ballet, Syliva, then do so! It is showing at the Erkel Play House. The 1876 original production was delightful to see, the choreography professional and the story fun. Written by Leo Delibes as a Greek tableau about love, desire, jealousy and nature, it features a wonderfully played Cupid who brings love to a ballet company. The sets are simple but elegant. The worship scene in the woods, mystical. The dancing is quite good, but the music! What fun and wonderfully played by the pit orchestra. Go See It!

Fantastic and beautiful. Didn't go on the official tour, but tickets to see a production are really, really cheap so it is really worth going to see something there. Seem to have a varied program with different productions throughout the year.
Opera House Tour. We were treated to a lovely tour by an English speaking guide. There is much history to learn. Beautiful architecture.
With nice internal architecture . We went to watch a ballet performance at Opera house during our visit to Budapest.The internal architecture is truly impressive.

Beautiful construction. If you find yourself passing this site, see if you can join a tour or at least peek in. The entryway alone is absolutely amazing. I'd highly recommend catching an Opera hear if you can--there just aren't that many halls built this way anymore.
Tour of the State Opera house. We enjoyed a very comprehensive and enthusiastic tour throughout the various aspects of the Opera house with lots of related anecdotal snippets of history

Beautiful building close to Opera Garden Hotel. This is a beautiful building and you can take free tours of it a few times during the day. The architecture is stunning and lots of history in and around this building
Rcihard Strauss. Saw Salome in a fantastic performance. Sung in German, text projected in English and in Hungarian. Singers, orchestra, and conductor, were all excellent.

Dour Dr Faust but fabulous experience. As opera virgins we went to a concert performance of Dr Faust - 90 mins rather than the 3 hr full opera. The opera itself wasnt thrilling but the screens with english subtitles helped our understanding and the opera house itself is fabulous.

Attend a performance than taking a guided tour. Beautiful building. But once you have seen enough Opera houses, you know that to know a Opera House it is better to attend a performance than to have a guided tour of it, but unfortunately there were no performances in the week I was visiting, so ended up taking a guided tour to seethe place. It is a pretty little Opera House.Would prefer coming back for a performance someday though.

No business like show business in Budapest!. Budapest is wonderful at staging grand events in wedding cake buildings. This is no less true than our visit to the Opera House on the opening week of "Faust". Here was a chance to watch fashionable Hungarian society at their leisure, and to ogle the architectural opulence of the 19th century decor. It transported one to a much more elegant time when to see and be seen in one's loggia or in the smoking corridor was an invitation to glamour and intrigue or worse.I had more fun IN the opera than AT the opera as the show itself was aiming for seamless contemporaneity way beyond its means. The production values fell flat, but the singing and music were excellent. However, after four hours I was thankful to be released and to dine at an excellent restaurant down the block.

Great. Enjoyed a guided Tour of this lovely building. Lots of access to various places in the theatre itself. Unfortunately, no performances in the time I was in Budapest. Hope to see something some other time.

This is a MUST. the Hungarian Royal Opera House, it was designed by Miklós Ybl, a major figure of 19th century Hungarian architecture. Construction began in 1875, funded by the city of Budapest and by Emperor Franz Joseph of Austria-Hungary. Sissy his wife use to frequent Budapest quite often. This is one of the most beautiful opera houses in the world.

Beautiful interior. We took the Opera House tour. There were very many English speaking tourists at the time so we were broken into 4 groups of 25-30. The guide took us both the boxes and the orchestra section as the stage crew was setting up for that night's opera. After the tour we stayed for the "mini concert" (an extra fee)as a soprano sang 2 arias. If you can't get there for a performance, it's worth seeing this great theatre this way.

Ornate and magnificent. I had read reviews that this was a must visit in Budapest so as an opera lover it was a must. For about $30 I sat in a balcony box and watched Dr Faust. My jaw almost hit the ground at how ornate and regal the place was. I felt like a million bucks and the acoustics and cosine so of the place was magnificent. Words can't describe the decor nor can pictures do it any justice. I loved it.

Faust. Literally no one sit was empty on the day Faust was performed. You can potentially get a good-view seat even with the cheapest ticket. In this case I would probably advise going with either 1st or last row (middle only) on the balcony. Other sits are fine, but do not rely (expect) to see something on the screens hanging from both sides, they are too small. Subtitles appear right in the middle above the scene, English and Hungarian. Quite big front, convenient to read from every location. Please take into account that once you are buying cheapest tickets to the balcony, there is a separate entrance, you are not allowed to enter via main entrance and should use the door from the backside. The performance itself is awesome/ lights, costumes, singing - all at the top level.

architectural marvel.. saw it from the outside.
beautiful building.
there r shows and tkts available for purchase.
we saw it at night when the lights were on.
lovely.
the entire stretch is marvellous.
Not really worth the hour tour. Not inexpensive, like 24 Euros for two. Looks nice inside but then it looks like any opera house. Barcelona has a nicer one.

A touch of class. Spent a night at the opera on the recommendation in my guide book that said it was almost as cheap to see a performance as to pay for the tour of the interior. This was a great tip. Spent about £5 on a ticket and had a fab evening.

Box seats for 50 Euros!. My girlfriend and I went to see Faust at the Hungarian State Opera. we bought our tickets two days in advance and were told that there were only box seats left. At a price of 50 Euros we decided to go for it, thinking that we'd been a little duped. However, on the evening of the opera it was jam-packed with not an empty seat in the house, and there we were with the best box seats looking directly on stage. The selection of intermission food refreshments was uniquely Eastern European I found with pretzels and open sandwiches. The performance was world-class and the set designs were inspired. My only warning is that the seats in the balcony boxes are not very comfortable.
Great building. Enormus building in the city centre, not available all times of the day for visiting. Very cheap tickets for attending a performance.
Beautiful! . The building itself is beautiful and worth seeing inside. We also saw Dr. Faust during the festival, it was very good! Great seats for a very good price!

Fantastic entertainment, uncomfortable seats.. The Opera building is quite imposing, with lots of statues that look better by night than in the daylight. We were surprised to find out that such a packed theater did not have the air conditioned functioning and it was rather hot all through the performace. The chairs are tightly packed, even for a petite woman like myself. and very uncomfortable, not anatomical at all.Go by all means, the performances are great, just get ready for some lower back aches right after.

fantastic experience. We prebooked tickets on line to watch the Faust opera, the whole experience was fabulous! The opera house is extremely beautiful and the opera was brilliant we had an evening which was unforgettable.

ABSOLUTELY MAGNIFIQUE!. Somehow neither the Germans or the Russians managed to destroy it. Thank God! It's not the Met nor La Scala (when La Scala was La Scala), but it is a lovely, historic opera house with a reasonably good opera company. While in Budapest we saw fine performances of La Forza del Destino and Carmen (the latter nicely done in modern dress. The second row center seats were ridiculously inexpensive.
Swan Lake. Elegant and resplendent Opera House. Loved sitting on the balcony and had the great fortune of seeing Swan Lake.

Worth the Tour - For Sure!. Beautiful building from the outside but the inside, majestic. However beautiful it will remain only beautiful until you take the tour and learn the history. Each room has a different purpose and design and for 45 minutes the well spoken English guide provided so many interesting facts. Buy the ticket with the mini concert if you aren't planning to attend some event at the opera house. If you can get a ticket for an event- do it.One take away I didn't care for is they charged an extra couple of Euros to use your camera; I thought this was a rather tacky thing to do when you are buying tour tickets. Either take pictures or not, but charging to do so....not cool!Having said that, don't miss it and the tour is cheap.

More beatiful than the Wien Opera. Amazing building in the Andrassy Street, there is a guided tour at 15 and 16 hrs. The interior of the house is even more beautiful than the exterior and it worth a visit.One of the few buildings that was not totally destroyed by the russian tanks, almost entirely original.
Take the Tour. Check for times as they change based on day and season. Small charge is worth it. Tour lasts about an hour. Learned a great deal. Can take photos.

Whistle stop tour of the Opera.. There are two tours a day, at 3pm and 4pm. There are many guides speaking in lots of different languages. We took the 4pm tour which lasted about 45 minutes. It all felt rather hurried and rushed. The guide was good and knew his stuff but gave no time to linger and take in the place. Ended up feeling rather short changed for the money that we had paid for the tour.

Beware closed on Mondays. What a fantastic building . It is simply magnificent !!! Since I was not able to take in an opera , although I believe Faust was current , I will next time I visit Budapest .
Must see (for single people). I've met the love of my life in front of this place 9 years ago. Highly recommended for single girls. :)

Beautiful Opera House. A beautiful opera house that has a great tour and a mini opera. The opera house did not want to compete with Vienna so it went smaller and luxurious with great acoustics. Good to take the tour.
Getting better and better. The Budapest Opera is modernizing the plays and changing in to a more actual -more Londoner style- so it´s trying to attract younger public. It´s getting better and better!

Prettier than Opera in Vienna. The Hungarian State Opera is gorgeous inside. Much prettier than the opera in Vienna which I actually found a little disappointing. Definitely make a trip here if you like opera, and cheap tickets can be found online for around 3000 HUF (10 euro/11 dollar).

Like visiting the Phantom of the Opera. The Hungarian Opera House is more or less a copy of the old Opera in Paris. It is beautifully decorated. It is possible to get a guided tour in many languages. The tour ends with a mini opera, lasting 5 minutes. On Saturdays there is an extra tour at 2 pm (normally 3 pm and 4 pm) but the extra tour doesn´t have the mini opera. However, if you wish to hear opera you should buy a ticket for a show. They come in all prices depending on the seats. Be there good time in advance since the line can be pretty long.

Do not miss seeing this historic site. We were in a very large English speaking group, over 100 people. They broke us up in to 4 groups which made the tour much more enjoyable. We did not reserve the tickets we were told by our hotel concierge we only needed to show up and buy the tickets, no problem. The building itself is a historic site very ornately decorated. The viewing boxes offered a very interesting perspective on watching a performance. After the tour was over we heard a female vocalist perform several songs from an opera. This was a real treat and should definitely be part of anyone's visit to this site. This is a must visit
nice building. we visited the hungarian state opera house but only a very small part of this building could be visited; at some times there a guided tours

Modern version of faust. Been there last night for the dreams rehearsl of faust and had a great timeThe opera is somptueus, seats confortable and sound quality incredible goodStage is huge and interval on the balcon a pleasure
Smaller than the Vienna Opera house but much more beautiful.. APT Tour group had a private tour with champagne and a performance by Zolt Molnar on a balcony above us it was wonderful

Superb building and great performance. This historic building is a must to visit, simply stands out and inside is beautifully kept. If you get a chance, see one of their shows - since the venue is spectacular - classy with a golden touch. We did not make a reservation and was lucky as there were a few seats available for Bohémélet. You can purchase the tickets in the building on either side, and the prices vary on the seats (from 400 HUF to 9,900 HUF). We got stall seats which presented a good view centrally, that was 8,000 HUF, which cost cira €25 each - in comparison to westend musical prices this was good value, especially as this was our first opera. Tips: shows started circa 8pm, and they ask you leave your coats in the cloakroom (bring change). I would also recommend to dress smart (since some people go all out). The opera was in Hungarian, though there was English subtitles above the live performance and orchestra. There was four acts, so a few breaks in between, where you can wonder round. Although our seats were good, the boxed seats looked private and worth a go if available, choice wise.

Mozart at the Opera. This was a dream that finally could be realized. This is one of the great music houses in the world. with the finest acoustic to be found. beatiful in all respects and very well kept. And then Mozart, the Marriage of Figaro which we thoroughly enjoyed from the first to the last minute. From the Overture, to Tim Robbins aria from the movie to the grand finale. If you are a classic music lover this can be one of your greatest life experience and you do not have to mortgage the house to buy 2 tickets. But do it with long before you are coming, it is usually completely sold out.

Astonishingly beautiful opera house. Excellent performance of Swan Lake. Not to be missed. Probably the most beautiful building in Budapest. We had a historic tour earlier in the day, then returned for an evening performance.

So impressive, lucky to get tickets.. The opera house looks very impressive from outside, but quite spectacular once inside. It oozes history and class. We were lucky to get tickets for Figaro, which were so cheap, so make sure you book in advance so you don't miss out.
