Wonderful evening. We booked tickets just before we left the UK and were sitting right at the top, in the back row. The sound was fantastic and we could see all of the stage except the very front walkways which were built out. It was very hot but once the performance was underway we didn't even notice. There were English and Hungarian surtitles. The Opera House is very beautiful and well worth a visit if you can get tickets for a performance so much the better!

Historic and worth a visit. Exactly as one would expect of old European opera houses.Located off one of the major shopping streets, best visited with a tour guide, though hosted visits are offered. Book early for concerts.

Great visist. An amazing tour visiting the Hungarian Opera House. I have bought the complete tour, including a small concert at the end, but the concert disappointed me because the singer sang only 2 songs. 😔

Great night out. We also had a look around the theatre - very nice - a great experience. What was good was the fact that they sung in Hungarian but there were subtitles above the stage which meant we could understand.

A cultural must. Stunning inside and outside, this opera house has all the classic beauty of the imperial days. I didn't do the tour but instead I saw the Nutcracker which they were performing around the Christmas period. I liked it so much that I got tickets to go back to see the New Year's Concert which was amazing too.The area around it is breathtaking in winter with the lights on Andrassy Avenue and it is worth walking back down afterwards. But first I would recommend a stop at the little cafe on the corner next to the opera where they had live music, delicious pastries and good mulled wine. A fantastic experience!

A beautiful production, but a limited view.... My boyfriend and I saw Le Nozze de Figaro here, and although the building is stunning we really did have a restricted view. I booked 3 weeks in advance but there were only a handful of seats left, so we ended up in the Gods. We were 3 rows back, but we could only see the rear right hand side of the stage. Had we booked earlier we would definitely have gone for the Box seats or stalls. The singing was stunning and we thoroughly enjoyed the production and the English surtitles, but we would not recommend the very top seats!

Beautiful interior, below-average tour.. Budapest certainly has expensive entry fees. We paid $17 Canadian per person for what we were told was a 45 minute tour and ten minute mini concert. While the building inside is certainly lavish, the tour did not meet our standards. There were at least 40 people in our Englsih tour group so most of the time was spent just moving from place to place...at most we got about 20 minutes of information. The guide was impatient with the group members and honestly seemed like she had been taken away from some more important job and could not be bothered. It was like they were doing us a favour??? Umm...we are paying YOU for the tour. The aria performance started before our group got there so we only got a song and a half...not worthy the extra 600 ft, especially since it was not even inside the auditorium. We were disappointed in the quality...it did not match the price.

Save your time, money, and energy!. We took the English guided tour along with about 50 others. Oh yes, we paid more to take photos and for the "mini concert" afterwards. all in all, unlike the rest of Budapest, a major ripoff. Too many people to see the rooms, too crowded and rushed to take decent photos, constantly having to shuffle out of the way for The German group, The Japanese group, The French group... Then for the "mini concert, we were bundled into a hall, lined up against a wall (seriously, not in the opera auditorium and not sitting at all) when a very seasoned singer appeared, warbled two short numbers, maybe 5 minutes total, and it was done. Spend your time and money more enjoyable elsewhere. I was so upset at the tour I didn't even care to buy a ticket to a performance. Hungarian State Opera House, you should be ashamed.

See It By Experiencing It. We saw a performance of The Marriage Of Figaro at The State Opera House. This is the best way to see this over-the-top edifice of Austro - Hungarian Empire decadence. Wear your heels and finery! (No dress code, but come on!)In truth, outside it is a bit drab and the architecture unexciting. Inside, it is a riot of golden columns, marble staircases, colourful painted ceilings and mosaic floors as you enter.Strangely, there are two huge cloakrooms, but no bars. They set up a table to serve drinks in the foyer before and in the interval of, performances. As usual in old places like this, ladies will spend the whole interval queueing for the pathetically inadequate number of toilets.The auditorium is even more spectacular: it's not that big (1600 seats, I think) but arranged in the typical multi-tiered boxes, balconies and stalls style. We had a seat in the central stalls, but probably anywhere would do for a performance to satisfy. The cheapest seats are about £2!I found the performance, though tremendously well staged, overlong (6.00pm start; 9.40pm finish. Four acts; one interval) and tediously repetitive, but a true opera fan would love it, I'm sure. The acoustics are excellent and the staging extended to bring the performers (immaculately robed, as you would guess) out into the stalls.Tip: either walk there or use The Opera Metro station.

The Marriage of Figaro. Myself and a friend went to the see The Marriage of Figaro here. We were about five rows back in the stalls and the tickets cost £18 each! I couldn't believe it!The opera house is beautiful and ornate inside and out. The opera itself was very funny; there was also a translation above the stage which allowed me to follow what was going on without being distracted.You should definitely get tickets before going to Budapest. It was easy and I printed my e-tickets at home. Well worth a visit.
must see. Try and book a performance reasonably priced and a great evening out if not be sure to book a tour they run two twice daily and like everything in Budapest inexpensive.
beautiful building. beautiful building, very well maintained, crystal clear programation, easy to access, easy to reach; a must downtown

A BEAUTIFUL MOCK GOTHIC OPERA HOUSE. A truly majestic building built in the grandiose exuberance of the Austrian Hungarian Empire. The interior reminded me of Turkish decorations, Italian ceiling frescos. A lot of gold and colour. Very interesting architecture and design of arches, staircases, opera boxes: all reflecting the hight of the Belle Epoque.

Amazing!. We did a tour which was available in the afternoons and were divided into groups depending on what language you spoke. It was well worth it, the building is amazing and is 2nd only to La Scala in Milan apparently

A must for opera lovers. Stunning setting, wonderful singing. Buy your ticket online as it's possible to get excellent seats at extremely reasonable prices. The acoustic is fabulous. Highly recommended.

Great guided visit. The visit is really great, with some interesting facts and anecdotes. Our guide did her first presentation in French, but she was really good. Doing the visit in French was a huge advantage because the group was much smaller (15-20 persons) compared to other groups like in English (100 or more?). Personally, I really enjoyed the visit of the Opera, I putted 4 stars out of 5 because you have to pay an extra to be able to do some photos inside, I found it a bit of a shame and a really "tourist trap" especially since the normal price is already quite high.Nevertheless the visit is a must see if you are in Budapest, and you will learn some interesting facts about this place.

Like Being in a Keystone Kops Comedy Act :). Tours of the Hungarian State Opera House are given in several languages at 3:00 and 4:00 in the afternoon. We got the impression that the tour was designed by someone who just wanted to have fun with the poor visiting tourists. First of all, you pay a general admission fee, then if you want to take pictures, you pay an additional fee, and lastly, if you'd like to hear a short 5-minute aria performed by one of the opera performers, you pay another fee.Then the fun begins. There must have been about 6 tours going on simultaneously in different languages, with one group going up, another going down, another going right, and more going left. If you aren't careful, you could wind up with a different group with the tour guide speak a language that doesn't quite sound like English anymore :)The tour is very rushed, with time for about a picture or two before you see your group heading out the door and you have to run to catch up. The real positive part of the tour (which upped my rating to 3) was the live aria performed, not in the theater itself, but in a vestibule area probably used by opera goers at intermission time. This was actually a positive, as our singer was no more than about 6' in front of us while performing. Very nice!!

Grandeur. A good tour, we payed for the mini concert which was limited to 2 songs from a terrific soprano, but sung in the bar. The Royal seats, chandeliers, the depth of the stage gives a lasting memories. All full length performances were sold out for our week.

Magnificent Opera House - like stepping back in time. We went to Budapest in March, 2015 and got tickets for a Hungarian Opera at dirt cheap prices. The Opera itself was good but the real spectacle was the Opera House itself. Stunning in its splendor we loved every minute of sitting in this beautiful building and listening to wonderful music. Wholeheartedly recommend going either for an Opera or just to tour the building.

Beautiful building. The tours however were expensive and chaotic. Our guidebook told us that a trip to Budapest would not be complete without a tour of the Opera house. English language tours run at 3pm and 4pm. It is hard to not be impressed by the building. However, the tour left a lot to be desired. Having to pay extra to take photos? People seemed to be taking them irrespective of if the had a band.The tour was too big, the guide too fast, and all in all we didn't feel this represented great value. Instead of fussing about orchestrating multiple language guides, an audio guide would have been far better.The mini-concert at the end (which was the equivalent of £1), consisting of two songs. It was good. But overall, the tour was expensive for what it was.

A beautiful building - a step back into history. The building can only be visited by guided tour only which can be booked in the gift shop on the left of the main foyer. The tours are also provided in a variety of languages. The architecture is truly beautiful and the mini concert (additional fee) was also a treat. A visit to the opera house is a must whilst in Budapest.

Beautiful Opera House. Beautiful venue, fantastic acoustics, great production of The Marriage of Figaro, a truly memorable evening. At the equivalent of 25 GBP for a seat in the stalls, eat your heart out Covent Garden!

Good value, wonderful performance, lovely venue. Book on line well in advance
Seats on the small and firm side - even the best ones
Quite a few steps
Metro immediately outside
Beautiful building. We did the tour with a mini concert at the end of it, took less than an hour and very cheap (£5 approx). Very grand inside with lots of art. Would recommend .
Very beautiful. I didnt take the guided tour, but took some nice photos. I recommend at least going in for a picture of the cielings and stairs.
Stately and ornate. Typical european opera house, very ornate and a lot of money was spent on it for a limited attendance. This opera house if quite small by european standards

A wow building and tour. The building is highly decorated with paintings and gold and marble. We saw them working on the stage, the guide gave us so much information, and there were several guides doing the tour in different languages. We all got together to hear a lady sing two arias which made you feel good. The tour go at 3pm and 4pm

Stunning. If you are in Budapest you have to at least go inside to see the sheer decor of this place, for those wanting some culture you have to book the opera, if you've never been tot he opera, here is the place to try it the once. I always say 'you can't have an opinion unless you try it'!

Fabulous. A "must" visit. The exterior is stunning in its own right - but the interior is incredibly beautiful. A sort of mini Opera Garnier/Paris, with its sweeping staircase, and galleries. Auditorium is gold leafed, plush reds and art work that makes it a photographers paradise. Theatre opens at 11am each day for box office, souvenir shop and at 3 and 4pm there are tours of the theatre - well conducted. If you enjoy culture, do go and see a performance - which is an experience in itself. One word on that - upper levels have their own side entrance - so you need to be booking stalls or lower loges (boxes).

Re: amazing. I'm not a fan of the opera but I'm a fan of this beautiful opera house. We had the chance to hear the singers while waiting for the English tour. We didn't get the extras like - pics and listening to some arias yet we enjoyed the tour. Make it a point to catch the English tour in the afternoon.

Wonderful Building, Orchestra, And Casts. We attended two operas while in Budapest. (Our flat was only a two-minute walk from the Opera House, so we took advantage.) The setting, in a magnificent 19th century opera house, is beyond wonderful. You'll take many photos, as do most attendees. The acoustics of the building are very good, and the performances are tight and professional - extremely enjoyable. Prices are not cheap, but are reasonable considering the place and the quality of the performances. To go to Budapest and miss the opera would be a terrible thing. Oh, and dress varies quite a lot. I wore a sports jacket with an open collared shirt, and my wife wore a long, black dress. We fit right in. Book ahead!
great building. large opera house has magnificently decorated interior with many other marble rooms.had a guided tour with a knowledgable guide

Beautiful.. The building itself is one of the most beautiful ones in Budapest, especially from the inside, but I think it shows its best form if you go to see an opera there, music has to be the part of the first impression. Just take the time and money, sit down, and imagine that you're in the peaceful part of the 19th century. :)

Neo-Renaissance Landmark. On a grand avenue of elegant buildings, the Opera House stands out as a real stunner. Built in the neo-Renaissance style back in the 1870-80s, it's a sturdy yet elegant-looking building and well known for its amazing acoustics. On opposite sides of its portico, look for the statues of Ernst Liszt (the famous composer) and Ference Erkel (who wrote the Hungarian national anthem). Today, the building houses the Hungarian National Ballet and is the venue for the annual Hungarian Opera Ball. When I visited, it was in the middle of a heatwave and there were no performances scheduled. I was informed that the opera house wasn't air-conditioned so it was easy to see why opera and ballet could only be performed in the cooler months. The best I could do was look around and admire the stunningly decorated ceiling and the grand staircase.

Great ,even if you do not like Opera that much. Hungary is famous by its music and composers, so if you happen to be in Budapest, reserve one night to go to the Opera house, it is not that expensive, so you can reserve yourself a nice place and enjoy a beautiful atmosphere, second acoustic only to Milan's Opera house and enjoy on the intermission, a nice (really,you must try and surprise yourself) Hungarian Sparkling wine, all, for a fraction of what you would pay anywhere else in western Europe
Stunning. We only went in to see the stunning ceilings they are gorgeous, the building and the spinx like statues are fab, we will definately go for a further visit next time

Buy a cheap ticket rather than taking a tour!. I made a spontaneous decision to buy an opera ticket the night before arriving in Budapest. Two of us went to see Jenufa for 600FT each, in an amazing box right by the front with spectacular views. It was wonderful. I highly recommend shopping around for tickets as I saw my same ticket for 59 euros elsewhere. A cheap seat not only can give you amazing views and the full opera experience, it's cheaper than a guided tour. We looked on Wikipedia for facts to educate ourself on our surroundings during the interval!! One note - we felt very underdressed having travelled around and not having super nice clothes with us to wear. A shirt or nice dress is best.

Beautiful building. We had a tour of the opera house and it is very beautiful, and only wish we could have had to time to attend a concert there. We walked down the stairs where the king used to enter in the old days with a hugh mirror in front of him so he could see what was going on behind as he came up the stairs. The VIP boxes were beautiful and would be an ideal place to take in the opera. We were privilege to have two opera singers perform excerpts from some of the great works before we left as we walked down the beautiful stair case.

What a treat!. Every year we visit in Budapest and book in advance at least one opera performance in the National Opera. It is a pleasure of various kinds. The classic beautiful building, the pompous glorious hall, do justice to one of the most professional opera teams, with a group of incredibly good local singers. We saw/heard this time Jenufa by Janacek. It was wonderful like we expected. The opera management should be praised for adding English surtitles to the Hungarian ones.
Opera House. Such a beautiful experience to visit this Opera house. Although we did not stay for a performance, we were treated to a couple of arias from the most beautiful opera singer.
Opera. Great building with beautifull architecture,one of the symbols of Budapest,must go to a concert to see it inside.

An experience not to miss!. The Budapest Opera is an absolutely beautiful building from the outside as much as in the inside. I've seen several performances, all of them of high quality. Tickets start from an amazingly low price so it's available basically to anybody. Don't miss it!

An opera house in the grand European style and an opera company to make a visit to the opera a truly grand event.. While this opera house was built on this grand scale only at the turn of the last century and is relatively young, it is an architectural gem inside and out with the auditorium, public foyers and grand staircases decorated in glorious style. I think the ceiling painting was by Lotz, famous also for the grand hall at the Paris department Store further up Andrassy Ut. So, if you cannot get a seat for an opera or opera is not your thing, try the conducted tours of which there are, I think, two a day.However, it is best to enjoy an opera in the house. While the seats are hard (cushioned only by the opera goer's own fatty padding!), the acoustic is superb thanks to the wooden floors. We saw a wonderful "Marriage of Figaro" sung in Italian, of course, but with Hungarian and English surtitles, that was sung beautifully by the whole cast supported by a wonderful sound from the pit under an excellent conductor. It was a great night at the opera in a stunning house.The bars in the dress circle salon were busy with slow queues but they offered reasonable fare and there was access to the grand balcony over the main entrance porte cochere though the dress circle salon is itself a wonderful room in which to enjoy an interval glass of wine.The wee shop is staffed by lovely, helpful staff. The only down side, as in many a theatre, are some in the audience of which I will say no more though the hard, uncushioned seats may have caused some of the bobbing about.

Opera Paradise. My wife and I saw the Marriage of Figaro last Sunday evening and were blown away by every aspect of the performance, from the singing and music to the staging. This was an understated, subtle and in places melancholy performance of an opera that has been subject in recent years to so many (increasingly) bizarre interpretations apparently in search of novelty. The simplicity and sheer beauty of this performance were key to our enjoyment. And then the Opera House itself, which is worth a visit (they do tours) even if one is not there for a performance, surely one of Europe's most impressive opera houses. Note that the opera is performed in Italian with English and Hungarian subtitles cleverly projected in a non-intrusive way. A truly lovely evening.

Impressive Opera House!. We had a private tour in Pest and our guide had actually sung in the Opera House as a child. Because we didn't take the group tour it was actually one of my favorite places to visit in Budapest, but without the personalized stories from our guide I would have not enjoyed it as much.

Grand and Opulent. Cannot get over how beautiful and vibrant the interior is. Our tour guide was animated, entertaining, and witty which made for a most enjoyable tour. Did not see an opera but if desired, need to book well in advance!
Outstanding performances. Visited this twice and the opportunities for great music, ballet and opera were excellent. What a treat.

Grand!!. We visited the Opera House with the 3pm tour guide.The guide was good.Since it was my first time in any Opera House it was special experience to me.Its really grand from the inside,though the building doesnt look that impressive from the outside.Had to pay extra for the mini concert.And believe me it was really mini.Skip it.Though the tour guide explained everything well towards the end felt it wasa bit rushed.

Great Night Out. We saw a rather obscure Czech Opera called Jenůfa here in April 2015. I am no Opera buff but having enjoyed an impromptu Opera Night in Prague a few days before we decide to go and see it.We thoroughly enjoyed it knowing very little going in. The venue is superb and the company were sensational. Particular mention should be made of the Orchestra who were fantastic.When you are in Budapest stop informant Opera, you won't regret it.Tickets range up to 14,500 HUF but you can snag some for less.
The best birthday present. An unforgettable and amazing evening .We take a reservation on the 2 floor and this was perfect.To see and hear the philharmonics was very lovely

Beatiful opera house. We did the guided tour which was informative and good value.If you are into opera and great theatre architecture, this building is an absolute gem. Our only regret is that performances were sold out when we there - seeing a performance in such a wonderful building would have been a thrilling experience.

A lovely night at the Opera. We saw St. John Passion here on Holy Thursday, April 2015. Balcony seats were very nice if just a touch small. The building was beautiful and the experience in total was sublime. Tickets were only $16 USD or thereabouts. HIghly recommended.

Beautiful. A lovely opera house. Seems like all seats would be good enough. Definitely a must see for theatre lovers. Tip-- when you book tickets online, make sure that you are booking for the correct theatre, there are many in Budapest!

Tour of Opera House. I felt this tour was worth the money we paid. We were able to buy tickets just before the tour started in the bookstore/shop. Our guide was very funny and knowledgable. You have to pay for a separate ticket in order to take pictures.

extravagant. So beautifully gilded on the inside. I paid extra for the ability to take photos and the 5 minute opera performance. Quite lovely. The guides are great with lots of inside knowledge and a few jokes. Very reasonably priced.
Impressive. feeling of little Paris is intense around the Opera, there were plenty of people around in the evenings, its a living cultural spot.
Imposing. I didn't go inside but just seeing the building is rewarding. Only a few minutes walk from the centre of town and definitely worth it.

Very attractive but hard stalls seats!. We saw a very fine Figaro opera but the stalls seats are very hard and creek like an old ship!The air con was poor and the international audience bob about in there seats, chat during the performance and then stand at the end so you see little if you are behind thoughtless people.The program had so little English we did not buy.Interval snacks and drinks were good but long cues formed.Pleasant little shop inside.

To be honest, it was a bit boring. The young lady who was our tour guide was very sweet and knowledgable, but really, the tour was a bit boring..lots of other tours going on at the same time--the only highlight was at the end when two opera singers surprised all of the tour-attendees and gave a short performance from the top of some steps.

Go and visit but.... We payed for the tour, the grant to take pictures (500 Ft) and a 10 min. opereta... While touring with the guide...everyone was taking pictures (but only I payed the Fee.. ): The opereta singing was while we were standing in a small lobby... It was nice... but, standing crowded in front of a singer on the same level with us...

Stunning. Try to book tickets for a performance rather than pay for the guided tour. The building is magnificent, you feel like you've travelled back in time. Even if you are seated very high, you do not need the binoculars, do not waste your 500 HUF. You will have to leave your coats before the show, for 200 HUF each.
Truly European. This is a great thing to do when visiting Budapest. The Opera House is beautiful and if you can get tickets to a performance, you should. We enjoyed our evening.

Excellent Opera House!. The Opera House is very beautiful! Amazing building from the inside! There is English guide every day in 15:00 and 16:00 (Last update March 2015).The ticket for the guide cost 2900HUF and 400HUF if you want to take photos.The most amazing thing is that the seats are the same from the very beggining. You feel like some lord when you sit there!

One of the most beautiful Opera house in Europe. Amazing building and fantastic operas and ballets. Not surprisingly there are lot of foreigners any time. Compare to the other Operas the prices are quite acceptable.
Culture + + +. No dislikes at all Beautiful place Fantastic acoustics made for or a very enjoyable evening concert. Were able to get extremely good seats - worth every penny !!!

Well - what can I say?. With great excitement İ made my way to the Hungarian State Opera House for not only a tour but also to book (so that İ could experience) a once in a lifetime performance. Unfortunately nothing was being performed and there were no tours available and I was very unceremoniously told to come back in a few days. Bit difficult really on a short break! Customer service is obviously not high on their list neither is a friendly face! Perhaps get your hotel to check this out before you make the trip to the location.

An hour well spent. I had already visited the Vienna Opera house, and was looking forward to the Budapest equivalent. On a much smaller scale as Franz Ferdinand would not allow it to be bigger than Vienna. A good tour in English, although the group on the English speaking tour was rather large. We got to see the buffet rooms, smoking corridor, main auditorium, inside one of the boxes. If you want to take photographs on the tour you need to purchase the red wrist band PRIOR, as well as the mini concert afterwards requires a blue wrist band prepurchased.

What an experience. I am only 21 i was traveling around europe and decided to get one of the cheap tickets for the opera. It cost 1200FT so like 5 euro, I could see the stage almost perfectly the Opera was a modern one, weird wonderful and waky. It was a really great thing to do in the evening ! and soo cheap too !! I was seated along the top balcony in the centre second row, there was no problem with visability at all, And the hall is about as amazing as it gets

Opera House. You don't need to book, just go there.It is a very beautiful place but it wasn't organised.We were a little disappointed.There were many people in the English tour & the guide didn't speak good English. There were moments when we couldn't understand what she was saying & to make it worse, there were other guides speaking in different languages.Saying all this , the place is beautifully & richly decorated & a place that one has to visit when in Budapest.A friend of mine visited & was satisfied.

Check Tickets for the Correct Theater. Don't be surprised with the opera you are there to see is not actually being shown at the opera house, it's actually at another theater on the other side of town at the Erkel or another theater. Taxis already know this happens all the time and they're lined up in front of the opera house ready to jettison you to the place with the operas actually being shown.

Enjoyable visit, although relatively expensive for a family. Would have loved to have seen a performance while in Budapest, but nothing happening during our visit. A guided tour was a poor second, but still gave us the chance to see the beautiful opera house. Our 12 year-old and 14-year-old boys were impressed by the building and enjoyed the visit. Please note, the tour itself only lasted 35 minutes, not an hour as expected - perhaps because our group had no questions to ask the guide.

What an experience!. I bought tickets online during the prescribed time of about two months in advance and got good seats for a Hungarian Opera with English subtitles on a screen. I think we were the only tourists. It was magnificent. It gave us a chance to see the spectacular opera house itself and also be among the friendly people. We were amazed to find that the main cast took curtain calls after each act, not just at the conclusion of the performance. We saw Bank Ban, a nationalistic opera that was playing because the National holiday took place that weekend. It was a great opera and I found the CDs of it sold at a nearby CD store. This was a great start to our trip.

Beautiful and Classic. The Opera House entices you with a beautiful exterior. As you enter the doors you are greeted with the charm of one of the classic opera halls in the world. Your mind takes you back in time imaging that this is what an opera house was meant to be. The floors creak, the chairs squeak, and the gradual slope of the floor leaves patrons in the row ahead of you at eye level but all of that is overshadowed by the grandeur of the hall and the experience. Ticket prices for the performance were very reasonable. The performance was in German but English and Hungarian subtitles were displayed on a screen above the stage. Do not pass by this attraction and catch a performance if you can.
One of the most beautiful opera house in Europe. beautiful architecture and interior design, not the biggest one but one of the best decorative interior

Attending a performance is a MUST!. A sublime architectural attraction which is worth more than just a guided tour. Prices are so affordable compared to other night-outs that for what you will be awarded, sound and art wise, it would be silly not to attend a performance.

Special treat of Bank Ban Opera. Got to see a performance of Bank Ban, the Hungarian state opera, the night before National Revolution Day (celebrating revolution and war of independence in 1847/48 against the Habsburgs rule). Performance had a lot of patriotism, love, suicide, murder, well-done scenery and costumes. I believe this opera is performed every year around this holiday.

What an experience!. To be honest, i had never been in an opera house again. I have never watched opera. This was the first time. I had a low cost ticket for 5 euros just to try the experience. I can not compare this opera to another one but what i felt inside there is pure magic. I am totally fascinated!

Amazing!. this was definitely on if the highlights in our tour! We followed the good reviews and went there spontaneously. There were only "expensive" tickets left (11,000 f) and we decided to take it - and relieved the most best place we could imagine. Anyway- go there. The opera house is like a scene from a movie. Would recommend to dress properly

Stunning Building. A magnificent building, inside and outside. We had a guided tour that provided a history of the Opera House from a very enthusiastic and knowledgeable guide. Easy to get to from public transport or hop on hop off buses. However it is VERY popular with tourists so get in early.

A must see!. this is one of the best location to visit in Budapest! Make sure that you pay the little extra so you can take pictures however I think the mini concert is not worth it as I was expecting it to be in the opera. It only lasted 5 minutes! So I would recommend to go and see a show instead to experience the real opera
Fantastic!. We saw Wagners Rheingold in this fantastic building. Production was a bit too modern to our taste, but great singing in world class atmosphere. Opera here is a must do in Budapest.

Beautiful outside and in!. We decided to go and see a ballet while we were staying in Budapest, and definitely didn't regret it. Between the four of us, I don't think a single one of us is into ballet or dancing of any kind, but the show was fantastic (I believe it was called "Manon"). Not only did we get to dress up, we got to see the inside of such a beautiful building. A really enjoyable night

gorgeous Opera. It was the first time we went to see Ballet and it was great night out in Budapest. The Opera house if beautiful and is a great attraction itself, plus seeing Ballet for affordable prices was one of great points in our visit. See some of the photos here: https://iamtourist.wordpress.com/2015/03/14/romantic-getaway-in-budapest/

A Must See. If you have time when in Budapest the Opera House is certainly worth a visit. The beauty and elegance of construction and decor is outstanding as is the history. To think it survived WW2 mostly intact when 80% on Budapest did not, is in itself a feat. My husband was a reluctant visitor but cannot stop raving about the building. English tours are at 3 and 4 in the afternoon. The tours do not concentrate on the Opera as much as the building. A couple of things to point out - the tour was noisy as they had 3 or 4 groups in different languages at the same time, and they were doing some work on the stage so at times it was hard to hear the guide, who was very knowledgeable. One other thing, it does cost extra to take photos so be prepared to delegate one in your group to do the photography.

Great Wagner's Rheingold. Fantastic singing (Adrian Erod as Loge and Cser Kristian as Fasolt) were fabulous. The production was very modern, with Star-Wars type design, at the same time full of humour. Great evening!

Opulent evening at the opera. We saw Madama Butterly here and really enjoyed the evening, from the grand building to the way most people dressed up for the occasion. It was just as fun to people-watch as to see the opera.
Beautiful. Beautiful opera house that offers tours and a small concert in the late afternoon (3:00 p.m. and 4:00 p.m. tours) for tourists. Worth the visit.

Not a bad view in the house. The opera house is relatively smallish, and we went to two operas, and sat in two different areas. For the first one, we sat in the box, in the "cheap seats" (3€ each), and while the view was excellent, the seats were pretty uncomfortable. There was very little legroom, and our seats were single (one in front of the other) up on a platform, one higher than the other). The second night, we sat down in the main auditorium, 17th row, seats 10, and the view was once again perfect.Both operas (Ariadne & Das Rhinegold) were well staged, but not traditionally done. The actors and the orchestra were very good, but both stories had been "updated" to a more modern theme. I would have preferred something more traditional (truthfully, I was hoping for the big Viking woman with the horns and breastplate, belting out the tunes!), but that's just my opinion. The Opera House itself is amazingly beautiful, and well worth going to see.

Beautiful and stunning performance. We thoroughly enjoyed Cosi Fan Tutte in this beautiful building. It was a spectacular performance in a wonderful setting. And incredibly cheap for opera! Would recommend all visitors to Budapest try to visit.

A not to be missed visit. Guided tours of this stunning building are available at 3pm and 4pm. It is also worth paying the very small amount extra for what they call a "concert" which only lasts 5 minutes and is basically to hear an opera singer (dressed for the occasion) singing some kind of operetta song and hitting the high notes!
Opullence in bucket loads. Do the tour at 3 or 4pm but don't bother with the mini concert unless it's actually on the stage. Beautiful decor and interesting history

Grand !. The State Opera House is a grand building in the Imperial Austrian style, richly decorated in gold and marble. Take the tour at 4pm and book 'with mini concert' and you get to hear 2 arias performed by an amazing opera singer!

Very good worth going to!. Did the whole tour with pictures and the little show at the end. Very good and worth it.
Also saw the show in the evening and loved every minute of it!

Incredibly beautiful. This Opera House was built under the Hapsburg empire. They had to get permission to build it. The one rule was that it had to be smaller than the one in Vienna, however, the officials forgot to mention that it should not be more beautiful either. The Emperor arrived for the grand opening and departed early after being stunned by the beauty of this Opera House. You can look around on your own or they offer daily tours at 3pm and 4pm. There are a number of good restaurants across the street in Liszt square.

Great Art Nouveau venue and experience.. Relative to the U.K., tickets for the opera are cheap but you need to be careful if sitting in the balcony – I would recommend sitting at least 3 rows back and slightly to the right as the stage juts out on the left. Performance we went to of “Ariadne auf Naxos” was dire but the wonderful art nouveau decor compensated for it.

Beautiful building and really great tour. Did the tour on passing one afternoon around the advertised start time outside and was very glad to have gone in. The tour shared the history and myths of the opera house and showed all the important parts of the building. Our tour guide spoke very quickly in perfect English and once you got used to her not pausing after full stops, was very informative and friendly!

New production of Wagner's Das Rheingold. If you like this opera, it is a must! Brilliantly produced and directed by Toth Geza, a film director.It is a visual and musical orgy. The staging is simply extraordinary. My wife does not like Wagner but was completely overwhelmed and loved it.

Intelligent guides with humor. Squeezing into the gift shop to buy a ticket nearly turned me off...they need to arrange a different method of paying admission where there is more space! I loved the fact that everything in the opera house except the chandelier is from Hungary...national pride at its finest.

A Must See. Unfortunately we did not have time to go to the Opera so settled for the opera house tour with a five minute music interlude at the end. This was one of the highlights of my visit to Budapest. Beautiful building and our guide was brilliant. The Soprano who sang at the end of the tour was fantastic, she sang two arias, the first so powerful it brought me to tears! Brilliant.

Nice facade.. The facade was really nice and worth to visit. But the entrance is so standard. There were not so many show as well. I thought to see an opera, but there was only Manon, which I have seen already.

THE 3rd BEST ACOUSTICS IN THE WORLD - AND A GEM OF NEO RENAISSANCE ARCHETICTURE.. Commenced in 1875, it took only 9 years to build. The interior is the classical style - all red and gold with the mandatory painted ceiling and hanging huge chandelier. The foyer, not quite as good as the Garnier in Paris, but not too far behind - with the winding marble staircase, the red carpet and the beautiful chandelier.The two most noted previous Directors are Gustav Mahler and Otto Klemperer.The exterior is just marvelous. The building is just sprinkled with statues of famous musicians and certainly it gives the Vienna Opera house competition.Also home of the Hungarian National Ballet Company, the building is open almost every day for Inspection Tours. If you are a visitor, don't miss it. But make sure that your 'shoe covers' do not come off. The guides really DO NOT like this, and I can vouch for that!Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.

Stunning interior!. We joined the visiting tour at 3 pm with 5 mins mini concert, the tickets were purchased in the gift shop and the tour are separated into different language group. The interior decoration is magnificent and the auditorium is stunning. The tour took about one hour
definitely worth the visit. We had a great tour of the opera with a very interesting guide, the greatest thing was the small performance at the end ! I would recommend this to anybody!

good tour, extraordinary architecture. I showed up 15min before the hour for one of two tours offered daily, and had no trouble getting a ticket. A large group was divided into language preference i.e. Japanese, German, and in my case, English. The guide was knowledgeable, clear, and concise. I paid a little extra for the mini concert afterwards-beautiful. The guides are clearly on a schedule and need to keep things moving along, but it was a great way to see the space and feel more connected to it all when I go to the opera tomorrow night!
Stunning Opera House. Went to see the ballet "Manon" recently. Beautiful setting a very reasonable prices. Must visit place.
Stunning Venue. Watched the Hungarian Philharmonic Orchestra here, what an amazing venue, great value for money. Well worth a trip here in the evening and then a walk along Andrassy... Perfect.

Well worth it. Whether you are an opera goer or not, a visit to Budapest is enhanced by going to the opera. We checked on line & booked our tickets-orchestra, 7th row aisle seats for $50.00 (CDN) a ticket-unheard of price in Toronto. The Opera House is very beautiful, the acoustics are very good & there are no obstructive views and there is a subtitle screen. Casual attire can be worn.

Amazing building!!!. The opera itself was weird in my opinion there where semi bake men and a bull on stage for the majority of the performance, we had seats in the second row in one of the boxes but as we where in the second row we could barely see anything I would recommend only getting first row seats or sit on the stalls. All this said the Opera House it self is one of the most amazing building I have ever seen the architecture and decor is stunning, most definitely worth a visit just to view the building.

World class acoustics and beautiful decor. It is difficult to compare and contrast opera houses. They each have their own personality and identity. I would argue that the Wiener Staatsoper is the best in the world. However, with that being the bar, the Magyar Allami Operahaz should not be missed. Four about 1/4 of the price of Wiener Staatsoper, you can sit in a box seat, experience similar grandeur, and nearly equivalent acoustics. Magyar Allami Operahaz is smaller than Wiener Staatsoper. I would also not suggest getting box seats in the second or third row (where it would be very difficult to see). But if you can get a front-row box seat, this is a wonderful experience. Champagne during intermission is also a must.

Wonderful experience: music and art. The interior of the Opera House is gorgeous. Performance tickets are relatively cheap so it's better just to book a show than take the day tour. The symphony was excellent and clearly filled with very talented musicians. The box seats are incredible, highly recommend! Certainly come early and linger after the performance to enjoy the elegant decorations in the theater and lobbies.When you buy performance tickets, just make sure you are selecting the historic opera house. The Opera company also performs in a second, newer opera building as well.

Τotally worth..!!. It is totally worth the visit..And I will recomend to anyone who can to pay 600HUF more in order to watch the 5 minute concert after the tour..The guy who makes us the tour was very nice and knew everything which needed..
visit. we didn't go in to see a performance but just going inside the foyer was amazing to see the building inside plenty photos taken they performance and ours are at 14.00hrs and 16.00hrs

Bargain evening. We managed to get tickets for 400 Fr equal to less than GBP£1 as we booked to see rehearsal performance of Ariadne. We had great seats right at the front, although we had booked balcony seats but were moved as not enough tickets had been sold for the stalls. However we did not mind being moved as seats near the stage. Incredible decor inside which is worth seeing even if you do not go to see an opera. Our tickets cost less than the guided tour.

Opera House. Not an inspiring building from the outside and I was very disappointed that you couldn't just have a peep inside. As with everything these days you have to pay. However the entrance/lobby was beautiful.

Wauw!. Went her with two friends of mine.Have been to a Ballet show, Manon, it was beautiful! The ambience in this Opera is great. We were seated on the second floor, a balcony. Price: not even 15 euro. If you're in Budapest, try to go.

Put some music in your life!!. A wonderfull building,easy access very well preserved.The guided tour was very enlighting and I think if you could find tickets it is ideal to visit and watch a live event.

The highlight of our visit to Budapest. We bought good tickets at great prices to a ballet : L'histoire de Manon, generally referred to as Manon,choreographed by Kenneth MacMillan to music by Jules Massenet . The ballet was performed with such passion and skill and was quite simply wonderful.

"Spectacular". A gorgeous, opulent building with some astounding architectural features. We went just before Christmas and the decorations were lovely.We saw La Bohéme, which was excellent. Very high production value at a fraction of the cost of seeing some provincial, half-rate production in the UK. (we paid £3.70 each, and these weren't the cheapest seats!!). Despite the price people seem to dress up which really adds to the experience. The only down point is that we had to walk up eight flights of stairs to get to the balcony. (no lifts.)If you go then book on line. Its in English and you print your own tickets. Really added to our pre-trip excitement.

One of the highest points of my trip!. This was a magical visit. We took a box (ordered tickets online well in advance) and it cost a small fraction of similar tickets in London or Vienna, where I have also attended the opera. The house was spectacular and the show (we saw the Hungarian opera Bank Ban) was excellent. The orchestra was not quite A-level, but the cast was really good and the production was a high quality. If you can't make a show, be sure and visit the guided tour in the afternoon. It is worth it to go around and see the magnificent building itself.

Went on the 50 Minute Tour!. The opera house is an amazing building inside! We paid to go on the Guided Tour (it is a must see). The interior is brilliant ,the Guide was very good and we also paid a little extra to have a "mini Concert" at the end of the Tour! It was in the bar area and a Female Opera Singer sang two songs for us. She sent shivers down our spines with her wonderful voice!

Go there and be classy!. We had such beautiful experience when visiting the State Opera! Highly recommended! If you'll go to the gallery/balcony, pick the seat in the centre, from the sides is very poor view :(
very interesting. The opera was build to rival Paris and Vienna's. It is located in a very large avenue. It opened in 1884. There are a lot of ballets and operas playing today.

A real Opera, beautiful building!. Its worth for visiting! One of the most beautiful buildings of Budapest! There are some guided tours too, but make sure you reservate in advance! To see an Opera you need booking in advance!

Take the Tour. We took the tour of the Opera House and found it very interesting.Beautiful interior with painted ceilings and gold leaf on the columns. Wouldn't like to sit through a Wagner performance on these seats though take a cushion!

Opera!. The opera was in German, but the English and Hungarian translation was above the stage and easy to read.
The opera house is magnificent!
Absolutely stunning! There are many level prices of seating, but don't shortchange yourself. It was worth every cent
A must for musiclovers. The music, the cast, the atmosphere, the intermission with a drink outside on the balcony overlooking Andrassy Utca, just great!!!
Beautiful. Our guide was well informed and spoke very good English. The interior of the opera house is opulent. Well worth it.

Beautiful . My sister and I visited the Opera House on our trip to Budapest. It was absolutely beautiful. Our tickets were about £7 for a 45 minute tour and a 5 minute live show. It's definitely worth a visit.
Ballet fans. The building itself is amazing, the tour was good, but we missed the performance, would have loved to see the performance. But still it was worth while.

Madame Butterfly. We fell lucky that this happened to fall on the same night as my wife's birthday and our wedding anniversary. I had booked tickets online about three months before travelling. Front row balcony seats £18.00 for FOUR TICKETS! We'd never been and had an amazing night in a truly wonderful building. If you are able to, go and see a performance rather than tour the building.

Not so impressed. We attended a ballet during the weekday. In Rick Steve's book it said that it would be adequate to buy as cheap a ticket as possible even with an obstructed view. Foolishly we followed that advice. We had to go in the side door of the opera house, up some concrete stairs to our upper tier seats. In order to see the front 1/3 of the stage we had to lean forward. We were not given a program and had no idea what was happening in the scenes. We were not impressed with the principal ballet dancers. Most people around us seemed bored. We left at intermission.The building dates back to the 1890's. It was damaged during WWII and restored in the 1980's. Is this as beautiful as other European opera houses, probably not.

a night of entertainment. The opera house was beautiful. I felt that I stepped back in time. The only downside was we saw a modern opera with little costume and set change. Felt the venue did not match the feeling of the opera.

A beautiful place to see opera and ballet. The Opera House is a stunning venue and the experience is very different from opera/balletgoing in London or Paris. Much more down to earth - the catering arrangements are less sophisticated and there is no scrum to get to the bar at all. Although we had read somewhere that it is good to have a snack in the interval we could only find nuts or rolls to go with the Hungarian sparkling wine we purchased (which again cost a fraction of the amount charged at Western European venues). Dress code is mixed - there were some people in casual clothes and at the other end of the scale some couples (although very much the minority) in ball gowns, furs and rather Hapsburg suits looking as though they had been trapped in a very elegant middle European pre-war time capsule.We found it very easy to buy tickets before we left England and we had tickets in the middle of the stalls for a price which was a fraction of the amount we would have had to pay in London or Paris.Definitely worth doing if you are visiting Budapest.

A night at the Ballet. Booked a performance rather than the tour. Great seats and the performance was amazing. We were able to look around the Opera house prior to the performance so get there about half and hour early. The seats are a little solid but after the performance started all your focus was on the stage so it wasn't a problem.

Ballet in Budapest - Nb1 quality. It is great you can buy tickets from home. Unfortunately we had balcony left side and the view was very poor from there. Ballet Manon was great, wonderful costumes, wonderful artists. Next time I go again for any ballet they offer.

Highly recommended. You can get a guided short visit twice a day. We chose to join a Spanish guide, it was interesting and enriching. The Opera is smaller than the Vienna Opera house but for sure it is unique and worth a visit.

Beautiful theatre. We saw an opera which we enjoyed.. had English and Hungarian written transcripts as it was in Italian. Lovely atmosphere. They do daily 1 hr tours during the day which are worthwhile

Beautiful. The opera house is beautiful. The tour was excellent. The only suggestion I would make is to go early in your stay in Budapest so that you have the opportunity to attend a performance. We went on our second to last day and they were sold out for Madame Butterfly.

jaw dropping...breathtaking. My husband and I waited outside for almost an hour and a half to go inside this beautiful building. The outside doesn't do the inside justice. The only way to see the inside of the building is to go on a guided tour ( that day there were about 20 Americans for the English speaking part of the tour) and the guide was very informative on the history of the building, when and how it was built, etc... the main theater is jaw drapping. And if you have time make sure to go to the Alexandra bookstore on and andrassy ave. On the way to the opera house. Go to the 2nd floor and there is a beautiful coffee bar that has mosaics painted by the same painter that painted the opera house.

Stunning! (Again). This Opera House is so definitely worth visiting. It is slightly smaller than the one in Vienna but more beautiful. We went on the tour which lasted an hour and was informative but we didn't get to go back stage which I would have appreciated. We were so inspired though we booked to go back in the evening to see a ballet. The ticket prices are very reasonable as they are subsidised and it was a fraction of the cost of The Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, London. We had an amazing evening as we were seated in the fourth row so got to see the full orchestra as well as the dancers themselves. The acoustics are really good due to the design of the building but the wooden seats are a little on the uncomfortable side! - Go prepared!
Better than expected. If u want to learn about the art district in Budapest this is a must visit. The tour guides are more informative than I ever imagined.

limited visiting times. walking up Andrassy Avenue we decided to call in to the Opera House to take some photos. Asked to buy an entrance ticket but were informed that we could only enter with a guide and the guided tours were at 3 and 4pm! I was quite happy to pay the fee but was disappointed when told that I could only go in at the designated times with a guide.

The best experience in Budapest. We went to see the Bank Ban opera in the last evening of our trip to Budapest and bought tickets in advance for only 1.70€! Opera was much better than I excepted, the building is so amazing and beautiful and the opera itself had an english subtitles so it was easy to follow. If you have time, go and see the show. Totally worth it!

Beautiful Building. This feels like a real Opera House...lots of gilt and sweeping staircases. I thought the seats would be uncomfortable as they were quite small and hard but I didn't fidget for the next 3 hours of Otello.
amazing experience. beautiful opera house, high quality performance, polite English speaking staff, English subtitles made it easy to follow otherwise Italian show.

beautiful. Easy to find straight opposite the metro station Line 1 the Opera stop. We didn't do the tour, we went to see a ballet instead. We booked on line, easy enough to do. Cheap as chips. We had a box in the grand circle. Beautiful inside. Drinks can be bought from a make shift bar as soon as you walk in, but very limited with choice. Wish someone had said you can't take your drinks into the box with you before we climbed all the stairs to get there. No food allowed in the boxes either. Don't know about the stalls. There was only one toilet on our level that I could see, but being British I'm used to queuing anyway. Shame we didn't have time to do the day tour around it.

Something different. I have always tried to book to go to the Opera House before we arrived, you can book easily on the opera.hu web site and print your ticket off.Its a magnificent building, there is a tour in English mist days at 3pm, check the website.Aida is waiting for us on April 12, 2015.

Lovely compact building, good tour.. Built NOT to outshine the opera in Vienna it is still a lovely building and the tour gives a good feel for its history and the etiquette that afflicted even the Hapsburg royals - they could only look straight ahead.
Beautiful elegant building. Loved the artwork and history of the building. The ceiling artwork, the staircase and the musicians that performed there made the building extra special

Wonderful experience. A fabulous opera house visually, acoustically and from the audience perspective. Very high standard of performance and so cheap compared with London! The cost for two best seats for three operas worked out at £65 per head including flights and 4 nights in a 4 star hotel and valet parking. Wow. We have been for three years running and surtitles thsi year makes it even better.

One of the World's Great Opera Houses. The Hungarian State Opera house is one of the finest in the World (we have attended Opera houses all over Europe and the North America - it is one of our passions). The house is much smaller than most other major Opera Houses (seats about 1/3 that of La Scala), hence the sound is very big and bold. We saw an outstanding performance of Tosca and a day later took the tour of the place, which was very well done with a good english speaking guide. I am fluent in Italian so didn't need subtitles for this opera - subtitles were in Hungarian (naturally). If they want to attract more english speaking customers they might add english subtitles too as they have in Vienna (only in the boxes) and Berlin.

Verdi's Otello at the Hungarian State Opera House. We scored last minute tickets for the performance (no small thanks to our friend's hotel concierge). It was the experience of a lifetime. While opera is not the performance art of my choice, seeing my first opera in a setting like this made it truly memorable. The opera house is far more impressive as a building than La Scala is (I have not been able to see any performance at La Scala).The neat thing is that there are organized tours of this opera house if visitors are not able to/do not wish to see a performance. This is a must-do for any visit to Budapest.
Chocolate box. We attended Manon ballet here. Wonderful production but the house is worth a visit in its own right. So much gilt. Extremely well priced seats. Check it out

Favorite part of Budapest trip. My sister and I popped in to the Opera House one day during our short trip to Budapest and decided to inquire about any performances happening during our stay. Lucky for us the Hungarian National Ballet was performing Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, which neither of us had ever seen. The performance was AMAZING, the dancers perfection and the props absolutely incredible. The building itself is also stunning! The pricepoint is unreal - for the equivalent of about 10 USD we got BOX SEATS. There was room for six people but there was no one in there but us! A truly singular experience, I would absolutely recommend a tour of the building, but more than that, try to see a performance as well! You won't regret it.
Great Othello!. Perfect opera with professionals. Facilities are beautiful traditional. Chairs comfortable. Service is good. Singers are great. Good location to reach and have dinner afterwards.

beautiful. i think every visitor in Budapest should visit the opera.it is a bit far from the shopping center of Budapest so it is better if you can find out from before at what time the tour start.we bought a ticket for a tour and a performance which was short but nice.its worth to see both.

Simply excellent . We saw the Bank Ban performance.It was amazing!Few things for the opera.Avoid the tour. It is waste of money since it's not that big as the Vienna's state opera.The tickets for the first rows even far left or right, gives you amazing view and are very cheap around 100 € per two persons .Don't miss it chaps....They have English subtitles on every play....

Night at the Opera. Saw the Nutcracker here last December and was delighted not only by the incredible opera house, but by the amazing talent of the Ballet dancers. The ticket prices, if bought somewhat early, are remarkably affordable and well worth the cost. While I did not get a chance to get a formal tour, the building itself is impressive in its stature and decoration. Would definitely recommend for anybody visiting Budapest
Beautiful Opera House. The Opera House was beautiful and the history is very interesting. Definitely worth a tour. The wood work and decor was breathtaking.

Operahouse. This nice building s situated on Andrassy Awenue, it seems like a huge buildig, but the true it is only an art twist. To the other side of the awenue was Istitute of Ballet, now they are working on it, will be a luxory hotel. The 1st performance was Aida and still we have a lot of really interesting of it. and I have to tell you it is lowcoast. If you want to arrive to the Operahouse you can use the 1st underground of the continent. And yes, from here you should go to eat a special hungarian plate at Liszt Ferenc Square.

Don't Bother with the Tour. My girlfriend and I love the opera, but we forgot to book tickets far enough ahead of time to actually go see an opera at the famed Budapest Hungarian State Opera House, so we decided to do the next best thing and take the tour instead. Unfortunately, this fell far short of what we hoped for.We took the tour at 3pm, and it cost 2,900 Ft (about 10 Euro at the time and more than the outdated information found on their website). While I didn't expect the tour to be very long because there was another one at 4pm, the total amount of time we were actually on the tour was about 40 minutes, if that. We saw the main auditorium, the main bar, the smoking room, the royal entry-way, and the staircase. And that was it. Sure, the guide told us some interesting things about the building, but nothing I couldn't have learned from Wikipedia.During the tour, the guide mentioned that there are regular seats for actual operas for 1,500 Ft. That being said, plan ahead and buy a 1,500 Ft seat for the opera and spend 3 hours there, soaking up the ambiance in the same rooms. The tour doesn't include anything technical, nor anything that interesting. So just think ahead of time and go to the opera instead. Otherwise, the tour is waste of time and money.

a must.... Impressive place... During the tour, they were testing the stage lights for an Hungarian opera, a nice way to see the work behind the presentations. There are tours only at 3 and 4 pm in 6 different languages. Unfortunately, the Italian guide, close to our Spanish group, has a louder voice making difficult to hear our own guide. The visit is nice but the next time I will buy tickets for an event there!

Beautiful opera house. The tour guide was really helpful and did make the tour really interesting. I wish there are earlier times for the guided tour, only 3pm and 4pm were available when we were there.

A Night at the Opera. I am not an opera buff by any means but our outing to Madame Butterfly this week was a fabulous experience - you can do tours of the building during the day but the true ambiance is best experienced by going to a performance - really gives you a nostalgic feeling for a grander age - and it starts at the opera metro station!

A must.... I am personally not a fan of Opera... you neither? Go anyway, the place is heartbreaking. We saw Otello an the prices are quite reasonable for the monument you are able to see, and see and see as many times as you want. The lower stalls are not as big as they seem in the website where you can buy the tickets, so don't buy the highest prices, but the second ones, the view is perfect. You have 3 acts with 2 / 15 minute breaks so you will have plenty of time (more than 3 hours) to watch the place and feel as a Habsburg while watching a classic opera show. Otello had English subtitles for your convenience :D

Amazing night. It was my first time at the opera so I didn't know whether I would like it or not. I gave the tickets to my bf as a Xmas present and I chose some nice locations (first row, second floor) and the price was about 60 euros ( the 2 of them). We watched Madame butterfly. It was an unforgettable experience. I strongly recommend it to everyone!!

SInging Praises for the Hungarian Opera House. Tour and PerformanceWe took the opera house tour and also attended an opera performance and found the theater to be both visually and acoustically exceptional. It does, however, have the age-old problem of not having enough restroom space for women (only two stalls each side of the ground floor, for example, meant a long, tedious wait during the performance intermissions). The tour: The house runs two tours per day (at 3:00 and 4:00) in a number of languages. The cost seemed nominal but the tour is only about 45 minute in length—and you must pay extra if you plan to take photos. (This is required even if you have only a camera phone.) The ticket booth accepts Euros—it is one of the few places in the city we found willing to do so: although Hungary is part of the EU it has not yet been authorized the use of the Euro. All ticket holders meet in the foyer and then split into groups based on language, congregating in different areas on the beautiful double grand staircase. Each group then takes off in different directions but all tours cover the same space. No backstage area is included in the tour, which focuses on the architecture, the art, and the history of the front part of the house. The building itself is Neo- Renaissance and is considered one of the finest buildings of its type in Europe. It was opened in 1884 and soon became one of the leading houses on the continent, with the celebrated composer Gustav Mahler being director for three seasons. According to one study, the house has the finest acoustics in Europe, following La Scala (Milan) and the Paris Opera. The 3-story high auditorium is in the traditional horseshoe shape and seats 1200+; the primary colors throughout are red and gold. On the top row the names of prominent operas are displayed on the exterior of the boxes. The royal box is located centrally on the second floor and is decorated with sculptures symbolizing the four operatic voices - soprano, alto, tenor and bass. On the ceiling are Karoly Lotz’s frescoes depicting Olympus and the Greek gods. A huge gilded chandelier hangs from the ceiling—it is lowered by pully annually so that all bulbs can be replaced. The orchestra pit can be raised to the level of the stage and during the Opera Ball, the seats in the orchestra stalls are removed to allow for dancing. On the day we toured, the stage was already set for the evening’s performance (Otello) and we got to see the details of the opening scene. The buffet room is decorated with events from Greek mythology in the ceiling and landscape painting on the sidewalls. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and friendly, was thorough in her presentation and answered each question completely. The tour was interesting and we would recommend it as a must do if you have time.The PerformanceWe were lucky enough to get tickets for an evening performance of one of our favorite operas, Verdi’s Otello. It was nicely stage, traditional but not stuffy. The cast was quite good, especially the lead (Otello) who was performed by international tenor sensation José Cura. The acoustics were superb, the orchestra well-rehearsed and dynamic, and the audience knowledgeable and respectful. As mentioned earlier, restrooms for women are a problem, even more so than in many other houses.A couple of observations about performances:Because of the horseshoe shape—which enhances acoustics—there are many seats with sight line restrictions. If you don’t get a seat in the orchestra (ground) try to get seats toward the middle to minimize the problem.Floors in the boxes are flat so if you are not in the first row you may find yourself watching bobbing heads instead of dance or opera. In some cases, you are allowed to stand if necessary.Performances (at least the opera) are still considered events and people have a tendency to dress. We didn’t see many evening gowns per se, but the vast majority of the audience seemed to be in business attire or better. We did see a few folks in casual clothes, however, so if you find yourself wanting to attend and didn’t bring formal-wear, go anyway. It will be worth it.Ticket prices compared to comparable theaters in capital cities across Europe are extremely reasonable. As comparison, we sat in row 2 in Vienna (orchestra) and paid almost $400 a ticket. For La Scala, for approximately the same location, we paid almost $300. In Budapest, for first row, we paid less than $100. We encourage everyone to take the time to see a ballet or opera at the Hungarian Opera House, even if not an aficionado. The atmosphere, the elegance, the history will draw you in…..highly recommended.

Lovely!!. I visited the Opera House to watch Wagner ... it was the first time i watch such a professional opera and it was amazing. the building added a lot to the play which gave it a more of greatness. Loved the building a lot and the plays are awesome there.

Beautiful building. The Opera House building in Budapest is more magnificent than the one in Vienna. We didn't want tickets to the opera but the building fell on our walking tour route. Ask your tour guide in case you want to witness the magnificence. The main entrance is very grand.

wow!. We came here to see the operetta "The Bat" at New Year's Eve. To make it short: It was outstanding. I was simply overwhelmed by the stage design, the costumes, all the details. And of course by the performance of the actors. Just amazing. I had goose bumps almost throughout the whole evening. I had seen The Bat before, but not as good as this...The translation on the screen is horrible, many mistakes in the English version and almost impossible to understand the German version (and that's my mother tongue...). But who cares when one is so fascinated by the play itself. Also, value for money is unbelievable, We would have paid much more in Vienna or München or any other place typically hosting Strauss operas and operettas. Also, the building is very impressive. Originally we just wanted to see this beautiful building from the inside and that's how we ended up buying the tickets...
Magnificent opera house. Great building and some of the best dance and ballet in the world. Opera is good . A must visit in Budapest

Beautiful building. We took the 3pm tour. Groups are split into different language speakers and the English group was by far the biggest. In high season the groups must be massive. The guide spoke good English and the tour was fine. I do think it was a little expensive by Budapest standards and be aware you need to pay extra to be able to take pictures inside. That said it is a beautiful building!
Magnificent. This is an absolutely magnificent Opera House, much better than Vienna Opera House. It is in the best location in Pest, namely Andrassy utca where all the expensive shopsare.

Magnificent Opera House. Do go and have a look, even if you do not want to watch opera. The building is wonderful with rich décor to appreciate. We were lucky to attend the recent New Years gala performance of 'Die Fledermause' which was a complete knockout! Wonderful orchestra, brilliant stage production.

A pleasure for eyes and ears. if in Budapest, visit the Opera House, even if you are not an opera fanatic. The building is beautiful, the stage is perfect and Hungary has some of best opera singers and singerinnes of the world. Many times famous guest singers appear in the performances.And then comes some special events like the Opera ball every year. Not only Hungarian politicians, representatives of the leading economy circles of Hungary and celebs of our days enjoy the excellent food served and dance all night, but several foreign guests and visitors as well.Before Christmas you have to be lucky to get tickets for the special seasonal performance of Nutcracker. This is a treat for children and grown ups alike and will put all in the Christmas mood with the nice music by Tschaikovski and the excellent ballet dancers.

A Christmas Experience. We managed to get tickets for the Nut Cracker. The only seats left were at the back of the upper circle and so we paid an amazing £18 for the pair including booking fee!!! We entered the grandiose main entrance only to be sent to the side doors for the cheap seats. After a climb and a half up endless stairs we came to the bar the décor is still amazing. The acoustics are brilliant even in the circle but there are quite a few seats with restricted views so you have to careful. The staff did let people in seats move round and stand to watch the show. I would recommend that you at least try it even if you aren't keen on ballet or opera. It certainly helped us get in the mood for Christmas.
Magnifiq. It's absolutlly amazing the beauty of the construction ,of the inside decor the culture ,the elegance is Nobil and gorgeous !

FOR THOSE WHO DO NOT LOVE OPERA. I had only 1 opera experience before visiting Budapest and I do not like opera at all. But this building + the atmosphere + the attitude of Hungarians towards opera event make you live the event, feel the music, enjoy it. We watch the opera outside the building by chance, visit the building afterwards and fascinated by both performance and also the building itself. I would recommend to watch a performace inside and but tickets before going there.

Grand edifice - Be careful selecting your seat. Acoustics are good but sightlines are difficult if seated along the sides, even more so if one is seated high up in the Gods. The Budapest Philharmonic sounded fine from seats in the center of the main floor, but seats on the corners of the balcony lose sight of parts of the stage during Opera productions. To get to the upper reaches one must go outside, enter through a side door, and climb many flights of steps. While the interior is elegant in the old world way, there are more tricky steps within the balconies themselves. For opera performances in Budapest, the Erkel Theatre offers better visibility and comparable sound, with interior steps that may be slightly less hazardous to negotiate.

One of the most beautiful opera houses in the world. I am a bit of a sucker for operas and when I have the chance to go to a performance I will grab the opportunity. In this case I saw Madame Butterfly. Tickets are a bargain compared to other places like London, Munich or Vienna and booking via Internet is very easy. The inside of the opera house is amazing and I used the time during the two breaks to wander through all rooms. Wonderful all around.

Elegant. We had box seats, on the first level. There was a great view of the stage, just over the heads of the main floor seating. Every thought was given to the comfort of the guests. The restrooms are directly across the hall from the entrance to the boxes. The lounge is a fair distance away, but it is spacious and there are plenty of servers to accommodate everyone during the intermission(s). There is an outdoor smoking balcony, with a view of Andrassy ut. The acoustics in this hall are wonderful, and, since the opera we attened was written and sung in Italian, the surtitles were in both Hungarian and English. The entrance and stairways are beautiful and elegant. You know that you are in for something grand when you enter.
Opera evening. Great show, but very low visibility, even if I had good and very expensive places. Artists were good, nice performance, still, not outstanding.

Elegant Interior. Tours are given in multiple languages at 3pm an 4pm, and take about 45 minutes. We found the interior to be beautiful, elegant and intricate. Fascinating! Easy to get to, as the Underground stop is literally right out front. We did feel a little rushed on the tour, our group felt a little too big, and getting from room to room seemed to be chaos, as we crossed paths with multiple other groups. Had I not been tall, and able to see the Guide’s paddle, I could have easily gotten mixed up in one of the other groups. Side Note: The day we visited, there was a special event going on, so there was no 3pm tour. All visitors were asked to come back & attend the 4pm tour. I don’t know how many people are typically in a tour group, but the foyer was packed to the gills, and organizing everyone into their proper language groups was a challenge. This issue may have led to the rushed and frenzied feel of our experience, but did not take away from the beauty of the Opera House. A must see!

Beautiful building with very good accoustics.. Very interesting tour of the Opera House and 2 visits to the opera were very enjoyable. Very good facilities and the seats, although they did not look it, were quite comfortable.Beautiful ornate building and acoustics to make a visit very enjoyable.

Impressive. The building of the state opera house is simply impressive! The building is imposing on its own. Worth it to take also the tour- lasts approx an hour and you can see the interior of the opera house! If you have time, make sure to buy tickets for an opera!

Fantastic architecture in superb condition. Well worth a visit even if you don't take in a show. We thought the whole building especially the inside was in top condition and we marvelled at the interior decor and imagined ladies sweeping down the big staircases. We took in Madame Butterfly whilst here and thought the whole experience was fantastic and topped off our few days in Budapest.

Oh what an Opera, Oh what a show!. What's not too like! We bought two stalls tickets about five rows from the front for less than €60 each which would have cost a whole lot more than that in London or NY. The opera house is divine and really lovely, very grand yet small and intimate at the same time. We were lucky enough to get tickets for Madame Butterfly which was performed beautifully. It was also lovely to see that so many people had really made such a big effort to dress up. A wonderful night and much recommended.

Fabulous tour. You can tour the Hungarian State Opera House twice a day for an hour long tour which is well worth the time. Tours are about an hour long and cover a majority of the opera house. They are very informative and if you can't get to an actual show at the Opera House it is a great way to get a peek into the building.
