The tour groups are large and multiple language groups go at the same time so it can be a little hard to hear at times. Stay in the front of the group. There is an optional "Mini" opera at the end which is worth the added cost which is minimal. Its a fun way to see and hear a song from one of the many operas at the house.

You can not be beaten on a great value experience. We were recommended to pop down on the day to see what shows were occurring. Luckily the ballet was on and under 26 we paid around £8 for a ticket each!!! Need I saw more :) brilliant experience even with the weird alternative warm up act
Great opera. This Opera is more luxurious than Vienna opera, but a little bit smaller. We enjoyed "Madam Butterfly" with very good actors.

Great opera house, buy your tickets online. Magnificent interior, great staircase. Book your tickets upfront and be sure to chose an opera that is subtitled in English if you don't understand German or Hungarian.When booking tickets, be sure to buy tickets for the Opera House and not for one of the other locations (Erkel etc.). Opera tickets are cheap here compared to Paris etc.

Music and ambiance makes a wonderful evening.. My husband and I experienced the Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra at The Hungarian State Opera. The building is so elegant and to be in such a historical place set the stage for a memorable evening.

Fabulous classic opera house. Have been twice to see a performance when in Budapest; and again an uplifting experience.
Add this to your "to do" list when here.
Not an opera buff, but the setting and style of the place is just so old world!
Excellent.

Beautiful opera house.... We went to the Flying Dutchman, great experience. We booked a box and we view was not great so we asked one if the staff to relocate is. 20 mins into the show we were taken to the stalls and had full views of the stage. An amazing experience, get there a bit early so you can have s look around the place. The acoustics were amazing as was the orchestra and the show, well worth going if you are in Budapest.

Beautiful interior. We went to see Madam Butterfly here and enjoyed it very much. The inside is like a golden jewel box. Had seats in the stalls which had excellent views of the stage, but be warned they are quite old and wooden, which in a way adds to the experience, but can be a bit on the hard side after a couple of hours.

It ain't the ROH but i like it.. So first off, don't expect the same kind of strict etiquette you get in the ROH of London. People will come late, talk, eat and take photos. Children will be there and will stand. This probably has a lot to do the with the price. We paid £1.50 for seats! But do be careful, views can be restricted and you will not be told beforehand. Spend more and get a better view.

1 hour afternoon tour of the opera building. An hour very well spent! The building is most beautiful and our guide was very knowledgeable about the history of the house and the royal guests as well as very friendly and amiable.

Beautiful building. As our hotel was just a few footsteps from the Opera house, we've seen it everytime we went out and it was a nice way to start our route. The architecture of this building is outstanding!

No Air. A striking building! We saw an opera but ended up leaving half way through as there was absolutely no air circulation. Even though it was April, we werely nearly faint from the stuffy heat inside.

Make the time for a tour. The opera house offers guided tours at 3pm and 4pm daily. Recommend working around these times to get the most out of the experience. Unless, of course, you plan on actually seeing a show.

Amazing music in a stunning building. I have seen a several operas here and the "quality" is very high, the singers are the best I think, for example the Aida was so stunning that I was nearly crying... The interior is so beautiful it's take your breath away!

An Opera Venue Not to Be Missed. Please make sure you go when they are having an opera. Tickets are reasonable and the opera quality is excellent. The interior is magnificent so arrive a little early to take it in.

Turando Opera. We were advised to see an opera when we visiting Budapest. We were not disappointed. The place was fantastic as was the performance and well on par with Covent garden. If you are a opera fan this is a must see.

Stunning building. Sadly we didn't manage to attend a performance here, but the guided tour was a great experience too. The architecture and decoration are beautiful and our guide was full of history and stories about the building.

a great opera tour. We took a guided tour of the Opera and although I usually do not like guides, ours was very knowledgeable and interesting. She explained many different stories and facts about the Opera and gave us a great tour. The opera is stunning and in good conditions and a tour is a must have !Prices are not so low, but it is worth it.

History and opulence. Best way to experience this magnificent work of art and design is in the audience of a concert. I went to see the symphony orchestra for a fraction of what it would cost in New York or Vienna.It was a stella performance.I suggest you bring a bottle of water as the refreshment venue is poorly organized.slow and incapable of handling even a small crowd but small inconveniencesare worth putting up with to experience this concert hall/
shame. We didnt get to go inside the opera. We were so rushed for time that day. Wish we had extra day and we would have done so.

International standard performance and venue. We saw "Onegin"; a fine production with excellent performances and much much cheaper than similar quality performances in Western Europe. The Opera House itself is magnificent even if completely out of character with its time of building in 1885.Strongly recommended.

Not looks amazing from outside. In compare of Opera of Paris or Vienna. i didnt like outside view.I know is very important plan and architecture job from Miklós Ybl in 19th century. we couldnt go inside cause it was late and we couldnt enjoy a performance, cause sometimes they do programs like opera in ERKEL theater. If you went there try to see the hall. and in very nice street try to see METRO M1 LINE that is from 1896 oldest electrical in Europe.

Interesting and tours available. Its very nice and a 1 minute walk from the metro station its small and they offer guided tours in all the main languages and its very nice the tours start at 3 and 4 in the winter and for about 12 dollarsdefinitely worth the visit
Don Giovanni. Beautiful building. Tickets reasonable compared to Glyndebourne and Covent Garden. Excellent experience.
Imponent. Fine piece of architecture reminding everyone that Budapest was (and still is) a throbbing heart of European culture.

Great ballet expierience. We saw the ballet Onegin in 3 acts at the Opera house. We very rarely go to opera's or ballet's but the expierience here, of the house, the music and the performance was excellent. Even our Young kids enjoyed the expierience, even though they would rate the cakes in the brakes higher than the actual artistic performance

Grandeur!. The Hungarian State Opera House is beautiful gem. Its decortation is remarkable both inside and outside.
One of the good things about Hungary is that culture can be real cheap. You can grab a ticket for the Opera for just a few euros. Don't miss the opportunity.

A wonderful building. We saw the Hungarian ballet at this most beautiful building and it was a fantastic experience and very affordable at about £17 for a box. Fantastic value to see great art. It's worth going just to take in the Opera house itself, glittering with ornate gold and marble. I highly recommended you visit the Opera House on your trip to Budapest.

A charming Nutcracker. We were in Budapest for Christmas and were able secure tickets for the Christmas Day performance of The Nutcracker. Full orchestra and a charming performance that helped make the Christmas for us. A beautiful building, easy to access and very affordable. Well recommended.

Stunning architecture, memorable venue to catch a show!. The Hungarian State Opera House offers an amazing opportunity to soak in the powerful elegance (yes, elegance) of Hungarian architecture. From the outside marble pillars to the ornate chandelier and vaulted ceilings, the Opera House is a visual masterpiece. I did not take one of the tours; however, I did have a chance to attend one of the opera shows and absorb the truth behind the "3rd best acoustics" rating for an opera venue in the world. If you have a chance, I highly suggest purchasing a ticket a week or two in advance to see a show as more seats will be available. For two people sitting in the upper gallery (offered a pretty good view, not great!) it cost only $16. Great for a date or just to soak in the artistic side of the city.If you purchase a ticket for the upper gallery, you sadly do not get to use the famous wide staircase to go to your seat. You must exit through the main entrance and head to the right side of the building. The access door to the stairs can be a little hard to find as we overshot our entrance door and had to double back when we were alerted to our error by a friendly door attendant. Brace yourself for a steep climb. There was an elderly man who really looked like he was struggling to get up the multiple flights of stairs...so if you have health issues, I would pay more to sit in an easily accessible area or ask for assistance to the top. There is a coat check for a small fee and a bar as well, even for the peasants who have to watch in the upper gallery like me. Overall, I highly recommend catching a show so you can at least humble-brag to your friends about how extremely cultured you are as evidenced by your experience at the opera in Budapest's premier opera house!

Impressive house. Just the house it self is worth the ticket with amazing decorations. Plus the tickets can be very affordable, we payed 1200 HUF (ca. 3 euro) for a balcony seat with full view of the stage on a saturday night. We saw a ballet but anything involving the orchestra (which is everything) is worth a visit!
Elegant and lively. The Opera house is beautiful but it is worthy to visit an evening performance. We saw an Onegin which was a really nice and melancholic ballet performance...

Lovely architecture. We didn't go inside the Opera House as there were no tickets available for performances but the outside of the building is lovely. Can't rate it any higher as there's nothing else we can comment on.

Take care if booking online for the Opera!. We heard seeing an opera here was a wonderful and inexpensive experience so we looked up the Hungarian State Opera and booked Turandot online. When we got to the entrance we discovered we had booked for the Hungarian State Opera but this performance was at a different opera house! We grabbed a taxi and made it just in time - it was a wonderful performance and a great evening amongst locals rather than tourists and the theatre was not as beautiful perhaps but still striking and for £8 for two people, no complaints but we felt a little foolish for making such an error!

Drama, Exquisite Dancing Emotions - Onegin. Originally an opera by Tchaikovsky based on a plot of Pushkin's verse novel Eugene Onegin.We managed to get tickets for this performance not knowing much about the dancers and the story. Having read the story we were looking forward to seeing this ballet very much.It is a simple story of love, betrayal and tragedy. A dandy rejects a young country girl's genuine love , she successfully grows into a worldly woman, he tries to seduce her, but it is too late. He also kills his best friend in a dual, which he regrets bitterly afterwards. The performance had great drama and understanding, danced mainly by Russian performers.In our opinion, this was an outstanding performance, one of the best we have ever seen in the Hungarian Opera House. It was a magical night, dancers, scenery, lighting were equally excellent. It was uplifting to the soul, even though it reflects on human behaviour shortcomings.If you have a chance go and see it. The encores and the celebrations and the number of curtain calls said it all. The normally subdued crowd that attend the Opera House, knew that they had seen something really special. I have written about the Opera House's productions many times before, so I will not repeat myself here. It is always a joy to go there and the ticket prices are a fraction of any other Western house's.

Oldest Opera House in Hungary. The ceilings are beautifully painted. Had box seats and had nice view of the stage. The interior of the building was very ornate and beautifully done. Expect to exit very slowly due to immense crowds.

beautiful building. We visited at a quiet time. The staff were shockingly unwelcoming, save for a guide whose English was very good. Since there were no other visitors, we could not take the tour! Obviously, this needs to be arranged ahead if time.

Great interior!. We couldn't get to the performance, so took a tour to the inside of the building for something like 3000 HUF for each person (you can get inside either at the performance, or with the tour, so this was the only option left for us). And it was so unexpectedly amusing! The interior is unbelievably beautiful, unique, and impressing - even after Moscow's Bolshoy Theater and Vienna Opera House. And the most of everything inside is genuine and so old! It's a miracle, that it survived the WWII. There are different groups for tourists with guides speaking different languages. Ours spoke Russian (which is not so easy))), was very enthusiastic and seemed to care about everything. The place itself has such an atmosphere, that we decided to come back sometime and see some performance in here.
Beautifull!. This building looks amazing! I love Budapest and buildings in this town! all of them have soul! I'll try to return when i have more time to stay!

Absolutely Stunning. The theatre itself is worth a visit, even if you are not seeing a performance. The interior is incredibly ornate. My sister and I saw a near-Christmas performance of the Nutcracker and the costume and set design were the most vivid I'd ever seen. We sat in box seats, which were surprisingly cramped and had two rows of seats. We were luckily in the first row - those behind us had to stand for the majority of the performance so that they could effectively see the stage.

Wonderful theater, too fast guided tour. The location of this Budapest attraction was the most confortable for us, since our lodging was located at 50 m from Opera House.Two exclusively guided tours are foreseen every day, at 3 and 4 pm, in different languages; to participate, it’s just a matter to go into the Opera House, just 10 min before the chosen tour, and take the tickets. The visitors are divided then into several groups according to the language, and gathered at different points of the entrance stair, and finally guided inside the building.The ticket fare is 2900 Ft per adult (approximately 9.00 Euro); I paid 500 Ft more to get authorized to take photos (I got a red bracelet, to be “identified”), but I saw several people doing it free-of-charge… Against a further fee, a mini-concert is offered once the tour is completed.Since many groups (languages) were simultaneously making the tour, the guides’ explanation was a bit noisy and disturbing each other; further to that, the tour and explanation were in my opinion too fast, not giving the way to assimilate the big quantity of information we were getting from the guide.I believe that such rushed tour was consequence of Opera needs for practice and staging, before the day show; nevertheless, the overall impression I got was that such guided tours are arranged with the main purpose to get money.Said that, the Opera House is really wonderful, showing a rich and stylish setting. The sequence of different halls along the way allows to appreciate lavish stairs, golden decorative stuccos, huge mirrors, and the wonderful fresco ceilings of Karl Lotz.The stage is very huge, as the parterre area is; Opera is proposing a daily show (it seems that the rates are affordable by everybody), consisting of ballets, grand operas, orchestras performances, alternating to each other.Summarizing, the attraction definitely worth a visit, but a slower motion would have been much more appreciated and could probably be better organized.

More wonderful architecture. I would like to have seen a show here but they were all booked out. Beautiful building with interesting murals on the ceilings and artistic touches/playful elements which made it fun to explore just the main flyer area - would like to have seen more.

Amazing Performance!. Mind boggling. Wonderful musicians and atmosphere. So much has happened since that visit. I believe it started with a cocktail welcome party. Programme was extensive and very informative. Altogether an unforgettable experience!

Special Christmas Concert. Wow! This opera house is absolutely beautiful. It is so richly decorated and ornate. I surprised my husband with tickets of the Budapest Philharmonic during our winter holiday and we had a great time. The acoustics were excellent and the concert was top notch. During the intermission, we purchased champagne and went out on the open air balcony that overlooks Andrassy street. Treat yourself to this and you will have a wonderful night.

New Year Concert ..... ... just for Hungarians!The wonderful Beethoven 9th Symphony was preceeded by a poem and a dissertation in Hungarian, funny translation in English and nothing else. Definetly below our expectations
Splendid. We say La Boheme for our honeymoon. Subtitles were clearly visible but if you know the opera this doesn't matter. The Opera House is exquisite and the acoustics, superb.

Impressive building and lobby. After spending time in Vienna at the Opera House, we were not going to duplicate efforts but since we were on the same side of the street and had some spare time, it certainly was worth walking in and admiring the history, the grand lobby and see what was playing in the box office window.

New Year's Day concert. We had a wonderful introduction to 2015 at the opera house's gala NYD event. A somewhat chaotic admission system prevents this from being a 5 star review but the music was marvellous and well played/conducted. There was a mix of poetry and speech as well as a contemporary piece. All in all a wonderful event.

Attended "The Bat" on 31/12. Very good performance, great cast and decorations. Cons - they miss organization comparing to operetta we've visited the day before. We've had to wait in a line to store our coats just to be told we need another line up in which the tickets were checked and for cloaks 1 floor above we had to go to the 3rd line.Also seats on balconies (even though the view is really good) - have very little space for legs.Still overall - very enjoyable

Great experience.. My wife and I watched Die Fledermaus on New Year's Eve and we thoroughly enjoyed it. The opera house itself is magnificent. We had a box in the dress circle and had an excellent view. A tip: if you do stay in a box make sure you have one of the three seats in the front row. The man sitting behind us could not see a thing and was all the time standing up to get a view of the stage.

Magical Evenings...Joy To The World!. This building will transport you to Another Era! We saw the opera A Trubadur by Giuseppe Verdi....beautiful production +performances! Skip Theme Parks....Go to the Real Deal places like this:)♡

Fantastic opera. The building is great, acoustics are very good indeedWe weer the for 'La Bohème' which in a previous occasion, I found boring, but here I loved itThe decors were amongst the best I've seen and the singers were excellent

Go if you like old buildings. We came to see the oldest (and only?) Opera house in Hungary. Almost entirely made by Hungarian workers and materials. In the end we were treated to an aria of an opera singer. One minor thing, because there were a lot of people in the tour (divided in smaller groups, each their own language) we got in each others way and sometimes it was difficult to hear the guide.

Beautiful building. We visited just before Christmas and booked some very reasonably priced tickets to see the Nutcracker ballet. To see something such as a ballet or an opera in such palatial surroundings has got to be done. This was a highlight of our trip to Budapest.

Go for the experience. You don't have to enjoy opera to enjoy the experience. This is a spectacular auditorium completely refurbished as it would have been and with great accoustics. Unlike many cities there are frequent performances and prices are very reasonable.

Beautiful building. Despite my family not being opera lovers we had to give it a try as it was rather inexpensive up in the gods.
It was a lovely experience.

I usually don't like performances but. I really enjoyed seeing the nutcracker. The Opera house in itself is worth the $30 my grandma said she spent on our 2nd level stall. But be sure to book WAY in advance. Maybe it's just because of the time of year where people are on vacation. But 11am on Dec 30 seemed like it wouldn't be busy but it was. No pictures allowed. 3 acts. About 1.5 hrs. Hopefully you don't get a seat on the sofa

a must visit in Budapest. Beautiful building both inside and out, great facilities for a drink during the performances, good pricing of tickets, no real snobbery, in short a fantastic place for families.

Sightseeing tour. While staying in Budapest, go for a sightseeing tour of the Opera house. It is a grand building with a fascinating history. I joined an English speaking tour in the Summer of 2013 and it was surprisingly fascinating. You don´t have to like opera to enjoy it. I liked all the little stories how the Hungarians wanted to have a grandier Opera house then the Austrians. You could sense the excitement of the late 19th century and all the building activity happening in Budapest at that time walking through the halls. Worth the money.

Culture and Beauty. One of the must do activities in Budapest, along with visiting the Baths or doing a Danube cruise.Butterfly Homes owner Andras organised great seats for a Saturday night and it was an experience to mix with the rich and famous in such an historical building. The social occasion was great, to watch the pretty people and be entertained by such theatre of the operatics was a sensational night.It certainly went for a while, 3 hours, but much enjoyment.
Olde World Opera House. What a fine example of an olde world opera house, ornate yet grand. The guided tour was worth the money and the private operatic performance was something to behold.

Old school. The opera house is old and beautifully preserved. The prices are really reasonable. I paid $50 for the best seats in the house and you can get real deals in the balconies. The style of the ballet is very old-fashioned, in a charming way.

Very nice building. During the night it had very well light decoration which looks very nice... inside of the building its just amazing. if you are planing to visit budapest, you should definitely count the Opera House.
Nutcracker at the Opera. Well done performance. It was hard to negotiate tickets, coat room, intermission. Show was a 5. Hospitality to a foreigner was a 2.

Good Tour Around the Opera House. Try the tour around the Opera House which is very good and a great way to see the Grand Interior of this palatial building (we went in December 2013).The tour is reasonably priced for Budapest and a great way to spend some cultural time whilst in the city.The shop in the Opera House has some interesting things especially those acquainted with the life of music.Enjoy.

Something different. This was the first time i went to an opera house/theatre. I was amazed. The paintings and interior were magnificent. There are different language tours and also a chance to see a mini concert at the end. The woman who performed had a breathtaking voice. After the visit, i have been influenced to experience more opera music. The building itself is amazing.
Grand and elegant. Our tour was interesting. We looked into the reserved boxes and learned about the history of the opera.

A Beautiful Night. Because we had such a good experience going to the ballet and opera in Vienna, we decided to also try to see something during a long weekend in Budapest. A local friend was able to get us tickets to La Bohème, and we made sure to pack nice clothes and read up on the story. In December the opera house is beautifully lit for the holidays, and we were greeted out front by characters from the Nutcracker and a choir singing Christmas carols. Inside, after a little confusion of where to go, we ascended the grand stairways into the gilded theater and our 5th row seats. I have to admit that I am not typically an opera person, but I can appreciate beautiful things. Highlights for me included the four male voices in Act 1, the party scene in Act 2, and the sets truly conveying the sense of winter poverty. The screen over the stage showing the Hungarian translation of the Italian opera wasn’t much use to me, but it hardly mattered. It was a fantastic experience!
See a show!. A must of Budapest. Dont just visit the Opera, go see an actual opera. Its a beautiful Opera house, with frequent quality shows and very cheap tickets. Book online in advance.
Wow!. Elegance, impressive. Just thought it was a privilege sitting there.We saw a great ballet show the night we were there.

Wondefull. It is a wonderful place and the guides speak many languages, we get a lot of interesting informations.The short opera show, at the end of the visit, doesn't take place in the opera itself, but in the bar. This was disappointing, though the singer impressed me by his powerful and wondeful voice.

The Nutcracker. Wonderful Opera House, take the tour during the day and feast your eyes on this gem of a building.We saw the Nutcracker and my wife thinks it was the best production that she has seen. Performance or not, see the house

Outstanding ballet, outstanding building. Amazingly, very good tickets were available at a reasonable price for three days ahead. The ballet was Coppelia, skilfully performed by a large company including a group of young dancers, who I suppose are the stars of the future. Having arrived in good time, we were able to take in this beautiful building, which appeared to be well maintained, clean with sparkling gilded paintwork. The throwing of flowers to the leading dancers and the shouts of 'Bravo' added to the 19th century atmosphere.
Beautiful building. Fantastic night at the Opera. Excellent value for top rate concert. Not to be missed- get dressed up and step back in time in this beautiful Opera House

Nice visit and final mini-concert. We visited the Hungarian State Opera House during a 4-days stay in Budapest. The building is very interesting and the visit is well done, the young guide speaks a pretty good Spanish. I found interesting to pay something more for the final concert, since I had never listened to an opera singer live and so close. Surely worth a visit!

Tour of the Opera House. Enjoyed a 40 minuted guided tour of the opera house. The staff split you into groups depending on what language you speak. Our guide, a young man was very knowledgeable and personable.

Beautiful building, disappointing seats. We booked tickets for La Boheme having never been to an opera before. The building is genuinely stunning, inside and out. There aren't an awful lot of signs which resulted in a lot of people not knowing where to queue. Queue down the middle to have your tickets checked and you will either be allowed straight through or sent back out to the main foyer so you can go up the left hand or right hand staircase for your seats. We had seats in Box 6 which was beautiful but we were initially put in the wrong seats so thought we had scored big time and were in the front of the box! This didn't last long and we were moved back to the correct seats which were a real let down. The seating plan on the website shows that we booked seats in row three next to each other. In reality row three is actually one seat on a raised platform flush against the side wall with another chair wedged onto a slightly more raised platform behind that. Leg room was minimal and it was practically impossible to see the stage at all. We stayed until the first interval and then left but we had seen what we wanted to see and given that the tickets are very reasonably priced we didn't really feel that we had lost out. If your plan is to go for the duration though definitely make sure you get seats further forward otherwise you will be disappointed. There is a small drinks selection but you can't take anything into the main theatre with you. There is a cloakroom but you pay a small charge to leave your coats. There are staff on every floor who will help you to your seat.

A night at the ballet. We booked to see the nutcracker suite before we went to Budapest - I had heard that you can get tickets very cheaply, this was almost sold ou do we paid £23 each for out tickets which was still a good bargain for great seats. The ballet was stunning and the building itself is magnificent and well worth a look in its own right- definitely one to add to your itinerary
Beautiful!. Worth taking the tour to see the inside and learn a bit about the history. Well organised and was a nice break from the rain!

Fantastic. We visited the opera with a guide, explained many things about Opera and history. The building is spectacular, inside more than outside, decorations, lighting ... After the visit was a small operatic interpretation of two parts, we loved it. If you have opportunity Hasten to a ballet performance is wonderful and tickets are very affordable, for two euros !!!

Unreal. We went here to see the Nutcracker. The setting is so overwhelming it was hard to keep an eye on the event. Seats were comfortable. But the statement this building makes is that the arts are important.

Stunning Building! . We bought tickets before we arrived in Budapest & paid just £11 each, we were unsure if our seats would be any good but much to our surprise they were brilliant. There were cheaper options available too, so would make a great family night out if you want to do something a bit different whilst visiting Budapest. If you fancy a pre-opera meal there are plenty of restaurants in the area. Definitely worth a visit!
OMG. This is so beautiful and historic and has guided tours in your language. Even had a lovely lady come at the end and sang for us. Perfect place for a visit

Simply magnificent!. My husband and I got box seats to see the opera La Boheme and thoroughly enjoyed it. The opera house is amazingly beautiful and the opera was so enjoyable. Not a bad price for the value either. What a wonderful way to spend the evening!

Beautiful building. We dropped by as we were strolling down Andressy Avenue and we were not dissapointed. They offer tours in English in the afternoon. The interior is magnificent. It's worth a quick stop.

Richly decorated. We saw Tannhauser here and had the privilege of sitting in a box. The theatre is stunning and has a good acoustic. The marbled entry staircases are wonderful. Ticket prices very reasonable so, in my view, this is the best way of seeing it.
Did not disappoint.. Did not disappoint. Despite a little crowd just splendid, the decoration superb totally enjoyed our visit.

Fabulous opera experience - including English surtitles for blockbusters. A stunning opera house, super cheap seats and broadly international standards, what's not to like? We went twice during our recent stay - to Tannhauser (with a famous American tenor in the title role) and Tosca? Both were fabulous but Tosca might be a better choice for newer opera fans as they even put the surtitles in English for this more popular work. We love opera but can't always afford good seats here in the UK. We felt really spoiled to be able to afford the very best seats here at around £28 each for even the front stalls. Both operas had two intervals and with a full house on the two nights it made sense to order interval drinks before the performance. If you're splashing out on the best seats it also makes sense to match this at the interval too. We had glasses of the really very good extra dry Hungarian champagne on each occasion. Couldn't believe it was less than £10 for four glasses! That was the gilt on the gingerbread for me!

Beautiful Opera house - a must see. We took a tour of the Hungarian Opera House and were suprised to see how ornate it was inside. The tour in English was great and the guides were very knowledgable and easy to understand. Well worth the fee to tour the Opera House - highly recommend!

Glamorous. We took a box for a performance of La Boheme - at ridiculously low prices! What a treat. The Opera House is in excellent condition, the performance was great with a wonderful set and it was a marvellous evening. We did book in advance, on line, before we even left the UK, to ensure we got the seats we wanted.
A beautiful building. If possible attend a ballet performance or an opera. You will be thrilled and tickets are a bargain.

Beautiful Opera House. I had the tour during the afternoon where the Guide was very nice, knowledgeable a good storyteller. He provide us with some juicy details about the history of this great building.For less than 10 euros, we bought tickets for the opera show at night which was also an unique experience. The opera lasts 4 hours but even if you just stay for 1 act (1h15m) is still worth it for the experience (audio and visual).Recommend!
Wonderful building. There was a good tour, although brief. After the tour there was a short concert that was good as well. Very talented people.

Budapest visit 1-4 Dec 2014. My partner and I enjoyed Wagner's Tannhäuser one of Richard Wagner's three romantic operas at the Hungarian State Opera HOuse in Budapest; to say it was a fantastic experience would be an understatement; the performance, spectacle and music were a delight so much so that we didn't even notice that the chairs threatened to be a trifle hard.The beauty of the neo-renaissance style, the paintings and the sculptures added to an extraordinary ambience; the accoustics were outstanding and I was pedantic in my choice of seating; it will be a very hard act to follow.Budapest you must be very very proud, we will be back.

A royal experience. A truly wonderful experience to have in Budapest. Making the most out of our night to see Tosca, we dressed up, had a bottle of Champagne in the royal ballroom bar and thoroughly enjoyed our seats in Box 1. Amazing. I'd go every night if I could! :-)

Beautiful theatre & excellent performance!. Did you know that the Hungarian State Opera House was originally called the Hungarian Royal Opera House and it's 130 years old?
The opera house is magnificent both inside and outside. If you are visiting Budapest, you must watch a performance because it will be a breathtaking experience!

Beautiful renovation. Bring cushion.. It was a beautiful space. We walked up to the top floor to look out and to peek into the royal box. Really lovely place. Translation overhead which was useful if a little distracting. Seats could use a bit of padding:) And performance of Verdi opera was magnificent.

Beautiful building and great acoustics. The building is really beautiful and has amazing interior decorations. Its acoustics delights. Wood paneling and decorations are wonderful. I recommend especially a tour in german language. In the group there were only few tourists so we had really good contact with the guide and we could ask all the questions we had. And of course in such small group we could easily take pictures (extra fee) ;) Unfortunately, the toilets are only available to spectators during the opera performance. :(

One of the most beautiful Opera Houses in Europe. Exquisite building, great acoustics, but the seating is old and wooden and a bit uncomfortable. Prices for Opera performances are very reasonable, and the street (Andrassy) is one of Budapest's most beautiful, with many embassies and designer shops.
Beautiful, we still need. Budapest is a jewel with a beautiful interior, fantastic sound experience. The chairs are a bit small and the small bar, but the atmosphere is wonderful.

Great place. Excellent Performance. The Opera is located in the heart of Pest, in Andrassy avenue. The building itself is impressive and the exterior has a lot of symbolic meaning, as it's decorated with scuptures representing composers. The Interior is beautiful too. Worth a visit. I went to opera Cosi Fan Tutti (Mozart, comedi). Acoustics was excellent and the quality of performance too. The audience is from all over the world, lots of tourists as well as Hungarians. The opera was in traditional Italian, subtitled in Hungarian and English. I sat in the balcony - great choice. Excellent visibility, very reasonably priced tickets.The entrance to the balcony is tricky though. Side door has to be used instead of the central. The ticket prices deserve special attention. Of course they vary from performance to performance and by seat a lot, yet are relatively low. They start around 5 Euros (or less). There are famous performances that sell out really fast. For example The Nutcracker (the ballet) that is traditinally performed in December and around Christmas sold out 99% in mid-October.

Rich music history. Budapest has a rich music history which was described by our knowledgeable and vivacious guide. Even without the music (wish I could have attended one of the numerous musical events), the building holds its own tales. Looking down from the Royal box seats takes you back a century.

Not very much fun... My wife and I wanted to attend the Opera during our stay in Budapest and so we booked seats for Il Trovatorre. Since we booked rather late, we had to get seats in the gods, far on stage left.We arrived late, not by much, but the overture was already playing. Apparently, when you have seats in the Gods in Hungary, you have to enter through a tradesmen's entrance on the side of the building, then climb four flights of bare concrete stairwell to arrive in a little lobby where we waited for the overture to be finished to be seated so as to not disturb the audience.When we were finally admitted, a very blonde little martinet no older than 18 stopped us from taking our seats, explaining that they had been taken by other patrons just before the show started. We both work in show business so we weren't very suprised but what came next was priceless.The gods were about 1/2 full, with most of the audience in the centre and a smattering on the wings which were four rows deep. Instead of letting us sit in one of the many easily accessible empty seats, we were required to stand on the landing at the top of the gods for the best part of an hour before being allowed to sit. During that time, the curtain closed three times for set changes and salutes and the house lights came on, for about a minute each time. We were not allowed to sit, but at least we had company, there were about 8 people on our side of the gods in the same predicament, whenever anyone tried to discretely take a seat during our 'penalty time', the martinet would, loudly, tell them to stand back on the landing.When we, at long last, got to sit, it was to realize that we couldn't see the stage at all. we expected bad seats, it is the gods after all, but we couldn't see the stage, by sitting on the rim of my chair i could just make out a little quadrant of stage and had to rely on a video screen showing the stage with horrible color correction.

Fantastic!. We saw Verdi's Il Trovatore and it was spectacular. Beautiful interior and great sound. It's not a huge opera house, so most seats have great views. We were in the rear orchestra section, stage left, and it was perfect.

Great visit. Ok so I am a opera virgin, never seen an opera or ballet, but after my recent visit I think this will all change. I dont think you can visit Budapest without taking a look around this magnificent place, our guide was very polite and informative. Again I left somewhere happy with more knowledge than what I had on entering this exquisite place.

girls weekend. nothing about this amazing building to dislike, from the minute you enter you will be in awe of its grandeur and the decor is stunning. never before have i seen such a grand building.i enjoyed the tour provided in english and other languages .our guide Thomaz was a mind of information and made the tour fun as well as interesting.after the tour we were treated to a mini concert which just topped off our visit for us. would recommend this opera house to anyone even if you if no interest in opera its definately worth seeing and you dont have to do the tour or have the concert if you prefer to just look around the ground floor.photos are permitted too.

My first opera was just okay. The Opera House is beautiful inside, and overall, I am glad I went to experience my first opera, Tannhauser by Wagner.There are several things I can recommend to make your visit better, and which would have improved my experience.If you are going to see an Opera, sit low to the ground or in the back. I had a seat on the second (American third) balcony to the right. The stage view was fine, but at that height, you can see the conductor's stand, and the lightbulbs on it are way too bright. I either had to hold my hand out the entire performance to block the glare, or sit back farther so the ledge blocked it (but then the fancy gilt heads blocked some stage view) My moving around probably didn't please the people behind me. The tickets are labeled "upper level circle" or lower level, etc, but the actual floors are simply labeled "I emelet, II emelet (first floor, second floor) etc. So you have no idea if you're on the correct level. Check with the attendant, even if you are sure you have the right level. We didn't.Make sure you know the opera before hand. The program cost an extra 1000 huf, I didn't pay so I don't know what was in it. There was no way for me to know how many acts were coming, how much time we had at intermission, or generally what was going on. There ARE subtitles in Hungarian, but if you don't know Hungarian, it doesn't help.The cast is Hungarian, I was told by another patron that most of them sang rather muddled German, so he could not understand them. Again, know the opera beforehand.As far as the Tannhauser performance, after watching other versions on Youtube, i think this would disappoint an opera enthusiast. Venus and Elisabeth are played by the same woman. The choreography was messy, and I thought perhaps ballet in the opera is not as important as the singing. But it would have been more impressive if, when the dancers made the same movements, if they were synchronized. It seemed very amateur. Go to the opera. Buy cheaper seats at the front of the balcony in the back of the curve. Bring some binoculars (though the auditorium is small, you will be able to see the general movement) and do some research before hand. It can be a great introduction.

The most beautiful opera house I have visited. Recently we attended operas at this opera house for the fourth time and each time it never fails ti impress. The interior staircases, halls and rooms are all magnificent, as is the theatre itself. The productions are improving, they have always been musically excellent and while in the past the staging has been somewhat old-fashioned, the recent productions of Cosi fan Tutti and Il Trovatore were impressive. Having sat in all of the different areas we would say it is worth paying more for the stalls. The Upper Circle tends to be patronised by groups of young people who are not always the quietist. The boxes are fabulous and really make you feel like royalty but can be cramped.

Great and short. Tour was not too long and not too short. just straight to the point. was impressing. was informative. Dont dare taking thw tour without taking the mini opera show afterwards. she sang too short songs for us and that was exactly what was needed. since most of us will not come for a regular 4-5 hours long opera.

A Must See Place. I've lived in Budapest for almost 2 years.I've tried to visit all of it's best places, and luckily I had the chase to buy tickets to several shows during my stay. You will find the Opera on almost every tour's brochure, they will also (probably) get you for the short tour between 15:00-16:00. You will get to see the interior, that's for sure, but if you want to enjoy in it's entire splendor, then you should definitely book for a play. This can be hard, as tickets are sold months before a show, so you should book in advance.

Good value. A superb interior that has to be seen. Fortunate to see "Coppelia", "Cossi Fan Tutti" and Il Trovatore", all VERY cheap and a very good standard overall. The productions are not cutting edge or "superb" but when you consdier how cheap the overall opera and ballet are you cannot really complain.
Culture at its best. A wonderful Opera , the stage set was ingenious . The opera House is so beautiful , the painted ceilings the ornate gold work , wonderful value .

A nice opera house. Went to see Cosi fan tutte in Nov 2014 and enjoyed the show and like the theatre. Bought the first level box seat (about U$65), it has 3 individual seats, and a sofa (sits 2), inside the box, there's coat hanger and a wall-mount stand to put drinks. Unlike some other opera, box 1 seat 1's view is impacted by the pillars of the first side box, so I'd recommend not to book box 1 level 1 from either side. We didn't get the time to go to the roof top though which should be beautiful at night. The sphinx is at the left side of the main entrance, which is featured in Budapest Opera House's TV ad.

Opera Experience. Arrived Friday for a long weekend and lucky enough to get the last 2 stalls tickets for "Il Trovatore" on the Sunday night. Very reasonably priced and an all-round wonderful evening. It IS a good idea to take a small cushion/padding for the back (original upholstery!) but otherwise no gripes. Order an interval drink in the 1st -floor bar to marvel at the ceiling there.
First class. Great decor and a very lovely building,we had a first class guided tour which lasted around one hour and was very iteresting

loved it. Went to Mozart's opera Cosi Fan Tutte here November 22, 2014. The music was fantastic and the building is over-the-top grand. The audience was enthusiastic and it was fun to see lots of families (it was a matinee). At intermission everyone rushed upstairs to a lovely lounge to have sparkling wine and big pretzels. What a fun experience.
TAKE THE TOUR !!!. You will not be disappointed in seeing this truly beautiful building. Even better, take in a show too as it is a wonderful experience. Dress up though as it is expected.
A Real Beauty. Worth the tour, A grand old Opera House ...outrageously baroque and fascinating...if you are there at the right time by all means go to the opera
A must. Beautiful building and nice ballet this evening. The pause was perfect for seeing the insides instead of taking the tour. This evening Viktor Orbán and Jose Manuel Barroso were visitors.
beautiful building. beautiful historic building - worth the visit to relive the history of a grander era and interesting past. the guide is amusing and informative

excellent production at their secondary space. I saw a production of Lorca's "Blood Wedding" at the Erkel theatre (opera's secondary space). An extremely interesting production with English surtitles). I love the performance, especially the design of the set and the director's interpretation. Beautifully staged. The performances were strong. Even if you may not be interested in Opera, it's worth seeing one performance while in Budapest. Ticket prices were extremely low compared to the costs you'd find in London and New York. Checkout the website opera.hu for more info. The Erkel theatre is very easy to get to by metro (the station is II. Janos Pal papa ter - on the number 4 green line). From the II Janos station you walk 1.5 streets and you're there.
Amazing building. Amazing building, both inside and out. Worth taking the tour to find out more about the history and traditions of the place.The grandure is jaw-dropping.

Great value treat. I have been going to the Budapest Opera for many years and thoroughly enjoy the performances. Even though they may not be world class they put on some enjoyable performances which have occasional stand out singers and unusual avant garde productions. Most recently I went to see 'Die Frau ohne Schatten' and at over 3 hours the lack of padding on the seats was telling. If you suffer when the seats are hard do yourself a favour and take a small cushion. The other production on my this most recent visit to Budapest was 'Tosca' with an outstanding vocal from the visiting Italian tenor as Mario Cavaradossi. Our visit was only marred by the visiting British Opera snob sitting next to us who did nothing but complain. Good value and a lovely night out, and bookable on line before you go

A Classic Opera House. The Hungarian State Opera House is a magnificent building. We saw Romeo and Juliet and had seats in the third row. The acoustics are wonderful and the entire building is a classic, similar to the Paris Opera House. If you have interest in beautiful buildings or opera, be sure to visit! There are also tours available during the day.

Stunning building and great overall experience for a "Opera first-timer". On Sunday evening me and my mum were walking down the avenue thinking of something to do, walked past the Opera around 18:35 and thought to look at the programme and maybe buy tickets for a show on Monday or Tuesday. When we walked in realised a show was about to start and asked if there were any available tickets left, and there were!! Paid only £20 for two, for pretty decent seats on the balcony. Had to use the side entrance to get to the right floor and there was a crazy amount of stairs, my mum has problems walking and no one has told us about it, so it took a long while to get upstairs, to the 5th floor (I think). But when we got there we easily found our seats and enjoyed the whole thing! Great experience!

well worth a visit. This building is very impressive and one of the larger Opera houses in Europe. We enjoyed three nights here of varying Operatic styles. Even the best seats are good value compared to say London or Paris.

Wonderful. First visit to Budapest. About a week before I thought, hmm wonder if we can get to see a performance rather than just do a tour. And so it was! Not the best seats, but for £4 for two people, what can you expect. Wonderful performance in fabulously opulent surroundings. Next time I'll think ahead and book better seats!
A nice tour. I visited the Opera house during August, so there weren't any shows going on due to the summer vacation, and it was a pitty. The tour inside were very nice and enjoyable though.
Tosca. A wonderful evening in this most impressive building. Easy to get tickets online. Also had dinner in the restaurant next door - Call as - very good.

OMG!. We got last minute discounted tickets to Tosca through our hotel (Butterfly Home). What luck!!! We got to see this most magnificent building and enjoy a brilliant performance all from the 8th row, centre. It just doesn't get much better. You can take public trans to the Opera stop (go figure)...conveniently located--so accessible for those of us who rarely get this kind of opportunity, it was amazing!
Wonderful Experience. Went to see the ballet Coppelia. I was surprised at how well priced the tickets were. The opera house is magnificent.

must see. An Opera House keeping its vibrancy is nowadays, unfortunately rare. But here, you feel the glamour and flair. If you are in the Budapest, it is must-see even if you are not over familiar with opera and ballet productions. It won't waste your time and mind!

Very Opulent. Opera houses are like cathedrals, you just feel the need to tour them when you are on vacation. This one is really nice and the tour was informative and long enough to take it all in. There was an extra charge of 500 HUF for a 'photo pass' to allow you to take pictures, which seemed a little odd - although we have been in some that don't allow photography at all, so you decide.

Wonderful ballet at the state opera house. We went to the ballet at the state opera house for "Coppelia".The opera house itself is not very big - but beautiful!The ballet was excellent and the dancer were very talented. I would recommend to go for hungarian champagne in the break and take a step out on the terrace.

Beautiful Building; So-so Tour. Our guide seemed rushed and nervous, which made this experience less rewarding than it could have been. If you want to see the short performance that often comes after the tour, you must buy tickets in advance for that as well. (No last-minute decisions.)

just Beautiful. An invitation for Tosca and there I was, in this beautiful place bringing you back to history.
The performance was great and would recommend highly once in Budapest is this a Must.
Great House, less great singing. Great house. You may not be able to see stage if you choose the cheapest seats. The singing of Tosca the night we went was not memorable.

Beautiful Place. We lucked out here. We were walking by and decided to look at the lobby. Well a tour was just beginning, I asked one of the tourists in line where to buy tickets and he told me the gift shop. So we went there and got tickets and joined the crowd. We had a very good guide who spoke perfect English and gave us a very good tour of the whole building. It all ended up with a mini concert by a female opera singer that was just magical. Like I said, we lucked out that day!

Don't miss this on your trip to Budapest. On a recent trip to Budapest, we got tickets to the opera, The Woman Without a Shadow by Strauss. The performance was four hours long, including two intermissions, but was spectacular. The opulence of the opera house and the fabulous orchestra are not to be missed. Be sure to buy your tickets online before you go. It's a very easy process and seats are very affordable.

Christmas performance of the Nutcracker. Went with our family to the State Opera House to the ballet "The Nutcracker". Sat in the dresscircle in the front row and had a wonderful view. Beautiful experience in a wonderful setting. If you are in Budapest in December it would be a great experience. The Opera House is a majestic building and if you are wearing coats check them in. The children attending were dressed up but the adults just seemed to be wearing neat and tidy clothes so dont let that stop you from attending.

Did the tour and mini concert. We did the guided tour and had a very knowledgeable guide who spoke fluent English. The facilities and architecture were phenomenal. The tours were only offered at 3 and 4 pm on the days we were there. We walked right in for the 4 pm tour. We paid a few extra Euros to get a mini concert where a few operatic songs were sung. The only bad thing is you get charged extra to take photos inside.

Evening out. It is a beautiful building. Saw both the ballet & an opera on different nights. Wonderful performances. Easy to get a cab back to the hotel from the restaurant next door - BUT careful to not get one with a "cheater meter". One tried to charge me over 5 times the cost to return to the hotel.

Go See an opera. If you like music I would recommend going and actually see an opera. I had the pleasure to get that experience and it was amazing. The building itself is beautiful, but unfortunately not as beautiful as the Vienna Opera, so if you're going just for the building you might be a little disappointed when compared to other Operas in Europe.

Ball in the opera house. I was invited to this very noble event and I was really impressed and shocked, at the same time. White tie as dress code, must be self explaining. . Everything was on place, where you would expect it to be, on a place for 800€ for a walkibg ticket.. But this paradise was destroyed by the time. A welcome drink followed by 2nd one before "the show starts" was the only drink you received... You needed to make yourself a card, which you charded up with money, and paid with it on the bar.... Everything overpriced... Overall: Unspeakably amusing interiour! Just as acoustics! Top staff! Entertainment was expected (and indeed) best! No possibility to have a Free water (or any other drink) without the official chaeged card.

Short visit. Beautiful building, full of history. However, the visit is very short, and the young guide was not able to answer questions in English. Guided tours only, at 2 pm, 3pm and 4 pm. We didn't need to reserve.

Cheap seats, great thrill. I ordered tickets via the internet 3 weeks prior our arrival in Budapest. There was an an event in most theaters almost every night. Be sure to pick Hungarian Opera House. Out of our 3 nights, Tosca was playing the first night of a Uniworld cruise. I choose unobstructed top balcony which was 14.50USD. Warning: there is quite a flight of stairs approx 5 long shallow flughts flóors up and down. The sound and view was fantastic. The opera house is stunning. We were shocked with how many young people there were and filled with locals. Wear layers as it can get very warm. Seat are tight. I am only 5'6 and my knees hit the chair in front. Get there early to insure you find your proper seat. If you are late the ushers will place you in standing area. On that note, you don't want the last row in any section or you will have people breathing down your back. This was one of our highlights to Budapest.

Beautiful building, superb acoustics, real bargain- a must!!. After reading the Budapest Opera House is rated third in Europe (behind La Scala and Garnier), we decided to give it a try. Once I looked at the tickets costs (Tosca performance), I was pretty perplexed- $10.00 USD for two??? SOLD!!Anyway, fast forward to performance night- opera house is very magnificent, music, libretto, performance and overall atmosphere were truly amazing and uplifting- a cultural treat! Go- you will not regret!
tosca. fab building cheap seats!! well worth a visit we booked on line and printed tickets off £4.00 each bargain and no queueing

Cultural treat. Stepping into the Opera House is like going back in time! We saw a performance of Coppelia by the Hungarian National Ballet it was a magical introduction to the ballet for my daughter.

stunning place, great performance. The building is beyond gorgeous, every balcony, staircase and chandelier. We bought our tickets late in the afternoon, got 5th row, center. We could see the drop of perspiration on the tip of the guest pianist's nose. It was incredible.

Absoultely beautiful and a must see. This has got to be one of your stops while visiting this city. We were amazed at the overall beauty of the building itself and tried to get last minute tickets to a show while there, but they were completely sold out. Our fault..we didn't realize how big the opera is and should have made advance reservations for it.

Over the top Opera House and great performance. Wonderful kind of Baroque opera house. We had a "box" and the performance of Cossi Fan Tuti was just exquisite. A totally enjoyable evening for fraction of N.American costs. The story goes the when Budapest wanted to build an Opera House, Emprorer Franz Josef said it cannot be bigger then Vienna's. So they built it smaller but a lot more opulent; Franz was NOT impressed.
Opera elegance. Old world elegance and glamour abound but creature comforts do not. No elevator, uncomfortable unpadded seats, and inadequate ladies' room facilities (what else is new?).

Fabulous Experience. The Opera House is absolutely gorgeous! It is modeled on the Vienna Opera House, but is smaller. This means that it only holds 1200+ people in a building with great acoustics. Unlike most large opera houses, the performers are not "miked." Skip the tour and just go see an opera! You can reserve online before arriving in Budapest. Note that the state subsidizes the opera company. This allows the cost of tickets to be much, much less than one would pay in the USA. And, you will never see an opera in a more beautiful setting.
See an opera and pass on the tour. Beautiful interior. The tour was very crowded, however. Wish we could have seen a live performance but it was sold out for the nights we were in Budapest.

Wonderfull building. It worth to take a visit - if you have not chance to see a perfomance too!
My opinion is that our Opera House is much nicer than Wiener or London Covent Garden.Don't miss it!

Love it!. First time I ever went to opera and it was perfect. The music was wonderful and the building made the whole experience even more wonderful. You have to see it! And if you want to see "the show", you don't have to wear suit or dress, but I wouldn't recommend jeans either. Just simple clean and tidy clothes do fine.

Better than the Wien one. Set on one of the nicest avenues of the city this building is remarkable. Please visit inside or even watch an opera to see the beautiful interiors.
Please dress casual at least.

Definitely Worth the Price of Admission. During our visit to Budapest, we were lucky enough to be able to attend a Friday night symphony performance at the Opera House (we are classical music aficionados but not fans of opera). The lovely staff at our hotel (Hilton Budapest City) had explored several options at different venues. We really wanted to visit the Opera House and jumped at the chance. I don't recall the price but I believe it was around $35 USD per ticket for the upper level - definitely reasonable. The building was beautifully ornate, just as you would expect, and the concert was outstanding (Tchaikovsky). The best part was being squeezed in among the locals and witnessing their traditions (certain ways of clapping, etc.) and their genuine enthusiasm for the music and the conductor.If you have an opportunity to attend a concert in this venue, I highly recommend it! Note: We were in Budapest in December 2011. TA does not allow you to select dates more than a year in the past.

Beautiful Jewel of a Building. The Opera House is just a stunning, beautiful jewel of a building inside. It is not difficult to imagine what it must have been like in the early 1900's with women in gowns on the staircases. The acoustics are supposed to be one of the best according to Wikipedia, third behind La Scala and the Paris Opera House. Saw Tosca and enjoyed the show, was impressed that the singers were all Hungarian. Surtitles are in English and Magyar. As others have noted, seats are a *little* hard (not sure how one brings in their own cushion, but if you can figure out how to do that it might be helpful).

Great. This is a beautiful building and probably the oldest in Budapest. If you want to take photos on the tour then you have to pay a fee and there's a mini concert (an opera singer sings a couple of tunes) another fee. All in the tour was about 4000HUF (about £10). Definitely worth seeing an learning about.

The building is a work of art. We attended an opera and we were able to book a box as the prices are kept low. The building is beautiful, but the views of the stage are not great. English subtitles were given which made the performance easier to follow.

Opera in Budapest. Saw Cosi fan Tutti and Tosca. The seats are not really comfortable, but maybe that is not what is most important although it certainly plays a role. Cose fan Tutti was entertaining, Tosca was in part good.

A very good experience. This was my second visit here and it was for "Tosca". It was a very good production with good voices, sets and orchestra. The inside of the Opera House is so lovely though I do find the seats (even in the stalls) a little thin - I did notice several people with cushions as I went in to the auditorium. Staff were very helpful and I will certainly be returning on my next visit to the city.

One of the most beautiful houses in world. Not in so good shape from outside but go see it from inside. Really nice operahouse. If you want go see a show, you should, there is also really cheap tickets to get.

first opera. Went with my husband to see an opera here one night during our vacation. The opera house is beautiful. We sat on the main floor and had a good view. The opera itself was outstanding. The performers were amazing. The opera we attended was Cosi fan tutte and was a 3 hour long show. This opera was in Italian but there were subtitles above the stage so we were able to understand what was going on :)

Fabulous performance of Tosca.. My husband and I attended a performance of Tosca in the Opera House. We had two seats in one of the boxes with a good view of the stage. The opera house is an extremely beautiful building. Very impressive. The tickets were well priced and the performance was very enjoyable.

A night at the opera. First experience of attending the opera. Loved it! Tickets were so reasonably priced and easy to book online in advance from the UK. It was fantastic to see so many young people there (including some children).

Tour and an Aria. The building is magnificent, the tour is well organized and packed with information. Our English speaking tour guide was delightful, entertaining and spoke clear and fluent English. BUT - the mini-concert that followed the tour was a miracle in about six minutes. A costumed mezzo soprano stepped out from behind the curtains and sang two arias . We were about four feet away from her glorious singing. We don't even like the opera very much. BUT being this close, this personal, was something unusual and wonderful. Highly recommend (although other guests heard a lute player, not so impressive). The first aria (don't know the name of it) was so sad (even though it was in Italian) that many in this small audience burst into tears. A rare treat indeed.

Nothing Compares. Have visited lots of opera houses but nothing comes close to this lovely palace for opera. Attended a production of a Mozart's opera and was quite bowled over by the beauty and richness of the building. Fabulous experience to enjoy an opera in this historical stately opera house. Just wish the seats had cushions!!!

Very expensive for a guided tour. For €11 you get a 30 minutes tour in English with approximately 20+ people. For an extra €2 if you want to take picture.Undoubtedly you see a grand building with paintings and marble stairs. I would watch an opera to experience the 48 meters deep stage and a hydraulic managed orchestra pit. The most expensive ticket is €60.

Interesting history - but no behind the scenes view. Fabulous building with an interesting history but no chance to see behind the scenes. There was a big government reception the next evening so security may have been tightened but if you want to get an insight into how a major theatre works you would be disappointed. Check what you get before you book!Extra 500Huf to take photos (worth it) and 600 to hear an opera singer perform two short songs lasting 5 minutes in the bar area (not sure about that). We did buy tickets for a performance of "Cose fan Tutte" and although I am not an opera fan it was a good experience and I am glad I went. Excellent guides with good English.
Beautiful place. It's a beautiful place to visit. The concert (Liszt's music) was good, the pianist was great, playing fast with brio.

Cosi fan tutte (Mozart). Great performance - just perfect! Oct. 19th, 2014Budapest Opera is one of my favorite Opera houses in Europe besides Milan and Dresden. Classical old style with excellent acoustics.

Rip Off. the only disappointment during our budapest visit. Did the tour only which was only 30 minutes by the time they decided who was guiding. Far too many in each english group. Must of been 40 people approx in each group. Unless you were tied to the guides you missed the majority of information. They charges 2900 hf and then you were asked for extra to use your camera and extra for short mimi concert , not in concert hall . I was also annoyed as I asked to use toilet prior to tour to be told I could not go then, but there was opportunity a couple of minutes into tour. 45 minutes later! No chance. Felt like a schoolchild! A rip off. Get them in, get their money and get them out! That was the feeling that left me., be warned!
Very expensive to go in.. We would have liked to have done a tour and also attended the short concert but unfortunately the time we had was limited and the price was too expensive to warrant it.

Don't Ask to Use the Lift in the interval!. Beautiful building, and the cheapest way to see it is to by an opera ticket! However, my husband had just had knee surgery and asked if there was a lift - well let's just say it was an interesting event and the staff were not too helpful!
It was still a WONDERFUL VISIT - a must see

Falstaff was great, very pretty opera house. Easy to walk to, or take subway, which is directly in front of the building. Helpful staff. We were in a box, front row. I am six feet tall, and didn't find it too cramped as some reviewers did. I would have been less happy if I was in back row of box. No one commented on us bringing drinks back to box at intermission. Good view of the stage, acoustics good. Ladies: how silly, though, there are TWO stalls in the bathroom causing a long line, so don't hesitate at intermission to get on line.

A must for fans of opera. You can do a tour of the building, but we really recommend to go for the real thing and get tickets for an opera. We went to see Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutte. The building itself is stunning, truly one of the top opera halls in the world, everything seems to be covered with plated gold. The opera itself was top-class, great singing and an equally great orchestra. This specific Mozart-opera is very suited for those who do not know opera, it is light and humorous. Libretto is projected on a screen above the stage in English and Hungarian.Just be aware break is short and getting something to drink is not easy.
going to the opera. This was a wonderful chance to listen to talented opera singers, even though I bought a last-minute ticket.
Amazing Performance. My first opera. Amazing. Great voices, good sound and a fantastic price at only $7CAD or 1500 forint. Highly recommended for the budget traveler or music lover.

Opulent at its best. The opera house is a must see. Have to see a show and enjoy walking into it then once you enter the Opera House you are spellbound by what you see. They have heating channels running along each row keeping you warm in winter. Your camera will be happy snapping because of the beauty that you see. You will leave in amazement as to what you just experienced
Great tour. Tour was absolutely fantastic: and at the end we enjoyed two musical performances, especially the song from La Traviata made us to applause!
great company. SAw two opers, Cosi Fan Tuti and Falstaff, both world class productions. The music was perfect the staging wonderful and the productions were a pleasure to see.

Dave G. A must see for the ornate architecture. Many tours stop here but I highly suggest going to an actual performance . We had a lovely time and they show English subtitles above the stage so you can follow along with the arias.
Private tour. We had a private tour of the opera house. The guide spoke excellent English and provided much information about the site we even had a mini concert by one of the mezzo sopranos.
Opera House, catch a performance. Easy and cheap to get tickets to view a performance, definitely the best way to view inside this beautiful building.

Overcrowded and disappointing guided tour. We visited the opera on a guided tour. The guide was not very involved in the presentation of the opera and its history and more or less seemed to be reeling off a rehearsed manuscript. Her English was in many instances hard to understand due to a heavy Hungarian accent and strange English pronunciation. There were around 40 people on the tour, which was clearly too many. There were tours in several languages conducted at one time, which resulted in eg. two goups of visitors being at the main concert hall at the same time making it even more difficult to hear and understand the guide.All in all, the opera is very impressive and beatifully restored and decorated. However, the guided tour was not very rewarding and at the price of 2900 HUF/person for a 45 minute tour on the above conditions, it seems a little steep. Add to that that you will need to buy an addiotional 'photo ticket' if you want to be able to take pictures inside the opera!

an appreciation of what goes into an opera. the opera house is a beautfil building but the organized tour that we took gave us the history behind the scenes and the tour guide told us some very entertaining stories that brought the opera house to life-well worth it! we did not opt for the mini concert afterwards.
Romantic and historic Place. How can you avoid from imagine Franz List piano´s sound on your head,or the fantastic gipsy violins chords fullfilling your wishes of a romantic era?
Exquiset. A trip to the past with great tour guides. A look well into design and architecture of a bygone era.
Symbol of Decadence. The Opera House stands as a reminder of the wealth of the city. The building is decadent. It's worth a look if you have a few hours. It not, at least walk around the building.

Splendid Opulence a Must To See. We couldn't manage a concert at the Opera House but got on one of the guided tours which takes you into intimate corners you wouldn't normally see. Built at the height of Franz Joseph's reign, the interior shows off the opulence of the Hapsburg empire to great effect with gold leaf and rich marble the main eye catching ingredients. The excellent tour guides show you around royal staircases and private boxes and tell you absolutely everything about the building and more besides. The stage is almost twice as big as the auditorium and it must be fabulous to watch a big cast performance on it. Great tour. Don't miss it.

Beautiful building. The opera house is beautiful inside. Very ornate. The tour is very interesting and you learn some history of the building. They do a couple of tours in various languages every day at 3 and 4pm. Highly recommended.
Fantastic. It definitely worths visiting and paying a little bit more for a ticket, otherise you cannot see that many things from the top seats! wonderful atmosphere and decoration!

Beautiful structure on Andrassy Street. Beautiful Baroque architecture inside and out. Located on the beautiful Andrassy street, it offers tours inside and tickets for events. Tickets are quite reasonable.

Nice Opera House. Liked the Opera House tour that gave us an overview of the music life in Hungary as it was created by the Austria Hungary government comparing it to the Opera House at Vienna I did not like the mini concert that you pay for this and you get it while you stand (not seated) in one of the corridors instead of sitting in the Opera hall and listen to a short concert (even if it is 5 minuets only).

Take a tour of the facility to see the grandeur. We basically fell into a tour of the opera house before the season had begun. If there had been a performance we would have gone to see it, but the beauty of the structure and the history are worthwhile if you have any interest in music venues.
Attend a performance. We went on a tour of the place but enjoyed it even more when we attended a performance. I'm not sure the tour was worth it to me.

Saw Tosca, and it was amazing. The Opera House is stunning. Travelers take note - the seats are very close together and so you must be prepared to be a bit jammed in. I sprung for a box and was surprised to have three across (in a space really for 2), and have 4 people sitting behind me on benches. It wasn't what I expected from a box seat at all. The Opera offers translation to English and Hungarian which was nice and the performers were very good. One caveat, they do serve food/drink (limited selection) but you need Euros. They don't take any form of card - which meant I had to go to the gift shop to buy water (as it was very stuffy inside).
Russian Language Tour--informational and enjoyable. Greatly enjoyed our official Opera House Tour and a short concert at the end. Definitely a must for Budapest stay, even if short

Beautiful opera House with interesting contemporary performance. Definitely see this beautiful opera House. If you have the time, go to the opera as well. We got second row tickets online about two weeks before - 2 of us for about $100. If we'd planned further ahead, a box would have been the best option as the seats looked much more comfortable than the stiff wooden, uncushioned ones we were in. That said, the space is spectacular and the opera was good (strong orchestra, skilled singers and contemporary interpretation). A must (and enjoy a meal before or after next door at callas)

ugly foreign tourists. Get out of your mindset of "sampling" an opera here. Opera is serious business. Would you go see Henry IV without first re-reading the text just to make sure you will understand it? How can you expect to really enjoy an opera if you havent the foggiest what it is all about? Ever heard of Wikipedia? Know how to do a google search? Know the meaning of "libretto"?The strength of the Budapest opera lies in its ability to present richly costumed performances with strong chorus, ballet, and orchestral support. Rarely do you get big stars here-- simply unaffordable. But solid, thoughtful, engaging productions. Titles are now in both Hungarian snd English. I buy tickets months in advance and go to every production available when i am here. This time my 17 tickets cost me about $200. Cheapest seats in St. Louis are around $40, I can only imagine what they must be in DC, LA, NYC. Dont forget the Erkel Színház either. Here is where you find the big productions...Aida, Turandot, Trovatore. Also it has been renovated in the last couple of years..seats are wider and there is more legroom.
Beautiful building. it is beautiful. Very similar to the Vienna opera house, however smaller. The Budapest Opera House seems to have kept its authentic feel and character. Worth a visit.

Some seats have no leg room. Beautiful building, but make sure to get a seat along a railing. We first tried sitting in the normal seats in the middle rows, but I literally couldn't fit my knees below the seat in front of me. I'm a normal height of 6'. We changed seats to the row along the edge of the upper balcony with a railing overlooking the floor below and had plenty of space.

Seeing an Opera is only $10 more than touring the house!. After a bit of investigation on my friends part, we learned that seeing an opera was going to cost only $10 more than simply touring the Opera House. So, we saw Cavilleria Rusticana by Pagliacci. AWESOME experience! The acoustics are incredible as is the setting. Go to the Opera... just go!
Opera. Really worth a visit-especially if you can get a box-beautiful building & good opera; terrace at front gives good views

Attend a performance to get the full experience. We'd ordered tickets online so all we had to do was turn up on the evening.
