The building is simply stunning and the performers were in fine form on the evening we attended. During intervals we went out on the outdoor balcony for a night time view of Andrazzy Utca and to enjoy a glass of bubbly. As for a dress code: the entire fashion spectrum paraded by before our eyes, from threadbare jeans to full-on gala gowns - so it's anybody's guess, but definitely entertaining to watch.

Well worth a trip. I have been 4 times and the performances have always been superb. However you should not use a Balcony if you want to see anything and the stalls are all on one level. It is however a really beautiful building and the tour is fascinating.

Beautiful venue to enjoy an Opera. The Opera House is spectacular and one I know is a jewel to the Hungarian people. They should be proud of this treasure that they have.We went to the matinee of Cavalleria Rusticana and Pagliacci on a Sunday. The performances were heartfelt and moving. The cast was splendid and had you engaged in their interactions and the story of both. The audience so appreciated the performance there were numerous curtain calls for both productions.We got our tickets late and had seats stage right thinking it would be an obscured view but we were in the second row, could see everything and were happy with the seats. Once again I will say the tickets were a fraction of the cost of a live Opera in the states.If you are traveling here and get the opportunity to see an Opera, it will be something that you will never forget.

A Must in Budapest. My boyfriend and I attended Tosca here in September. The quality of the opera was fantastic and the building is gorgeous. As others have said, the cost of tickets is very reasonable. We couldn't find much information about dress code, but I would say a short but nice dress for women is fine and men can wear business casual. I saw men both with and without a jacket. Of course, if you want to get dressed up go for it. There will be others very dressed up too.

Gorgeous architecture and furnishings but very crowded. We booked a tour in English and we must have had over 50 people in our group PLUS, there were 7 other groups in different languages. Our guide had to yell and it was organized chaos. BUT, the opera house is stunningly beautiful and worth seeing. We paid to take photos and for the mini-concert afterwards. I would do both again. Our guide was well-informed, had fun stories and managed to keep us all entertained. So many people suggested seeing it, we are glad we did

One of the most beautiful if not THE most beautiful opera houses in Europe. When I visited I could not find any production that I wanted to see but I looked around inside of this beautiful building. Serendipitously I found a gift shop that had unique, mostly music related, gifts.

Wonderful night. Stunning architecture , great atmosphere as the audience arrive to take their seats . Even if you are not an opera fan, it cannot help but impress. Saw 2 small operas - Pagliacci and Cavalleria rusticana

The guided tour is excellent. The State Opera is well worth the time for a visit. The only way to see the interior is to take one of the frequent quided tours, a requirement which I sometimes find discouraging. The tour is informative, interesting and avoids the all-too-common pitfalls of endless and mind-numbing historical litanies.

Wonderful. Very ornate and beautiful building. Regal staircases, marble, crystal and paintings abound. Not to be missed. We had a mini-concert which was fine but it would have been great to have the time to sit and enjoy a performance in the actual theatre.

Great guide - she spoke excellent English - asked for questions periodically.. We took the English tour of the Opera House and it was a well worthwhile experience. Our guide spoke excellent English and was quite knowledgeable about the history, materials used, etc in the Opera House.
Highly reccommend.
Great Tour!. Wonderful informative tour of the Opera House .. Great performance by the singer in the Mini Concert

Hear an opera in this spectacular place and you'll quickly become spoiled.. Come early to savor this restored and world-class opera house where the musicians are first class. You'll treasure this experience, even if you're not an opera lover, and it will all be tons cheaper than in the U.S. One of the great wonders of Budapest is its classical music and the Opera House is its finest venue.

Magnificent. We did an Opera House tour and was not disappointed, quite wonderful. Stunning architecture. The theatre itself is very grand and it would have been fantastic to have experienced an Opera or Ballet there.

Visit of the Opera in Budapest. There were offered conducted tours in several languages.
One Group separated for each language.
After the tour we attended a Mini-Concert (two popular songs
from two Verdi Operas performed by a Singer (Soprano) and her CD-player in a separate saloon, so I could not admire the famous original acoustic of this Opera in Budapest!
Beautiful.... I stayed just few meters away from the Opera House, but didn't manage to watch any opera. However went inside (the main hall) and architecture is brilliant.

Saw Tosca in this beautiful opera house - seemed a smaller replica as Vienna. What a beautiful venue- worth seeing versus doing a tour. Was my first opera (bucket list item I wanted to experience). I must admit the big break between the 3 parts really turned the evening into an slightly arduous 3 hour outing. FYI even though in Italian - there is a video teleprompter above the stage in English and Hungarian. Starts promptly at 7pm- no delays. Dress code is between smart casual and gowns- do what feels right for your evening. Seats are a bit uncomfortable. Best seats are the first floor section or rows 1 or 2 of the second level. I'm not sure if the 3rd or 4th level would make any sense to experience. Street Trolley can be used for transportation. We bought tickets very reasonably through their web site very last minute, so my group say apart - which really didn't matter much at all. Price is amazingly reasonable by American standards.

Buy a ticket for an opera or full concert -- you won't regret it!. We lucked out by stopping by on the evening of the Opera's 130th anniversary gala. We were able to buy box tickets just before the event even though the event was nearly sold out (and the seats were well worth the reasonable price), and the event was truly spectacular. The evening consisted of a shorter (compressed) opera (which was part of the first opera performed when the operahouse opened in 1884), then a film celebrating the history of the opera and various performers, a short choral performance, and finally, an incredible and energetic premiere of a modern dance set by Robert Norris (which was full of movement and African beats, and had a bit of humor as well). I absolutely loved the breathtaking dance portion and would gladly pay to see the performance again. The dancers truly electrified the audience. I should also say that the opera performance was also first rate and featured spectacular sets and costumes. Another fun part of the evening was that there were 100-150 people in period costumes (circa 1884), and they appeared to be together from a local music high school or college academy. They were certainly having fun, and we truly enjoyed this window into Hungarian culture. After the concert, fireworks lit the sky above the opera house. Again, the performances were professional and top-notch, and what value with the ticket prices as they are! The venue itself is also incredibly beautiful, and you can just feel the history in the building. I saw that some reviewers have had negative experiences when just doing a tour or a short "mini-concert," but I can say that coming for a full-length performance is a very different experience. If you are in Budapest for even just one night, it is worth it to buy a ticket for a full-length performance here. Truly amazing experience and wish we could go back for another opera or dance experience.

Awe Inspiring!. We bought tickets for the first symphony of the year - three Russian composers with a guest Russian pianist. Third floor box seats, near center, second row - a little over $17 USD. The opera house was classy in the gilded style of other famous European venues. The acoustics were fantastic, performance amazing - two piano encores after the Rachmaninoff. My recommendation is splurge for front row of box seats or orchestra rows as we had an obstructed view and stood through much of the concert to watch the players. Balcony is very high, yet good views, especially first row. Concert lasted 2.5 hours, and we (two women) felt totally safe walking .75 miles back to our apartment.

A Night To Remember. When you walk in just be prepared for luxury and beauty. My fondest memories where made there. My booth was on the third floor on the far right next to the press box. It's truly a magical place. I was there on opening night when the filmed sleeping beauty. The costumes and makeup well what can I say, just spectacular. One of my favorite things always was the intermission. You can get a drink and go out onto the roof top to look down at the people walking along the streets. Miss it very much and very fortunate to have been there many times.Enjoy Sarah

So very impressive. Most efficient booking on line. Just visiting the Opera House could be enough it is so beautifully restored but added to that we saw two ballets. The first Trojan games was very modern and athelic then Les Sylphides beautifully performed. The bar area (a lovely ornate room) had a balcony overlooking the old ballet school, people were smoking there but it was a lovely area to see Budapest at night.

Wished we'd booked an opera performance!. We are opera fans and try to visit various opera houses when we travel abroad. The interior was in grand European form. We selected the "mini concert" and it isn't really so. There were two arias nicely presented by a costumed singer, however, the location was crowded and standing was the only option. So my recommendation is to take the tour, skip the "mini concert".

INCREDIBLE. Absolutely mind boggling Opera House. There was nothing for us to see as they only had Ballet on and we werent interested in that. However the guided tour was wonderful and in English. Stunningly beautiful restoration. Recommend it.

Well worth a visit. A beautiful building. The guided tour was a little rushed and crowded, hence the 4 star rating. There was a mini concert afterwards which I had thought would allow me to hear the acoustics but in fact it was held in the bar. Worth a visit anyway.

Dissapointing. The Opera House is quite lovely. We chose a tour with a mini concert.The crowds were heavy and the organizationwas almost non excitant. The tour guides couldnot be heard. The mini concert was in a jammedroom and also poorly handled Very disappointingand no reason for it not being organized and amarvelous experience.

Mini-concert...I think not!. So we are not opera fans and thought that a 3 hour 'real' opera would be too much, so we opted for the Opera tour with mini-concert.The visit is #1, the French speaking guide was great and the building is spectacular.Unfortunately, the tour ends in the side room where the intermission bar is located.An opera singer in costume came out with her tape recorder (aka gettho blaster) and sang to a few tunes. Her voice is fine, but it's such anticlimactic... We came out laughing about the odd ending with others, thinking of how lame this was... Since the only the last 5 minutes of the tour are awful, this one gets an 'average' rating.

Spectacular elegance. The staggering Hungarian State Opera House is a richly decorated building in neo-Renaissance style with numerous baroque elements featuring on the façade and it's equally opulent interiors, located in the very heart of Budapest, in Andrássy Avenue, one of the most beautiful boulevards in the world. The building was originally known as the Hungarian Royal Opera House and is considered the masterpiece of architect Miklós Ybl, a major figure in 19th century Hungarian architecture. Construction was co-funded by the City of Budapest and the Emperor Franz-Joseph, and the Opera House opened to the public on the 27 September 1884.Numerous important opera-singers and musicians have since performed there, Ἐva Marton made her débout in 1968, followed by Sylvia Sass in 1971 who also made her first professional operatic appearance on it's stage; the composer Gustav Mahler was the Opera's Chief Conductor for four years (1887 -1891) and Otto Klemperer, one of the leading conductors of the 20th century, has been it's music director from 1947 to 1950.Although it is not one of the largest Opera Houses, it had the advantage of surviving the horrors of World War II and of emerging unscathed through the vicissitudes of the Communistic Era. As years went by though there was the immediate need for a series of extensive renovation works which began in 1980 and lasted for about four years, making thus the reopening on the 27th of September 1984 to coincide with the exact centenary of the Opera House. In consequence, although it completely adheres to the typical layout of a traditional 19th century Opera House, visitors nowadays may admire a completely and masterfully renovated perfectly functional Opera House. From the richly ornate Entrance Hall one is guided over a very grand sweeping staircase to a series of vast grandiose public spaces which provide the opportunity for people to mix socially and enjoy a glass of champagne during intervals. The auditorium is magnificent in appearance and semicircular in shape, with an approximate capacity of about 1,260 and according to entirely unsubstantiated rumours -at least hitherto not supported by any scientific evidence- boasts the third best acoustics in Europe after La Scala and the Palais Garnier in Paris. A three-storey high sumptuously decorated series of tiers of boxes fully occupy the sides of the horseshoe shaped auditorium, culminating in the very imposing ex- Royal Box which is located at it's very centre, presently offering the best view towards the large stage and the orchestra pit to the President of the Hungarian Republic and to visiting Heads of States. It is richly decorated with full-sized gilded sculptures on pedestals representing the personifications of the four operatic voices: soprano, alto, tenor and bass.A glittering giant bronze chandelier weighting more than three tons is suspended over the middle of the auditorium. Young children and bored members of the audience usually spend long periods of time calculating what damage would ensue if the chandelier accidentally happened to fall on unsuspected members of the audience. It illuminates a beautifully executed rather populous fresco by the German-Hungarian painter Károly Lotz, entirely inspired by Greek mythology and depicting an apotheosis of the god Apollo.Tours take place daily and twice, at 15.00 and 16.00 and are given in English, Spanish, French, Italian and German; all languages start and end at the same time.Tours in Japanese are given on Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and each Sunday there are also tours in Hungarian. Each tour lasts for about 45 minutes. Tickets can be bought directly at the Opera Shop, to the right of the entrance hall, immediately upon entering through the main entrance of the building.English speaking visitors are usually the most numerous, so if you master any other of the languages in offer, do opt going for a tour in this other language, it's so incredibly less crowded which makes guides naturally much more relaxed and your experience much more pleasurable.At the end of every tour, visitors may decide staying behind and listening to a "mini recital" of about 5 additional minutes, which includes two arias performed by a professional opera singer from the Opera House. This recital takes place in the Opera's very ornate Main Foyer and I would most warmly recommend it, not only because it costs a mere extra £2 to your original Adults Opera Tour Ticket, which is about £11 per person, but because it is the perfect musical ending to an Opera House tour.At the end of our visit a very beautiful lady commenced singing "Oh mio babbino caro" from Puccini's Gianni Schicchi, which was followed by a rendition of the "Brindisi" from Verdi's La Traviata. She was not Maria Callas but her interpretation was very theatrical and she had charm, grace and musicality in her performance.If you are not lucky enough as to assist at a live opera performance, then this very professionally organised and equally well operated tour is the next best thing to explore this absolutely outstanding building.

Great building, disappointing visit. Opening time is short, visitors crowd and groups mix.We payed an extra for a "mini concert", expecting to hear some little music in the main hall, but we got six minutes baritono while standing in the hot and crowded bar area.Deceiving.
Beautiful Building. Yet another stunning building in Budapest. Set in wonderful surroundings on Andrassy Street. The facade is stunning and the interior truly spectacular.
Concert visit. We booked on the day for a sympony concert in the evening. Much better than a walk around daytime tour. Not expensive to go to the opera here. Definitely worth a visit.

WOW!. What a beautiful building. Recently restored to its original splendour, I doubt there are more than two other opera halls that can compete. This place is designed in the opulent fashion of the early 20th century. The craftsmanship in the woodwork, gold and metalwork are of the highest quality as befits its original Austo-Hungarian aristocratic audiences. Take the guided tour. It explains all.
Beautiful Architecture and inside decor. Just a very beautiful building and restored decor inside. The design and colors inside make this a must stop on any visit to Budapest.

Travel back in time. We were fortunate to find a Sunday Matinee of Figaro playing while we were in Budapest. This magnificent and famous Opera House is well worth a visit and, if possible, enjoy an opera performance and pay for a Box like we did - a fantastic experience. If unable to take in a show they have Opera House tours - better that than nothing. A beautiful old building. Go to Opera Station on the Metro.
Nice. A nice opera house with some nice stories around it. Guided tour was good but felt a bit pricey for what was offered.

This was near the parliament. We didn't go inside but it appeared to have some famous composers on top of the building. One was a Jewish composer which the Nazis tried to knock down. Its still there i believe
Fantastic.. We paid 2500 to sit in the gods and watch 2 short brilliant ballets and I think the tour of the opera house cost more.
Cav. & Pag.. Excellent music and singing. Superb theater with brilliant frescoes/murals.Seats are very hard! The bar service at the interval needs a better system.
Great opera house and performance. A great venue and a Great performance of Puccini. Acoustics were excellent, sat on box on l side of stage.
stunning. Amazing theatre. stunning artworks on walls and ceilings. Breathtaking performance at reasonable cost.

Simply Glorious. One of Europe's grand dames of opera houses. It is richly decorated and will transport you back to the time of Franz Jozef who ordered that it not be larger than the Vienna Opera House. They honored his stipulations on size but he was shocked that it was far more beautiful. Don't miss it as you walk up Andrassey St
Wonderful Setting. We saw a ballet performance here; the setting is incredibly grand. The booking was easy and tickets are very reasonable for the quality of the productions.

The highlight of my visit to Budapest!. I did not do a guided tour (these are normally at 3pm and 4pm). Instead, I treated myself to a full-priced ticket to see two modern ballets on the same evening: Troy and La Sylphide (cost just 12,000 Ft, great value). Both were sublime, in their own particular way. The interior of the opera house is magnificent. If you go to an evening performance make sure you get there early to enjoy the atmosphere and this wonderful building. Programmes are available in English, and English-speaking staff will assist you with any queries. Whilst many people had dressed up for the occasion, I didn’t get the impression that this was necessary. Smart casual attire is fine. This was probably the highlight of my visit to Budapest! Highly recommended.

a must see with great accoustics. Fabulous building and well worth a tour because this tiny opera house is beautiful but also has such a quirky and interesting background and you'll learn quite a bit about Hungarian history too. I went there a few times including for the Freedom Opera Gala - a free concert celebrating the 25th anniversary of the opening of the borders. I also caught an open air rehearsal by the orchestra and cast of an upcoming opera.

Great opera performance. We were there at the beginning of September and they had daily open performances in front of the opera, usually small but nice with the live music performed by the small orchestra. Last day of our stay in Budapest there was a free concert in honor to 25-th anniversary of Hungary's open of border, with stars like Piotr Beczala, Anja Kampe and Ferruccio Furlanetto, with free entrance. We paid also for the opera visit day before, but the experience was average, since it's more concentrated on the paintings and architecture that to music. Try to catch some performance rather and enjoy this marvelous place in its essence.

Unbleavable , excellent opera house inside. From outside looking not so attrractive. But inside was gold plated whole marvelous ,1300 + seating arrangment , one of place to must see in Budapest.tour guided in english was very informative. Whole Europe is full of history which they have preseved , & earning , every where is ticket to enter. Well done europe , they r very much ahead of most of the world.

Simply wonderful.. Our visit to the State Opera House was a delightful surprise. The production was simply wonderful, as are the acoustics. The music and costumes were absolutely breathtaking. If you have a chance to visit, don't miss it.

Opera House tour / visit. We bought tickets, at around AUD$13.50pp, for the opera house tour which was to begin at 3pm. There were many, many others waiting for the English tour so we decided to wait for the next one at 4.30pm which turned out to be just as crowded. Our guide tried her best but there were so many other tours at the same time in English, Italian and French and we were all in the same place at the same time, everyone competing for space, the guides all trying to be heard over each other that it was a waste of time. It's a lovely building and would have been worth seeing if it had been better organised - it took about 35 minutes and was not value for money. Unfortunately that's not the point as we would have liked to see more.

Baroque majesty. Ornate, opulent........and majestic, this temple to the art of opera was well worth the £8 for the guided tour. We gasped at the sheer magnificence of the marble interiors and the gilded columns. Go if you have can - it's worth it.
For Opera lovers. It is a long standing Opera House that has been updated keeping most of the original art work.the entrance is spectacular, the performances are first class.Nothing but the best!
Hungarian State Opera. This is special. A must visit for anyone who enjoys this area of the Arts. The Opera House itself is magnificent .

Overpriced Tour but sumptuous building. The only way to visit is on a tour, which runs at 3 and 4pm daily except Sundays. Tours get very crowded and noisy as each guide has to out shout the others if they are too close to each other. Why they cannot have different timings for different languages, I don't know. The majority of visitors are those who have coupons from other tourist services such as the hop on hop off bus tours so look for these coupons if you want a discount as the standard pricing is expensive and you have to pay extra to be able to take photos, and extra too to listen to a mini concert after the tour. It would be better to buy tickets to a performance if you can instead of taking the tour as you could see the best parts of the building without being on tour.The guide I had was a young girl who was spending so much energy shouting loudly one almost pitied her but her vocal cords were in good condition and she lasted the distance.

Beautiful and a performance too!. My family and I took the one hour handicap accessible tour of the Opera House. Beautiful ! At the end of the tour, for a few dollars more, we were entertained by a retired opera singer who performed two songs for us! What a treat! It was a guided tour and learned alot about the history of the Opera House too.

Opera in Pest. An average looking European opera house from the outside, yet magnificent inside. Make use of the guided tours, daily in English, just to see the wonderful décor, even if you are not interested in opera itself. Note: no opera performances in summer apparently.

Beautiful opera house, so-so tour. This is an amazing opera house, but the tour was a little disappointing. There was a large number of people touring the day we were there so they broke us up into 5 or 6 different, smaller groups, some based on language, but really didn't have much of a plan for the logistics of getting all of our groups through. The tour guide was ok, and told a few good stories but I would have hoped for more. Also, we didn't see anything backstage (as we had in Vienna). They also charged extra to take photos, which I didn't like. At the end they offered a 'mini-concert' for 2.5 eur each, which we thought might be a good chance to hear the hall's celebrated acoustics, except for that the mini-concert wasn't even in the auditorium, it was in one of the lobbies. It consisted of two arias sung by a a singer who was way past her prime so this was very disappointing

Well worth a look!. I'm so glad I followed my instincts and booked a tour of the Hungarian Opera House during a recent visit in Budapest. Although I wasn't in town when I could see an opera, I thoroughly enjoyed the tour of the building with a young lady who spoke beautiful English and gave us so much interesting information about the building. The tour was followed by a musical presentation by a gifted soloist who sang a couple of opera arias so beautifully that I was in tears. A statue of Franz Liszt, their most famous composer, stands in front of the building.

Opera Building. From outside... a beautiful building... haven´t gone inside, but all feedbacks are very positive.In concert dates, there are lot´s of people around... tourist and hungarians. Not expensive.

Opera House. The Opera House is not only one of the most significant art relic of Budapest, but the symbol of the Hungarian operatic tradition of more than three hundred years as well. Very nice building,
Very cheap and usually vry good. Good opera staged here. I saw a home-grown Hungarian one which was amazingly sung with great panache. It is a beatiful venue, if a bit hot
arhitecture top. The Opera House is an other great old building from the hungarian arhitecture.Only 5 minutes walk from the fantastic church St. Stephans Basillica.

Gorgeous building. Although this is a very small opera house, it is truly beautiful and worth the visit. We went in August so there were no operas being performed. Fortunately, as part of the tour, the Opera House included people who sang songs from various operas to give you a feel for the magic of the place.

The guide was right. Our guide of Budapest said that this opera was better than the one in Vienna, which is more famous, although we didn't go in or even stop. That provoked me to go back. It is indeed a beautiful opera house and very well maintained. I couldn't stay for the complete tour of the building. If you're an opera fan go to a performance during the season.

Do the tour!. If you only have a short time, try the tour. It cost 2900Huf ( £8 ) plus another 500Huf for the mini concert, you can take photos for free, and large parties get split into smaller groups, our guide was clear and interesting. Took about 45 mins altogether. Easy to get there, no trams in Andrassy U so get off the Metro at "opera" line 1 the yellow line . Trains run every two mins , Heroes square is four stops further on takes about 10 mins. Buy ten tickets for 3000 Huf at kiosk in the station, each journey is then 300 for as long as you want in one direction, equvalent to 80p and you can use them on the trams as well.

Beautiful!!!. Our family attended the opera, Tosca, at the State Opera House. It is a beautiful, beautiful venue!We had the front row seats in a box that afforded a great view of the stage. The only down side was that it was very,very warm during the performance. In fact, we left after the second act. It was just too hot for us. However, it was definitely worth the reasonable cost of the tickets. I will add, that if you do not have the front row seats in the boxes, your view of the stage could be very limited.

Beautiful building but a disappointing tour. The building is beautiful and well-worth a visit, but perhaps it is better to go to a performance than to go on the tour. There are tours in 6 languages, which would be a big plus if they weren't all done at the same time. It was like being in the general assembly hall of the United Nations. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and answered everyone's questions with incredible patience. The auditorium is very impressive.

Disappointing Tour. We paid for the English tour on a Friday afternoon. It turned out to be a cattle call. When we started the tour seated in the opera hall. Our too large group was surrounded by two other group with guides simultaneously talking in Italian and French. As a result we could hear very little. We gave up and requested a refund which was given with an apology for the situation. The limited bit of the Hall that we saw looked great. If you go be sure that you are not in a group of more than 15 or you will not get much out of it.

oh wow!!. Such a wonderful evening of Classical Music in this incredibly beautiful Opera House. You cannot miss the chance to be carried back in time through the romantic music, skilled musicians and ever so talented performers
beautiful restored operahouse. take a guided tour including a classic mini-concert. They have guides that speak many languages, he/she guide will tell you a lot of details and this is added value.

Beautiful!. I wish the opera company had been performing. But the building itself is more than worth the time and admission. This is a real gem of a theatre, reflecting the wealth of the Hapsburgs before WWI. I highly recommend it.

Wonderful. The State Opera House was only open for tours at 3:00 or 4:00We did the 3:00 tour. They separate the tours by languages spoken and it becomes a walking obstacle course walking around and past other groups! The tour guides do a great job! They offer a 5 minute Opera experience at the end of the tour which was amazing.I am glad we paid the few extra Huffs to see this! The main stage is closed for the summer and renovations were in progress but we got to see the entire building!
Excellent. It was superb, the only bad thing is that the visit is too short and a bit of caos before starting it

Beautiful building worth visiting. Very enjoyable hour which included a mini-concert. Superbly renovated with gold leaf glittering everywhere as well as beautifully carved woodwork & numerous staircases.

Pretty. My sister and I took the opera house tour and we both really enjoyed it. They do charge a bit extra to take photos. However, it is worth it to do so. (it was minimal) It is very lovely inside the opera house. Our tour guide was very good and informative. The gold leaf interior and beautiful ceilings, along with the beautiful mirrors were really worth seeing.

Nice Exteriors. Since we visited in July and performances did not start till late August we were not inside the building. We did not go for a tour since these are usually a waste of money. The building was undergoing renovations. The metro stop to our hotel was Opera so we saw it many times on the way to and from the hotel.

Wonderful building. Go and see the outside of the opera house and the lobby if you're short of time, but if you have an evening free go to an opera! The cheapest seats for an opera are much cheaper than the guided tour. My partner and I got two tickets for less than £10, and it was worth much more than that to see the fantastic orchestra and experience the acoustics of the hall. We saw Die Frau Ohne Schatten - the best experience of our few days in Budapest!

The tour was a complete waste of money. The building itself is beautiful but the tour was a complete shambles. They split you up into groups of different languages which is obviously a good idea in theory. However, you then complete with the different groups for space in the various rooms and its very difficult to hear when you have two or more guides all talking in different languages in the same room. The tour itself wasn't very long and was certainly not worth the money.

Gorgeous place. Absolutely beautiful building,wonderful performance! I don't remember when was a last time I went to opera performance. I was worried and we had an escape plan but for my surprise the songs were written on a digital board so I new what they were singing and it was really enjoyable.BUT: it was written in Hungarian and my husband doesn't understand it.He said it was delightful performance anyway.At intermission I was surprise to hear and see 80% of audience spoke English or other language than Hungarian. Why on the earth it is not written in English??

Family Vacation. Budapest is really a beautiful city and this opera house is one of its jewels. Did a tour during the daytime which was really informative regarding the beautiful art and history. Returned for an evening performance which was one of the highlights of our trip.
Wonderful stay. Just visited the lobby and was impressed. OUt of time so could not do the guided tour. But we were quite satisfied to see the exterior and the lobby!

Even if you're not an opera fan.... Even if you are not a classical music fan, I highly recommend attending any performance you can at the Opera House, just to enjoy the architecture and history of this exquisite building. Tickets are very reasonable, and easy to pick up at the Box Office.

A trip back into the Hapsberg era. Well worth the tour if you like architecture, this opera house was not really destroyed during the wars, it is almost as it was in the 1800s. A good English language tour.

Do the tour and enjoy the show. We're told that Austria only agreed to finance Budapest's opera house on the condition it could not be as big as Vienna's. The Hungarians responded by making theirs more opulent instead! Whether you believe that story or not, there's no denying how impressive the building is inside and out.Know that the State Opera House runs only two tour sessions a day across multiple languages. Watching the guides in action is a show in itself. With each tour group taking a different route, they have this down to a fine art, burning through a well-rehearsed script with efficiency and trademark Magyar detachment. Despite this, they're highly informative, happy to answer questions and the tour is very thorough.
Beautiful 19th century architecture. The Opera House is a magnificant bulding, inside and out. The ceilings are opulent and the wood work is incredible!
Maagnificent Architecture. The magnificent statuary that adorns this building makes it a must see even if only from the outsider. It sits on famous Andrassy Boulevard.

A real classical experience. If you love classical music, you appreciate the tradition and feel good in a luxurious,friendly ambience ... this is the place .The building is well proportioned, with wonderful decorations, intuitive and, most importantly,the scene visibility is very good from anywhere in the room .I saw a classic ballet (La Sylphide), great played and one modern (Troy game) alert, surprising and simply beautiful.An act of culture at the highest level ...do not miss a show here if you could.

Lovely but somewhat restricted tour. The Opera House is magnificent and we loved the presentation by our guide, especially the part about the air conditioning! However, we were not taken to the balconies to look out over the square whereas we saw other groups out there at previous times we had seen the Opera House so we were unhappy about that.

Worth the tour fee. Took the English tour just so I can get inside the opera. And it didn't fail me. The interior was really beautiful! The tour guide was explaining the history of the opera house, the function of each rooms, and the details of the interior. It's amazing to be in such historical and magnificent building. The tour was about 7.5 euro for student and lasted for around 45 minutes. But personally I think it's really worth it.
We took an English speaking tour for the "inside" of the building. Tour ended with a "mini" concert.We learned "all " that one should know about the building. little details, fascinating
Wow!!. This opera house was gorgeous! I was fortunate enough to watch the Nutcracker for the first time in this wonderful place. Certainly do not miss this!!

Classic Architecture. If walls could talk what stories could this beautiful building tell? Go for the tour through this classic opera house and enjoy! I couldn't help but compare it to the magnificent opera house in our city and think about our air conditioned comfort, perfect acoustics and comfortable seats! However, we have none of the history and grandeur of this beautiful structure. Enjoy the guide and the stories of the Kings and Queens, operatic greats who sang here, and history of this grand building.

Classic Opera House. Due to the crush of so many tourist tours, it was really hard to absorb everything that the guide covered about this place.It is a marvel that the building survived in such beautiful condition, you do get a feel for the rich cultural heritage of this place. A worthwhile tour due the the impressive nature of the opera building and it's cultural history.
Just beautiful!. no performances during summer holidays, but can take an organised tour through the building - worth seeing as its just stunning! architecturally with very grand interiors;

Impressive and beautiful.. A must for opera and music enthusiasts. If you are interested in seeing the inside, the guided tour is at 11am on Mondays, not in the evening as other days. Beautiful at night.

Really good. Being a big opera fan I was looking forward to the tour. But my son, who is 16, really was loathing this. Well, it was 45 minutes very well spent. The tour itself was really informative. My 16-year old didn’t complain, but rather learned quite a few interesting facts and even enjoyed the opera signing that we were lucky enough to witness during the tour. The structure itself is magnificent, so even if you are not a big opera fan, make sure you go in to enjoy this piece of art The tour is offered only at 3pm and 4pm on a daily basis, not sure about Saturdays and Sundays as, depending on the season, some attractions are closed on Sundays.

It was ok... When I visited Budapest the Opera House was one of the must attractions that we had to visit. Although I really liked the exterior of the building and its architecture, the interior was just ok... Maybe I had higher expectations, but it does worth visiting.

Stunning Opera House. There were tours every day at 3 and 4 pm and I certainly advice you to go on one! It only takes about 45 minutes but the inside is breathtakingly beautiful and worth seeing on informative guide tours. If you don't have time for the tour, at least go and see the foyer.

Good Value Opera. Went to see Rosenkavalier. Easy to book via our hotel reception (Soho in Dohany Utca). Cheapest opera tickets we'd ever bought and last minute too. Beautiful opera house based on the one in Vienna. Production was a bit quirky and there were a few costume malfunctions but the singing was good and we didn't feel too out of place in the best of our tourist clothes! Opera was in German of course but well surtitled in English (and Hungarian if you're capable!).Watch that you don't get rear box seats as we did as you will have to stand up to see over the folks in front of you. In all a great evening out and recommended.

Another beautiful building. This is another example of beautiful architecture which has survived the ages. We did not get the opportunity to attend a performance here but it is truly stunning and should not be missed.

city tour. The building is very beautiful inside and out. Got to sit in a box seat. View was amazing and the accoustics amazing. One of the female opera singers gave us a mini concert. Wow. Would love to attend an opera there. There was much renovation going on but did not detract from the tour. Was interesting to see. A must see even if you didn't like opera.

Beautiful and interesting, but impossible to enjoy. The Opera House is absolutely breathtaking, but you'd be hard pressed to actually get to enjoy it if you go on the tour. To start with it costs 3000 HUF to go on the tour, and an additional 500 HUF just to take photos. Already here we should've known we were in for a sham.The building was absolutely packed with tours and if we weren't bumping into the group in front of us, we were being bumped into from behind. Our guide looked more at this wristwatch than he did at us, and there was no time to really stop and take in any of the myriad of the details in the opera house.If you want to see the opera house in Budapest, go and see an actual opera. But don't do the tour, it is absolutely awful.
Beautiful building. The is a beautiful building with fabulous interiors. Our guide had us sit in the balcony box to view the stage. This is a must see while visiting Budapest.

One of the most beautiful opera houses in the world. Designed by Miklós Ybl, a major figure of 19th century Hungarian architecture, this is one of the most beautiful opera houses in the world. Do not miss it, if you have chance to visit Budapest.

Cheap tickets. You can get really cheap tickets (like 5€) with a good view of the stage and actors (albeit from afar). The one I went to had english subs on top so you can follow the play quite easily. The Opera is stunning inside
Opera house. This is a must do, the building is astounding, real gold leaf has been used, you have to see it to believe the grandeur inside.

Wonderful old building, tours available. Our tour company arranged for the best tour available - all parts of the Opera house (although we had some people who did not want to do many stairs, so we did not see the floor level or backstage). During the summer there are not regularly scheduled opera performances, but there was a surprise serenade by a soprano and tenor who sang from 3 arias. An amazing experience.They let us take pictures everywhere, and there were terrific exhibits of the past productions. Lots of statuary. Neo-classical and historical. Very cool!

Loved the Lobby!. We ran out of time to do the full tour, but if I'd known what I know about Parliament, I would have done this one instead. It's really beautiful inside, and I couldn't stop looking at all the surface decoration. Try for a performance, as they are very reasonably priced. Along the far side (on the left as you face the Opera House) is a street full of restaurants, where we had a very good dinner. Food for the eyes, and food for the body.

Hard no to compare!. I visited the opera house this afternoon and I would say it was an 'ok' experience. There were so many people on the tour that we were split into 3 groups at the start. I thought that was great, as too many times I've been on tours in too large a group and you can't see or hear what the tour guide is saying. The tour guide's English was very good and I could easily understand what was being said. The theatre, or at least what we saw of it, was much like any other theatre. I have been to many theatres in London and felt this was no different. As a paid tour, I was hoping to see something not generally open to the public. Although, maybe the area at the top of the royal staircase is not generally open. I would like to have seen some of backstage and how the theatre works. I am sure that all the information and photos on the tour could easily be found on the internet. Maybe I'm just hard to please, after visiting the Baroque theatre in Cesky Krumlov, which was incredible!

What you see is beautiful, but could be much better. Ticket to get in, ticket for photos, ticket for a taster of two arias ... And I am sure there were other options I have missed. We only took first two. Glad we didn't go for the arias as this does not take place in the main hall but in the buffet lounge.Tours are on the hour so plan your time of arrival.I object to the paying for photos when they don't then police those who don't pay but then take photos anyway!!Overall I would like to have seen more for what we paid. The guide was certainly very informative, but the tour lacked depth.

Beautiful!. Beautiful building and they do a great job with the tours. We were glad we visited to experience some of the Hungarian architecture. It was also interesting to learn about how royalty would interact with the space. We purchased the ticket with the mini-opera and also enjoyed the performance.

Impressive. We took advantage of the English speaking tour. We added the brief concert which was fantastic! The singer sang three songs in a small room to a group of us and it was enchanting. It's a must!

A must if you visit Budapest. If you go to Budapest then this charming opera house should be visited, check the tour times to take full advantage of this lovely building. The interior is an architectural delight with a beautiful sweeping staircase, ornate painted ceilings, wooden panels and gas lamps, and that's all before you enter the actual theatre which is even better. Our tour included an operatic performance from a female singer in the bar area, which was delightful and an appropriate ending to our visit.
Wonderfully opulent. Even the foyer is stunning, marble floors and sweeping staircases. The shop is interesting too. Worth catching a guided tour (3pm)

very beautiful concert hall. Watched "Taming if the shrewd" here, it was a good show and as it is a ballet show (no dialogue), it is very suitable for tourist who don't understand hungarian. Personally, I think that watching a show is a better experience that taking a tour :)

Tremendous value and such a young cast.. The best seats in the house @ £38 ! Great view. Excellent acoustics. The cast for the opera looked to be 20-30 somethings (though one in the choir looked like she was in her 80's) and the opera was really enjoyable (Ephegenia in Tarsis). The setting, staircases and rooms are elaborately decorated and the whole place has a touch of class about it.
Saw a lovely ballet. The opera house is so beautiful.. Definitely worth seeing a performance.We saw La Sylphide. The interior of the opera hues is amazing!!

Put this one on your list!. What a beautiful place with a good guide. Disappointed no operas during the time we were there. However you can pay for a mini concert (two arias) about 5 minutes - well worth it.

Not to be missed. The Opera House is stunning, both inside and out. It is also very accessible. Several of the "hop on hop off" busses stop across the street. We were there in early June and able to buy tickets about 10 minutes before the tour started. However, there weren't huge crowds. Tours are offered in various languages but only a couple of times a day. During heavy tourist season it would probably be a good idea to buy the tickets earlier in the day. The interior is absolutely beautiful and the guide was very informative. We choose to buy the optional mini opera concert which was delightful.

Opera house is lovely. The opera house is a beautiful building. The tourist in June is overwhelming. It is a shame more tours of this building is not more often. The tours in various language all take place at the same time. The acoustics are incredible. Therefore, one can literally hear the other tours in a different language. One looses the impact of the history of building because soooo many guides are takin fat her same time. Our tour in English was cut short because the French guide spoke louder.
You must see it in Budapest. Second only to the old Paris Opera house. Its grand ,its elegant and its worth the trip if you are in Budapest

Disappointing. This Opera house does not contain much of the original. Most of if is replicas. The tour was almost a complete waste of time. There were so many people and although the tours are separated by foreign languages, all the groups are walking through the Opera house at the same time. It is impossible to hear the tour guide because all the guides are speaking at the same time. While you can see the opulence it is hard to appreciate any of it thru the crowds.

You can skip it. There are so many beautiful things to see in Budapest and you might think that the Opera House is worth the visit. It's not. Perhaps it's because I've been to more magnificent opera houses. Or that I've been on better tours. But this tour was rushed, basic, and not that great. The highlight was at the end, when, for an extra fee, a couple opera songs were song by someone who has clearly retired from the stage.Felt like tourist cattle being herded in and out and the Opera House is lovely in its own way, but not among a "top 10" I would recommend in Budapest. Better to simply attend a performance here and enjoy it for its intended purpose.

Opulent Hapsburg indulgence with much musical history. Beautiful late 19th century opera house (opened 1882) which we were told was based on the Vienna Court Opera House (but slightly smaller on orders of Emperor Franz Josef). Extravagant exterior,entrance and interior.Beautiful also.The acoustics are very good.A reminder of a world long gone and also of the many great artists who have worked here;not least the long list of 19th and 20th century Hungarian maestros: Solti,Szell,Reiner,Dorati,Kertesz,Fricsay, Nikisch etc.There is a tour (and additional photo taking) charge.About $15.Well worth it and very reasonable.

Guided tour well worth it. The guided tour was worth the extra money, as you cannot see the inside without it. They show you all the rooms and auditorium and tell you interesting stories about the place. The only downside is that you have to purchase additional camera tickets to take photos, and the mini concert is also extra. The mini concert is held in an intermission room, not the main auditorium, and it is one performer singing a few songs. It was quite enjoyable, so if you don't feel that the extra ticket is too expensive, then go for it. It adds to the general feel of the tour and only take 5 minutes.

Very Enjoyable Experience. We were lucky to attend the performance of Tosca at the Opera House in mid May. We booked our seats in one of the upper circle level boxes almost two months in advance. The booking process was very easy: we went to the Opera House's website, which redirected us to Jegymester.hu. You can choose your seats and pay with a credit card. The site charges a very reasonable commission (about a euro or less per ticket). We printed out our tickets and took them to the Opera House on the night of the performance. Our seats were excellent and the price was very reasonable (9,500 HUF per ticket, including commission). Book in advance if you want to get good seats! One small tip: before attending the performance, we stopped for tea and pastries at the Book Cafe (Lotz Terem). It is located on the second floor of the "Alexandra" book store (Andrassy ut 39). The bookstore (and the cafe) are a 4-5 min walk from the Opera House. The cafe is a popular spot in the afternoon, so plan for some extra time not to be late for the opera. Tripadvisor reviews of the cafe can be found here:http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g274887-d2295984-Reviews-Book_Cafe_Lotz_Terem-Budapest_Central_Hungary.html

Ornate and Beautiful. It costs to go on a tour of the opera house, and we ran out of town, so we opted to do our own, main lobby "look around". It was absolutely gorgeous, I am sure that the insides are just as gorgeous, if not more so!

tour is OK, opera would be better. We visited the opera for its 3 pm tour on the last day of the season. Perhaps this is why it was so crowded. We were in a group for English speakers and there were at least 30 of us, but there were that many in all the different language groups (German, French, Italian, Spanish) that I saw. Also, the ticketing system is not great. The basic price doesn't include the "mini concert" (two arias sung by an excellent soprano for 500 HUF), the right to take pictures (another extra fee), and I found this a bit disturbing. Also, the mini concert didn't take place in the theater but in one of the refreshment areas. We had to stand, although it was so short it didn't matter.Next time I would just buy a ticket to the opera and go but since there were no more performances we didn't have that option this time. The building itself is lovely and our guide was a very friendly and convivial young man who was knowledgeable and whose English was excellent.

Opera tour. We enjoyed this tour very much, especially since had just left the House of Terror. The building is beautiful. Our guide was very knowledgeable and excited to introduce us to this wonderful building. There were about 20 of us on the English speaking tour. We did not opt for Operetta, but we could hear while we waited for our tour to begin. There are a lot of stairs, and we did not notice an elevator.

Go to see an Opera. the best way to see the Opera house is simply buy a ticket to an Opera.it is great experience to see this impressive Opera house filled with people,sound and stage scenes. Feel like you visit the Opera during its greatest Absburg era.And everything in a bargain price....it was definetly one of my trip highlights

Strauss at the Opera House. They were having a Strauss festival at the opera house when I was there, and I saw a perfect production of Der Rosenkavalier and a modern, surprising, glorious production of Elektra. all in one of the loveliest buildings in the world.

Beautiful Venue. I am no opera buff. I've never been to one before. But we thought it would be a good idea to check one out in Budapest. The opera house itself is stunning. It is smaller, but may well be nicer than the one in Vienna. The performance, as far as I could tell, was really good. One tip though: pay a little more for some slightly better tickets. They are really cheap to begin with. I got the second cheapest ones - but I would have paid more to have a better seat. When you are in the boxes on the sides, there are extremely limited views of the stage.

Great experience. The performance we saw of Puccini's Tosca was stunning. The Hungarian State Opera House is an incredibly beautiful facility with wonderful acoustics. The vocal performances were wonderful.
Electra was great.. Very pretty opera house. I hope to come back to Budapest and see more operas at the Hungarian State Opera.

Offer yourself an opera night in Budapest. Offer yourself an opera night in Budapest, it is worth both money and time. The building is fascinating and a glass of champagne at its terrace between parts offers some moments of class.

A visit to the Opera House. We enjoyed a morning of a formal tour and then decided to take our own walking tour. We visited the main square with all the stores and then walked along to the river. Stopping in the Opera House was areal treat as the architecture both outside and inside is beautiful.

An interesting tour of a beautiful opera house.. Compared with other opera house tours we have taken this one was good but not great. The history is interesting and the theater itself is beautiful. Most of the flooring is uniquely wooden. The hallways were the most interesting to me, with beautiful staircases. Worth a visit if you have a few days.

Couldn't join the tour. We appeared at the ticket office five minutes before the hour when the next tour was to depart but were told that it was too late to purchase tickets so we did not go on the tour. We could see the tour group assembled and it did not appear to be so large that a couple of extra folk would have made a difference.I was most disappointed with the attitude of those who sell tour tickets when I feel that we could easily have been accommodated.

Excellent experience.. This was my first ever experience of live opera. A relatively easy and short work. Cant really comment on the performance, but really enjoyed the visit to this remarkable building. Arrive on time and you will enjoy being in one of the great opera houses of Europe
Elektra - Strauss opera. The building is fabulous. We aren't really opera fans and this modern adaptations of the opera just didn't do much for us.
Beautiful! . This is a nice change from my usual vidits to churches and cathedrals.... Tours are at 3&4pm... Not too expensive eith. The mini show at the end was a lady who sings 2 songs....

Amazing memories!. The Opera building inside and outside is great! I can compare it to Prague and Vienna State Opera - and I say that opera in Budapest incomparably beautiful! We went for "Elektra", and we do not really like this modern staging. But the hall was full, and many people liked it. I definitely would not recommend enjoy "Elektra", but anyway I will come back here for something else.

Forget the tour, go to a performance. I did go on the very expensive tour which was interesting, but not worth the money. However I also went to a ballet performance which was excellent value for money and I had a box on the Upper Circle. I saw two ballets. The first, Troy Games was unique as it was a ballet for eight men only, no women. Then the 2 act La Sylphide, not to be confused with the classical ballet Les Sylphides. Go across the road to the Muvesz Coffee House for dinner or a drink before or after the 7pm performance.

First Opera Experience. On my first trip to Budapest, back in early 2011, I went to an opera in this beautiful Opera House. I figured my first opera might as well take place in one of the most renown performance halls in Europe. I'm not an opera-aficionado, so my review is limited. The opera was enjoyable, if only for the aura it presented--sitting in a historic art relic. And if I remember correctly, the price was right, especially when compared to a Paris or London show. The beauty of the house is worthy of admiration alone, and definitely a must-see while you're in the city. My second visit to this beautiful city was in April this year and while I didn't take in a show, a peer and I went into the house, and again, I was amazed at its architecture, intricate design and overall exquisite interior. I highly recommend stopping here while you're in this city.
Very good. Very good guided visit. The building is really impressive and it permits to know a little more of the splendor of past eras of Budapest.

Great performance and a must see building!. The Hungarian State Opera House is as gorgeous as the Vienna or Paris Opera Houses. It is one of the highlights of the city. Not only that, the performers are top level artists that you will be drawn completely into their act. However, I recommend that you do your homework or research before you go to a performance. We saw "Elektra" by Richard Stauss. It was fantastic but we read up on the story and also listened to the music before we went. So it was easy for us to understand what was being sung. However the Hungarian Opera House provides a translation of the plot so you can read while you are listening to the performers. In this case, it is better to sit up higher because the translation is shown at the upper part of the stage. It was difficult to read for us because we sat at the bottom floor, center in front of the orchestra. If you have problems sitting on a wooden chair of a couple of hours, I recommend you bring a coushion. Tickets are more affordable than in other large European cities so I really recommend a night at the opera if you are in Budapest!
A true Opera House. A great Opera House! Architecture wise outside so much to see. Inside has all the grandness you would expect!

Spectacular!. This is an architectural wonder. The wealth of the Hapsburg dynasty is evident. It is a fascinating tour albeit a bit crowded given its popularity. It is a jewel in the crown of European opera houses.

Magnificent venue. We took a tour of the house one day and went back to see Strauss' Ariadne Auf Naxos the next. The opera was a crazy story, and the staging made it even more ridiculous. Prices for tickets were a bargain by US standards. Surtitles in English and Hungarian.

Great performance, shame about the intervals!. The epitome of a classical opera house. We had booked for a performance of Der Rosenkavalier before arriving in Hungary, tempted by the very attractive (compared with London or Glyndebourne) prices. Front seats in a dress circle box and a great performance. However . . . perhaps we might have found out beforehand, but the first interval was a good half-hour, but the second was almost a full hour, so the curtain having raised at 6pm, it came down at nearly eleven, by which time a noticeable proportion of the audience had left. Make sure you know the timings before you book!

Jewel Box Opera, great design, good productions. The Opera House is a famous building and you should experience it both as a venue for opera and as an architectural treasure. Tickets are much less than in Vienna, and they have English supertitles...possibly German as well on occasion. The productions are good (we just enjoyed "Rosencavalier"). There are nice traditional sandwiches at the bar during intermissions, plus drinks. But the building is also interesting historically and technically. It was built in the late 19th c. with "air conditioning" of a kind...I won't give away the secret. Also saved from total destruction during WW II by a miracle. Take the tour; believe me, it is well worth it!

A night at the Opera. We saw "Electra" - my boyfriend and my first opera. It wasn't what I was expecting but it was a great location - very intimate so I would say there's no bad seat in the house. However the seats could use a little updating - not the most comfy seat. For our first we chose a 2 hour opera vs a 4 hour and I am glad we did. I read up on the opera when I got home and found out it's "modernist" so I will try another opera in the future but will make sure it's the traditional one and I may enjoy it a bit more. But this opera house is very beautiful from inside and out.

Superb. Went to see: Woman without a shadow (in German) and were not disappointed. It was really well staged.A memorable place - so interesting. There were 2 intervals and we had lovely food and drinks on a balcony outside. We were there 4 hours for the opera and we weren't bored (expected to be!!!)A lovely opera house. If you can't actually see an opera there are tours of the place itself.

Beautiful Opera House + Great Performances = A Budapest Must. My wife and I saw Salome in the Opera House the other week and loved the performance, and even more, the Opera House itself. Though smaller than its upstream cousin, the Vienna Opera House, the inside is opulent and spectacular. As a slightly smaller theater, all the seats are closer than expected to the performance. Even better, the State funds the opera, so tickets can be found from 5 to 70 euro... stunningly cheap for any performance, especially one of this caliber. I can't imagine going to Budapest and not seeing the opera, this is a MUST DO!.

Enjoyed Tosca very much in a great opera venue!. It is a great hall, but do invest in something better than the cheapest tickets that have obstructed views. We easily walked from our near Danube hotel to and from the hall.

Strauss Wouls Be Proud!. Budapest, you did it again...outshine Vienna with a wonderful opera like this! Adriane auf Naxos was a German opera bringing slapstick comedy & beautiful music together. What is the theme of this oddly amusing performance? The endless competition between high and low art for the publics attention. If you are here this summer, please check it out...fantastic music. Ok...so this place is also very appealing to the eyes. Opulent would be the better word here. Get there 20 minutes early and snap a few photos. There are no breaks in this opera, so grab a wine before the opera begins. Seats? Well, if you love box seats...which I do...get the first row in them. You will be sad if you sit behind someone in the box as many have obstructed views. Stay out of the uppermost seating...floor seats look good at this point. Dress? No tuxedo in sight...slacks and dress shirt...blazers and the odd tie were the norm. Ladies, dresses is all I saw. Wonderful BTW. Just don't wear shorts, whatever you do. Have fun!

One of the city's gems. This is a genuine working opera house, not just a landmark. The archetecture is ownderful inside and out, and it is well worth the tour. However, more importantly, there are constant ongoing operatic performances, and no better place to experience them.

Wonderful building. We walked past the Opera House at 15:55 and saw that there was an English tour at 16:00 and so popped in just in time. Our guide was good although I imagine that he spoke too quickly for those whose English was not their first language.The building was truly magnificent and we intend to come back to Budapest to go to the Opera in the future.
Fantastic. Did the tour in the afternoon and went to see the opera at night. Very good tour with knowledgeable guide and excellent production of Salome to follow.

A Budapest pleasure. The interior of the Opera House is an architectural delight. Touring this amazing structure made me long to see a performance. Two tips that might prevent disappointment and frustration. Ignore the "Ticket Office" sign pointing to the side of the building and just open the front door for the Opera Shop inside, the actual site to purchase tour tickets. When you purchase your tickets, ask for the additional ticket that allows photography (yes, there is another fee). We were not informed about the photography charge until we were already on tour, so weren't allowed to photograph the spectacular venue.

Great theatre, excellent performance. This is an impressive looking building from the outside but is even better on the inside. There is masses of gold gilding in the main auditorium, and an impressive painted ceiling.Our stalls seats were old, wooden, fold down seats, somewhat lacking in padding but surprisingly comfortable. The performance of Salome that we saw was excellent, all performers of a very high standard, creating a great atmosphere. It is also incredibly cheap, when compared to the often ridiculously priced tickets you pay for in Western Europe, with our two stalls seats being the equivalent to about £20 sterling for both. A great night out that I would highly recommend.
Faublous Opera and Opera House. We saw a fantastic production of tosca in an opera house that is a real gem. Highly recommend a visit when in Budapest.
Worth a look.. Beautiful inside, lots of gilding everywhere. They said they couldn't building it bigger than the one in Vienna, so they made it more opulent. Full tours available.

Arabella by Richard Strauss. Nice experience. I booked tickets over internet from Jegymester.hu. Opera house is beautiful, especially from inside. Seats are old and might start feeling hard during long performance. Overall experience was very good.

Richard Strauss Festival. I'm not an opera buff but the beautiful architecture alone makes this a must-see theatre (and they do tours throughout the day). I saw "Arabella" and "Die Frau ohne Schatten" on consecutive nights (seven and a half hours in total) and enjoyed both immensely. The Hungarians enjoy their opera, with curtain calls at the end of each act. Really worth a visit. There is a bar serving a variety of drinks and snacks during the interval and a terrace above the main entrance where you can have a quick smoke.

Impressive main chamber. Main chamber was very impressive (with pure gold decor). Our English tour guide Kristina spoke almost perfect English, and was very much fun. It was 45-min long and very informative. I recommend you take the tour if you are in the neighbourhood (or a music lover!) Btw, no need to buy the HUF500 "photo taking" extra because everyone will take pictures (and nobody from the opera house cares!)

Quite small but beautiful. We booked a 45 min english speaking tour through this small yet elegant opera house and thoroughly enjoyed the details that our guide shared with us. With out her, it would have been just an other pretty looking building. But for those who have seen opera garnier in paris, please dont go in expecting to see a speactacukar like that!

Auhentic and beautiful. A great experience in a superb, well preserved building.It has a human size and the sound is great in the opera.The play was Arabella,and it was a great busy evening.A break after roughly an hour allows you to enjoy a local wine as well as some finger food.if cyou can preorder your drinks before the play start it will prevent you for queueing up for the service.A real nice experience for a cultural evening!
Nice place.. Little hard to find. Thx trip advisor for map :) it beautiful place. Something that you must see! Nice exterior and interior.

Small but very Beautiful. The Budapest Opera House is a smaller version of the Vienna Opera; with 1200 seats; still very beautiful structure and design from the outside and inside; it’s a great location to visit.

Stunning interior. Great building , just felt a little like you were on a conveyor belt and don't think 2 songs in the bar area quite constitutes a 'mini concert' not much extra paid for that but it was a bit of a let down. The building is stunning and the auditorium beautiful. Do go to a performance if you want a flavour of the opera though.

Tour was a disappointment . Really wanted to see the building. Tour guide Tamas started enthusiastically but seemed to rush us thru. There were conflicts as another tour guide came by and made it difficult to hear our guide. Tamas spoke so rapidly that many in the tour group complained to each other & even asked him to slow down. Beautiful building but not sure it was worth the $15 apiece to o sit through a difficult to understand tour. If you have to use the restroom-hold on because you have to wait to the END of the tour. Really not very tourist friendly !

Tosca-tastic. Bought tickets to this in advance (from the very easy to use Jegymester Online Ticket Store (jegymester.hu)) and was very pleased we had. The building was worth the price of admission alone, it's just stunningly beautiful, M.C. Escheresque confection in marble and gilt. Unfortunately the performances were all excellent with the exception of the female lead. Bit of an issue if you're watching Tosca... Still glad we went though. intermission on the balcony had the most fantastic canapes...

Italian Opera with Hungaran subtitles. Saw Tosca at Sunday Matinee. The opera house is magnificent and has the best acoustics. The price of the most expensive seat was $35. Even though it was Italian opera with Hungarian subtitles as long as you read the libretto you can follow the story. Ordered tickets online before our trip and was able to pick seats from seating chart. Great Experience all around.
Nice place and nice play. I went there and was watching very nice ballet.It was a very good ballet and the opera itself is very nice and I recommend for both visit opera itself and play also.

Outstanding Performance. Beautiful architecture.. I attended a performance of Prokofiev's Ballet Romeo and Julliet by the Hungarian National Ballot. It was the first time I had ever attended a live performance of a ballet. The performance and sets were exceptional. It is always great to attend a performance in a grand opera house and this one takes you back in time to the 19th or early 20th century. The exchange rate to Hungarian Forints is quite favorable enabling me to purchase front row seats for less than I would have paid for least favorable seating at another opera house in western Europe or the U.S. Note that all the Opera House's web site does not list all performance so it is best to call or visit to inquire. I was able to purchase my tickets the day of the event.
Wonderful. One of the most beautiful buildings in Pest! Lovely outdoor terrace to enjoy good wine before you enjoy the Opera!

Stunning. I was able to visit the opera house and they had tickets for a show that evening. It was very special to attend an opera in such an amazing building. It was visually spectacular the opera and the building

Everything you could want in an opera house!. Stunningly beautiful, regal, enchanting. I took my family to see The Nutcracker and it was an amazing experience. World-class without feeling pompous or snobbish. Great service from the coat girls to the seating staff, and the show was outstanding. A must-visit for anyone traveling through Budapest.
Beautiful building. Although it's smaller than we expected, the opera house is a magnificent building. It's worth taking a guided tour

A night at the Opera. The Opera House itself is beautiful and well worth a visit. We actually went to an opera there but unfortunately there were no subtitles in English. We heard from other people that the guided tour is not worth the time or money.

Don't miss it. We wanted to see the Opera House during a performance rather than doing a tour. The prices range from about £2-£50, but I would think the sound is good where ever you are. We saw a ballet, which was lovely and paid about £10 to sit at the back of the stalls, we had a great view.Use the cloak room, it's worth it to see how efficient they are at getting coats back to everyone in just a few minutes.The bar was worth a visit, we ordered a glass of Champaign each (about £2) which was chilled and waiting for us at the interval. All round great experience and I would recommend it to everyone.

I only went in to see the architecture. I was just walking past and decided to take a look inside. The house is full of decorations and is beautiful, unfortunately you apparently need to pay for a tour. Still worth visiting just the lobby :)

Terrific tour. We're here with an APT river cruise and this visit was part of our bus tour.
We were guided through the building by theOpera House's own guide. She was very well informed and explained so much to us.
This was thoroughly enjoyable

Beautiful building. This is a lovely theatre. the building is gorgeous, the sight-lines good,also plenty of leg-room, and the Tokay at the interval is also very nice. The prices seem extremely reasonable compared with the UK, and booking was easy on-line. My husband really enjoyed the operas we have seen. I must however say that the ballet company isn't up to Royal Ballet standards, but unless you are really fussy about ballet, you should not let that deter you - the overall experience is worth it.

Beautiful. A must when in Budapest.. We woke up to a wet Sunday morning in Budapest and found that there was an 11.00 matinee at the opera house. For £6 each we were able to see two ballets of the highest standard in a beautiful building. One of the highlights of our recent tour of Central European capital cities.

Tosca was nearly perfect. We had great seats in the stalls and compared to the prices in London, these were very cheap. Getting a drink in between the scenes was very time consuming and we suggest you do not bother. It was quite hot inside so dress appropriately. Public transport too and from the Opera was superb, cheap and fast.It is a wonderful building and even if you are not going to an opera, going to look around the Opera is a good idea.
a must see. a fascinating place to visit, guided tour is rather short and a bit light on details/history, would have killed to learn and seen more.

Ballet visit. Had an amazing night at the opera we had a box which meant we had an unobstructed view beautiful canapies served at the interval. The performance was so moving a beautiful small opera house worth also the afternoon tour with the short arias acccompanying.

What a treat!. We decided to take the tour on a whim. What a treat!. We learned the history of the building, and enjoyed the spectacular rooms. The best part was a lovely opera performance or 2 arias by a beautiful soprano in costume. When you purchase the tour, definitely opt for the performance, it makes the show.

Classical Opera house. We visited here and to our dismay there were just a few tickets left for the opera performance. I bought two tickets at a very low price and was warned by the ticket seller that they were limited view. My plan was to go that evening and buy extra tickets from someone reselling and only use our tickets if we were unsuccessful.We didn't find any sellers and used the tickets. The cheaper seats have their entrance so you can't see the beautiful main stairway. Our seats were at the top of the opera house and the ticket seller's warning was quite accurate. We could barely see anything if we twisted out bodies like pretzels. However the sound quality was very good and we enjoyed what we heard. The builidng is worth seeing and if you like opera make sure you buy tickets in advance. On the night we were there every seat was taken.

Another Great Budapest Attraction.. A spectacular interior. Tours in many languages. The additional cost for the Operatic performance at the end of the tour is worth taking as it makes the visit complete.

Beautiful building, good ballet. We attended a ballet here. It is probably advisable to book tickets in advance for cheaper seats, however, no complaints as we paid an average price (around 15-20 pounds) for a show on the next day and got seats in an almost-private stall above the orchestra. The staff at the ticket office were very helpful and patient both times round. The building itself is fantastic (probably the prettiest opera house I have been in), and the show we saw ('La Sylphide' with a great pre-show of adrenaline-filled 'Troy') was really good. Great dancing, really good costumes and absolutely stunning stage setting scenery. If you can get on this show (it opened at the beginning of May): go!!

Expensive but worth it. You need to plan your visit - it is only open for visitors at 3pm and 4pm. The staircase and the the auditorium are impressive although not that big compared to other theatres. There's a mini-concert in the end of the tour, but you need to buy an extra-ticket for that.

Beautiful building. Not the best opera I've ever seen, but well worth going for the atmosphere and the wonderful building. We had front row Pitstalls Seats and they were good value. They are at the back of the stalls, on the same level but slightly raised so you get an excellent view and they are good value. the chairs in all stalls seats are a bit uncomfortable -not much padding.
