Only the seats in the sort of boxes around the edge of the stalls are more padded.

Beautiful Inside - Make Sure You Go To A Performance!. This is an absolutely fantastic building both inside and out.We visited the opera house in the daytime and booked tickets to watch the Philharmonic Orchestra there the same evening for a cost of about £20 each. These were all that was available and were the most expensive, but you can snap some up for about £4. This means you don't have to pay for the touristy walk around as you have plenty of time during the interlude or afterwards to wander around to your hearts content.Whilst there is a dress code, this is not held to and there were people in trainers, jeans and t-shirts. However, to feel comfortable I would advise you go for smart-casual or formal wear.

What a building , dont miss it. Like so many buildings the opera house has been beautifully restored to the splendour of the 19th century. The auditorium is the highspot but the whole tour was very informative. It was a bit pricey and the tour lasted about 45 minutes. The tour also visited the main bar and smoking galleries where you have the option to hear two arias by one of the singers. This was disappointing, we had to stand in a huddle whilst the performer sang. We late heard that it was probably cheaper to buy gallery tickets to one of the evening performances! Tours only at 4 and 5 in the afternoons so it can get Crowded at these peak times.

Opera house. Very disappointing visit. Sales staff were very brusque, verging on rude. Ironic considering the opera house should be a cultural experience. Very expensive. We also paid for the mini concert.The tour comprised a visit to the main bar area and smoking galleries and balcony, and a view of the royal box from about 5 metres away, so you could not see much.The mini concert comprised one singer and two songs, accompanied by a mini stereo! We were a standing audience, no seating was Provided!If you want to see this venue attend an opera it is much cheaper than the tour, especially if you get tickets in the gallery.Toilet facilities were only provided at the end of the tour, prior to that you were not allowed access.

Tour and Arias. The opera house is a beautiful building with wonderful wood carvings, gorgeous real and fun fake marble columns and a 'skinny' mirror at the top of the royal staircase. The arias after the tour were interesting as well.
Opera House. Nice tour, but skip the opera singer offer. We thought it was going to be in the Opera hall, but was just in a room with a CD player. Otherwise, very nice tour and friendly guide

Tour. What a great building, the history, the beauty. And to think Queen Sissi preferred it over the one in Vienna. The tour was comprehensive in the information it offered. We really wished we had had the time to attend a performance, although the short offering at the end (extra charge) was quite enjoyable.

Nice guided tour. This historic, nice building has informative guided tour in different languages. Plan in advance if you want to have also 5 min, mini opera concert or food for extra money before you buy your ticket. Enjoy the stories about the royal family and the opera and let your imagination work.

Go for the experience alone. I had a fantastic evening at the Opera House with my partner last June - it's one of those places that no matter what performance you go to see, you can only be impressed by the beauty of the building both inside and out. We saw a ballet of Snow White and the Seven Dwarves, which admittedly was probably geared more towards children, but it was so charming we didn't mind. I would recommend hiring seats in a box - it was the equivalent of about £17 per person (a fraction of what you'd pay in the UK), and well worth it, giving great views of the stage and a bit of privacy. There are seats in the stalls that are the equivalent of a few pounds too. Note that in the boxes, there are four seats, so if you want it to yourself you will have to hire them all.At the intermission, everyone went out onto a terraced area, ate lángos and drank Tokaji wine - - two Hungarian specialities I highly recommend! Despite the setting, the atmosphere was relaxed and nowhere near as stiff as I had feared. Perhaps because it was an earlier show (starting at 6) and geared towards children, people were dressed in a mix of casual and smart clothing - nothing too formal.Staff at the Opera House were polite and professional. Not all spoke English, but knew enough to be able to direct us to where we were sitting.I would highly recommend a visit to the Opera House for the experience alone.

Nice tour. Nice to see the place. Guides not very much enthusiastic, sort or repeating always the same, like a "human recording".But place is nice and just in the corner the CALLAS CAFE has nice cakes.

Beautiful building - take a cushion to sit on for long performances!. My husband and I attended The Marriage of Figaro during the first weekend in May - as a way to see the inside of the Opera House in all it's glory.We paid a measly £2.50 per ticket for the upper balcony seats. Only thing I would say is that if you are in for a long performance,then consider taking a cushion or something to sit on, as the seats are a little on the hard side!!The Opera House itself is a sight to behold and well worth the uncomfortable seating to see inside.

An glittering night out in Budapest. We love the ballet but Covent Garden has long since become unaffordable - if you want a decent seat. So a visit to The Opera House in Budapest is a wonderful treat. We’ve seen several ballets here now (we arrange out visits to Budapest to coincide with the ballet season) and each visit has been a delight.The standard of performance is excellent and the venue is superb. We “splash” out on a balcony box and have a wonderful view and sound experience.At the interval make you way to the bar area, where you can also purchase food, and then head out onto the balcony. It’s lovely to stand on the large balcony, champagne in hand, looking down on the evening street and up at the classical architecture of the building.Thankfully we are never alone in taking photos of the auditorium, staircases, bar etc during the intermission and the staff have always been really friendly and happy to take a photo of you. Yes, I know it’s a touristy thing to do but whilst this is a stunning classical venue it’s not as stuffy as most. Saying that, people do tend to dress up more than at Covent Garden which is now quite casual. So don’t be surprised to see evening gowns and dinner jackets being worn. But as long as you’re smartly dressed you won’t feel out of place.At Christmas you have the added delight of the giant Christmas trees inside & outside of the Opera House. The outside one is enormous and has giant gingerbread decorations hanging from it. There’s also a snow-clad hut and the two glass display cabinets on the pavement outside have mannequins of characters from the Nutcracker in them. I understand there are guided tours of the building, and it would be worth going on one to see the beautiful decoration inside, but if you like ballet or opera then don’t miss an evening here. You won’t regret it.

Magnificent. The interior of the opera house speaks for itself. There are daily tours in English but we did not take one. We did attend Parsifal and really enjoyed it. The music was excellent, particularly the soprano and the tenor leads. Sometimes finding voices big enough for Wagner can be a challenge. This cast was certainly worth ten bravos! We bought our tickets online in the States, using a credit card. The Web availability/support was therefore impressive as well.
Old world grandeur. Amazing building. Would have loved to see it but was closed to the public. Needs to be open with guided tours.

The second most beautiful opera building. Worth the money to check out an opera. It doesn't matter if you can understand it or not. Book a balcony place on the first floor and you will have the most perfect experience. There is so much to see and the acoustics are perfect. I can highly recommend to do this once during your stay in Budapest.

Opulent European opera house. An old European gilded opera house. I went on the guided tour, which was OK - the history of how it was built, and what went on there. If you are there to see an opera, I'm sure it does a very good job as an opera house. If you like the kind of extremely elaborate, ornate kind of interiors of the aristocratic Europe of centuries past, this will be the perfect place for you. I personally find that these places seem to be very common and not particularly interesting.

Parsifal Opera. I saw an Opera in this venue and it was just splendid. I couldn't imagine a better place to see one. The grand entry way was just inspiring. The amount of detail that was put into the opera house was just amazing. I would recommend this house for any type of opera or ballet.

Worth the trip. We were recommended this tour and it is worth it. There is a reduction with a Budapest city card. The guide we had was very wel informed and spoke good English. Tours were available in many languages, and the only down side was that they all started at the same time so you were always just avoiding one another as the groups went around. Really interesting insight into the society of the Hapsburg Empire too.
Opera house. A very good tour, but would have liked to have seen more behind the scenes and the working of the Opera House. Excellent young tour guide, but did appear to be rushing us through.

Beautiful Surroundings and People - Great Ballet. We've got into the habit of going to see a ballet in all the cities we visit - and I'm so glad we did in Budapest. Not only was the theater itself a treat (really sumptuous decor) - the Hungarian State Ballet were excellent and their version of Romeo & Juliet, though a little bit odd, was danced beautifully. Dress up - suits and dresses with heels were the norm, and pre-order your interval drinks at the bar to save queuing so you have time to pop out onto the balcony.

Shame the singing did not match the building. This is a simply stunning building and well worth a visit just to admire the wonderful marble and wood work. We bought tickets for Tosca before we went to Hungary using the very efficient Jegymester website and had excellent seats. Although these seats looked a little basic and uncomfortable they were fine. They do not allow patrons to enter until about twenty minutes before curtain up, consequently the crush in the entrance foyer is uncomfortable. Cloakroom facilities (400 HUF) were very good and efficient and put Covent Garden and the Met to shame. Programmes (1,000HUF), in Hungarian and English, were interesting and informative. As for the performance there were many positives. The orchestra was good as were the acoustics. The sets were also good. The singing, with the notable exception of Scarpia (Kálmándi Mihály), was second rate in the extreme and it was sad to hear much loved arias not receiving the treatment they deserved. The 'Te Deum' at the end of Act 1 was such a disappointment, with the chorus singing off stage they could hardly be heard. Such a stirring end to an act became a whimper. Having said that, we thoroughly enjoyed our visit and would definite recommend an evening at the opera. Our seats in the orchestra stall cost just 11,500 HUF. Where else will you find an opera bargain like that?

What an interior.. The National Opera House has a great exterior. On walking up the steps and in to the foyer/lobby area you are met with a beautiful and ornately decorated area that just is amazing. Alas we did not have time to do the tour as it did not fit with our itinerary.

Wonderful evening. We saw a ballet (Romeo and Juliet), and the whole evening was a magical experience. We booked a box, which was really very cheap and definitely worth it (but make sure you get seats at the front - the other seats really aren't very good).

A truly memorable trip to the ballet. This was the highlight of our holiday; a trip to the Opera House to see the ballet "Romeo and Juliet". The atmosphere, the beautiful dancing and the wonderful music all made this an experience that we won't forget

Beautifil, but too expensive. The opera house is beautiful, but you can't see much without taking the tour. And if you're taking the tour you can't miss the 5 minutes concert at the end of it. But all of this costs too much to it's value.I think skipping it wouldn't harm the enjoyment from your trip.
Marriage of Figaro. My husband and I went to see Mozart's Marriage of Figaro. Beautiful performance, we truly enjoyed it! The theater is absolutely gorgeous!
Amazing. It is very beautiful inside, and I would recommend, rather than taking a guided tour, you can enjoy for a better price nice concerts in this Opera House.

Disappointed. Perhaps we didn't research the venue well enough, but booked tickets for a piano concert before leaving the UK. Seats were high up (not a problem, you expect that for the cheaper prices) but the entrance was 'round the back' (looked the the "poor relations" entrance) and we had to climb about eight flights of stairs. Far too few women's toilets for such a large seating area when we got there!But the most disappointing part was when we took our seats in the second row of balcony, and could not see the front half of the stage at all. As the piano was placed there, we could see nothing. We're used to venues like the Albert Hall and Covent Garden which also have high, cheaper seats, but unless the seats are sold as 'impeded view' of similar, you can at least see the stage. It certainly had the gilded interior of so many London West End Victorian theatres... but was not very user friendly.All that said, the essentially Hungarian audience seemed content (though we never found a programme that told us what pieces we were listening to or who was performing) so perhaps our expectations were too high.... and its drawbacks may not worry other visitors.We always try to take in a music event when visiting a new city—Barcelona and Prague, for example, were wonderful. But this was, sadly, a disappointment.

Stunning venue. I attended a ballet performance of Romeo & Juliet and was impressed by both the show and the venue. I had a front row seat in a box on the first level and views were great, though I imagine that folks seated behind me had a harder time (hopefully they paid less). Overall, this was a fantastic experience and an incredible value for the price of the ticket. You would pay at least 3 times as much for that seat and level of performance anywhere else in the world. Seeing a how in this venue is an experience not to be missed if you're in Budapest!

A gem of a place.. Beautifully restored, shiny memorial to pre-war affluent Hungary and its society. Could be a little more comfortable, but you can pay 50 times more for an opera in any other capital city.

Well worth a visit. A very beautiful old building with a stunning interior decorated to an incredible level of opulence. We could not attend a performance which is a great pity in retrospect so we went on the guided tour and enjoyed it immensely. The guide was very enthusiastic and gave out a great deal of knowledge about the history and traditions of the building. The building is well worth a visit, don't miss it if you are in the area. Note you can get a discount if you have a current hop on hop off bus ticket.

La Bohem. Budapest is my birth place, but I am British by accident. My mother took me to see the Nutcreaker when I was six. I have seen many productions since then on my annual returns. Last time I have been there we saw La Boheme with my husband. It was an OK performance as far as the production goes, but the set and lighting design was a average. The building however is outstanding. Ticket prices are good value too. The seats are very hard to seat on not necessary in today's technical advances. They should replace those. All in all it was a pleasant experience.

Beautiful facility. Just returned from Budapest. Was fortunate to attend the performance Romeo and Juliet this past Sunday. Excellent to say the least. Stunning facility and beautiful performance. If you take a jacket/coat, you must check it with pick up post performance. Very reasonably priced. Dress was anywhere from formal to jeans. Had early dinner at Callas Cafe directly next door to the Opera House which was very good and relaxing.
Beautiful. Beautiful building with great detail and atmosphere. The surrounding area is also worth a wonder with some nice places to eat too.
Breathtaking!. This opera house is absolutely gorgeous with astounding acoustics! I have told everyone I know that is travelling to Budapest to marvel at the glory of this house!

Great singing and good value. I try to take my wife to the opera for her birthday. This year we tried Budapest and went to see the 'Marriage of Figaro'. The singing and music were first class. As a added bonus, the cast threw flowers to the audience and I was lucky enough to catch some for my wife.

Beautiful building, excellent performance. We were staying very nearby so we went to see a ballet (Romeo & Juliet) at the Opera House. The building is beautiful inside and out, with wonderful ceiling decoration, and the auditorium is magnificent.Due to short notice we were only able to book seats at the back of the stalls for quite reasonable prices. The seats were fine, if a little hard, with good leg room, but the rows weren't very well staggered and the floor rake was very gradual so you could easily end up sitting directly behind someone tall who could ruin your view. Boxes looked much better but bear in mind they have rear seats which are on the same level as the front ones so again you may not see much unless you're prepared to stand through the whole show. Basically, go on the website and look at the seat prices, they will tell you everything about the quality of that seat - as far as I could tell there are no "bargain" seats here.At the interval we were able to buy drinks from one of the four bars in the upstairs room and then walk out onto the balcony overlooking Andrassy Ut.The ballet itself was excellent in every way.If you're not visiting to see a show, you will need to book a tour to see most of the building because casual visitors can only see the main foyer, but I thoroughly recommend even doing just that if you're anywhere nearby, it really is a marvellous building.
must see. The opera house is a must see during your visit to Budapest. it is known for it's elegance and striking exterior.

Supping at The Opera House... How can one miss the Opera House...? There are two alternatives ..One is to take a guided tour which happens once or twice a day or better still book a performance and please 'dress' for the occasion..This elegant and stately lady deserves no less than you return the compliment of her elegance and utterly stunning decor...In the summer during the interval , a glass of champagne on the terrace overlooking the grand Andrassy Street is a memorable moment..There is a Metro station No.1 ''Opera' or a casual walk past elegant shops and restaurants can too be a pleasure....Before, if you have time ,a cocktail at the 'Callas' bar next door is a good beginning..I had the good fortune to be a guest in the box overlooking the stage and sneaked in quite illegally a bottle of champagne and glasses which added to the thrill..but box,stall, balcony or 'Gods'...Take in this experience..
Great music. Great musical and creative experience. Unfortunately, the opera was in Italian with running titles in Hungarian, so there was no English translation

Incredible!. Totally awesome experience! I sincerely regret that I could not attend a performance in this stunning theater. I have never seen a more opulent venue. Logistics: Tours are at 3 and 4pm, they divide you into groups by language and take you to several areas including the main auditorium, the Royal Bar, and the smoking corridor. The guides are knowledgeable.Not surprisingly, our English tour was quite crowded, but the theater is large and the guides allow plenty of time for photos and questions. We paid about 500 HUF (which is about 2 dollars) extra to see a performance of 2 arias in the Royal Bar following the tour. I am sure it was an understudy who performed for us, but regardless, it was AMAZING. When a beautiful soprano performs Mio Babbino Caro in such a setting, it really takes your breath away! Highly recommended for anyone who appreciates music and/or opera!

Nice building, don't take the mini-concert. There are only guided tours at 3 and 4 pm. The English tour is very crowded so if possible choose another language.Lovely operabuilding and the "stories" or "legends" that go with it are great.You have to pay extra to take pictures : do !You have to pay extra for the mini-concert : don't ! You don't see anything new and the singer (with CD-player) wasn't good.Discount also with hop-on-hop-off ticket.

Spectacular setting. Beautiful building, made one think of the old imperial days of the Austrian-Hungarian Empire. We saw wonderful ballet, Romeo and Juliet. In any other country, the ticket prices would have been out of our reach. Excellent value in Budapest.

Unbelievable!. I sincerely regret that I could not attend a performance in this stunning theater. I have never seen a more opulent venue. Tours are at 3 and 4pm, they divide you into groups by language and take you to several areas including the main auditorium, the Royal Bar, and the smoking corridor. The guides are knowledgable.Not surprisingly, our English tour was quite crowded, but the theater is large and the guides allow plenty of time for photos and questions. We paid about 500 HUF (which is about 2 dollars) extra to see a performance of 2 arias in the Royal Bar following the tour. I am sure it was an understudy who performed for us, but regardless, it was AMAZING. When a beautiful soprano performs Mi Caro Bambino in such a setting, it really takes your breath away! Highly recommended for anyone who appreciates music and/or opera!
Super Production. Die Fledermaus: comic opera in a stunning setting. Superb value, go experience on Opera or Ballet rather than a tour looking at , the albeit, stunning building
Fantastic evening. Took the family to watch the Hungarian State Orchestra and wasn't disappointed. Booked a private box that almost touched the stage. Fantastic performance, well worth a visit.
Beautiful building!. The opera house is a very beatuful building both inside and out. We went to see the ballet Romeo and Juliet and had this way time to see all the rooms from inside. Impressive!

deserves a tour. absolutely deserves the tour, discount with Budapest card. Not strict dress code, but sb could feel uncomfortable when casually dressed.Wear at least black clothes and attend a play. Must!

Excellent. A really enjoyable tour. We were staying just around the corner so we did it because it was convenient rather than for any other reason. I have to say wherever you are staying you should take the time to do this because it is so interesting. The English guide was excellent, so enthusiastic and knowledgeable about the place (a music student we thought) and she really brought the place alive for us. It doesn't take long - do it, it's well worth it.

Amazing building and fantastic performances. Not to be missed! The building itself is breathtaking and the performances were awesome. We went on a choral rehearsal night, with a full orchestra and various choruses performing. It was inexpensive and awesome

Amazing inside outside. This building make you to say waooooo the artistic value very high,very we'll maintain beautiful paints statues unic in this category. Who ever have chance should go to visit this memorable building
Beautiful theatre. We went to see The Flying Dutchman.....wouldn't see it again but it was nice to see the opera house.

Fantastic Building. My wife and I visited during our wedding anniversary trip, and bought tickets (online a few weeks before) for Erkel's "Bank Ban." The building is magnificent, our only complaint being that as we only had cheap seats we didn't get to walk up the grand staircase! The view from our seats was good, despite them being the cheapest opera seats I have ever purchased, and the auditorium was opulent to say the least. The performance itself was excellent, the music and singing of top quality, and the English surtitles kept up with the performance and were much better spelled than those used by the BBC! I'd recommend a visit here to any opera lover.

A beautiful building. A free tour is held every day at 3pm and 4pm; a great way to get some extra info and trivia. Be warned though,they charge you extra to be able to take photos in the building. Which is extremely silly in my opinion.

A Very Special Experience. We are not opera buffs, but decided we could either take a tour of The State Opera House, or alternatively actually attend a performance and soak up the atmosphere. There are guided tours between 3 and 4 o'clock we believe, but we chose to enjoy a performance at the State Opera House. Firstly, the building will not disappoint, even externally the decoration is truly magnificent and the interior of the building is most certainly worth a visit. Sitting inside our gilded box on the fourth level we had an excellent view of the stage although we felt sorry for the three people who sat behind us as their view must have been quite restricted. All the seats are allocated, so perhaps they paid less than we had done for our front seats. Before the performance we simply marvelled at the beauty of this fabulous building, our camera never stopped clicking. During the performance photography is not allowed! The performance of "The Flying Dutchman" was well received and the total experience was one we will treasure. As a previous reviewer mentioned, the seats are somewhat uncomfortable, but we felt the experience was well worth both the reasonable cost and the temporary discomfort.

Hungarian State Opera House - Beautiful venue for opera and ballet performances in Budapest. The Hungarian State Opera House is a Neo-Renaissance masterpiece, built by Hungary's finest architect - Miklos Ybl in 1884. Europe has its share of fabulous opera houses and this is certainly up there with the best of them. The outside of the State Opera House is nice but its the interior that you will long remember after visiting. The entrance area, red carpeted staircase and ornate decorated foyer are bound to impress. Then you enter the lovely auditorium, with gilded box seating, attractive stage and a beautiful ceiling fresco and chandelier. The box seating area is well decorated and makes an enjoyable place to watch an opera or ballet. Do have a look at the impressive Royal Box for the heavy gilding and statues as well. During our recent visit, we watched the Taming of the Shrew ballet and found it to be a good performance. The costumes were delightful and the ballet was entertaining to watch. Tickets were purchased directly through the State Opera website and tickets printed at home. Compared to attending ballet and opera elsewhere in Europe the price for box seats was very affordable. Overall, we quite enjoyed the ballet seen at the Hungarian State Opera House and we'd happily attend another ballet or opera performance here in the future. This is a world class venue providing very reasonably priced performing arts for visitors to see in Budapest.

The Flying Dutchman. Wonderful old building with fantastic architecture and adornments. Saw Richard Wagners opera The Flying Dutchman (absolutely fantastic).Only one criticism is when you sit through an opera lasting 2.5 hours it would be much more enjoyable with a bit of padding on the seats. Still a wonderful experience.
beautiful. great value. we saw the golden brush ballet. beautiful venue but ballet was bit too long for my husband's tastes. worth seeing the opera house though.

What a treat. Coming to Budapest we decided to book tickets for the Flying Dutchman. This was our first opera and the whole experience was wonderful. The building itself is a joy, if you do go to a performance make sure you go to the bar upstairs and go out onto the balcony. You will feel like a million dollars. The tickets are not that dear and you will have a fabulous time.
Amazing!. Such a beautiful building, wonderfully decorated and with tickets for about 7000 Forints, about £24. Where you get those prices? I absolutely loved it there!

Great value, gorgeous building. Must see/do experience....watching an opera at the Hungarian state opera.You can bok the tickets like for all cultrural shows va internet in advance,I saw the tragic opera story of Jenufa,It was an tremendous experience. The whole place is gorgeous and quite breathtaking. Even when you sit at literally the cheapseats...views and sound is great. I suggest going there when its not so full. Because the room for your knees is quite tight if you are over 6'2ft or 187 cm like me.The best is the prices. At 600ft thats less than 2€ for tockets. before the show...enter the building thru the main entrance...enjoy the grandeur of the opera builing. For your seats you need to enter via the side entrance for a lengthy 6 stair climb to the top.best cheap seats is right on the balcony..if you sit behind the view could be somewhat restricted,This place is much better than the opera in Prague. It ;looks so grand and beuatifull. A must vist IMHO when you come to Budapest. Even if you dont like opera. An oepra is splitin 3 parts and we went away after the 2nd intermission.
Wagner. Went to see The Flying Dutchman... can't say I'm an opera fan but the music and the acoustics were to die for!

Experience opera at the Opera House. When we planned our trip to Budapest, we knew we wanted to see two buildings: the Parliament and the Hungarian State Opera House. Since we had purchased on-line tickets for the Parliament, we thought it would be a great idea to experience opera at the Opera House rather than pay for the guided tour. Best decision: we got orchestra seat tickets for about 25% the cost of tickets back in the States and saw Janacek's JENUFA. We had time to wander throughout the building before curtain rising and during the two intermissions. It was interesting to hear the opera in its native Czech language and to see supertitles in Hungarian rather than English. Good thing we knew the plot! The opera was wonderful and the choreography superb. We were hoping to get tickets to Tosca but unfortunately was sold out. To find out what's going on during your stay in Budapest, check out the following URL which allows ticket purchases to museums, Parliament, concert, theater, exhibitions, etc. http://www.jegymester.hu/eng/Index

Impressive. We did the guided tour of the Opera House and thoroughly enjoyed it. It rivals all the great opera houses of the world, albeit on a slightly smaller scale. Impressive auditorium and assembly rooms etc.

Wonderful tour. We loved the tour of the Opera House. It is a bit expensive but, in the end, felt that it was worth the price. Our tour guide was fabulous and we loved seeing the amazing architecture, the opulent interior spaces and beautiful art. Our guide gave us great information about each of the spaces we visited in a fun and interesting way. We did not pay for the mini concert at the end but wish that we had.

Flying Dutchman in German. Loved the opera although I did not know it at all. It is quite challenging trying to understand the plot when you don't understand the Hungarian translation but it was still a wonderful experience. Good seats in the main auditorium for only £30 each. My advice would be pay the money so that you can see what's going on on stage it's not expensive compared to ticket prices at home.

How not to go the opera. Beautiful building. Cheap pre-booked seats for Tosca - but surely you should be able to see some of the stage (even the Tv screen was behind a pillar. But wonderful performance - just stood at the back for the last act.

opera house visit. if you get time and like great buildings or opera book a show. subsidised by the state this is relatively cheap and what an experience great building we got a private box for £35 per ticket just go to the box office when you get there and enquire they speak very good english, there is no real dress code so don't worry too much about that.

Ticketing Needs More Explanation. I enjoyed the tour of the Opera House, but wasn't informed at the ticketing that there was an extra charge to see the mini-concert (and all of the advertising bills a "Opera House Tour & Mini-concert), so unfortunately I missed out on that.The building itself is nice, and worth a visit if you're in the area at the time of the tour (3pm and 4pm); however, if you're not an opera lover, I wouldn't say that this is a must-do in Budapest.

Taming of the Shrew Ballet at the Opera House. The building is beautiful!!! We were all blown away by how beautiful it is! The ballet and music (acoustics) were just wonderful!!! I can't use enough superlatives! This was a highlight of our trip! However, you do need to have an idea of the plot in advance to follow the plot of the ballet. The Dancers were just amazing!
nice building. The building based Andrassy street, shopping brand-name street, it easy to get there with underground

Stunning!. Watched a performance of "Bank ban" on the weekend of Hungary's national holiday on 15 March and we were very impressed both by the quality of the music, opera singers, the beautiful costumes and sets but also from the beautiful building! It was a lovely night and we also had the opportunity to see the full moon from the balcony of the first floor!

Night at the Opera. A terrific night at a beautiful opera house watching a ballet version of Taming of the Shrew by Hungary's top company. The cost for a seat in the Gods (but with a very good view) with a glass of champagne was a total of £6 each. Don't miss it !

Beautiful opera house!. Now before I start it must be said I have only visited three opera houses inclusing this one but I can honestly say it is stunnigly beautiful and well worth your time in Budapest. Lots to learn here and I only wish we had time for a performance! Only one tour at 3pm to 4pm I found a little odd but make rime to visit this fascinating place.

Bit pricey but impressive building.. Bit pricey and a quick wiz around the place. Impressive building though. Interesting history. I thought it a bit of a cheek to charge to take photos when the admission ticket wasn't cheap to start with.

Ballet - great bargain. We had box seats at the Opera. It is extremely affordable and a great way to see the inside of the Opera House and a show. The box seats were approximately $17. And you could get obstructed view seats as cheap as $2. A must do. You can buy tickets in the lobby of the opera house. They post all the shows and prices near the ticket booth. Very easy to buy.

Beautiful and Amazing Acoustics. I an my wife love music -- have heard and seen many things in various cities - this is a wonderful music venue, beautifully baroque, with perhaps the best acoustics of any8 hall we have ever been to. We saw, by accident, a choral performance, not an opera, having shown up to see an opera that was at another location! Tickets are so inexpensive we sighed and bought tickets for the choral concert, so if you order tickets online, make sure you area headed to the correct theater!

Bank Ban by Ferenc Erkel. Not a great fan of opera, but loved the Opera House itself. Great value, with good seats for £25 each. Had never heard of either the opera or its composer, who is almost a Hungarian hero, but enjoyed the experience, thanks mainly to the soprano (playing Melinda) who actually sang beautifully, rather than shout, as did the tenor. The baritones were also great.

Takes your breath away. The tours are at 3 and 4 in the afternoons. You are split into groups according to chosen language. It is a very emprehensive tour and you get to sit in the boxes. The gilding in the main theatre with the mirrors makes it truly spectacular. If you just want to see the foyer which in itself is amazing then you can go in any time and it is free.

Grand opulence, an experience of a lifetime. We saw Puccini's Tosca at the Opera House, what an incredible experience! Just being in the building surrounded by such richly finished opulence is incredible. Add to that the amazing performance and it was transcendent! Tickets are not expensive, so catch a show if you get the chance.

First Time. First time at the Opera, Barber of Seville, tickets very reasonable, building beautiful, Didn't understand a word, no english sub titles, but great singing voices. Respect the venue and wear a nice shirt and trousers, even though some don't

Excellent Boito production. I saw both Mephistotle and Tosca. The Tosca production was traditional and the performers gave first rate performances.The production of Boito's Mephistotle was outstanding - stunning; a world class presentation. The entire production, sets costumes, performances in fact the realisation was both unique and at times breath taking. Congratulations to all involved.

Another Stunning Budapest Building. We paid for the guided tour in English, the largest group,and also to take photographs. The young Hungarian man's English was excellent, but rushed. He explained it was opened in 1884 to rival those in Paris, Vienna and Dresden and the magnificent interiors were the life's work of a Hungarian architect called Ybl. The vaulted, gilded ceiling in the foyer is covered in amazing murals, with marble columns at every turn, and chandeliers galore especially above the sweeping staircase (some weighing over 2 tons) , which give the whole opera house a feeling of opulence and grandeur. The theatre itself is awe inspiring. Two tips, too late we noticed the hop on/off bus offers a 20% discount, which we bought the next day and... only about half the people on our tour bought the right to take photographs (which was not enforced) therefore everyone happily snapped continuously,having paid or not.

Stunning. Went as a family on Saturday night to see the barber of seville....Amazing building truly magnificent and magical. The opera itself was amazing and kept all three of my children engaged. However, the staff are a little rude, but we did not let that ruin our evening. If you are in Budapest it is a must.

Tosca at it's finest.. This is one of my wife's favourite operas, and we have seen it several times. An excellent production in a majestic Opera house. One slight problem we didn't see her jump off the battlements at the end,
wonderful. Gorgeous building. We saw the opera buffa Don Pacuale and on other night the ballet Onyegin. Both spectacles very high quality.An unforgettable experience.

Excellent Opera play in a monument. What a chance watched an Opera play-Mefistofeles of Boito- in that gorgeous Opera of Budapest...Very interesting modern uploading of the play in a classical Opera theatre...
Oldest theater. This isquite an old opera theater , I did not get time to see it completely but for those of you who understand opera music , this place is worth visiting.

opulent splendour. Beautiful exterior, easily rivaled by the magnificent interior. there are two guided tours every day (15.00 and 16.00) in different languages. the tour takes you through the history of the build and then through the buildings which has incredible art work. the guide is knowledgeable and open to questions. the only regret is we didn't book tickets to the opera or ballet and hear the full acoustics!
Lovely building. This building is beautiful and is certainly worth a visit in my opinion. It is very easy to find and within easy walking distance from the main area in Budapest.

Glorious old building. Impressive from the outside and equally if not more magnificent on the inside. Worth a look. We did and even went to a world premiere Opera performance at a price equal to the price of a building tour.

Nice Opera. We visited opera in a guided tour (there are two tours a day), it is on 6 languages at the same time (different groups). Inspite of the fact that it was built smaller that Vienna Opera is not worse. Its scene and acoustic is one of the best in the world! It is really very interesting tour because you can visit places closed durinf performance (for example the hall which was used by Sisi). English tour is interesting, the guide answered all the questions and was very pleasent
guided tour. Sadly, we were not able to attend an opera performance. But we very much enjoyed the guided tour. The guide was excellent and the building was very interesting.

A mini Palais Garnier. Budapest reminds me a lot about Paris, and the Opera House is no exception. It is luxurious, acoustically perfect, prices are so inexpensive, and still has much of the 'old Europe' flavor.

Great performances in a beautiful theatre. First wow factor is the opera house itself, amazing architecture, ceilings, walls, murals: you have plenty to gawp at before the performance starts. We saw Eugene Onegin (ballet). Music was extremely well played, staging excellent and most of the dancing of the highest standard. I'd booked online, not realising that to get to the balcony you had to climb innumerable flights of stairs, but an extremely kind hostess saw me limping and took us backstage and up a lift. So full marks for service!

Wonderful!. La Boheme and The Nutcracker, booked online without any difficulty but wondering just how good the production could be at such low prices (compared with Covent Garden). Two excellent evenings of entertainment with stunning sets and costumes in an absolutely dazzling opera house.

impressive. I liked my visit there approx 45 min tour, very nice and impressive building the tour was in English with a good humored tour guide , I found the tour interesting and I recommend. NOTE if you take the green Hop ON HOP OFF bus use the discount coupon.

State Opera House. We booked to see Onegin, on Saturday 1st Feb 14. The tickets we found were very reasonably priced and we had two seats in a box very close to the stage. On entering the Opera House the main staircase is very impressive, and this fuels the expectation for what the seating area and stage will be like. we were not disappointed, wow what a place to visit to see any show. At the break the Bar was very close and so we were able to get in ahead of the crowd, prices were again very cheap. i would really recommend that anyone visiting Budapest takes the time to visit and enjoy an opera ballet or whatever is on when here it is not to be missed....

Good experience. We went to the Opera house to see an opera show, and between the acts we looked around on the beautiful architecture and decoration. The interior is very impressive and certainly worth seeing. If you see a show, I recommend using the intermissions to wander around in the different floors and look around you.The show itself was very enjoyable, although I wish they had used also English for subtitles, and not only Hungarian. We did expect it could happen so we read the story in the hotel before coming there.

Gorgeous and elegant...well worth a visit!!. My husband and I saw Ariande Auf Naxos by Wagner while in Budapest on vacation. Although the opera itself was a little strange to say the least, the opera house is beautiful and well worth a visit. The prices are very reasonable, and you can get a seat in one of the private boxes for less than the price of the cheap seats at most other opera houses. The opera boxes are elegantly lined in reds and golds, and make you feel like royalty while watching the opera. We have been to La Scala in Milan, and although the Hungarian State Opera doesn't have quite the reputation that La Scala does, it is a beautiful and magnificent opera house well worth visiting to listen to an opera or concert. They also have a nice lounge area where you can get a glass of wine or beer before the show and during intermission.

Ballet Onegin. With great pleasure we visited Budapest's Opera House. Great building, good acoustics. Beautiful ballet statement. It was very interesting to see the ballet Onegin, because we listened the opera by Tchaikovsky and were not sure that ballet is possible .

Fab building. I took my Mother to see Onegin ballet last week. We took a box which worked out at about £30 a ticket (3 seats to a box) and there was space to hang your coats inside the box, and the cloakrooms just outside the boxes.I was told off for taking a photo at the beginning of the ballet of my Mother. I did not have the flash on so it did not disrupt anyone. I thought this was a little harsh as my 78 year old Mother had travelled a long way to see this ballet in this building, and wanted to have a photo to remember her experience by. Shame on you State Opera House!It would have been 5 stars had it not been for this incident.

Anyegin. One the most beautiful architectures of the city. Enjoying the wonderful view sitting at the first floor gallery from a separate box with friends, gave us an amazing feeling for sunday evening ballet performance Anyegin. Colorful costumes, very delicate moves and creative acting. The directing is very creative with its before scenario ending moves. One the most beautiful shows of the season, a must to see performance. Having a separate box gave us the convenience of hanging our coats directly next to us. We had a direct access to the long area for refreshments between the scenes. Rest room was just in front of our door and didn't had to wait in any line. Parking is a bit hectic around the opera, so would suggest to take a taxi or arrive 30 min prior the show. Taxis are available just in front of the entrance after the show or the underground which stopped exactly at the entrance (gavel you an amazing oldies feeling to use it).

Amaz ing balett experience. We went to see the Ballet Anyegin....it was really a very nice experience....in the most powerful theatre in Central Europe....such a beautiful building with the whole spacious character. The building itself is a must to see....if you have a chance for a ballet or an opera or a classical music concert. Highly recommended for music lovers or even for a really different niteout....

Amazing. Amazing building. We went to see the ballet. We sat in row 10. This was perfect. The building is amazing, opulent and so inviting. You will need to hang your coats up. The interval drinks are inexpensive. Taxies are available at the end of the evening.
Get the seats for 1 Euro. You can buy a ticket for one Euro and move to the empty seats. Stunning views. I can highly recommend anyone to visit opera house.

Visit just to check out the arcitecture. Purchased tickets online prior to visiting Budapest. They were very low cost but not so good for seeing the opera. However got a great experience of seeing inside this magnificent building. I would not have missed this for the world. DO VISIT IF YOU CAN

Stunning. Went to see Don Pascale last week...the building was absolutely stunning....what a treat...be careful with the taxi's outside...we jumped into a cab outside and he charged us 6 times more than the taxi that took us there.

The Greatest Gift Shop in Budapest. I am not a big fan of the Opera and would have never stopped in, except that I was told during a walking tour that the Opera house had an amazing gift shop. I was quite impressed with the FRIENDLY staff and the items that they had for sale, (yes, they have opera items, but they also have an extensive display of Budapest items) and they appear to be the cheapest in town. They even have old Hungarian stamps and currency that make great gifts. I do know that there are two tours, at 3pm and 4pm and it costs a little extra to take pictures). You can buy your tour tickets in the gift shop.

Small opera house and badly run tours. There's not a TON to see in Budapest, so almost every tourist comes to the Opera House. It was badly managed--why in the world do they tuck the ticket counter way back in the back nook of the shop? Why do all the language start at the same time--why not stagger entry? The tour itself is not that great...some interesting facts were shared, but overall, it was disappointing--especially if you've been through Vienna's or Paris' opera.
beautiful building. We attended a Strauss comedic opera one evening so experienced both the beauty of the building but also the excellence of the productions in this historic opera hall.

Great Building, shame about the Opera.. The building is truly stunning and clearly Budapest society takes it seriously as everyone was dressed up. But the house has some strange aspects, the seats are unnumbered so finding seats is messy and they insist you check in your coat. (although you can ignore the entreaties as we did!!) We saw La Boheme which was very poor. The actors needed to come to the front of the stage to sing, which meant they were standing in a line. This works for some parts but is ridiculous when the couple are falling in love but not looking at each other. Acts 2 and 3 were confused and the Italian was not particularly good. In contrast the music was excellant. Certainly worth a visit when in Budapest.

Excellent!. Decided to go and see an opera rather than book the guided tour because it was possible to get ok seats for less money. Very pleased that we did. The performance was very high standard and the building itself is beautiful. The musicians were very impressive. Tip: You have to pay to store your coats and they won't let you take them in with you.

Most beautiful interiors in Budapest. Did the guided tour. The building is stunning and worth seeing. The tour is not cheap. There are even operas/concert tickets that are cheaper so rather book to see something than do the tour.

Gem of Imperial Style. What a pretty little opera house! It is intimate, the acoustics are excellent, the music, the scenery, the voices and the overall look of the production are all wonderful. We saw "La Boheme" and it was beautifully done. The only thing I was surprised about was the fact that, although we had a box, we were not allowed to bring a drink inside. Frankly, what is the point of having a box if you cannot be comfortable? Never mind, that didn't spoil our evening.
Saw the Nutcracker. Nothing to say but amazing! The Opera House is beautiful. The ballet was such a great experience for our daughter and it was just a very good evening.

Wonderful building. We took in an Opera (Die Fledermaus) for New Years Eve and had a great seat in a box, which us a lot closer to the interval bar and washrooms than the stalls. Reasonably priced and outstanding singing and staging. Quite up to the standard of London and a much more magnificent building.

Beautiful building. The building itself is beautiful from the outside, the same in the lobby. There are tours at 3 and 4 pm that we were not able to take but I'm sure they can give you a more in depth look to the opera
Hungarian State Opera House. This tour was very interesting, both in terms of the architecture and of the history of the building. I'm glad I went, even though I'm not a big opera fan.

Magnificent Building. This late Victorian Opera House is built in the same Neo-Classical/Neo-Renaissonce style as the Opera Houses in Vienna and Kracow. The building is an impressive stone structure that is extensively decorated inside in gold and red with marble stairs, murals and sculpture. I saw two performances on Christmas Day. The first was the Nutcracker where the orchestra and the sets were great. The principle dancers were good although the dancing by the supporting cast was a little clumsey. In the evening I saw La Boheme and it was also excellent. At that time I sat in a box and the view was extremely good. Acting, singing, music and sets were all excellent for this performance. Tickets are relatively cheap and so this is a good opportunity to hear opera in an old world setting. You can also have tours of the building itself.
lovely a gem!. superb architecture, petite compared to the major operas in Europe yet its distinctive style makes it so cute! Pity we did not find tickets for New Year's Eve!

Last tour of Opera House in 2013. Brilliant tour given by an extremely knowledgeable guide. We were taken throughout the opera house as well as in the auditorium. Our guide spoke perfect English with a lot of humour. Definitely worth it.
New Years Eve. We visited the Opera on New Years Eve to see a performance of Die Fledermaus it was a fun evening and the fireworks at midnight were great....

The tour - a taster of opera - ideal for reluctant teens!. On New Year's Day we booked the 4 o'clock tour of the opera as a last minute thing to do before heading for the airport. We just turned up 20 minutes in advance and bought tickets for the tour from the souvenir shop - including tickets allowing us to take photographs and for the mini performance at the end. The tour lasted 40 minutes and the performance lasted 10 minutes or so. We were out easily in under an hour as there were rehearsals due to take place for that evening's performance. 2 guides divided up the English-speaking group as we were by far the biggest tour group. We crisscrossed around the building to avoid bumping into and overhearing the German, French, Chinese tours- a feat in itself! The info we were given was very interesting and informative but the highlight was the mini performance at the end. It was a moving experience to be standing 4/5 feet from an opera singer who projected her voice as if she were on stage performing to a large crowd. At one point she held an empty wine glass in her hand as she sang. I was half expecting it to shatter but it didn't! Very memorable and special

Worth visiting- book a performance!. Having done some research prior to visiting Budapest, I knew I wanted to see the Nutcracker at the opera house. To get tickets online, you can book them in advance about two months before the performance. Seats are a very reasonable price, so we opted for the stalls, but I would have loved a box. The nutcracker itself was spectacular and certainly a very festive addition to our winter break.

Hungarian State Opera House. Delightful surprise! We were a group of youngsters and we had a bilingual guided tour around the Opera. Simply amazing! The luxuriant decor, the rich story, I was in awe. The guide was extremely good and in the end we had a surprise mini opera concert. For sure the singers were extremely talented. The Opera House is a must-see on any trip to Budapest. It is totally worth it.However, in order to take pictures inside the Opera, you have to pay a small fee of approximately 2€. Also ticket prices for performance are extremely affordable and relatively cheaper compare to other european Opera Houses.

A jewel in town. You can find so many old opera houses, but only two-three in the world are so nicely decorated and so big as the Budapest State Opera House. Fresques and wooden covered walls, beautiful. Visits in different languages almost every day. But try to get a ticket, it's better!

A great experience. No matter whats on, opera or ballet, attending an event at the Hungarian National Opera in Budapest is a great experience. The Opera is an architectural masterpiece, beautifully maintained with tickets at very reasonable prices with the most expensive ones being around 55 euros.The opera website is an excellent way to find tickets and if one cannot find availability, hotel concierges usually have their way.We watched La Boheme, and although not understanding Italian nor the Hungarian subtitles, we found the experience to be unique and thoroughly enjoyable.

Great Place. My wife and I saw two different shows at the Opera House. The architecture and the acoustics were amazing. It also has a metro stop right in front of it which makes getting there easy. Look forward to going back in the future.

La Boheme matinee performance. During our stay in Budapest we attended a matinee performance of La Boheme at the magnificent Hungarian State Opera house. The building is breathtaking on both the inside and out. This was the first time I have seen La Boheme and it's now one of my favourite operas. The subtitles were in hungarian so make sure you read the synopsis a few times beforehand. The opera is broken down into four acts with a 20 minutes intermission after act two. Like normal, there are long queues in the ladies toilets so allow yourself plenty of time or see my tip. Photos and videos are permitted inside but not during the performance. A great cultural experience. Tips Go up the stairs where the stalls are as there is no queuing for toilets there.There is a charge to store your coatDon't sit to close to the orchestra pit as you may find the conductor a distraction There are opera house tours at 3 and 4 o'clock most days

Great way to start the holidays... We were able to get box seats the day before the performance. We enjoyed the production especially from our seats. Since we didn't anticipate going to the ballet on this trip, we felt slightly under dressed compared to the locals who do dress up.

I have a great desire to go to the Opera. We were not able to take advantage of the Opera House tour on our visit to Budapest last year so on our return this year it was on the top of our "To Do" list -Thank goodness!Bought tickets in the shop at the opera for the 4 pm tour.There were about twenty others on this tour with the English speaking guide.the tour lasted about one hour and was filled with the most interesting information.To walk around and have the history explained was a delight and to finish sitting in the Auditorium made us wish our visit to Budapest had coincided with an opera. Nert time perhaps.I would recommend this tour.

Fantastic architecture. If you don't get the time to watch an Opera, go inside the building and look up the ceiling and around. Get a local guide to tell you the story how the opera house was built, it's fascinating.

Fantastic. One of the best memories of my visit in Budapest! The building was amazing!!! The performance(La Bohemia) was good and although it was in Italian with Hungarian subtitles (so it could be a problem for those who don't speak Italian or Hungarian) the act was indulgent!!! If you don't like Opera you should at least see the building!

Well worth having the guided tour.. This is a very impressive building and you are able to go in and have a look round the ground floor which is stunning. We booked onto one of the regular daily tours which take place in various languages. Our English speaking guide was very fluent and informative and we felt it was worth the 3300 HFTs (approx. £10) per person. We didn't purchase the add on performance (only about 15 mins) as we were short of time but we did have to pay to take photos. The tour took about 1/2 hour once we got started.
Nutcracker superb. I'm not an avid ballet fan but its definitely worth going to watch. The opera house is a good to see and is absolutely amazing inside

A great experience. I should say at the outset that I am not a ballet or opera fan, but treated my wife who is to a performance of the Nutcracker. Wow - what a place - wonderful theatre with over the top decoration. Make sure you go for a drink in the bar before the performance - it's the grandest bar you'll ever visit.Oh and the ballet itself was really good - I think !!!!

Budapest Opera. Visited La Boheme by PucciniVery impessive but translation is only in Hungary and no English Cheap seat prices can have view limitationsareHall and entrance very impressive Orchestra and conductor very good

Opera House - Budapest, Hungary. I was there for a tour and not a music production...very good tour. Did hear a little music as the piano was being tuned...nice. This building is spectacular inside....definately is a building to take the time to see.

Spectacular experience. We watched the philharmonic Christmas concert from box seats, complete with red velvet chairs and railings, for $33 each. [Note, I booked tickets online two months in advance.] We felt like royalty perched above the crowd. The sound was superb. Sitting high allowed us a great view of the stage as well as a closeup of the frescoed ceiling, crystal chandelier, and other adornments. We were allowed to take photos until the show started for no extra fee on both the grand red carpeted staircases and inside the house. No coat check was required as there are coat hooks inside the boxes. There are bathrooms just for the box seats in the hallway. Besides the exquisite classical guitar playing by Csaki Andres (truly amazing), one of our favorite parts was joining the synchronized clapping to invite encores. And ending with a spirited encore of Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairies was a wonderful surprise. Why spend money on a limited tour when you can take in a show. Tickets on the floor or in the balcony are often less than the tour price.

interesting and informative. Although we did not stay to take in a performance, I found the tour to be reasonably priced, very informative and even though you paid extra to take pictures, no one ever checked.

Budapest Boheme. Bargain price seats with limited view, but a great experience and a wonderfully decorated building. Nice Xmas touches outside. Competent singers and solid playing. staging a bit cheap looking but we weren't expecting Covent Garden!

A spectacular vision of beauty. We took a tour of the Opera House and found it to be one of the most beautiful buildings inside that we have visited. It is a smaller room but very lovely. We did not attend an event but understand that the prices are kept reasonable so that locals can actually attend the events.

Amazing. After reading reviews we decided to purchase tickets for the ballet via the web very easy. So pleased we did. The building is beautiful the price of the seats, although they are quite hard, are much cheaper than other ballets we have been to. Drinks (800 huf for 'champagne') were very cheap considering the venue. We were in row 12, seats 8 and 9 and had a very good view of the stage as the seats are staggered. A wonderful evening in an amazing building.

Cracking!. My wife booked tickets via internet for a Nutcracker. At 6pm on Sat. 7th Dec., apx. 35GBP each in stalls row 5, which I think is a very reasonable price all things considered. Have some small change for the cloak room. There are two issues here: one is the building itself and its décor, the other-the performance. On both counts outstanding!The Budapest Opera House is a gem. I would say it was built in an eclectic style; with gilded plasterwork everywhere, marble and frescoes it at times resembles the inside of St.Mark’s Basilica in Venice. It is not a very big or spacious edifice but full of nooks and crannies, impressive staircase and foyer where one can buy drinks and snacks between acts. It is well worth a visit on its own but seeing it in its full glory at the time of the performance, with crowds having great time was a joy not to be missed.I would not miss the ballet for a world either. I am not an art critic yet I have seen quite a few ballets in my life and this performance surely must count as one of the best. The quality of the dancers, the rich scenography, the music was first class. What a wonderful night out around Christmas time! If I were to criticize anything it would be that the seats are not padded enough to my liking, in which-my wife reminds me-it is not unlike in the La Scala. Perhaps, like in a church your mind is meant thus to be directed to loftier, spiritual or artistic matters? It was an unforgettable evening completed with a light supper nearby and a leisurely walk back to the hotel.

worth a visit. On our recent trip to Budapest we did a 1 hour tour of the opera house tours daily 3pm or 4pm the guide was very informative. The opera was very impressive, it was also a reasonable price for the tour.

An experience not to be missed!. We passed by the Opera House every time we went out to see the city, so actually going in finally to see the premier night of La Boheme was a special treat. It was a short walk from the hotel too.There was a group singing carols outside but we couldn't stay to watch as we didn't want to be late for the show.The opulence of the interior is just outstanding! I'm pleased that they allowed photography before the curtains went up. I managed some great shots with my iPhone but it could not capture the classic beauty of the grandeur.The show itself was amazing, my very first opera, and I enjoyed it. I did find however when the actors were taking bows at the end of each act just how unhappy they are. Maybe they're nervous excited but a smile wouldn't hurt! The actor who played Mimi was simply astounding. Her voice is incredible.I'm glad I got to experience this and in such a beautiful place no less!

Not to miss. I took the guided tour. Even though there were a couple of aspects that reminded me of the Opera House in Vienna, this one is smaller but much more richly decorated, with a profusion of materials, colors, shapes, patterns that some might even find a bit excessive.What I really, positively, absolutely adored was the auditorium. Just...ravishing!

Madam Butterfly. We were going to be in Budapest for 3 nights at the end of November so checked the program of events in advance and booked tickets online for Madam Butterfly, the process was very easy and they emailed the tickets to me also the cost was £28 for 6 tickets !!! and the seats were in the front row of the upper balcony. The seats were brilliant and the show was fantastic, although sung in Italian and the subtitles were in Hungarian we still understood what was going on as we had researched the story before arriving.It was a great night out.

Book months in advance. Online booking system was super easy and all emails were answered promptly. We got private box seats for Giselle ballet - wonderful production with world class dancers and the opera house interior was breathtaking. Come 30 minutes early to get some great shots of the building.

Book the Ballet - it's wonderful!. The actual building (like most in Budapest) is stunning and impresses you both inside and out. We booked to see the Nutcracker Ballet and thoroughly enjoyed it!! The price of the tickets were very reasonable, we booked two in a box which was fine but we had an extra person with a chair behind which insisted on squeezing in next to us to watch the show. If I went again I wouldn't pay for box seats - you are looking sideways which also hurts your neck a bit. I'd be quite happy in the regular seats next time!They do charge to put your coats in the cloak room so take some change. The refreshments at the intervals gets very busy so you need to rush to get to them if you have any chance for getting a drink before the performance starts again.Overall a very lovely experience and would definitely go again!
Nutcracker ballet. Simply outstanding even from "the gods". So many beautiful dancers, huge appreciative audience. A great experience.

Zero view to the stage. Very nice building and all but it is ridiculous that so many seats have ZERO view to the stage!! Why do they even sell tickets for places with no view? Even being the cheapest seats at the opera they should have a little view. We didn't even stay the whole performance. Advise: Don't buy cheap seats for the highest balcony if there not in the front row!

Stunning Experience - Book Tickets Early. A truly magical experience combining a beautiful building, stunning performances and wonderful ambience. No trip to budapest would be complete without seeing this stunning venue.

fabulous tour with great tour guide. the opera house is very beautiful and it's great to get more detail about how it was built and information on the people who did the building. You pay extra to take photos and you also pay extra to get a mini-performance at the end (our tour got 2 popular opera pieces by a very competent performer - and she included an audience member).

World's Greatest Opera Bargain. I attended Strauss' Salome on 28th November, Puccini's Madama Butterfly on 29th November, and Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker and Verdi's Otello on 30th November. Excellent gallery seats with terrific acoustics. Total cost? About 25 USD.And the performances? Absolutely world class. I've rarely heard better (and have often heard worse) in San Francisco, and Chicago, and New York, and Vienna. What's more, the productions were consistently enjoyable - never disfigured by the sort of egomaniacal directors, indifferent to the composer's intentions, who tend to plague the aforementioned venues.When it comes to value for money, opera-wise, Budapest's only rival is Prague.
Hungarian and international performances. How many of our world famous opera singers started their carreer at Budapest Opera House... and still so many talents are singing and dancing for you here...

Wonderful "Madame Butterfly". We were lucky to get the last two seats together in a center second balcony, second row booth. For $45. for the two tickets, we were thrilled. The performance was fantastic. The Opera House is beautiful with lots of pink marble, gold leaf, and paintings of Greek myths. It was a fantastic evening.

Superb Building. Featured in the new Dracula series that was filmed in Budapest earlier this year.
My first Opera Experience and building is visually much more interesting than La Scala
Excellent acoustics, very comfortable

Thrilled to see Madame Butterfly. Because we were staying in Budapest three days I checked the Opera House site as what might be playing. We're not opera fans but when I saw Madame Butterfly was there I checked tickets and couldn't believe I got two seats way up in highest balcony for $15.50. When we arrived and took in the beautiful grand entrance and then showed our tickets the young attendant said we'd have to use the side entrance!! We had to laugh...aha..cheap seats!! We actually had fine seats and could see the stage and of course the acoustics were perfect. Our night at our first opera was a great experience even though I had to keep poking my husband to stay awake!!

Been there many times. Very affordable by American prices standards and good productions. The house interior itself is one of the most beautifaul in the world and rivals Paris. Not many can compare. Get a box for a great performing arts experience!

Beautiful Opera House. The Hungarian State Opera House (Magyar Allami Operahaz) is a beautiful theatre with fine acoustics. We saw "Madame Butterfly" there and it was a terrific production with a talented cast. Unlike theatres in the USA, this theatre features opera all day long. Be advised: You can see a wonderful opera at 11:00 A.M. for a lot less money than the evening performances go for.
take a tour. stunningly beautiful building, we took the tour and paid a little extra for a mini concert, well worth it.

Madame Butterfly at a wonderful price. I have been here before, enjoy opera and love a good evening out. My wife had never been to an opera and wasn't sure. Having checked the price of Opera at Covent Garden we have always steered away until we were sure she'd like it. So when in Budapest imagine how happy I was to see that a) Madame Butterfly was on and b) seats in the stalls, 7 rows back were only £45 each. It is a gorgeous building, extremely ornate and a brilliant setting for an opera. The show was really good and an excellent introduction to opera. Well staged and beautifully sung. Interval drinks on the balcony overlooking Andrassy Ut is also something to experience...but pre-order your interval drinks as the queues can be long. All in all a great evening and my wife is now a convert....so we may bnow treat ourselves in London.

A grand theater. Toured the Opera House this morning. It's a grand baroque palace. Gold leaf abounds, with formal staircases. I did feel that our guide rushed us through, even though we were the only group there. We took the tour at 9:00 am but the Gift Shop didn't open until 11:00. That was annoying!

Beautiful Original Opera House. A truly beautiful building in pristine, original condition. We had a great guide who was extremely knowledgeable and spoke very good English. They do charge two euros to take pictures. A site not to be missed in Budapest.

Beautiful, but hot inside. Don't dress in heavy clothes if going to a performance; the seats are very uncomfortable and the temperature is very hot. But it is a lovely building and the music is usually very good.

Tremendous Experience. We went to see Madame Butterfly and thoroughly enjoyed it. The place was full so do prebook but this was easy and straightforward. Do go smartly dressed: it adds to the experience!!

An Elegant Jewel. Before we left for Europe we were able to buy tickets on line for La Traviata . Excellent seats were half of what one would pay at the Met here in New York. The house itself is perfect for slightly more intimate operas, and the production we attended was delightful. We were surprised to find the opera began at 11 o`clock in the morning, but that gave us time to enjoy a leisurely lunch and do some sight seeing afterward. Going to the opera, even if it is in the daytime is obviously a special occasion so people were dressed very nicely. The hall is a real beauty, so even if you don`t go to a performance a tour is well worth while.

Wonderful experience and certainly the best value for money in town!. Sometimes booking online can be a nightmare. But I have to say that the portal for the Hungarian State Opera is really user-friendly. And the most amazing thing is what you pay at check out. For a few minutes, I thought I only paid for the booking charges ... . You don't get to watch quality opera for €27 anywhere in the world. This time round I watched La Traviata. As others have noticed, the acoustics is excellent and the interior is beautiful and charming. The accompanying orchestra is just superb. The only minor complaint I have is that the production and staging is very staid and not at all innovative. I feel like I am watching a recording from the 60s but you can't fault anyone technically for their singing except - maybe for the poor Italian diction of 'Violetta'. (I'm somewhat finicky though.) So, the music and the singing is splendid if you love opera. Overall, the HSO is a must for opera lovers. It is by far, the most inspiring few hours I spent in Budapest. Tips: 1. Don't worry too much about the seating - it is a very small theatre and even the seats at the far back of the stall or circle are good. 2. The surtitles are in Hungarian, so it is useful if you understand the language the opera is sung in or if you are familiar with the piece.

Stunning building but tour a little rushed. The tour costs 2,900 HUF (check for discounts from companies such as tour buses) plus 500 HUF for a photo licence Tours were available in many languages and I guess there were maybe 100 people in 6 or 7 groups. Our English-language guide was excellent but the tour was a little too rushed as one group had wait for the preceding group to vacate an area before it could move in. The intricate woodwork in the lesser rooms was impressive but this left too little time in the auditorium - especially as we had bought a photo licence ticket.We did the tour on a Monday afternoon and mistakenly thought the 3pm tour on a non-performance day would be fairly leisurely but it lasted only 50 minutes - presumably in time for the guides to prepare for the 4pm show - maybe that one would have been a little less rushed.The building is stunning and overall the rather expensive tour is worth doing.

A night at the Opera. This could be one of the best bargains around for lovers of music and culture. For the price of a baseball ticket we sat in the front of two rows in a semi-private box of this small jewel, which is said to be more beautiful than the opera house in Vienna. At the first intermezzo the bartender had the snacks and drinks we ordered just before the opera started ready on a table with a silver platter. After the performance, during the curtain call the audience began clapping in unison, faster and faster, until they broke back into regular clapping. We were not sure if this was a Hungarian tradition or if this was meant to be a united compliment by the audience. Either way, it was a wonderful way to end the performance. We finished the evening with a light dinner next door at Callas restaurant.
Excellent venue and Accoustics. Excellent value for money with all the trimmings that go with attending a great opera spectacle. champagne glittering chandeliers and great performances.

Be careful. If you buy tickets on official site opera, See in which theater it is. Some people buying tickets for opera house but in last moment in Opera house him told that this show in Erkel. This is new scene in other place. We are take taxi and not too late, but some people confused and lose money.And the most important thing that the new scene is not necessary, interesting old building.We turned around and walked away from this sludge

Beautiful opera house; wonderful opera. We saw Othello, and it was phenomenal. The opera house is typical Baroque complete with frescoes, etc. the boxes are old-fashioned and small with fluffy red velvet cushions. We sat on the second row, and the tickets were very reasonable. We loved being able to see the faces of the orchestra as well as the cast. Take the tour at least if you don't have time to go to the opera.

Madam Butterfly in Budapest. Stunning building with lavish decoration. Buy a drink at the interval in the bar. It's like drinking in an opulent palace. Seeing an opera is so much better than just having a tour. You really get into the feel of the place. And Madam Butterfly was great too!
Nutcracker ballet. Excellent performance, outstanding performers all round, both the orchestra and ballet. Fantastic venue, great value

Impressive opera house, nice tour. The opera house was so beautiful. So stately, grand, not overly ostentatious, but just beautiful & a real presence. I’m no opera buff, I leave that to hubby, but we did manage a tour which was about an hour & after all you get a ‘mini opera’ [about 5-10 minutes of small performance from a singer, ours was male & pretty amusing, you simply stand around in the foyer & watch until they usher you out]. The tour guide was young but knowledgeable & you are shown around various parts of the opera house in a well oiled operated. It is a lovely place & we elected to not see the show as it was almost 4 hours & my hubby was not sure I’d have the stamina. But compared to Vienna & Paris the shows here seem very affordable & this is an opera house which matches the best of them.

La traviata - very nice!!!. First of all, the building itself is already worth a visit! It is a very old and looks fabulous. It isn't as big as the state opera in Prague but nevertheless I think it was even more beautiful.The showroom in which the opera took place was quite big and very impressive!! The opera itself was fantastic! I haven't seen lots of operas so I can just tell you my personal impression, but I was enchanted! The seats were a little too hard though after 2 hours an a half, but you cannot miss a spectacle in the opera if you visit Budapest and if you like this kind of spectacle!
