A lovely experience. Our tour of this fabulous Opera House was well worth the visit. It gave us such insight into the history of this beautiful structure and all that it means to the Hungarian people. Stay for the mini opera at the end as it is a wonderful culmination of your tour....

€14 for tour and mini concert. And that's not including photography charge, which I didn't purchase. Not the grandest opera in size or interior, not sure about the acoustic as I didn't attend a proper concert there. I know y they can afford to constantly restore the whole building while other opera houses in the world are constantly begging for donation. I really think it's overpriced and the mini concert was absolutely mini mini, about 5 min, you just stand around to 'enjoy' it. Real disappointed with this tourist scam.
Nice ballet performance. Visited the opera for 'The golden brush' a ballet performance.Everything is gold, gold and gold.I would suggest a dress circle box, nice private and a great view.
Spectular building. What a pleasure to see an opera in this wonderful building.An absolute must if you are visiting Budapest.

Rich in history and talent. We were able to visit this beautiful opera house on a recent tour. Named as one of the top 10 opera houses in the world, this building is kept in mint condition while preserving its history!!! We were surprised with a mini performance by a male and female singers! Their songs gave us chills! What a great stop on our tour of Budapest.

Pity we'd seen Vienna's first. OK perhaps 3 stars is a bit unfair but when compared to Vienna that we had visited a few days earlier, it gets beaten hands down. Yes it is a mini edition of the other opera house and the funding came mainly through the same royal purse. The tour was more expensive than Vienna, the decor similar, the tour shorter and more hurried, and we didn't get to see backstage in this case. We did pay an extra premium for a mini-concert lasting 10 minutes officially - 2 arias, very well sung - but over in 5 minutes.Probably more entertaining than all those dusty museums, but there's a Caravaggio exhibition on currently till early next year. That would have been the better bet.

Performance needed more passion. The opera house is beautiful and if you are not interested in seeing an opera you can join a tour of the opera house in the afternoon at 3.00 or 4.00 p.m. My wife and I have been fortunate in visiting many opera houses in Europe and have rarely visited a more beautiful opera house. I wish I could say the same for the performance of La Traviata that we saw. The soprano climbed to the top notes and the baritone put in a workmanlike performance without any projection or passion. The saving grace was the orchestra which was superb led by a world class conductor. We left after the 7th curtain call and the audience were still whistling & cheering. All I can say is that if the Hugarians think this is a top class performance, they should get out more.

Beautiful building. Did a tour of the Opera House last month. Tour was good, but included nothing about "behind the scenes" and we could not take any photos as we did not purchase the ticket allowing this. Our tour guide in the English tour was a young guy who was very interesting and engaging.The "Mini Opera" involved dozens of people standing in a room listening to a man (who was admittedly very good) singing along to a tape recording of 2 songs. In hindsight, I would happily have skipped the mini opera, but there were people in the group who seemed to really enjoy it.

Go to the Opera !. Instead of doing a tour of the Opera House - why not go to a performance. Unlike London, Opera in Europe is accessible and reasonable. I paid £42 for a fantastic seat in this beautiful opera house to see La Traviata. Even if you aren't sure if you like opera - its well worth going and is nicely informal but smart.
Nice tour. Our tour included a mini-concert of about 15-20 minutes which was a lot of fun. The building is beautiful and very interesting.

Fabulous building, brilliant ballet. One of our treats was a visit to the State Opera House to see the National Ballet Company in a ballet about a hungarian artist, Mihály Munkácsy.The Opera House is an absolute gem, and has retained all its original features, without being compromised to offer the uneccessary frills and furbelows demanded by a modern mimsy audience. I am disabled, and have mobility problems, but I would not want to see one part of this beautiful building altered to accomodate lifts or escalators. We booked our tickets online, and were dealt with speedily and efficiently, with helpful courteous staff on hand at every turn to assist us to our seats, two seats in a shared box, next to the Royal Box, for just £12.00 each. What a bargain, the box was fine, we arranged our seats to afford an excxellent view, and the performance was first class. In a building of this size and grandeur, I was amazed at how well maintained and clean the building was, obviously well loved by both staff and public alike, and extremely well supported. During the first interval, we had wine in the bar, with access to the grand balcony overlooking Andrassy Utca, what a treat! For those with limited views, large screen TVs were provided on each side of the proscenium, so the needs of the audience have been considered, but not at the expense of the superb original building. Highly recommended, but the best way to see any such venue is during a live performance, it is as though the whole building comes alive.

Skip the "Mini Opera". The tour is good, everything you would expect to see inside, but I wish they included the backstage as well. Just SKIP the "Mini Opera"... you will see an actress lipsynch to two opera numbers at the bar area. It was painful to watch.

Inexpensive Opera At A Beautiful Venue. The performance of La Traviata my girlfriend and I saw didn't quite measure up to operas we'd seen at The Met, but it was still very good opera in a world-class theater. Apparently the acoustics are among the best of any opera house in the world, and I thought they lived up to their reputation. As the other reviews point out, tours for the opera house are much more expensive than watching a show from the third floor. The tickets we bought were about 7 dollars each, and we were perfectly happy with our seats. If you're wondering whether to opt for the absolute cheapest tickets, I'd suggest paying a little extra so you're not sitting in the back rows of the canopy sides. Those seemed like the only seats in the house where the stage might not be clearly visible.It's also worth noting that checking your coat into the cloakroom is mandatory, so be sure to bring around 400 HUF in change.

Elegant building, excellent production. I was hesitant to try taking my small kids to the opera but finally decided that if we could get cheap-ish seats it would be worth an attempt even if we had to leave early. I am so glad we stopped in to ask if there were inexpensive seats left one night because we scored 4 seats together, facing the stage, on the 3rd (highest) tier. I had heard the cheap seats all have views facing away from the stage or are behind other seats without any lift so you can't see anything, but we had a really good view for 6,000 florints total. (about $30) I was annoyed by the extra coatroom fee (non optional) as it was not specified ahead of time (what if I wasn't carrying cash at the time?) but it wasn't too exorbitant, I just don't see why they don't add it to the ticket price automatically. I was nervous that the kids would bother other people sitting around us but they managed to be quiet and still until the very end of act 2 of La Traviata. (I spent most of the time nursing the youngest and holding the others hand to remind them not to bother anyone.) We left at the second intermission before they got too bored to behave nicely. The music was spectacular and the sets and costumes were very well done. I was quite disappointed to leave early but wanted to keep the whole thing fun for the kids (so they'll want to return in future!) and not make the evening unpleasant for other fans. Many people have said the seats are uncomfortable but they seemed fine to me, just not uber padded. There is a thin velvet pad over a old fashioned wooden theater seat. The arm rests are even at a comfortable height for supporting an elbow while nursing. ;-)

Wonderful old building. The tour is pretty useful, meaning that despite it does not last very long, it is informative enough. The building is wonderful and beautiful, reminding of the Habsburg era. Try to attend a show, but do not expect to see any subtitles :)

WOW!. I went to the Opera House to see the ballet group. The interior is outstanding beautifull. T hough i need to write some remarks. The out look of the Opera is neglected. I felt like wanting to take a brush,water and soap and give it a clean shinnng look. My second remark : i bought the ticket via internet,therfore i had to go to a side entance and climb 5 floor by feet... why?
Just Walk in and Look Around. Didn't see a production there but walked in and gawked at the gilt and marble and architecture. Worth a walk-through.

When is budapest going to use some of its huge Tourists profits to change the seats in the Opera. This is the second time over a span of many years that we have attended an Opera performance.(1)why charge an Outrageous fee at the Cloakroom.(You cannot sneak in with your coat on!) (2) With such a large number of tourists,why NOT have a translation other than Hungarian ? (3) such a beautiful building with such awful,creaking ,uncomfortable seats !We left after the Second Act as we could no longer sit ! I have set more comfortably at football stadiums.For a City that lives on tourism,eventually tourists will come to see the building but NOT to hear operas ! SHAME !

Just a visit rather than an evening out.. This is quite an intimate Opera house. The décor is quite stunning in places and generally impressive. We took a tour round as we did not manage to get tickets for an opera. The tour was in English although other language tours were also given. We paid a supplement for a short operatic taster at the end which gave the flavour, Two "pieces" were sung with no holding back! It is on one of the stops on the hop-on hop-off red bus.

Very pretty. The opera house is a gorgeous building, nicely maintained inside and out. The tour is crowded and pretty short, no behind the scenes tour and no performance in the theater. A solo singer came out and sang in the Royal lobby, which was cool.

Grand Building and Opera for $3!. This was my first Opera experience. We had expensive cheap tickets, cheap cheap tickets can be had for 600 HUF, so were front row up in the clouds which was great but being cheap tickets we were pointed out of the main entrance round the corner and in through a side entrance to a bare stairwell. Seating was very tight but the building is magnificent, the experience well worth the time and certainly beats deciding where to eat your next meal.

Tour of interest!. The Opera House was amazing! You will have several choices of tickets to purchase. The tours are given in many languages. Just make sure you get in the correct group. Our guide was very knowledgeable and truly was proud of his heritage, as he should be, and very much enjoyed sharing his vast knowledge about the famous Opera House. Architectually, the building is beautiful and it is difficult to distinguish between the faux and true marble. I was made aware that most of the marble here is actually Hungarian. It takes about an hour but to me was so worth it.

BEAUTIFULLLLLLLLL!. We had a wonderful tour of this magnificent building, and then were serenaded by members of the opera. It brought tears to my eyes and was beautifully done. Wish we could have been in town when an actual performance was planned.

Opera Visit. Very popular visit and a bit chaotic to start with but they are used to large groupos interesting and worth a visit you also can have a "mini" concert. This was a lady singing a couple of arias at the end of the visit and quite fun
Hapsburg era opera house. A very beautiful and impressive building which allows one to appreciate the opulence and style of the era in which the Hapsburg's ruled from Vienna.

Tour of Opera House Expensive, Guide Not Understandable. The short tour of the Opera House costs 2900 Forints (about $13.75). Our guide (very much impressed with herself) spoke marginal English with a strong accent, and to make things worse, there were multiple tours going on in the same room with different languages. This tour shows only a small section of the Opera House, compared to the tour of the Vienna Opera House, which shows you EVERYTHING for US$8.80!

a night at the opera. We came here last year for a night at the opera and Carmen was the opera showing at the time. Arriving early the day before we got tickets with no fuss to one of the boxes on the side for about 21 pounds each. We were happy to pay for these as they were front row of the box and a million times charioteer than the UK.There are some seats above the boxes that sell for around 500huf which is about 1.50! But we thought treat ourselves and dress up.The night was lovely with a couple of minor things we could pick faults at:We both suffer from vertigo, our own fault for seat choice really.The building could do with some minor touch ups as showing its age.Bring a small cushion as seats aren't the most comfortable.Hungarian subtitles above the stage mind of spoil the ambience a bit.But all in all, a very enjoyable night at a cost to that is similar of the tours during the day. If we do go back we will probably shell out for the cheapest seats as the music reaches it just fine there as well.

Truly a Memorable Evening. After taking a tour of the opera house in Buenos Aires, I have visited others...in Paris and Vienna... and this one in Budapest was magnificent. I went to a performance by the state opera, and it was very entertaining. I will always remember it, and very fondly. The gorgeous theatre, the boxes, the people watching and, oh yeah, some people singing in Italian and killing themselves on-stage over mishaps and misunderstandings about love. (It was Tosca. Eh.)I can't comment on a visit and/or tour instead of a performance but do try to see this spectacular building and theatre in some way if you are in Budapest.
in the footsteps of Sisi. Did not see a show, only visited but fans of Sisi will like it. It is pretty, sound is good and historic side of it interesting

A Must See. The Opera House is magnificent! Beautiful rose marble staircases and gilded viewing boxes. The Opera House is a must see architecturally. We were also fortunate to be able to attend a performance of Giselle while there - Wonderful!
Great evening.. Saw The Royal Philharmonic Orchestra here and it was fantastic. Beautiful building. Wonderful experience for our Honeymoon. Worth seeing what is on in order to spend an evening here.

Such an impressive building. You need to go just to see the building. We did the tour and it was very well done with interesting information regarding the building. If we were going to see an opera there I think we would opt for a production that is not too long. The seats are all history and as such are not the most comfortable. They were designed to keep people awake and it works. This is an incredible building and such a wonderful insight into the period.

A Wonderful House. This is a small venue by US standards but magnificent in design and decoration. I don't think there is a bad seat in the house. Sound was undistorted and clear without amplification. It did not matter that we understood not a word of the German text....the cast projected all the necessary emotion.

Must do. What a fabulous theater, super service and well organized.Only one point of improvement, the seats are wearing thin and when attending an opera of 4 hours, this starts to feel.Do let this keep you away. Just entering the building is worth any ticket.

opera for the deaf. Went to two productions (Falstaff and Wagner) The production and lighting was unbelievably bad. The cast of singers some of the worst I have ever experienced. In a ciountry which bosts Bartok Solti etc I had really expected more.

Good orchestra - not so good seating. The orchestra that played Mozart was excellent. However, the seating was simple wooden chairs bolted together so they wouldn't move. As a result it was very tight seating and difficult to see the stage.
Don't miss the Aria at the end. Very informative tour... good tour guides... especially liked the opera singer at the end presenting two short arias... don't fail to include that!
Cool building. I did not get the chance to go in. Seems like it need to be rebuilt in some parts, but still a beautiful building. It seems to be worth another visit.
Must seen. That's another classic decorated, incredibly beautyful opera Houses of the European music history. You can't miss this one... You'll regret, if U miss this!

Beautiful Building and Beautiful Voices!. Saw Der Rosenkavalier but had difficult seeing in orchestra seats...trying to look over or between heads of those blocking my vision. Seats are not very comfortable and the length of the stay was inordinately long because of the length of the two intermissions. Nonetheless, the voices were superb and the feeling that generations of opera goers had experienced this elegant setting was worth the price of admission!

Always a good option. Opera Houses around Europe are amazing and the Hungarian State Opera House is incredibly beautiful. Try to visit during the day, maybe a guided tour and stop by in the night to see the lights around it.

Have I found the most beautiful opera house on the planet.. The sumptuous decor, the sculptured marble, soaring ceilings, Franz Josef's box, the history. I got to see the artists and stage builders work on Falstaff for that night's performance. Amazing!
Beautiful. Listened to the Verdi200 opera compilation. The building itself is massive impressive. Worthwhile to take the tour.

Gorgeous Building, Uncomfortable Seats. Saw Der Rosenkavalier--good production, but very lengthy in the most uncomfortable of seats. Two intermissions--one of thirty minutes, one of over 45 minutes (not sure why this was necessary). The opera house is fantastic--beautifully restored. The tickets were reasonably priced and bought online before we left the US, which was great. I'd recommend going, but take a pillow!!!

Lovely place, but no English subtitles. I didn't expect to see English subtitles in central Europe opera houses, but they had them in Prague and Vienna, so I had hoped they'd have them here, too. They didn't. Sound was ok. Elegence amazing.

Don't miss out!. Wanted to see an opera, but there were only 2 tickets left. These were on the 3rd row, but costs less than 75 USD each. The opera house is gorgeous inside. The staff is very friendly. It was also a great show!

Quality Productions on both our visits. First time we had been to the Budapest opera. We had tickets for Tannhauser and it was great. Well produced and very good singing. We splashed out the next night ( we were on holiday!!) and went to the Verdi Gala. We just did this on the last moment not expecting to get in, but the box offce in the theatre could not have been more friendly. Again we got great tickets at far better value than in the UK. My wife likes the opera, and we have been to a number of Eastern European opera houses and they represent good value for money compared with UK rip off prices. I booked for Tannhauser on line here in the UK, and that again was straightforward and easy. They have a great line up of productions here, so if you like classical music, ballet or opera then do not miss this!!Dr Malc

GO!. Went to see 'Turandot' in February this year (2013).Hadn't got a clue what was going on as it was in Italian with Hungarian subtitles. Did not care a jot though as the Opera House is absolutely magnificent! We only paid £7 as our seats were right at the very top but that was great because it gave us a wonderful view of this spectacular building. And the classic 'Nessun Dorma' is part of the performance.Also, to the right as you leave there is a great old school bar/restaurant where we ordered Kir Royale cocktails again at a reasonable price.

BUDAPEST Opera House. This grand Opera House is clearly a competetior to Milan, Rome, Vienna, Brussels, and even Paris Opera Houses. It has withstood the wars, the times, of 130 years, and the major transitions from being barely maintained (during the Communist Era) to the grandeur of the Emperor of Austria-Hungary through to the newest regime in control of government. We thoroughly enjoyed the delightful seating in color and arrangement, the fantastic control of sound and fury form the instruments, and also the spectacle of entrance in the great hall. Many USA citizens of Hungarian decent, who fled before and during World War II and also the 1956 revolution, came from this area of the city. This included (Hollywood Movie Stars) the famous three Gabor sisters and also Madame Rozsi Pogany of cosmetics' fame in the USA. You must do whjat we did, walk from the Basilica to the entrance to Andrassy Utca and walk up this fantastic street to the Opera House, seeing all of the shops and thinking you are in the 1870s to the 1920s.

One of the Grand Operas of Europe, worth a tour!. The guided tours remain excellent, as this house is one of the finest old opera houses in Europe. We were there on the day of the opening of Falstaff, but couldn't arrange tickets, much to our chagrin. The opera building is stunning to see, but the performances are priceless. Andrassy utca, the street in front, is fun to stroll and if you are up to it, walk all the way to Heroes Square along this, one of the grand boulevards of the city, and all of Europe.

Beautiful venue.. The opera house offers two tours daily at 3 &4 PM. The venue is beautiful and well worth a visit. One small catch, I found their pricing a little misleading. I thought that the tour price included the opera mini concert (of two arias). This is a separate purchase.If you like beautiful architecture and opera, you will love this tour. Even if you don't like opera, you will probably still enjoy the tour!

Excellent Classical Productions. Always very proffessional productions performed here. Tickets reasonably priced and usually very available at the box office or thru your hotel. Very well worth the visit, parking usually available along Andrassy ut or a short cab ride from major hotels.

Not worth the tour. For $15 I expected a little more than a 20 minute tour, most of which could not be heard as there were 3 other tour guides speaking at the same time, in other languages, in the cavernous stairway that echoed everything. I would rather have paid a lesser amount for a matinee performance to see the interior and then read up on the history of the Opera House later. That would have been much better. This tour is not worth it.

Superb - not to be missed!. We attended a performance of Sicilian Vespers last May and it was excellent, the singers and the orchestra also the staging. The Opera House is really spectacular, very impressive and traditional. The tickets are reasonably priced and we enjoyed walking around the building especially the bar which served snacks as well as a variety of drinks, again at good prices. Always a highlight of a visit to Budapest and more reasonable prices than many other Opera Houses in Europe.
Guided trip. Took a guided trip in English The place is beautiful . Finished the trip by listening to 5 minutes of singing. The singer had an amazing voice.
State Opera House. What a beautiful music venue! This is by far the most impressive opera house we have seen in all of the European countries we have visited.

Great Architecture. Budapest Opera House is not as big as the one in Vienna. However, it is worth the visit. Unfortunately we were there at a time when there were no shows scheduled. But we got the chance to enjoy a tour of the opera house. There are 2 guided tours scheduled: one at 3 and one at 4 in the afternoon. We were heistant if we should do one of the tours. But we are glad we did. Cameras are allowed at a very low fee. There are many resturants in the area. There are few restaurants just across from the Opera House near the intersection to your left after your leave the opera house. It is a lovely perdestrian street full of nice local and international restaurants. Go there and enjoy a late lunch or early dinner after the tour.

What a beautiful opera house!. We had a tour of the Opera House before attending a small concert which was put on specially for our tour. The interior is amazing and we sat in one of the boxes that royalty have used. I was impressed with the pride of the staff who showed us through and it was well placed. Its a beautiful place and I would recommend it to anyone whether or not they like Opera.

Absolutely spectacular. On the basis of advice offered on Tripadvisor I booked tickets to see Giselle at the Opera House. Good decision! Even of you are not a ballet fan you cannot help but be enthralled by the beauty of this theatre and the real buzz of the occasion. The scenery for the production was the best I've ever seen and the dancing was superb, but to be honest I would go and see anything just to experience this place for an evening.

Wonderful Evening. What a beautiful building. Reasonable prices for good seats and architecture to take your breath away. We saw 'La Traviata' with Kolonits Klára in the lead role. She had an amazing voice, pity she dies at the end... The set and the supporting cast were also excellent, if you enjoy opera this is a must. Well stocked bar with efficient staff and having booked online before leaving home all went smoothly. We did go to the trouble of dressing appropriately for the venue and while this is not essential it was appreciated by our hosts. Eat before the opera at the Callas Restaurant next door, not the cheapest but really good and of course very convenient. Service brilliant. We enjoyed a gentle stroll back to our hotel afterwards through the bustling streets.
Hungarian State Opera House. It is well worth a visit, it is a beautiful building with all its Gold decorations and Marble pillars etc.You have to pay to take photo's, but it is worth it.
La Traviata. A lovely smallish opera house. The box office service was great and we got tickets at the last minute. The production was very good indeed.

Magnificent !! Don't miss a performance there. The opera house is a gem. The best thing to do is watch a performance there ,preferably a ballet , and enjoy the opera house while enjoying a show. In my opinion it is a lot better than pay the expensive ticket of the guided tour ,since there is no other way to enter the opera house and enjoy its inner structure.

Very beautifull. ... nice classic opera house - inside (i do not take a trip inside, just on corridor where you can walk for free) and outside it is just as it should be - nothing modern and strange. Shop has a variety of stuff with composers, notes - you can stuck there for a while etc :-)

A night at the opera. I would definitely recommend seeing a performance at the Opera House, rather than just joining a guided tour. I saw Giselle there last week and whilst not a fan of ballet, I enjoyed the atmosphere and the real sense of occasion, not to mention the opulent interior.We had met one of the principal dancers at a party the night before so that also added to the experience.A word of warning, if you take a coat, the 'cloakroom police' will not allow you to keep it with you and you'll face long queues to place it in the cloakroom and a bit of a scrum at the end of the evening to retrieve it.
Great place to visit, go see an opera!. A beautiful building with an astonishing interior. Be smart and go see a play or an opera to fully experience and enjoy it.

Great architecture but skip the mini concert. Beautiful place to see, with guides for up to six groups, speaking Hungarian, English, Italian, French, Italian. Smaller than Vienna, but more opulent. The only way to see it is via an afternoon tour, unless you buy tickets for a production.But do NOT buy the additional ticket for the "mini concert." We stood for about 8 minutes in the bar of the opera house while a soprano sang one Verdi aria and another by Puccini , all while accompanied by an instrumental recording on a boom box. She was pretty good, but really...! For this I paid an extra 6 Euro?

Small but Beautiful Opera House. The interior of the building can only be described as opulent. Very similar in layout to The Royal Albert Hall in London but much smaller which creates a more intimate atmosphere. We saw a production of Falstaff, one thing to note is that the subtitles are only provided in Hungarian, so know your chosen opera's storyline if you don't speak the language it is being performed in.

A pleasant experience. When you visit Budapest, you must go to an Opera at the Opera House, (recommend building your tickets a head of time on line), as you then appreciate the beauty of the building at the same time as enjoying an Opera.

A night at the Opera. Well it was the ballet in fact, "Giselle" , traditional staging and excellent principals and corps de ballet. Great chance to see inside the splendours of the Opera House and enjoy the buzz of performance. I booked tickets online before travelling,(Jegymester online, small charge about £1!) which was quite straightforward, seating plans made it easier to choose. The tickets cost 4,000 HUF's each, so we saw a delightful ballet in wonderful surroundings for approx.£12:50 each! Not bad eh?the guided tours cost about half that..but why bother, go and see it in action!
Falstaff. Very good staging and great singing ! An experience to remember. Not the most popular Verdi opera, but when performed this way, it becomes POPULAR and EASY !

A "must visit" for any Budapest trip. This beautifully restored opera house is very central, located on Andrassy Street and on the metro line 1. We saw an excellent performance of the ballet "Giselle" and the dancers were amazing - very well trained and it was a beautiful production. Get your tickets online before you leave - the performance we attended was booked to capacity. There is a lovely bar that serves drinks and cold food before the start and during the interval and there is a lovely open air terrace with views of the passing crowd on Andrassy St. I believe that the opera is of equal high quality. The performance we saw equals or betters anything you'll see in Europe outside Russia and Denmark. Don't miss it!
Gold, gold, gold. The decoretion is wonderful, look around if you succeed to buy a ticket. You may buy ticket in advance, we arrange ticket through our wonderful hotel's staff in advance.

Great opera house. The tour of the opera house was interesting and informative. The opera house itself is quite beautiful. We stayed at a hotel across the street and were there for opening night of the season. Although the tickets were sold out, the opera house set up seats and a large screen outside so that anyone could watch a broadcast of the live performance -- sitting right in the middle of Andrassy Ut! This is truly the people's opera house.

English tour very crowded. The Opera House is magnificent and well maintained, but on Sept. 17, 2013, the 4pm English tours were over crowded. We were unable to hear our guide and our group was shuffled out of the way for other foreign speaking groups. On the entry staircase there were at least 4 groups with the tour leaders all speaking at the same time in various languages. Quite pricey, chaos among the tour leaders, and we were unable to view the Royal box. Crowd control with timed entry would seem to be a way to organize the tours.
Beautiful Jewel Box. Very inviting for tourists by offering tours. Lovely design & interesting history. Not good access for anyone with walking difficulty.

Gorgeous theatre - mediocre tour. My wife and I were sorry we didn't get to a concert at the Opera House. I'd make sure not to miss this next time. The theater is gorgeous, while still being intimate. The tour itself, however, was what a well-traveled doctor at our hotel labeled "humble". A different tour guide might have given us a better tour, but you get who you get when you sign up for a tour, and our guide was mediocre at best. We signed up for the music interval afterwards, thinking we'd get to hear something in the theater itself, which has wonderful acoustics, but instead, one of the performers sang a few bars of a few arias for our group as we stood in the hallway outside the "smoking room", Pretty corny.

Attention Eyes & Ears. When the King gave permission to build this opera house, his terms were that it could not be bigger than the one in Vienna. He neglected to say it could not be more magnificent. Yes, Kings make mistakes too.

Some of Europes BEST Opera and Ballet!. The opera house if totally first rate and the performances excellent! We saw a ballet performance that was wonderful! Great venue, great talent, right on the metro. Do not miss this.

Venue outrageously incredible... quality of Opera singing... to be desired.... We decided to buy a couple of tickets rather than going on a tour to see the whole opera house as well as test its accousrics! ;). We saw Falstaff for the 2013 season... well although the costumes and set design was amazing, the actual opera was quite poor. I, however, totally enjoyed my night as well as the venue and would recommend anyone to come and see something here.
Stunning place. Wonderful guided tour through the opera. Well worth a visit. One can even step into the Royal Box. For a few HUF extra they offer a mini concert - just amazing.
Magnificent surroundings. We saw Giselle more to experience the building than from a love of ballet but it was a great evening and amazingly inexpensive compared to UK prices.

Stunning venue. We booked for a guided tour. It was very busy as the Opera company were doing final rehearsals for "Falstaff" and lots of groups (with commentaries in many languages) were hustled into & out of the auditorium quite swiftly. But then our guide showed us round the rest of the beautiful building with all its marble, chandeliers, paintings, sculptures etc. It was good value & for a small extra fee you could stay to listen to an Aria or two.

Wonderful building, but the tour disappoints. The Opera House is beautiful and well worth a visit. That said, the one hour tour and "mini" concert is disappointing. The tour groups are very large with multiple groups touring in multiple languages during the two, one hour afternoon time slots. The guides, while friendly, rush through standard scripts to ensure the tour moves quickly and stays on tight deadline to orchestrated and move in concert with the many other tour groups in the over crowded rooms and hallways. The "mini" concert is just one of the lesser supporting opera singers providing two 2-3 minute songs, NOT in the main opera hall, but rather in the buffet room....what a let down. Enjoy the beautiful facility and take in a full opera performance, but skip the crowded and bland tour.

Nice tour. Did not have the opportunity to listen to a formal concert but attended a tour and a short informal performance. Nice to see if you have some time. The tour guides were good at providing an interesting historical perspective while showcasing some of the unique facts about this particular opera house. It wasn't life changing but still worth the admission price and time.

Forget the Tour and Actually Go see an Opera. For basically the same cost as a tour one can actually take in a performance at this famed European opera house.The interior is grand and ornate with great acoustics definitely worth the visit when in Budapest add it to your Must Do List.Every time I walk past this majestic building I cannot help but wonder what it must of looked like it is glory days when it was clean and pristine on the outside although its aging does add to its rich cultural heritage in its own way.My tip: Don't rush past it either a visitor should take the time to really marvel at the ornate detail adorning the exterior of it.

Beautiful building, disappointing tour. It is well worth seeing this beautiful building whilst in Budapest. The way to do it is to book in to see the opera or ballet that is on. The tickets are reasonable for the main performances. The tour is however a waste of time and expebsive for what you get. Hundreds of people and multiple enormous groups crouding for space and the 'mini concert' felt like a scam with two arias standing in the bar accompanied by a cheap battery CD player. They can do better than that.
Good tour but busy. The tour we had on sunday afternoon was very good, the place was packed and the tours often criss cross each other, good guides and well worth the money
Hungarian State Opera House. Beautiful! We did not get to an opera, but the opera house is beautiful. Just to go in for photos was enough, but a concert would have been awesome.

A night at the opera. We booked late but were able to get two tickets (apart) to see Faulstaff a Verdi opera. Great seats great atmosphere but WARNING read a synopsis of opera before you go as they sing in Italian and have Hungarian subtitles.
A beautiful building and special night.

Wonderful, despite ill mannered usher. Gorgeous opera house, really impressive. We went to see Giselle and took a couple of pictures with our mobile just before the show started (everybody else was doing the same). On the intermission the usher came to me speaking Hungarian; he changed to English as he realized I could not understand and asked me to delete the pictures I took, once it was forbidden. I apologized, I did not know it was forbidden and haven't seen any sign about that. He made me feel like a criminal. I opened my phone and asked him which ones he wanted me to delete. I had several pictures from the building and din't know what was allowed or not.That didn't make him behave in a more pleasant way, and we left the play at that point.I guess there are always many ways to say the same thing and transmit the same message.Despite his youth I could sense some soviet authoritarianism in his manners. Too bad.

Beautiful interiors!. We took the guided tour to view the interiors. The building is indeed beautiful. The seats, the columns, the boxes... It's easy to get a ticket for the tour. Just show up at the souvenir shop. They also have a mini concert after the tour. We didn't stayed as we are rushing to the house of terror.
Wonderful. The music was superb and the setting magnificent. A very good price also, English was widely spoken so Jo problem booking, and none of the stupid "booking fee" charges.

visiting the Opera Haus Sept. 17th. The building itself was spectacular so I encourage anyone going to do your own research before you go. The tour guides seemed terribly disorganized. There were a lot of disgruntled tourists. They had too many people in a group and the groups were so close to each other all speaking different languages it was very distracting since you could hear the guide next to you over your guide. Our guide had a voice that did not project, you had to stand right next to her to hear her. We paid for a mini concert, what a joke, the singer sang two songs to us in the lobby while we were standing and left. Do not pay for a mini concert you won't get any value. The singer was good but we didn't get to sit down.

Needs smaller tour groups - couldn't hear anything. In spite of asking him 3 times to speak louder and slower our guide just continued talking - very unresponsive to us. He recited his talk watching his time, and would start without waiting for the large group to approach him. That was soooo disappointing. I didn't learn anything about the grand hall.But - the brief concert in the end by a tenor made it worth the effort. If only he could have given the tour. He was fantastic.
Interesting Visit. Loved the opera house and mini operetta but the english speaking groups make up the largest contingency so its hard to hear the guide at times

Interesting Tour!. There was no operas performing in August so we opted for the guided tour. English tours leave at 4 & 5 pm everyday. The guided tour lasts about 45mins, then you can choose to go to a mini concert (500 Hungarian Forint per person). We had a professional soprano that performed O Mio Babio Carlo and The Drinking Song from La Travata for us. It was a wonderful experience! The tour itself was very interesting and insightful. We had a nice guide with a good sense of humour =)

Beautiful. Had a guided tour of this beautiful opera house. Knowing my love for photography, our Viking tour guide suggested I pay the modest price for the privilege to take photos and he was right. I would have been very disappointed had I not paid for the privilege to take photos.

Impressive architecture but a little bit too bling maybe?!. It's a beautiful building, draped in miles of gold leaf, so it is impressive, but you do feel as though you've wandered into a Las Vegas copy of an opera house.We made the mistake (yes, this is going to sound a bit negative folks) of booking front row seats for a performance of the philharmonic. Unfortunately this meant the stage was about 10cm away, with no leg room and hard seating. The building was packed, which meant queues for the toilets. There was nowhere to get a drink, even water - people were drinking from the taps in the washbasins of the toilets - not a good image.The music was good, but we bailed after the first part of the performance as it was just too uncomfortable to be there.

Wonderful night.. From 1USD you can go back to the 19th century watching "La Traviata" or "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" for instance.
If you are there on weekdays, check if the main cabin is empty during interval from act 01 to act 02, so you may stay there and have the best view of the stage.
Great Tour. Extraordinary architecture and opulence. Took an afternoon tour (1 hour) to see the interior of this great building and learn of some of its history. Well worth it.

If you love music and history you have togo. May be the Budapest's Opera Theater is not so famous as Vienna's and Paris's , but if you are in Budapest it's worth to visit. The interior will return you centuries back in to the Austro-Hungarian empire, and its really pleasure to see this impressive piece of art.

Drop in. Splendidly ornate that evokes the grandeur of times past. You could feel the presence and hear the murmur of the dapper, manicured bygone spectators in every main area. The music was sublime.

Stunningly Beautiful. I have been told this is more beautiful than Vienna. Entering the lobby is amazing from floor to ceiling. Get a tour. If you are luck, see an opera. Read the Invisible Bridge, sad as it is about WWII and Budapest but the description of the areas is wonderful and so much more meaningful when you visit this wonderful city.

Ornate Beyond Belief. You will be on gold leaf overload after this tour. The tours can be crowded but do go and enjoy. You are given the option of a mini concert but it is not worth it. This is a beautiful concert hall with a facinating history.
Nice place and well kept. It is a nice place and well kept historic building. Unfortunately, there is no show at the time I visited.

Beautiful Opera House Worth a Visit. We were pleasantly surprised at the beauty of the building itself and the informative tour. We didn't think the five minute "mini opera concert" at the end was worth the extra cost. It was a bit hokey.

Check out dates first. We were disappointed that we didnt check the dates before we booked the trip - the Opera House was close for a break for 2 weeks. Though we didnt watch any performance, still the outside building was worth sitting around and taking photos.

Magnificent building, great tour. The tour of this magnificent building was great, the tourguide had a good command of the German language. We chose the German tour because our command of the German language is as good as our command of the English language and the German tour was far less crowded. We did however speak a bit with the English tour guide, and he spoke a good amount of Enlish.Since we carried a large camera when we bought the tickets, we were told to buy an extra ticket that allowed us to take pictures. During the tour however we found that not everyone taking pictures had bought the extra ticket, but nothing was being done to prevent them taking pictures. For us, the added 50 forints were a waste of money.The mini-concert we got at the end was fun to do. It would have been way nicer if the concert was on the main stage, instead of in the bar of the first floor; this way we didn't really get a feel for the (supposedly) wonderfull acoustics of the building.

Wonderful. We booked a 45 minute guided tour which shows you the royal box, the galleries and the beautiful halls of this wonderful Opera. Don't forget to buy the mini-concert ticket (600 HUF) which allows you to listen to 2 short arias in live after the tour.
We have booket a privet cabien for very resaballe price. I liked the feeling of special privilege to watch a show with my daughter and her husband (I didn't tell them that it is inexpensive treat)

Beautiful building and mini concert. We were with a river cruise that had local guides take us on a Sunday morning for a guided tour in English. The building is gorgeous, and the tour only takes an hour or so. We had the mini opera at the end (which has singers on the stairways), and felt it was glorious. Not sure how much it cost to add the mini opera, as it was part of our total tour price, but it was enjoyed by our entire group.

State Opera House. Beautiful, interesting, great tour guide. Don't need a lot of time to view. Not crowded, but may have to wait. Groups are divided into smaller groups so it is easy to hear. Unfortunately, we couldn't go to the concert that evening as it was booked.

Off-season tour. The tour, provided in six languages, is well organized and interesting with an optional "mini opera" at the end that is well worth the cost. We, unfortunately, did not go to Budapest when operas were being presented.

Fantastic. Worth a look round, even better attend an opera.. Beautiful historical building. Just go in and wander around. We were bought tickets to see an opera and even though it was in Italian it had English subtitles above the stage.

Short and sweet. The tour is a bit pricey and short but an excellent way to see the building without buying an opera ticket.Public tours in various languages are only at 3 and 4 in the afternoon. It's worth it to buy the photo pass to take pictures during the tour. Unless you are an opera fan it's not worth it to buy the mini show (it's only about 5 minutes on the staircase).
Beautiful site. Very interesting beautiful site in Budapest. Guided tours and mini-concerts are included in the Opera tour ticket.
Great experience. Saw Carmen and I was impressed. The house has an old world charm about it, very comfortable. Made me wonder how many people sat where I sat and who they were.
Gorgeous facility, fabulous performance. The building is an architectural and historical treasure and the opera company was fabulous. Leave time before a performance to really explore the building!
Snow White and Seven Dwarfs. Seeing a show is the best way to see the Opera House and highly recommend. Pre-booked via the internet and had a box with great view.
Hearth of the city. This is the hearth of the city for a music lover like me. I enjoyed the rich design too. Definitley one of the best sights in Budapest

Long wait for tickets. To purchase tickets is a pain and frankly, what little you see is not worth the effort. The Liszt Ferenc Memorial Museum and Research Centre is more interesting an only one metro stop away.

Over the Top. Grand doesn't quite cover it. though smaller than the one in Vienna it is much more opulent !! The stair ways were all in marble. I like the bar for ordinary folk ,better than the one for the "nobles".
Beautiful!. This is well worth the time and trouble to take the tour of the Opera House. It is a beautiful building and it would have been great to see a performance there.
Interesting and beautiful. What it must have been like in the "hey day". It is amazing and I wish we could have seen a performance there. The tour was worth it.
gold, gold and gold. It is a wonderful building. We were lucky and we could buy a ticket and I am so glad that we could see it inside. It is full of gold and the decoration is wonderful.

Excellent Don't Miss it. This is an amazing show. A must if this is your first visit to Budapest. The place is small so dont need to book the most expensive ticket. The middle range is perfect. The performance gives you a true flavor of Hungarian music and dance.
Beautiful building. Very elegant, have only seen from outside. Was told by a tour guide that it is being made in to a hotel.

Amazing Opera House. There are tours at 3pm and 4pm guided by English, German, Spanish, French, Japan, Chinese speaking guides. There's also possibility to buy an extra ticket for short concert but we didn't take it. The Opera House is amazing! Walls and ceilings covered by gold, huge beautiful spaces. You have to go there!
how can it be so cheap?. it´s a wonderful opera house, full of great plays, and it is amazingly cheap so it is practically a sin to go to Budapest and not go there!

Grand, Traditional Opera House with a Contemporary Ballet. The goodThe striking beauty leaps out from every corner of this grand opera house. We saw the Brothers Karamazov Ballet in October 2012. The detailing almost overwhelmed the senses, but was exactly what we wanted from our visit to an old European opera house.Despite the grandeur, the venue felt intimate. Our box seats were spacious, but cozy. It didn't look like their was a bad seat in the house. The rows of box seats along the sides and rear allowed for lots of additional seating without the depth endemic to American theater balconies.We found it easy to get good seats on short notice. We had not planned ahead, but bought tickets online two days before the show, at a very reasonable price. The theater was full, which demonstrates their ability to keep prices in check with demand.The ballet was wonderfully performed. The dancer's grace impressed us both. The ballet itself was very contemporary and filled with action. The narrative portions were translated into English on the screen above the stage, which suited us perfectly.The not so goodWe expected a more romantic ballet. That was mostly our fault for not being in touch with the ballet community. At times, the ballet was violent and masculine. Great for half our group, but not so great for the other half.After visiting London theater, we missed the ice cream in being served in the aisles. Hardly a serious complaint, but a subtle difference in attitude between the theaters.The final wordGo! It was a great experience. We highly recommend seeing at least one show on your trip to Budapest!
Opera glamour. Taken on tour of the elegant building .. lots of gold and marble and wonderful ceilings! It was a better experience than the Milan opera house tour.

Poor value compared to other attractions. While the male tour guide was friendly and a good speaker, the tour was overcrowded and lasted less than 40 minutes. The content of the tour was limited - especially when compared with visits to the similar Opera House in Vienna. We didn't get to see back stage or any of the boxes and really didn't see anything that you would not see if you were attending a performance in the building.While it is indeed a beautiful building, in my opinion the tour is very expensive @ approx. €36 for a family of 4 and not good value for what we were shown.

A must see. There was not anything on we wanted to see while visiting the city but we decided to take a guided tour. A great way to get a look inside and learn about the history of the place. I would recommend paying the extra money to have the mini-opera at the end as it was a great finish to the tour.

Fantastic!. Having visited Vienna's State Opera House a few days before, and been very impressed, we really weren't sure what to expect but as the Hungarian State Opera House was so close to our hotel we felt we should pay a visit. The tours are at 3pm and 4pm each day and the prices very reasonable (we obtained our tickets from our hotel, but they are available at the venue). There is a small supplementary charge if you would like to take photographs, which we would recommend as the Opera House is simply stunning. In our view, it was considerably more impressive than the (very good) Vienna State Opera - the opulent interior is very well maintained and every room we visited oozed luxury... The place was extremely busy so you can expect to be part of a large party but there were plenty of tour guides - ours was very knowledgeable and engaging with a nice sense of humour.Don't miss it.

Absolutely fantastic! A must, if you enjoy classical music/ballet/opera. I enjoy watching opera/ballets and it was a reason why we decided to go to Budapest - we had heard about the beautiful Opera House and we managed to book two tickets for Onegin while we were here. During the day, we took a guided tour to see the Opera and that is definitely recommended as you can take pictures and get to know the history about it etc.When we returned in the evening to see the ballet, we were mighty impressed with the live band and the whole ballet. Both me and my partner (who only recently 'discovered' ballet) were in a state of awe after the third act and I can say that this was one of the most over-whelming and best experiences of my life (so far). It made such an impression that we now actively look for new tickets to Budapest to see other ballets. I cannot recommend it enough and the prices are reasonable, everything ranging from EUR 2 (for seats with no view) to EUR 50 (fantastic seats)An absolute must if you enjoy ballet/opera/classical music!
worth to visit. The architecture is wonderful, lot of gold. You can watch a world-class opera for very affordable ticket prices.
A Work of Art in Itself. Lovely facade but the entrance hall will take your breath away. Very helpful staff, a gem which you should experience.

Gorgeous space, excellent opera. The Hungarian State Opera House is fabulously beautiful. I couldn't stop taking pictures before the performance began - every detail was just perfect. I was pleasantly surprised at how comfortable my seat was, and how much room I had - I'm a big guy but it was more comfortable than an American movie theater, by far. The production itself was captivating and of the highest quality. Usually I can't stay awake at the opera, but I was riveted to the stage for all three acts. I'm very glad I went. A highlight of my time in Budapest.

Impressive. First time at the Opera.
Sound is really good & the building amazing.
If you buy your tickets on the Net you can have places at 2 to 4 euros (it true).
wonderful opera house. Superb acoustics and beautifully renovated. Excellent facilities. Worth trying for tickets to a performance, but may be difficult as very popular..
Beautiful building.. The tour is very worthwhile, but understand that the daily mini opera concert at the end of the tour is held in the bar area, not in the concert hall. But still worth it!

Buy a ticket in advance. We stayed in Budapest for many times and always attended the Hungarian State Operahouse. The house was designed by the same architect as the Vienna Opera house. It is said to be smaller than the Vienna one, but more beautiful. Tours are also available. Hungarians love culture, especially music, so the house is usually full.

Beautiful. We went in the off-season (July-August) so there were no performances. The tour was OK. Great English tour guide but they wouldn't let us pay with credit card and you are paying the same price for a tour as you would pay for an opera ticket in season!

Hungarian State Opera House. Very nice place to visit. They only had guided tours at 3pm and 4pm whille we were there. Spectacular building.
Cute gift shop with some original (but expensive) souvenirs. But nice if you are looking for something a bit nicer than paprika as a souvenir.

Wait for the Fat Lady to sing. The Hungarian State Opera House was "allowed" to be built by the all powerful Hapsburg family and their Vienna-based empire. However, they were ordered spefically that the Hugarian Opera House MUST not be larger than the State Opera House in Vienna. It isn't . . . but it is far more beautiful, by several orders of magnitude. Go for the guided tour with a 10 minute live opera at the end, its spectacular. Lunch while waiting for your tour at the cafe across the street (I think Calais Cafe?) was also terrific.

Spectacular Opera House. We stay in Budapest for extended periods and always take in one or two operas. The house was designed by the same architect as the Vienna Opera house. It is said to be smaller than Vienna's, but more beautiful. Tours are also available. Hungarians love culture, especially music, so the house is usually full.

Magnificant building. This is a magnificant building in appearance. However, there are only limited guided tours which give access to the interior. There are beautiful paintings at the dome of the foyer. It is worth visiting as a part of the walk along the busy shopping street Andrassy ut. At the front of the building is a statute of Liszt Ferenc.
Historical building. Worth it just for the architecture, but you can watch a world-class opera for very affordable tickets. Stately and haunting!

Budapest State Opera. One of the finest opera house I have ever visited. Took the guided tour with a very knowledgeable and excellent English speaking guide. Then we had a short but very good recital and also paid a small fee to take photos to make this a wonderful and unique experience. It is definately well worth it and easy to find by metro (M1) stopping just in front.
Opera House. You cannot gain access unless you join one of their tours therefore check up on times beforehand. If you are on the hop on hop off buses this does not always marry up.

Impressive design. Didn't go inside, but the outside was interesting with the various composers featured. It wasn't just angels and priests like on a church. There were figures in more modern clothing and that was kinda cool.

Worth a Visit. Good opera visit and very nice décor insideIt can get crowded for English guides and they split our group up into three. Worth paying the little extra for the mini performance.Regards Gary Saunders
Hungarian Ballet. Ballet company and Opera House are a must see! The season ends in late June so plan accordingly. Very accessible location.

Beautiful Budapest is very easy to find your way around. Stay away from commercial hard sales people not necessary there are some religious sites that insist you pay on entry this is not a requirement inmost religious establishments
The Barber of Seville. A wonderful performance in a historic Opera House near our hotel. The Subtitles were only in Hungarian, though, so we were glad to be familiar with the story!

great building. it's a beautiful building . but was a bit disappointed by the guide ! it seems they learned their lesson by heart and just tell the story at an awful speed and you you just end up switching off . even when asking the guide to slow down at numerous time she didn't changed her way ! Pity !
Tour of a beautiful building. English speaking tours are conducted at 3 & 4 pm by very knowledgeable guide. Would not recommend the mini concert though
worth a visit. Bit hard to hear guide as several talking at any one time. Good information though . :-) :-) :-) :-) :-) :-) :-) :-) :-)
Beautiful Place. Went on a tour and saw a beautiful building. Wow, it is great. Was unable to see a performance but hope to see one on another trip in the fall. A must see.

Impressive building. An interesting neo-Renaissance building. We didn't take the tour and it was worth passing thorugh it as part if our walk in Andrassy ut. You might want to pop in if you have a 24 hour metro pass (just stop at the Opera metro station and go back on track).I wouldn't bother coming here especially. If you don't take the tour you can only see the reception hall (which has interesting painting on the ceiling).

Amazing architecture for a great price. I still just started to listen to opera (as part of getting old), and still not my favourite genre, so I can't criticize the music, but the building is amazing, and what I love is that they offer a chance for people with lower budget, students too to enjoy performances with cheap tickets.
Wonderful building and a great performance. We greatly enjoyed a performance of Eugene Onegin in Russian with Hungarian subtitles. Fortunately we had studied the plot beforehand.

Well worth a visit. We took the tour which included a 'mini opera' and it was excellent. The building itself was beautiful inside and the tour was very informative. The auditorium and it's acoustics were amazing. The 'mini opera' consisted of 2 arias sung by a male member of the cast and was a fitting end to the tour.
Beautiful and nicer than Vienna. I was astounded by the beauty of the place. The opulence of the royal box as well as the overall theater is breathtaking.

Intimate opera. We attended 2 operas during the week we were in Budapest. Musicianship is near the top; Voices uneven, but there were certainly some up-and-comers; production values, good; seats and sight-lines, good with very good value; acoustics, good where we sat. A small and intimate hall with a company good at the chestnuts and better at the rarities. If you don't like opera, attend a ballet; if you don't like ballet, take the tour. I doubt anyone would be too disappointed.

Opera tour. Fab building, interesting facts given by guide. However our group was too large at around 40 people, whereas the Italian group was 1. Don't bother with the opera singing its in the bar and not the stage area (1 woman sings 2 songs with music from a CD) not what I was expecting. Worth seeing if smaller group, otherwise don't bother
Beautiful Building, Interesting History. Did the tour which I enjoyed. The craftsmanship inside was truly impressive. Amazing building and was nice and cool on a very hot day.
Nice visit in Budapest. Located at Andrassy ut, the fashion street in Budapest, with impressive archiecture and luxury decoration. You can pay for a inside visit.

Lovely Building. The Opera House is a lovely neo Renaissance building. The interiors can be seen through guided tours. Unfortunately, we could not see a performance since none were scheduled during our stay in Budapest.

No tour. I badly wanted to take the tour of the opera house- but unfortunately, the whole area was closed off that day because of a big parade. WE were leaving Budapest the next day and could not make it. I have seen pictures of the interior, and they look stunning.
Beautiul to see. It's a nice quick visit if you want to see what a classical opera house looks like. I don't care for opera, but it was good to see this place.

The perfect opera house. Wonderful music, beautiful building and enthusiastic audiences.. It was on my list to go to the Opera in Budapest. What a fine idea. Such a beautiful spot. My ticket was for the second row in a box, when I walked into the House, I nearly swooned. So lovely, gilding gilding gilding. There are beautiful carved things everywhere. Luckily there was no one sitting in front of me so I hopped into the front row. Great view. The opea was Verdi. The Sicilian Vespers. A rare rather political opera I thought it appropriate for a country so often occupied. The performers were old favorites with the audience and now new favorites with me. I can't wait to return. I did have to laugh when the meant to be helpful written words dropped down...in Hungarian of course

Beautiful building and great ballet. We missed the opportunity to do a tour (not enough time), but we did attend the ballet, Snow White and so we were able to enjoy the magnificent interior from the splendour of our very own box at the opera! Highly recommended and yes, when we return to Budapest, as we surely will (it's awesome), we'll do the tour and get the gen on the place!

wonderful building and some great music. I've been 4 times here when visiting the city in the last 2 years and now when I'm living in BP I just can't wait the season to start! Some really good singers here. The building itself is really beautiful and worth to see even if you're not an opera lover. The spectators are mostly tourists and other random people... but try to go to the highest gallery, where particular singers' fans often are for every performance of their favorites! The atmosphere on this gallery is a smell of what you can feel if you go to the other opera theatre of Budapest, Erkel Theatre, where all people are locals, and... but I'll write that in the respective review. Anyway ig you're in Budapest don't miss the Opera House. I'd reccomend especially the Hungarian national historical opera, Bánk Bán, which is usually played around 15th March, the Hungarian National Holiday.

euro Holiday June 2013. A visit to this opera house was included as part of our river boat cruise with Uniworld. I am not an opera fan but it was a great way to experience the local culture and entertainment scene

A beautiful building. Lovely opera house - but the tour was a bit lacking. Too many tours in too many languages at the same time! Difficult to hear at times, and tours were stepping on each other. But - the building is fabulous - helped that I was staying around the corner and could hear the singers practice in the mornings!

Beautiful Opera House. I saw a performance of Snow White and the Seven Drwarfs at the Opera House this June. It was a fun ballet. The Opera House was the star of the show though with it's beautiful construction and elegant chandelier and painted ceilings. It's definitely worth seeing while in Budapest. However, if you end up catching a show there, make sure to buy a ticket in the main seating. I had terrible seats in the nose bleed section and could not see very well and the seats were terribly cramped.

Great for a quick visit. Beautiful building, well worth the trip. You can buy tickets to performances for as little as 3 USD, but be warned the view is very limited. Still, worth it -- even if you don't stay long -- simply for the atmosphere!

Nothing special. You can't expect nothing special if you compare this opera house with other cities' opera houses, like all in Hungary are written in Magyar so you are really lost because nobody will help you.-

An artistic treat. We visited the opera to see a performance of Ariadne auf Naxos (booked tickets from home before our holiday).Splendid House, richly addorned and a pleasure to visit. Ticket prices SO cheap - the Hungarians seem happy to subsidise the arts - and an exceptional performance.Particularly impressive was the dual language concert programme - a tome in Magyar and English - which would be the envy of many an opera house. All for £2.50

Beautiful and a must see for Budapest. A beautiful site, elaborate furnishings. Certainly worth the time to visit inside. But if you're planning to catch a show there, then I would skip the tour. Didn't find the tour all that interesting and nothing that was said that cannot be read online. We did the tour to get an inside peak. Opera ticket prices also seem be a much better value than Vienna, at a much nicer setting. But I didn't actually catch a show so can't vouch for the show itself.
spectacular building. well worth a visit. you pay to go inside but even if you don't it is worth poking your head in the front heavy doors just to see the foyer. remarkable building

Beautiful interior. Guided tours are twice a day at 3 and 4 pm. A very impressive building inside and a friend told me it was more impressive than the one in Milan. We purchased our tickets at the hotel, so we were unaware that you have to pay extra to take photos ( you are given,a wrist band) or to listen to the small recital ( another,wrist band ) Tours are in many languages and often you have to wait to the group in front has finished but considering the large groups there was little noise from each of them. I am glad I did it.

MOLTO INTERESSANTE. Very interesting: a hump in the glorious past of this town. excellent guide in every language: magyar, english, spanish, german, japanese and italian. There is only one problem: the visits are only in precise period of the day and not every day. You have to ask for when you can have the visiit, that surely is very interesting

Glad we did the tour. We did the tour while visiting. Very interesting to hear about the history and see "all" the rooms. The light were out in the big auditorium, but it was because it was getting ready for a new gala concert so it made it even more interesting. Our guide spoke a little quiet, and the group was loud at times, but he spoke good english and knew a lot. Do it!

Amazing show and great staff.. I wanted to see the interior and by chance saw that there were a few tickets left for morning performance of Snow White ballet for the day I was in Budapest. I paid £17 for best ticket although in truth it's not that big and I would have enjoyed the show from any seat. The show was incredible, the absolute highlight of my trip. Booking was simple on line with a self print ticket.Most impressive though were the staff - my train into Budapest was delayed 2 hours by the floods and I finally reached the opera house 10 minutes after the start of the show expecting to have to plead to be allowed in for the second half - but they were very decent and helpful, let me in and I sat in an empty end of row seat before taking my proper seat at the interval. Fortunately the plot of Snow White isn't too difficult to pick up!The architecture, interior design and acoustics were every bit as good as expected.

Very nice building. The tourist tour is too expensive but it’s the only option to see that beautiful building from inside (if you don’t go to an opera show.)The mini concert is ridicules and a waste of time and money
A small jewel. Guided tours only twice a day. You are given details and facts of the building. Don't miss to visit it. It's a masterpiece.

Great building outside and especially inside. We took sightseeing only, so we were not in the opera. But still definitely worth of visit. Location is great, because in Andrassy street you have other sights as well(it ends in Heroes Square).
Beautiful building, like so many others in Budapest too.
A must see. The Hungarian State Opera house is beautiful and a must see when in Budapest. Tours in various languages are given at different times so check before going.

Woonderful perforance in a fantastic building. Snow White was both amusing and very well danced (my wife's ballet teacher in Cincinnati knew of this work). School children in the audience were rambunctious.
Smaller and nicer than the Wiener. Or that's what you'll probably hear all the time. It's probably true, on of the most beautiful Opera Houses I've ever seen.
Wow. We took a tour of the Opera House, very interesting and informative. We had a mini operatic performance (10 minutes) but didn t see a full opera. Prices seemed reasonable tho. £12 in the God's.
Ballet was Fabulous!. We went to see Snow White & the Seven Drawf and I was so pleased. The performance was outstanding and the Opera House was so cool!

More karaoke than concert. The tour and " mini-concert" was the lowlight of our trip to Budapest - expensive, underwhelming and the mini- concert a total rip-off - TWO songs by a female singer in the bar area, accompanied by tinny music through a CD player. We thought we'd get at least two more from a male, then a duet. Two arias do not a concert make! The Opera House itself is fine, but the guide's relentless would-be dramatic tales of its eventful history irritated. The Callas cafe opposite is great for its gypsy trio while waiting, and the terrine ain't half bad.

Stunning!. The Opera is a must-see in Budapest! It reflects the golden days of the Austro-hungarian Empire. The building, inside and out, is stunning. Gilded and ornate, the artwork, statues and marble are all breathtaking features. This Opera house is a contender with any in Europe!
Worth it. Watched a performance from a box! Good price tickets and amazing grandeur inside. Highly recommendcoming here

Best Opera House Acoustics in Europe. This is a fine 19th century opera house which has, arguable, the best acoustics in Europe. Acoustic engineers cannot figure what makes it so good so it retains its original 19th century finishes out of concerns that renovation attempts might wreck it. he tour is rather pricey--go and hear some music!! Orchestra and opera tickets are very reasonable in Hungary. Enjoy!!

one of the most important operas in europe. for sure have a tour and enjoy the decoration and the main hall, with paintings full of history. is nice that has a history with their princess and they also show you the balcony of Madonna's filming Evita!
Must See. Guided one-hour tour, in groups by language, was engaging and informative. Venue is spectacular. 10 minute, live "mini-concert" was a good glimpse into opera, up close and personal.

Take the Time to Attend an Opera!. We were lucky to stay long enough in Budapest to attend the Opera. We saw Tosca and were thrilled to pieces at the whole experience.We did dress up, and were happy to see the crowd also came dressed for the occasion. Orchestra quality was Excellent, and the vocals were really awesome.Atmosphere of attending Opera in this kind of setting......simply breathtaking. Tickets are available online, and you can print out your ticket before you leave home. If you are seated in a box, try and get seats in the front row for the best view.
Attended an Opera. Even if you aren't an Opera fan you will be after going here. Beautiful performance in the most beautiful Opera House! Elegrant evening. Go after to Callas next door for dinner.

Good value. We wanted to see a bit of an opera without staying the the entire event. This is perfect because you can get really cheap upper balcony seats and then you wont feel like you wasted money if you leave early. The interior of the opera house is quite nice too. Enjoyable experience.
Great opera. Visited the opera with my grandfather and enjoyed the wonderful atmosphere of the building as well as the great performance on stage

Wow - great performance for small money. We watched "Snow White" in June 13 there. Had one of the cheapest tickets - just 800HUF, unbelivable! but it was really good, and it might be even worth it to invest a few more money (the most expensive tickets are even just 6000HUF). the opera house itself is awesome and in addition the performance was excellent!

Elegant. Beautiful building and architecture. On Sunday tour is at 3:00. You can pay a bit more for a short aria performance. It is worth the extra but I was disappointed it wasn't performed in the theater
Surtitles are in Hungarian if that matters to you.. They made a mistake on my seat and I was given a 9th row orchestra with their apologies. Great since I bought 5th balcony.

Elegance and History. This is a grand hall with exquisite gold leaf motifs, fabulous marble, and eye popping chandeliers. Not to be missed. If you can, have a guide provide the interesting story behind the construction as well as quirks of the nobility. Of course, if at all possible arrange to see a performance. You'll feel ike you are in another world.

The opera house is a step back into the Art Nouvelle era.. The acoustics were wonderful and the entire experience incredible. The seats were comfortable and I lost myself in the beautiful music. I was transported back in time and wished Franz Liszt were there to play some of his heavenly music.
Guided tour. Bit pricey, but worth it for the experience of a guided tour. Book in advance or at least familiarise yourself with timings for the tours.

A marvel to look at. During our tour by Discover Budapest, we learned the amazing creation and how this Opera House was designed etc. Although closed for tours at the time we visited it's truly worthwhile seeing

Verdi Opera Stiffelio sung in Italian sertitled in Hungarian. We had not seen Stiffelio before so had to look up the plot on the internet after attending the performance.
The Orchestra, Soloists and Choir were all excellent and the free glass of Champagne beforehand was an added unexpected bonus.
The building is spectacular and ticket prices about half those charged at ENO.
An experience not to be missed.

We enjoyed the tour, but unfortunately couldn't attend the opera. We would have loved to have seen an opera, but our timing didn't work out. However we were very pleased that we went on a tour of the Opera House. Our guide spoke excellent English, and gave us lots of background and history of the venue. We paid a little extra for a very short performance by an opera singer, which we enjoyed, but which wasn't really necessary. It's worthwhile just to admire the architecture and decor.
hungarian state opera house. this site is a must. recommend the tour at 3 and 4 pm. The guides are excellent and there is much history for this site.

Value for money. Culture programs I'm Budapest are relatively inexpensive in European standards. That's why the opera house in Budapest is well visited by locals as well as by travellers. Very friendly staff, who guide you where to find your seat. This is important because it might take you ages to find which floor you should go and which door to choose etc.I personally found the bar is way too small for the amount of visitors. So I didn't bother going to the bar and wait in queues during break. It is also very nice to walk around in break.P.s. you can only purchase the opera program from the staff upstairs. It costs 1000 HUF.

A must-visit in Budapest. It would be a shame to be in Budapest and not see the Opera House. Opened in 1884, it has hosted such luminaries as Gustav Mahler and Otto Klemperer. The architecture both inside and outside is striking and beautiful; inside one feels that they are journeying back to the Hapsburg empire. The season lasts from September to June and boasts a rich repertoire. The seat prices are very reasonable by North American standards. In the three weeks that my granddaughter and I were in Budapest we went to six operas. We had seats ranging from $50 to $5 (the $5 seats were last minute and at the top of the building). The sound is good everywhere but he sight lines need some adjusting. If you have a seat in a box in the second (ie back) row, you will have difficulty in seeing everything. So choose your seats with care. Also the operas are performed in the original languages (usually Italian or German) with Hungarian over-titles (i.e. titles above the stage). There are no English over-titles, so one needs to know the plot beforehand (the programmes are in English which helps a lot). Even if you not an avid opera fan, you will be impressed by attending at least one performance.
