Wonderful Experience. We could not resist a visit to this wonderful place! We bought tickets on the day for Simon Boccanegra having missed the ones for Macbeth, but we were not disappointed. They cost us four pounds each and we were at the top but the view was wonderful. The opera house is absolutely beautiful and we had heard the singer practising from the street the day before so we knew it would be fab! there is no dress code,so if you haven't packed a ball gown ,no worries,this place is accessible to all! We purchased a programme,being unfamiliar with the story, as the subtitles are in Hungarian,and it was fine. the bar was empty at the interval unlike other opera houses we have visited where you cannot get near the bar at all! The place is beautiful,has a wonderful ambience and the cast were called back onto the stage numerous times by a deeply appreciative audience.A wonderful evening,even if you do not like opera go for the experience,and to really appreciate the purpose of the building and hear a wonderful orchestra and beautiful singing..lush!!!

Only if 5 stars is unusual. We have just come back from 3 consecutive evenings of Verdi. All good but I Vespri Sicilliani which is a rareity outstanding.The Opera House is in itself well worth seeing but may be a little overblown.Eastern European singers are not always well trained in Italian and may be incomprehensible and titles in Hungarian which for me is no help so study the story in advance! Tours are useful but these my be brief, about 30 minutes and not backstage. If taken in English note that some or many taking this option perhaps do not understand anyway.Note that reasonable seats may cost a fraction of the best.
Bravo. Where else can you sit in a box with a view of the orchestra and the sensational production of Verdi's I vesperi sicilian

Stunning building. We went there last week to see a performance of Ariadne auf Naxos..Unfortunately we came a bit late so we didn't have the time to soak in the grandeur of the building and the stunning interior. The performance was good and very moving with good costumes and decor.The price is really good compared with venues in the UKI would highly recommend a visit to anyone even on only a guided tour. If you go to a performance, be aware you might not have English subtitles
Beautiful building, well worth seeing. but the opera itself is all sung in Italian (obviously) but only had Hungarian subtitles ( not so obvious for a tourist). So I had no idea what was going on...

Small but grand and beautiful. Went to the Vienna opera house and the Budapest one, the Budapest's may be smaller but it is certainly grander. Went on a tour visit and also included the photo ticket and mini concert. Having the photo ticket would cost you 500 florith? Or 2 Euro but it is worth it.The photo ticket allows you to take photos during the tour and you definitely want to take photos!!! As for the mini concert..... I really enjoyed it. A man came out and belted out a few songs. It was my first time to hear an opera and he was really good. I guess it depends on your personality. I enjoyed listening to all kinds of music so listening to the mini concert was a no brainier. You can choose to take the mini concert or skip it. As for the tour, it was enjoyable. However, there is a crowd for the English speaking tour. If you know Japanese, German, or French, it would be better to take that group as it is a smaller group. If you are in Budapest, I really recommend to take the tour.

Great performance in a fabulous building. We bought seats for an opera and we enjoyed the whole atmosphere of the occassion. The singing and music was superb. The building is richly decorated with its tiers of boxes and is worth a visit in its own right. Where else could you enjoy an event like this just twelve rows back for £26 a ticket.

The guides do a great job. We went for the guided tours later in the day but it was worth it. I enjoyed the way our guide shared so many details about the opera house in such humorous way. This in addition to the grandiosity of the opera house itself made for a great visit

Worth going. The guided tour is very interesting and the Spanish guide was nice and gave a informal touch very much appreciated. I would avoid the miniconcert after the tour. It is not interesting at all to liste to a singer backed by a CD minisystem.
Beautiful building and tour. We enjoyed the daily tour of this beautiful building. It was nice to hear the history of the building and we enjoyed the small concert at the end.
Tosca By Puccini. beautiful building built in a neo-renaissance style with elements of Baroque, brilliant acoustics. Great experience.
Lifetime Experience. Madame Butterfly, a Japanese story, sung in Italian, with Hungarian libreto, in the spectacular State Opera House. An experience not to be forgotten.
a Magnificent Opera House. We saw Tosca. It was a satisfying production in a wonderful setting . The interior is in a classic grand ornate opera house style.

Fantastic experience. We attended two performances, one reserved in advance online, and one with tickets purchased the day before. The performances were wonderful and the theater is just beautiful. The price of the seats was much less then we are used to in New York.
The absolute most beautiful opera house!. I have been to the opera before, but this was like going back in time. Simply stunning is the best way to describe. Would love to go back on my own:)

Ok. Not the cheapest excursion and only lasts half an hour. When I booked I was asked if I wanted to pay extra so I could take photos. I declined yet was able to snap away during the tour.The building is beautiful and i had a very good guide. Could well be cheaper and definitely more atmospheric to go to a performance

Great Music - Great Room. We saw Richard Strauss's "Adriane auf Naxos". Our seats in the front row of the first level boxes were roughly $50 each. We easily bought them on line and we bought as soon as they became available. This less-performed opera was sold out. From the web site it appeared that this house will sell out early so it pays to arrange your schedule around the opera times and buy as early as possible. The room is glorious. The orchestra is larger than you see in many pits these days. Most of the parts were sung to perfection. The room is more splendid than the Met or Covent Garden. The performance was almost up to the level you would expect at the Met or Covent Garden. Go every night you can.
very impressive. A beautiful building with fantastic interiors. Beats the Vienna opera House hands down. Worth going for a show or even just the guided tour.
beautiful inside and out. fabulous frescoes on the ceiling, lots of gold and phenomenal sound one of the most beautiful buildings in a city full of them!

Amazing Night Music. Wow - its hard to say anything less. We decided to do the tour, prior to going to the Ballet, later in the week. Doing the tour helps to know what the locals know when intermission comes - an advantage.  A beautiful Opera House in the midst of Budapest, very easy to get to via subway. With lots of nearby restaurants. Built in a grand style that no one could duplicate these days. Lots of guilded accents, with perfect accoustics.  Getting tickets for a live performance might be the highlight of visiting this wonderful city. We got to see the ballet's premier of Romeo & Juliet - I'm still stunned by their interpretation. You will definately hate having to leave.

Beautiful building, great acoustics. When booking our hotel in Budapest we decided to go to the opera as well. I read that the acoustics and quality of performances should be great in the Budapest opera house and I can certainly say that this is true. We went to see Tosca and had a lovely evening. We didnt go on a tour because we already saw much of the building while attending the performance. If you're interested in attending an opera, Budapest is really a good choice as the opera tickets are much more affordable than in for example Vienna, but the quality is very very good.

Madam Butterfly,an experience. We booked online to experience an opera, it's not our normal lifestyle. The best tickets were less than €40,whilst a ticket to simply tour the opera house was €11,so duh. Its a stunning location, and for people like me who are not opera lovers it was well worth doing, a wonderful experience. The encore went on for ages, not sure if that's the norm.
Beautiful building. Located on Andrassy avenue. Only been to the entry area, but it s beautiful. You can also take the tour if you dont want to visit a performance.

Beautiful historic building. We did the tour which included a mini concert at the end, it is a spectacular building. It was so interesting to see behind the scenes of this opera house where all the great opera stars have appeared.

What an Evenng. Went to see Tosca on Sat 18th it was magical, the building is unbelievable the acoustics great, we paid about £40 each for a box, the one right next to the stage. It made hair stand on end, note perfect. I would tell anyone to go and see a performance.

Stunning. Opera tours are everyday at 3pm and 4pm, you can also get an option for a mini concert. You can pay for a photo licence, we didnt do this and where not stopped from taking photos of the building.The Building is just as stunning as the other we had seen on our trip and if you get the chance to see an opera whilst there you should.it is certainly fit for a King - for which it was built, lush hand made carpets, mosaic floors, paintings and gold everywhere and stair cases so wide.

You don't have to see an opera. If you don't want to see a full performance, you can take a tour of the opera house [about an hour] and finish it with a mini concert. We were there last week and enjoyed a couple of arias sung by a superb soprano. Equally, if you want to see an opera or ballet, tickets are very reasonably priced and you can share a box with another couple at a fraction of the cost such a thing would cost in England.

perfect. It was fantastic! We watched 3 operas - in german with hungarian subtitles and in italian. So if you don't speak those languages, you can always find a libretto in the internet and read before the performance. That was really amazing experience, the music is awesome, the singers are very professional. The tickets - we took at the balcony - very cheap. It was worth it for sure.We wouldn't recommend at all to go to the Callas cafe on the left of the opera, if you stay in front of it. Now, that was plastic quality and snob attitude of the service. Overpriced. You could say what to expect from the place with such location, and I would say - nice manners of a waiter would be enough, since visiting that place was pure pass-time before the performance. If you want to enjoy the high cuisine, just go to the 5 stars hungarian restaurants like Onyx, but for the coffee and dessert near the opera - anywhere nearby except CALLAS cafe.

Oh what an opera!. After having a look into the opera house, we decided to attended an opera - Tosca. Before the performance we googled it and found http://www.opera.hu/en/Tosca/cselekmeny. My husband and I do not understand neider latin nor hungarian, so it was very useful to get to know what was going to happen. During the 2 brakes we could walk around and look at the opera. Is is extremely beautiful.

Opulent is not the word! Excess springs to mind!!!. Guided tours @ 3 & 4.00 pm daily with a variety of languages available. Wonderful experience. TIP:- get the mini concert option & don't forget to pay for a photo licence!If you have the time attend a performance which are all reasonably priced.

The building is very beautiful and the guide was so good. We chose an Spanish guide and it was an nice surpriseHow that woman could be so interesting telling the story and also be so entertaining in a perfect spoken Spanish!!She made the Opera tour one of our best visit in BudapestThe only cons was that you cannot take pictures inside the Opera hall if you do not pay an extra fee and also the mini concert, It's not worth it

Leave the Tour, Attend the Opera. Party of 8 lads in Budapest for a long weekend. Decided the opera house was worth a visit but not the tour. Why pay to walk around with a bunch of old dears and at the end hera a 5-min warm-up.No way, Madame Butterfly tickets were going for 4000HUF for 8, that came to 1 quid fifty! Now these were "nose bleed" seats, but we got to see the opera house, the roof, have a drink, hear an opera - first act, and still hit the streets by 8pm. Def worth a visit, but skip the tour and attend the opera, you won't regret it!

We loved the opera.. Having never seen an opera before we booked tickets to see Toska. Didn't know what to expect but loved the whole experience. The building is fabulous, the tickets are so much cheaper than anywhere else, the forty piece orchestra were amazing and although we didn't fully understand what was going on the singers were so impressive. We had drinks and tiny open sandwiches in the interval and the whole evening was special. As some people next to us said - they all die but sit back and enjoy the music. We certainly did.
Madame Butterfly. A lovely Opera House and a lovely performance. Black tie not needed and a suit is most usual, though there were a few people in T shirts!

Wonderful opera house. We ordered our tickets in advance via the official website and managed to secure tickets in the stalls (Row 6) to see Puccini's Madam Butterfly. I'm glad we did this because I think this performance was a sell-out.Tickets were reasonably priced, the performance was good and we had a very good view of the stage from where we were sitting. Seats were a little uncomfortable, but no worse than those at the Royal Albert Hall in London.The only downside was that sub-titles (above the stage) were in Hungarian only - but, even so, this didn't detract too much from our enjoyment of the performance.The interior architecture is absolutely beautiful, the acoustics are amazingly good, and the atmosphere is electric.Even if you are not interested in opera, it's worth booking a ticket for the experience alone.
Stunning. Stunning architecture and decor. I saw ballet and opera. Both were exceptional performances. I favored the ballet, which surprised me. Had box seats.

Bring a cushion. What a gorgeous building, enjoyed chance to walk out onto a balcony at each interval, and do pre-order drinks for interval as rather chaotic queueing!Take care with seat allocations, as each row has same 4 sets of numbers, so get advice. Also worth bringing padding for seat!

A wonderful Tosca. Saw a great performance of Tosca. wonderful singing, believable acting, an enchanting night of Theatre. Great seat too in stalls.Tip is to ask for Left side seat 1 or right side seat 1. That way you are on an aisle seat with a clear uninterrupted view of the stage.Also saw Madama Butterfly. More like a moth.If you want to get great photos of the ceiling and chandeliers, get a seat in the balcony. View of the stage is not gret, but you can get wonderful pics of the ceiling - all for about $5 Aud.

A beautiful place. I just enjoyed walking around taking photo's. Budapest is a growing city, know a Buda - Pesch, as they say it. One side of the river is Buda, the other side is Pesch, thus.....Buda-Pesch.

Magnificent old structure: must see!. Spent an evening here and saw Tosca and while certainly not the epic size and stature of the Opera House in Vienna is nevertheless quite an extraordinary step back into a grand old time. Breathtakingly beautiful and not terribly expensive by Europesn standards. Go if you enjoy opera and bring your camera!

Book in advance to get the full experience!. Bought very cheap tickets from their website. Paid 600 HUF per ticket which gave us the worst view possible. However, as soon as the show starts, you can ask the lady at the door to change seats :o) (and there are always better seats available which are not being used). We watched a performance form the Hungarian National Ballet and show, location, stage was absolutely stunning. Please go and order cheap tickets and see for yourself. If you don't like it, walk out during the break. Please note: people dress up when visiting and you do want to look the part. LOVED IT (and so did my 8 yr old son!)

Beautiful and a great experience. Please find time to attend a performance. We watched Taming of the Shrew and were comletely taken by the setting and performance. You would pay 4 times more in the UK for less inspiring setting. Have a pre-performance drink on the first floor balcony to people watch.There is a Veuve Clicquot branded Bar next to the Opera which is great for an after performance cocktail or 2.

impressively beautiful!. We watched our first opera ever! Although I didn't understand a word the soprano was singing, it was really good. The opera house was gorgeous! The accost excellent! The ticket price... so affordable.
beautiful decorated inside. the tour was very crowded but luckily they slit the group and had 2 tour guides, ours was very enthousiastic and had a lot of stories to tell,

Puccini in Budapest. We stayed just in front of the Opera House and used this opportunity.
"Madame Butterfly" was fine. I cannot say that there were superstars
but everything was at the very decent level. We enjoyed the building
as well. Our places were far enough but everything was clearly
visible, and the acoustic was also excellent. All in all, very good.

Interesting..but.... A bit dear..you have to pay extra to take pics. The "mini concert" took place in the bar.A bloke appeared from behind a curtain accompanied by a full orchestra backing on a CD player. Sang 2 snippets.

Wonderful architecture and culture all in one!. If you get the chance take the 3 or 4pm tour each day of this wonderfully constructed 19th century opera house a real rival to the Vienna Opera House or better still take in a performance.Apart from the obvious beauty of the interior and the tremendous acoustics, the innovative designs and incorporated safety and comforts are interesting to learn about!I would also recommend paying the extra for the Mini concert performance (about £2) which is short but a lovely opportunity to hear a good tenor.

A good experience. The performance was as good as another performance in opera. The building itself is was quite a dissappointment,it is pretty but not asi I exepected (in compare with i.e. Opera in Prague). It is a bit small and simple. On other hand,the price of tickets are cheap and the refreshment in the bar too. We do not regret going there,it was nice evening.

Very special evening. My daughter and I enjoyed a wonderful evening at the Opera House. We saw Taming of the Shrew which was stunning - beautiful costumes and breathtaking dancing! The interior is magnificent - allow time to wander about. We treated ourselves to a glass of champagne on the balcony. No need to dress up but I wish I had.

Old charm Opera House. We bought our tickets to see an opera so we can see the inside of the building. Our tickets were fairly cheap about 2400 forints per person. Then we found out that the entrace of cheap tickets are from the side. It turned out good for us since we wanted to see the opera house and from balcony you have the best view. To my surprise the opera itself was pretty good as well.

A nice and interesting experience. I'm not an opera/ballet fan. Not at all actually.I went there to see the "Taming of the Shrew" ballet show. Found some cheap seats in a good location, and went for it. And I'm happy that I did it.The atmosphere inside the opera house, its architecture, acoustics and design, the people that come for the shows, the attack that you get on your the senses by the performance of the many ballet dancers on stage, all of these make going to the opera house worth it!One tip: update yourself with the plot of the play you're going to see before you go there. It enhances the experience.

Best opera house. Although built by the same guy who built Vienna's opera house and supposed to be not as nice; I was in both of them and the Budapest one is nicer, by far. It must have been something to have been in it in it's hey-day.

Absolutely magic. 15 € for a magic experience in Budapest. A wonderful experience, an amazing view and a very romantic time.
check it online before the departure...

Must catch a show. Take the guided tour and then see a show.
We were lucky that the ballet taming of the shrew was playing during our trip and we could see it. Amazing
Lovely. We only saw the entrance hall, you have to go to an opera to see inside, but even the foyer was worth seeing, beautiful frescos.

Beauty in reality. This place definitely worth a visit.... try and catch the mini concert.... that is the highlight of the tour. Besides the sheer beauty and decoration of the building itself will captivate you if the guide does not!!!

What value!. We saw a couple of months ago that Madame Butterfly would be on whilst we were in Budapest, and looked at on-line booking and saw plenty of seats available. Decided to wait until we arrived before buying tickets, but then took another look just 3 days before we left home and, panic stations, saw only a handful of seats left. So we booked online (self printed ticket) for the huge sum of 500HUF each (my credit card has been charged €3.40 in total!!) At that price we were expecting a large pillar in front of us, but at least it wouldn't affect hearing the opera.We had to enter through a side door, and climb seemingly endless flights of stone steps (rather austere in fact) before reaching a bar area and entry into the auditorium itself.Wow! - such a contrast to the stairway,so breathtaking with gold decorations everywhere.We were on the top circle and our seats were on the top row to the side. No pillar obscuring the view, but we could only see a third of the stage or just over half if we stood up. There were however large Video screens either side of the stage. A thoroughly enjoyable performance and experience all for less than £3!!

Very Specil. I have never taken in opera in the past. I don't know that I will again. But the opera house is something so fantastic, it was worth the visit just for the experience. Opera in Italian with Hungarian written banner. But we loved it.

It worths a visit!. I was amazed by the surrounding of the Opera.It was big,it had a lot of gold :) It really worths going there and watching a performance.I watched "Madama Butterfly"!The ticket is very cheap.I paid 1300 HUF,about 5euros and I could see very good from my seat!About Budapest,you can also read my critics about the Bo18 Hotel Superior and the Museum of Ethnography.
Fantastic night. Saw the ballet here.It was such good value.£23 each.Fantastic night.Beautiful surroundings and the performance was superb.

super. Finally, I was able to visit Budapest, a magnificent city with lots of historical places - I was very impressed by the beauty of Danube who is crossing through the city and you can Buda and Pesta both :) really wanted to say how impressed I was :).

Magnificent. We had booked an orchestral concert in the State Opera House before we visited Budapest. The opera House may not be the most ideal performance area for a large orchestra but the atmosphere makes up for that. We heard a performance of Tchaichovsky's piano concerto played by an amazing performer with an unpronouncable Hungarian name. His playing was just stunning and the initial silence at the end of the piece gave way to cheers and a demand for more - which thankfully we got.

Christmas Eve Nutcracker. One of the best decisions I have ever made was to take my extended family to the Hungarian State Opera House for the Christmas 2012 production of the Nutcracker. The theater is unsurpassed in beauty and the production entertained even the most uninterested spectators. It will be some time before I see a better ballet or a nicer theater. Tickets were immensely reasonable--a third of what a comparable production would cost in New York.
Very nice place. Very nice place very very cheap lots of locals and expats, unfortunately we left before the end of the show we couldn't understand anything lol
Worth it. Take the tour. Its very interesting. The short performance is also very nice. Disliked? Not very much. Funny? You have to wear plastic bags over your shoes so you dont mess up the carpets.
A Classical Experience. This is a true example of high period opera. Tours are available in English. Suggest reserving in advance to attend a performance.

Spectacular musical experience. I have been inside many opera houses, but the Budapest State Opera House is one of the most stunning pieces of architecture and one that must be seen from the inside as well as outside. Even if you are not an opera fan you can tour the inside. If you do go to watch an opera, you may be tempted to take the cheapest tickets on the 3rd floor, but I recommend spending a little extra to get better seats. The cheap tickets place in a position from which you cannot see most of the stage.
Grand opera. We were on a APT guided tour which included drinks and a short performance. What a magnificent opera house.

My First Opera. We went to the opera house on a whim, and we both really enjoyed it. The building is beautiful. The singing was great. The scenery was inspiring. The only drawback was the language. The opera was in German and the subtitles were in Hungarian. Alas, my wife and I speak neither. With that said, we were able to follow the story once we read the synopsis in the program.

Fabulous Structure; Ambiguous Protocol. Not To Be Missed! Ideally you should take in an opera (or ballet) to fully appreciate the spendor of this building. After all, what makes this edifice so magical is that is is a living thing. Unlike so many of the grand buildings we tour, this opera house is not a relic or a museum piece from a distant time in the past, it is used today as was designed to be used over a century ago. And you can experience the building's beauty and vitality today first hand as a participant in its active function.. But if you can't attend a performance, you will want to take the tour offered at 3 PM and 4PM every day. And if you do take the tour, you WILL want to take photographs. But here's the catch. You need to pay extra for the priviledge. This fee is nominal and not the issue. The iksome thing about it is that, for most of us, we were unaware of the requirement until after the tour started. By that time it was too late. At least a dozen of us on my tour were disappointed as we put away our cameras. The space is just too photogenic.There is no mention of this extra requirement on the tour's official website. And there was no notice of any prominence,if at all, stipulating the requirement at or around the cashier's desk. Only one member of our group knew about this beforehand. She wore a red wristband which signified that she was authorized to take photographs. For the rest of us, photography was verboten. So be sure inquire about a photo pass when you buy your tour ticket.In any event, do go and enjoy a truly manificent piece of architecture.
A little gem!. Beautiful theatre - great orchestra. Booked affordable stalls seats for Tosca the day before the performance. Highly reccomended

Beautiful and great value for money. We went to see Onegin (ballet) during our weekend here.Wow, what can I say? The building is stunning! We got great seats for a fraction of a London price. The bar was beautiful and we could go out on to the balcony in our intervals.A truly enjoyable experience!
Amazing!. We saw Romeo & Juliet - definitely the highlight of our trip! During the interval you can enjoy your drink on the roof terrace overlooking Andrassy Utca :-)

Toska. We was in Opera for "Toska", Opera building is fantastic and spectacle was very nice and professional. We use e-tickets wich I buy 2 weeks before owr visit. Keep in mind that good tickets needs to take 3-4 weeks before show, I can take just balcony (no problem with view and sound).

Beautiful building and informative tour. The opera house is one of the only original buildings still standing in its entirety after the Second World War, and thank goodness it is.Friends had suggested I take the tour as it wasn't very long (they advised not bothering with the short opera performance afterwards, but that was never even offered as an option!) and it was a truly beautiful building.The guides are very informative, and having some lovely anecdotes, but the opera house itself is definitely the star. The only thing I would suggest is that you take as many photos as possible, as you won't revisit any of the locations (definitely make the most of the main auditorium, as it is stunning)Hopefully you'll be as lucky as I was to see them fitting and teching pieces for one of their performances.

Magnificent building that was not destroyed by the bombs.. Went on a guided tour of the opera house. Tour guide was very imformative and lively. It lasted 1 and a quarter hours. We booked to go to the ballet on the following evening. Was a real experience.
Spectacular. Amazing and interesting - tour was about an hour, completely held our attention, even though we are not Opera fans

First rate performances at rock bottom prices.. We attended the Opera house twice during our stay and enjoyed concert performances of the St Matthew Passion, Mascagni's Messa Di Gloria and Cavalleria Rusticana. The quality was without doubt at the highest level of performance and the cost was so small compared with London prices. A stalls seat only cost us £15 each and the standard was worth considerably more. Overall the soloists were vocally of an international standard and it would be hard to criticise when we paid so little. We will definitely return.

Spectacular. The Opera House is absolutely stunning and the service outstanding! The Ballet: Romeo & Juliet was beautifully, traditionally interpreted, and all the pomp and wealth of the era not compromised.
Definately a must. Book times online and just enjoy the magnificent building and a professional performance.Tickets for a guided tour cost more than ones for a play so think that carefully and enjoy

A reminder of the opulence of an empire. The Budapest opera house is one of the best reminders of how opulent this city once was. It is more ornate than its famous cousin in Vienna. For any classical music fan, it is a relatively affordable must see.If you are less classically inclined consider a ballet, perhaps a bit more palatable than the opera. We saw A Midsummers Night Dream last weekend, and it was magical. Our tickets at 12000 huf (just over 50 USDollars),were the most expensive in the house (a splurge for my husbands birthday)... Much lesser priced options were also available.The side streets of Andrassy ut are overflowing with cafes, bars, and restaurants. Our traditional choice is Menza on Liszt Ferenc Ter.

Grand opulence. This is a must see in Budapest. It is grand opulence at its best. Even if you don't see an opera it is worth looking around. But i recommend going to see an opera as it only costs about £21. It may be the best opera house in the world.

Beautiful opera house. It is a gorgeous building and lovely inside. We saw Xerxes there and enjoyed the while experiebce. It was very affordable- about 4000ft per ticket. Will definitely be going back for another show.
Amazing if you can get cheap tickets to show. This is a bit of a hidden gem. Sometimes you can get tickets to the opera for only a few euros! Best way to see the opera house

A day at the opera. I bought a ticket on a whim; surprisingly, it was the equivalent of less than $25. It was like being transported back in time. I had never attended an opera and really did not understand much of it, but the experience of the sound and the building was amazing. I sat in an upper box during a daytime performance and was able to appreciate the architecture from that vantage point. I did not have formal clothes to wear, but I did not feel out of place. I wore a nice sweater and jeans, but saw others in T-shirts. Some attendees were much more formal -- it was a mix of all walks of life, tourists and locals. I highly recommend attending a performance here. It is a much more complete experience than just a building tour, which also is offered.

Ornate and old world charm. The opera house should be visited when on a trip to Budapest. Do time your tours so you are at the Opera House a little before either 3 or 4 PM when they have guided tours in various languages. Our tour guide Sophie was very friendly and informative.We did not take in a performance so I cannot comment about that.The building is beautiful and very ornate.
Worth a visit. Lovely building. 45 minute tour with English speaking guide + 5 minute concert with someone singing Opera (Not on the stage + music on a CD but still very powerful sound).

excellent performances, wonderful building. I have gone on the tour of this building and also attended several concerts there. All were great; I really got the feeling that I was being uplifted by a cultural event because the gradeur of the setting contributes to this. Even if you are not a lover of classical music, at least go take a look at the interior. It is stunning.There is also a nice little gift shop.

A must for lovers of classical music while in Buydapest.... We spent the weekend in Budapest, and were lucky to get tickets for both Rigoletto (Saturday night) and Tosca (Sunday noon). Excellent performances. (The tickets Sunday were one third of the price from Saturday in the same seating area.) The building in itself is a landmark and well worth visiting, even when you are not attending a performance.
A midsummernightsdream. This ballet was great and like a fairytale, since you have Felix Mendelsohn beautifull music mixed with scary music and sounds when the puk is there
Beautiful Building from the outside. Tours when we were there were at 3pm and 4pm. These, unfortunately did not work for us, so we did not get to see the inside.
Take the tour. Two tours are offered - 3 & 4 pm. Time your Budapest walks to End up on Andressy Ut in time to take one of these great Tours given in English.

Glamourous - at least the building. The building is really 19th century splendour, somewhere between the old Vienna State Opera before it was destroyed in the war and Garnier's Paris Opéra. The acoustics are poor as the scenic productions are we saw during our visits, while singers and orchestra are doing a good job.

A must. It's not just a theatre, it's the centre of Budapest musical life. There's a performance every day and it's so richly decorated and furnished that it resembles the Parliament. Toghether with the ticket you have the chance to pay alittle extra and listen to a mini concert. Well, it's not so expensive, but you can skip it, because there's only one tenor singing a couple of airs on recorded music, but what is worse is that it takes place in the bar of the theatre and you have to listen to it while standing. Really, this is not worth while.

Opera for 4000 HUF. Found two seats in boxes close to stage on the jegymester site on Saturday pm for Sunday's performance, only 4000 huf, the cheaper seat had a very restricted view. We could see 85% of the stage so no real problem. Great ballet based on Midsummer Night's Dream. Dancers were excellent and the orchestra particularly the lead violin were fantastic. Beautiful opera house and had time to look around during the two intervals. Perfect. Would cost you £200 in Covent Garden and I,m not sure it would match this.If you have never been to see a good ballet or opera try it out!

Ornate. Interesting and informative tour of the Opera House. Smaller than Viennas but more ornate. Great story behind why it was built. Really not a bad seat in the house. Will try to post a picture from a box seat.

beautiful place , wonderful performance. We bought tickets in much advance . The performance of Cavalleria Rusticana was outstanding and we had very good located seats . The only problem was that the seats were stiff and rigid .
recommended. beautiful as the Basilic. worth to visit on a rainy afternoon. brings you to a good mood and it is very unique.

Hungarian State Opera House, Budapest. Although I only speak a total of about 20 words of Hungarian, I decided to go with my relatives to see Bánk Bán at the famous Budapest Opera House. This opera is considered the country’s national opera. All of my relatives who grew up in Hungary studied this opera in school. The story is a Romantic melodrama by Ferenc Erkel, and takes place in 13th Century Hungary. It’s virtually unknown outside of Hungary since the opera was written and composed for Hungarian singers. There certainly aren’t many opera singers outside of Hungary who can sing opera in Hungarian! This opera is so treasured by the nation that the Hungarian State Opera in Budapest has opened every season with it since the theater's founding in 1884. First of all, the Budapest State Opera House is stunning…absolutely stunning. Built by Miklós Ybl in the neo-Renaissance style, the building is replete with paintings, carvings, sculptures, gilding, crystal chandeliers, and sweeping marble stairways. We arrived early just to gawk and take photos. Our seats were fabulous—five rows from the orchestra pit—and cost 12,000 forints each, or about $51.00 US/Canadian. Where else in the world can you get such fantastic seats at a famous opera for such a bargain? You can order tickets on line. However, our actual seats were not very comfortable…they were very hard and not at all cushy enough for a three-act opera. My four, very tall male cousins felt seat-weary by the end of the performance, and we saw many people fidgeting in their seats throughout the performance. Although there were German subtitles on the night we attended the performance, this didn’t help those of us who spoke only English. When my cousin in Budapest booked our tickets the previous month, he was told that there would be a written summary of the acts available in English so we could follow the story line. However, when we arrived for the performance, there was nothing at all in English! It’s a good thing there were three relatives in our group who spoke Hungarian so they could tell us the story plot. We also got a short verbal summary in English from a staff member during the intermission. If you plan to see this opera in Budapest, and no English subtitles or written summary are available, I would highly suggest that you find a summary of the story plot on the Internet so you will know what’s happening. Print it out and take it with you to the performance so you can understand what’s going on, act by act. I also found a movie of the opera on YouTube, and it was helpful to watch it before I left home. If you have somewhat of a clue about the story line, then not knowing the Hungarian language will not be a msjor disadvantage. The opera itself was a joy to see. The costumes, the quality of singing, and the stage sets were all top-notch. As was the music. There were some typically Hungarian instruments used by the orchestra…listen for them! After one patriotic song where the hero sings about his homeland of Hungary, the audience clapped in unison for several minutes and stopped the show. It was an extremely moving moment. Having a glass of wine in the bar during intermission was a special event as well. The male server behind the bar spoke impeccable English, so ordering a drink was easy.If you can’t arrange tickets for an opera performance, or are concerned about watching an opera in Hungarian with no English subtitles, daily tours of the opera house are available in English.All-in-all, this was an experience in Budapest that I’ll always treasure.

The place is amazing. An amazing Opear house - acoustics are the best our Rigoletto was good but not outstanding - u are not allowed in until less than 30 mins before curtain up and so no real chance to have a drink before the show !

Bargain tickets, fantastic night!. Booked last minute 500ft tickets (about £1.50) for the ballet, Midsummer Nights Dream. Although we coudn't see the whole stage, we could still appreciate the great peformances, the wonderful orchestra and the splendid Opera House interior. We hadn't seen ballet before, but I really loved this - much recommended.

Great combination of history, culture and architecture. We took one of the daily afternoon tours and were impressed by the building and its history. The optional extra costs to take photographs and hear a mini- concert were well worthwhile, and our English-speaking guide was knowledgeable, entertaining and helpful. I wish we had been able to attend a performance in this grand setting.

a cultural/historical experience. Had a wonderful tour guide who provided lots of good information about the Opera House and those who funded, attended it. Be aware that you must pay a separate fee to be able to take photos. Spend the few florints it costs- worth it. Also, the 5 minutes of Opera music was fun- acoustics great.

Magnificent architecture. I wold thoroughly advise booking tickets to see an opera but there is no need to pay for the expensive tickets. I managed to get box seat tickets for only 4000 forints. Admittedly they weren't the front seats but I still got a good view, definitely worth the experience.

A great evening!. One simply cannot come to Budapest without visiting the Hungarian State Opera House. Tosca was definitely one of the best performances we have ever seen. The Opera House itself is breathtaking. The interior decor has to be seen to be believed! It's well worth spoiling yourself for a special evening out.

lacking a certain something. the tour of the opera house was very informative and paying the extra for the short concert was also worthwhile however the acoustics of this show in a small entrance leaves you wondering what it would actually sound like around the auditorium, if they had something to give you the feel of this experience it would have made whole tour complete

if you can, see a performance here while in Budapest. We booked tickets through jegymester.hu (or something similar) to an opera on our last night in Budapest. We were not disappointed! The stagevwas full of musicians, the singers, and a huge background chorus. It was a treat for the eyes as well as the ears. The acoustics were amazing, and the building itself is a treat to see. Our experience was fantastic, except for the disapproving stares from the locals who did not approve of our dress--being travelers to a cold and wet city with limited luggage space we dressed the part. However we didn't let it mar our experience of a wonderful night at the opera.

Beautiful to Look At. The Opera is a magnificent building and so we bought tickets. We had been to the Prague Opera the week before and went to the Krakow Opera a few weeks after. The Budpest Opera simply did not compare. The sets were minimal and the lighting distracting. The singers were acceptable. We were sorely disappointed. Perhaps it would be better to take the tour than buy a ticket. Or, perhaps just look at the building from outside.
Nice for picture only. Very cool, old and nice, but i didnt take a look inside, actually it's very nice if u just take a walk along andrassy street

Go for a performance, rather than a tour. Yesterday I visited this place doing the guided tour (daily at 3 and 4pm), priced 2,900 HUF. It's fine, and you get ample opportunity to take photos, but you don't go back stage, and it's not really good value given that today I went there to see a 4 hour Wagner opera for 7,500 HUF.My criticisms would be as follows:Latecomers are admitted whenever they want, which can be really irritating, especially given the flooring is made of creaky old wood;The seats, whilst offering lots of space, are also made of creaky old wood, so when people move about, it makes a lot of noise;You're obliged to put your coat in the cloakroom;There was every expense spared with the set of the performance I saw (Parsifal) - there was virtually no effort in the set design;The lighting is poor, and bleeds out a lot into the audience, which already has quite a bit of light in it with lots of stair lights and a couple of TV screens for people right on the sides.Aside from this, the acoustics are good, the 60 piece orchestra was excellent, and the building is quite beautiful throughout.

Must be the best opera house in the world. We went to this opera house after visiting the opera house in Vienna. This is way better than the one in Vienna. Very beautiful building fully decorated with gold. We did the guided tour and it was very informative. This is a must see in Budapest

Don't miss this - brilliant value. It's very cheap to visit this beautiful opera house - you can get a ticket for a performance for 1000HUF or so (less than £5!) via the website. I've never been to an opera before, but rather enjoyed the production (Eugene Onegin). My seat was in the balcony but the view was pretty good. Not particularly comfortable seat, particularly the lack of legroom, but acceptable for a short time.If you do go for a cheap seat in the balcony, note that you have to go in via the side entrance (rather than the main one at the front) and climb several flights of stairs. Also it is compulsory to leave your coat, bag, umbrella etc in a cloakroom just before you enter the auditorium, costing 180HUF (so have some coins ready). There is a good bar at the balcony level, to get drinks in the intervals.

You have to go if you are in Budapest!. A must go in budapest. The building is glorious. The performances are fantastic. Simply one of the best perfomance venues i have been too...and tickets from £1.50!!!! You can also book in advance and print your tickets before you leave England through their selling website...Jeggy something...Even if you don't fancy opera or ballet...try it this place it might just convert you ;-)
Opera House Tour. Definitely worth a visit. The tour is only 45 minutes. The guides are friendly. I recommend taking in a show if you can.

Stunning building, visit even if you hate Opera. Much better if you're an Opera lover; well priced tickets and a good variety of Hungarian and international opera each season. Otherwise join a tour - very afternoon at 3 or 4.

Beautiful building. This is a must see the opera house is beautiful inside. You do have to pay to take photos inside. You can pay for a mini concert basically it is one woman singing 2 opera songs to a CD player not done in the main opera house. You have to pay for this, in my opinion I would sooner have paid to take photos. Well worth a visit though.
Visit to the Ballet. It was a marvelous occassion and magnificent building.My first visit to a Ballet and it was the ballet "Gone with the Wind" seen the film but very different as a ballet.

Stunning gem of a building.. Best way of seeing the whole interior is to buy ticket for the opera. But be warned, whatever you go to see, try and be familiar at least with the story, and the music as well if possible, because there are NO supertitled translations, and the programmes are only in Hungarian. Considering that this is one of the Top 10 things to see, I think the opera house managment should make non-Hungarian speaking visitors more welcome.
Great experience. We got 500Huff seats (about £3). We couldn't see much, but the building, music and experience was lovely.
Good acoustics, nice view and helpful staff. The hall has good acoustics, interior is old and nice, needs cosmetic renovations. Staff is helpful, speaking some foreign languages to some extend.

Beautiful. Stunning interior and an interesting tour of the public areas and the places where only grandees would normally go. No backstage element unfortunately. I'd have liked to walk on the stage and try out the acoustics! Shame there wasn't a performance the day we went!

Amazing place. Sadly we didn't get to go to an opera or ballet on our visit, but we did go on the guided tour. The building is staggeringly beautiful and well worth a visit. The whole place is in pristine condition and the tour was very informative and worthwhile. Pay the little extra for the mini-concert at the end of the tour, which was great fun.

Tremendous. We took the English Language tour (3.00 and 4.00 daily) which took about 45 minutes and it gave a detailed insight into a fabulous building. For a few Forints extra we went for the "mini concert" which was a very good tenor singing a couple of operatic arias backed by a small CD player in the bar area.A good way to while away an hour.

A romantic night!. We bought tickets online for Don Giovanni in February when we visited Budapest. It was great to get dressed up to go out for the night with my boyfriend. It was hard to follow the opera but once we had looked up the synopsis in the interval we enjoyed it much more.

Close your eyes and you are back in time. I also recently attended the performance or Tournadot a small world. Speechless. The performance was nice but the star was the building. If you enjoy old buildings and fine craftmanship then you cannot miss this building. Stunning from the outside but inside is just spectacular. the detail is mid boggling. there are tours and they are given in english, but step back in time and experirence the building during an pera like it was meant to be experienced. I was a guest so i do not know the price but it was worth it at any price. The intermissions were enough time to view that building. My friend thought it wsa on the small side probably because of Hollywood and how anything looks bigger on screen, but i reminded him that in days of old not that many people could afford to attend the opera so a giant setting was nto needed. Just a plain great experience that will linger long in my memory.the booths bing back memories of historical intrigue and the king's booth is quite elaborate.

A highlight of our stay.. What an experience! We saw a fabulous performance of Don Giovanni in this opulent, historic opera house. Excellent seats in the front stalls for £26! Wouldn't have missed it for the world. A highlight of our stay in Budapest.
Wonderful performance. The building is worth a visit and the prices even for the top seats represent very good value. We saw Turnendot.
Turandot. Loved the opera, but the venue was also great. Small by city opera house standards, but very elegant and cosy at the same time. Great value tickets.
Othello. Beautiful building, and the inside is an ornate palace. The accoustics were very good. Brilliant evening and so cheap. Booked well before we travelled to Budapest and the tickets were £3.75!

I wasn't impressed. For a city with such beautiful architecture, I found the exterior of the opera house tame and borderline tacky. As with most opera houses it copies Paris was this one really missed the mark.

Well worth attending. The tickets are priced according to performance and are a good value. The house is small enough that the box seats are in close proximity to the stage. Old world charm paired with classical and modern productions. We were enthralled.
Xerxes!. Beautiful red and gold interior.Efficient cloakroom facilities. Full house. Quality singing/acting. Modern version took some getting used to but overall a good performance.
Stunning. We popped in to see the lobby. We'll definitely do the tour next time. This building is beautiful inside. The staircase alone is gorgeous!

A Beautiful Building, A Capable Opera. Went to see Turandot at the State Opera House and, while I liked very little of the staging of the opera (which, to be honest, I don't really like in itself to begin with), it had several sublime, inspired moments, and the architecture and decoration of the building itself is well worth the absolutely astonishing value of the tickets. And you get to brush up on your magyar with the subtitles. (You might want to refresh your knowledge of the libretto before you attend a performance if your magyar isn't great--mine is non-existent--and you don't have an ear for operatic Italian or German or whatever the case may be.

Like opera? Go! Not expensive:-). Once one of Europe's leading opera houses, this newly restored opera house has not lost its former glory and elegance. Unless you consider opera as bad as rootcanal work, you MUST owe yourself one night here. Compared to most other European capital opera houses, this one even works on a budget holiday: I paid 13.000 huf for the most expensiv ticket available (at e.g. the opera in Copenhagen, this is the price for the cheapest, crabbiest ticket), so the cheap tickets are really cheap:-)

Amazing building, BIZARRE show. The building is without question stunning - dont miss this while you're hereAs to a show - we got great tickets in the stalls for just €30 each, which is a bargain. However, if you're used to Opera in The Royal Opera House Covent Garden, you may find things a bit of a let down... The costumes are a bit drab, they used UV paint in classical Puccini and they had so very many stage extras doing odd dances that detracted from the singing. The female singers tended to really show up the weaknesses of their men too. Maybe stick to a tour of the building at 3 or 4pm!
Grand building. Definitely worth a visit. There are hour long tours at 3 and 4pm. Spectacular building in good repair (unusual for Budapest).
Great experience. We attended a Puccini opera during our stay - fantastic performance and incredible surroundings with lots of gilt-edged ornamentation and fresco-ed ceilings

Why pass this up? . With tickets online from only 500 ft (2.27 US Dollars) you really can't beat this. My seat was not the best but I could still see and experience the music and architecture. It's usually over by 10 so you can easily go out after if you want to. Also, if you really just don't want to foot the bill or sit through an entire performance, go in the building a little before 7 when it first opens. You don't need to show tickets until you get to the theatre inside so you can see the beautiful lobby for free!

Fantastic performances in a fantastic opera house. Went to a ballet performance to an adapted story of Gone With The Wind. An amazing performance with great dancers. The orchestra playing the music was fantastic too. Well, I like both going to opera and ballet. But even if you're not into this kind of cultur, it's a great experience going to such a beautiful opera house. It's also worth to dress up a little bit, maybe start the evening with a nice dinner in a good restaurant and round up with going to the opera. Don't forget to check out the opera bar where you can order drinks e.g. Hungarian champagne.

Weird and Wonderful. Amazing building, both inside and out! The Opera however was very random. It was this weird breakdance musical with everyone opera singing their lines! We actually left half way through - the show itself doesn't come close to the professional work of London's West End. Still worth every penny to just sit in the most beautiful theatre I have been in and I have been to a fair few!!

Beautiful Opera House. The Opera House was a magnificent structure. So very beautiful with amazing architecture and paintings. I also went to a ballet there in the evening and it was a great experience. One of the best Opera Houses in Europe, and definitely worth a look!

amazing. The biggest scene, the most decors, an excellent accoustic quality, comfortable seats, an air-conditioning "avant la lettre", in short, extraordinary, rich, beautiful, big, golden, worth the visit!
Magnificent building. Even if you don't go to the opera it's worth popping in to see the decor. It's breathtaking and well worth the visit

Great pricing for concerts. The Opera House tour is a little expensive, although very interesting. But the great about this Opera House is they offer quality seats for great concerts and with excellent prices, usually startinf from 500ft per seat.
So it is recommended to do the tour and come back later to catch a concert!

So cheap, beautiful. We were determined to watch whatever we could at the State Opera House after being informed by our tour guide of how cheaply we could buy tickets. We only paid 500HUF and although from these seats we couldn't see a thing, we were happy to move and stand towards the back of the room where we could see perfectly. If you've never seen a ballet before, we would highly recommend going here just because of how inexpensive it was and you couldn't ask for more beautiful interior- a must see building.

Do the tour and then go to the opera. This is a beautiful building and well worth the entrance fee. It is great to hear the stories, and to experience the building. We did the tour and then attended a performance that evening. It would be worth it to get full stage view seats in the upper balcony (which we didn't have). And be sure to read about the opera before you attend since the captions were in Hungarian (obviously).

wow - such a beautiful venue. the opera house is very grand and has fantastic accoustics for listening to opera. We booked our tickets in advance as we could choose our seats. We had a box on the upper circle - box 2 which had a good view. Not sure that what the opera was about - Xeres bit odd but an amazing evening. Interval drinks with lovely delicate pastries and sandwiches on offer. Lots of fur with the Hungarians present a grand affair!!

Handel's Serse. Witty, wacky production of the Opera Seria that confused London when it first appeared. The Opera House itself was simply gorgeous - and the fact that we could understand nothing as the opera was in Hungarian/Italian didn't really matter. Some great singing - some rather indifferent - but a very enjoyable evening all told.

Excellent!. The opera house is truly spectacular and there are tours daily at 3 and 4 pm. We also managed to get opera tickets for the next night...we were in the 6th row from the stage and it cost us £30...not prices you see in the uk! The opera was wonderful...definitely recommend an evening there!

very beautiful. building is very beautiful inside and out, be sure to take the tour~~! starts at 3pm, 4 pm everyday, also get a ticket to see a performance, very nice and very good prices, however no english subtitles, so if you don't understand italian or the opera's original language, be sure to find out what it's about first, or something....

Must see. If you get the chance to see a performance here, it will not disappoint. The acoustics are fantastic and the decor is phenomenal. Tickets are very reasonable and for only 4,500 FT we sat in box seats.

Beautiful Building, Lovely Show, No English Subtitles. Managed to get a pair of tickets to see a performance of Don Giovanni at the last minute. The building was breathtaking, especially at night. The show was quite good. Our only disappointment was when we discovered the Opera House only offered Hungarian subtitles to our Italian Language Opera.

Beautiful opera house capturing the old style and grandeur, nervous young lady guide included. There is a subway stop called Opera which brings you straight to the entrance. It's really advised to take the tour for around 2500 HUF. When you want to visit the opera, you should be aware there are only 2 daily visits, at 3 and 4 pm. We bought a photo ticket which gives you a wristsign but it does not seam that it makes any difference, our guide let everybody take pictures.The guided tour bring you around beautifull wooden and marble decorated strairs, smoking room, the entrance of the presidential loge and last but not least, the upper balcony on which you can overlook the opera and make you feel like one of the rich people form the past. We had a young sweetFrench speaking guide who was very enthousiastic but also very nervous to guide us around, which added to the pleasure of the visit.

Spectacular building, cheap seats are good, smuggle in some wine ;). My girlfriend and I watched Don Giovanni, in italian with hungarian subtitles, it was this reason that i smuggled in beer and small bottles of wine as thought in may be needed to make it through the evening! Although it was needed the night was great, the auditorium is amazing and from the cheap seats right at the sides you can see the orchestra from above which is really nice. Id advice reading the story behind the opera before you go as you can follow it much better. Buy a few mini bottle of nice wine before you go and you can just take them in your bag, no probs. Also there is a nice thai restaurant down the street towards town on the right hand side. was very good food, cheap and right next to the metro so you can jump on it before it closes at 11.

Magnificent building. We missed the daily 3 and 4 o'clock tours but were able to explore around the building and the foyer - it is so grand and all built using Hungarian materials. The marble colours are so opulent and distinct for the area. There is a very interesting history accompanying this grand building - it is a definite must see!

Great time. The building looks great from outside and decided to do the tour. I have to say that the building impressed us and we enjoyed the the tour a lot too. A bit of a history of Budapest and Austro hungarian empire. Tour was in english (spanish and german language are available too) and was quiet pleasant. We only regreat that didnt go for a play but... hopefuly next time

Extraordinary experience. So pleased we followed advice and opted to visit the Opera House by watching a show. Having never been to an opera performance before, we thought it might be a one off experience! Watching Don Giovanni sung in Italian with Hungarian subtitles could have made for a long night, but both me and my partner loved our evening! Building is gorgeous, was a real treat to dress up (my boyfriend brought his suit and I wore a nice dress), music was beautiful, orchestra was fantastic and the singers were outstanding. Highly recommend. Also get there a bit early, as different seats have different entrances, which can be a bit confusing! Oh, and book your seats online before you go. We had front row balcony seats for £11 - bargain!

A must at Budapest.. You must take the guided tour to learn many interesting facts about the structure. Worths to pay some. Most of the boxes are gold plated. A huge (20mx20mx48m) stage. They designed smoking areas (holes) years before the prohibition. You can enter to the best boxes (lodges) during the guided tour. Smaller but probably better than Wien State Opera house. Highly recommended.

7 mins away from Trendy Budapest B&B Hostel. The Hungarian State Opera House (Hungarian: Magyar Állami Operaház) is a neo-Renaissance opera house located in central Budapest, on Andrássy út. It is home to the Budapest Opera Ball, a society event dating back to 1886. Before the closure of "Népszínház" in Budapest, it was the second largest opera building in Budapest. Today it is the largest Opera building in Budapest and Hungary.
Cheap tickets for Opera. I went there with first time Opera-listener, who slept through most of the first part - but for 1,5 euro Its okay :) The inside of the opera is so beautiful!

Wow!. This is a must if you are in Budapest and interested in culture and great experiences. I saw Don Giovanni which was a spectacular performance, and the building itself is breathtakingly beautiful. Take a glass of champagne in the bar during the halftime and just enjoy the magical atmosphere. Top notch opera evening in all ways. I just loved it.

Beautiful building and a fun experience. Before our trip to Budapest I was checking on some things to see in the city, and noticed that the tickets at this opera house are incredibly cheap. Being a 19 year old guy, I had never been to an opera before, and it seemed like a fun thing to do.So we booked some tickets for €1,75 each, fully expecting a very amateuristic performance and to be seated behind a column. Yet the music turned out to be fantastic, and it was cool to see an opera being performed, even when the subtitles were in Hungarian.I would definitely recommend to anyone even remotely interested in either music, architecture or, hell, even opera!

Opera fan? You will be disappointed. The Hungarian State Opera House is a beautiful building. It was a lovely evening to spending here, and people do get dressed up here still, which is a nice change from anything-goes these days in New York and London. That said, if you are an opera fan, and you know what really good opera is, then you may be disappointed as we were. We saw the opening night of Der Fliegen Hollander on 19 Jan. Bizarrely, it was shown in its entirety without an interval, despite scene changes--2 hrs 20 min or so. That said, if they HAD had an interval, we wouldn't have returned for the second half! Weird staging, lacklustre conducting, and singers who perhaps were not on the way up, but had peaked in their careers. The chorus was jolly good, despite their completely naf costumes and pointless staging.
Great building. Although we couldn't see a performance here, it was still nice to go along and look at! The building is very impressive inside, even though we could just see the foyer area ;)

A must do, the opera house in Budapest. We saw an opera at the budapest opera house. This was one of the highlights of our trip. We are not huge opera fans but this was such a great experience I highly reccomend it. the building is absolutely stunning. Don't miss out on a great experience.

A Must See (and listen). This is a magnificent venue, rich in history, steeped in culture, a must see. My suggestion is to take the option of hearing a performer at the end of the tour (given in at least 5 languages) for a delightful finish. The decor is beautiful and the singer even better. Very enjoyable

Try to see a show rather than the tour. Unfortunately we weren't able to get tickets to a show while we were in town (we booked our trip only 5 days in advance and a new production was premiering that weekend). We wanted to see the building so we opted for the tour instead. I hoped to see back stage areas or portions of the building you wouldn't see on a night out. Other than a quick peak into a loge box we didn't see much that you wouldn't see during a show. Granted there was a bit more information provided, but considering the tour cost more than some of the tickets for a show I would have much preferred to see a show.Overall, the building is worth seeing, given it's age and architectural detail, but I think it'd be better seen during a performance rather than the tour.

Hungarian splendour!. Such a beautiful building - both the interior and exterior. We had an English-speaking tour guide and paid a few Forints extra for the mini-concert, which definitely added to our overall enjoyment. The tour guide was very knowledgable and it was a very interesting tour.

Beautiful! Excellent Tour. The beautiful Hungarian State Opera House offers tours daily at 15:00 and 16:00. Arrive 15-20 minutes before to purchase tickets as the small gift shop where they are sold is quickly crowded. Tours are offered in a variety of languages and our guide spoke excellent English. We really enjoyed the history and the splendor of this fantastic sight! Don't pay for the 'concert' as it is only two singers and a guitarist in a side salon room, but we did pay extra in order to be able to take pictures inside the theater and capture the building's splendor! Directly across from the Opera metro stop and located in a high-end shopping district.

First time in Opera. This was my first time in opera, and i think i could not have chosen a more better place for that. The surroundings are magical, and the music sounded good. Beautiful place, with lot's of old world charm. Go here, even for only the tour!

Opulence galore!. Amazing building - lots of music history, Mahler was DOM here for a while. Heaps of gold leaf and red furnishings & curtains in the auditorium, paintings and chandeliers. Looks like it's been given a facelift fairly recently. You can imagine the royalty and aristocrats from the old Austro-Hungarian regime fronting up here for the opera. They even had their own staircase so that they wouldn't have to mix with the "plebs". We had a guide - worth it to learn about the background.
La Boheme. We had tickets for La Boheme on the 25th of December! What an experience. A beautiful opera house, superb acoustics, excellent production. Loved it. Stunning opera house!

A wonderful evening!. We saw a Hungarian opera called "Hunyadi Laszlo".We bought our tickets ahead of time from home on the website. We chose to buy tickets in one of the boxes towards the side of the stage. I have been in numerous opera houses and these seats were great! On the ticket, they were called: "Stalls Level Boxes Left 2nd Number row 1, seat 2 and seat 3". There were two other people in our box, and they didn't have as good of a view as us. I believe one of those seats would have been sold as an obstructed view. There was also a settee in the box, which may seat other people, I'm not sure. On our night it was empty. Having a box, even when sharing it with strangers felt very glamorous :)The translation was in English and appeared above the stage, it was easy to read and still watch the actors on stage. During intermission, be sure to step outside onto the terrace with your drink. So lovely. It's also very easy to get to, as there is a metro station directly outside the theater (aptly named "Opera"). Do check what time the metro runs until though. We went for a drink afterwards at a nearby pub and had to walk home as the metro was then closed. I highly recommend seeing an opera here, it's a wonderful experience!

Terrific Tour. This is a gorgeous building on Andrassy, right in the heart of the action. The guided tour is amazing, I loved hearing about the history of this historic building as well as the legends.

Beautiful. Well worth a visit. easy to book via the website - you can even pick your seat direct from the seating plan. Such a beautiful building and a wonderful experience. Always try to go when in Budapest.

A smaller version of La Scala in Milan. We did not see opera in Budapest but went on a guided tour. The building is beautiful with wonderful acoustics. At the end of the tour, a trained opera performer sang a piece from "Phantom of the Opera." The only thing to remember is that if you wish to take photos, you must buy a permit at the same time that you buy your entrance ticket. It would have been nice to know this in advance.

Lavish and grand. We went here twice during our stay to see The Nutcracker Ballet and Puccini's opera, La Boheme. It was fabulous. The interior is beautiful, with lots of gold and little busts built into the architecture. We had a box for La Boheme- for the price they are it can only be classed as a bargain. Both performances were fantastic and were made even more magical by the wonderful setting! Do not miss an opportunity to see something here- you will not forget it!

beautiful opera house. Tour was informative and helped me appreciate the symbolism and history of the building and the decorative elements. We wished it could have been longer and more comprehensive. We had a little performance by an opera singer at the end of the tour, which was wonderful.

Wonder!. Opera house of Budapest can only be described as a wonder! We had the luck to see LA BOHEME (Puccini) which was very nice.The building is impresive, covered with gold and marbles. People travel from neighbor countries to enjoy opera in Budapest.
Beautiful and a must see!. We watched Anna Karenina and booked tickets online from the UK. They were unbelievably cheap and well worth it, the building is simply stunning.

Beethoven Rocks. For less than $10 a seat, we enjoyed a night at the spectacular Opera House. Don't get me wrong. We would have spent more, but you don't have to and these were the last seats available. Generally, the sound in the upper balcony is very good and you can look down upon the incredible interior architecture. It might be fun to splurge on loge (box) seats. Anyway, it turned out that New Year's Day was a televised national concert. The performance was Beethoven's Ninth Symphony including the dramatic finish with a large operatic choir and solos singing "Ode to Joy". Wow!

High class venue at low prices. Beautiful building, couldn't believe how cheap the tickets were (approx £30.00 for the ballet), which was Anna Karenina and was breathtaking. Pop into Callas a lovely cafe just to the left of the opera house for a drink before the show.

Worth a visit but try and see a performance . We would have loved to have seen a performance but there was nothing on with our timescales which is a shame as the prices were very very reasonable so we went on a 3/4 hour tour (circa 6000 hur) what a lovely place oh I wish we could have seen something. People were taking photo's without buying a ticket without a problem , a chance you take I guess

Fascinating. The visit was very interesting, it is like going back in time to the Austro Hungarian times. We heard about Sisi and Franz Joseph, about the construction of the opera house about the architect. En bref, don't miss the tour.

A marvellous opera.. The decoration , the beauty of the place and the artistic quality of the operas and concerts given there. Budapest's Opera House can also be visited in the afternoon.Its location is righjt in the centre of the city, on Andrassy Street.

beautiful opera house and performance. it was a wow...........packed for a Sunday matinee, small and beautiful and so very well kept exactly what you would expect of a first class opera house and company

Historical ornately decorated building. If you go to Budapest it would be a shame not to take a tour round its famous opera house. The tour lasts for just under one hour and is very interesing as it shows you all around the stunningly decorated building and provides you with much historical information. It was much larger than I expected it to be and the tour guide provided us with some 'Light amusing' stories. If you dont intend going to a show then I would recommend tagging on the 'Little Concert' extra as for a small fee you can listen to an opera singer for 5 minutes or so in one of the beautiful rooms of the opera house whch puts a nice end to this tour.

Highly recommended. Saw Anna Karenina the Ballet here. Beautiful ballet in the most beautiful Opera House. If you are visiting Budapest, I would recommend a visit here to see an opera/ballet, If not, take a tour around the opear house.
Grand. First time at the opera! Grand theatre, interesting mix of tourist and local audience. Watched 'The Nutcracker' - lovely experience

Do the tour!. We were in Budapest during Christmastime and would've loved to see The Nutcracker at the Opera House, but unfortunately we were pressed for time and opted for the guided tour instead. The tour is offered in many different languages and at certain times of the day (check the website beforehand). The tour is absolutely worth it, the building is beautiful and it's lovely to hear about the amazing history. Our taxi driver said that parts of the movie Evita were filmed here!

A place to be. We saw La Traviata there. Great play, great singers (poor production though). The place is astonishing. It "travels" you back in time. We issued our tickets earlier (on line) and we had a good price deal for them.

Magnificient interior, but many places with limited view and poor subtitles. be aware that the cheaper tickets come with a very limited view of the stage - but they can be incredibly cheap so worth it if only to see the splendid interior of the opera.Came for "Die Fledermaus" (The bat) - as commented elsewhere, the subtitles provided were good for the first act, but then whoever prepared them seems to have run out of time and they became quite useless. Wardrobe and bar accept Euro cash as well.

See a show!. The building like many others in Budapest is full of beauty and grandeur! Try to buy tickets to an opera or a ballet before hand as it is definitely worth seeing a show inside and not just a tour! Tickets for an opera can start as low as a few hundred forints (<£10). Our seats were in a box shared with 8 people in total (4000HUF ~£13). Great experience!

deplorable organization. I have to admit that the whole music hall is magnificent, in a splendid italian old-style.I have witnessed "Carmen", on 16th of October 2012. The show, as I saw it, was good, especially the artistic performance of main role (Carmen was Erika Gal).The visibility of the scene was poor, even if I bought tickets that promised a good seat, tickets that were purchased online, with a month before.What broke down all night, and I did go during break, was the unfortunate incident with my seat. After only five minutes during the beginning of the concert, I woke up pulled on my shoulder by a lady that showed me a ticket that was past the same place as mine!!! Because was a lady and unwilling to disturb the show, I stood up from my chair and watched the concert (half of it, like I'm said) in feet.Disappointing experience, but beautiful concert hall!
State Opera House. It was closed on the day we visited so we could not go inside however the outside facade was truly impressive with the massive colonades framing the entrance.

A must see. If you want to tour the Opera House you need tickets. The process to secure was easy. The Opera House is so beautiful and we had the privilege of hearing one of the performers as she was getting ready to sing later that evening.

Amazing building. Amazing building, with great program for operas. Nevertheless the New Year's concert was not at all as expected. To my opinion it should be music to celebrate the New year, and it was not at all like that...

Great experience!. One of the places I enjoyed the most. The house itself looks impressing, It was my first opera experience, and we went to see La Boheme. The tickets were cheap as chips, but the show was amazing! Shame that they didn't have more information and leaflets in English, considering that most of the visitors there were foreigners

Tour was okay. The Opera House itself is a brilliant building steeped in history with fantastic architecture, however that said, they only run tours twice a day at 3 and 4pm which last for approx 45 mins this results in huge crowds of people of all languages congregating at the same time, although the tours were then split into different languages, there were too many people that if you were at the back of the group often you could not hear what was being said, also I felt that we were being rushed through the tour as they were trying to get so many groups of people to see the same parts of the building which was a shame.

Amazing building, poor opera performance. The building in itself is magnificent on the inside. We visited for an opera show, but you can also tour the building with a guide, which I would recommend. The opera (Die Fledermause) was in Hungarian, although it is a German piece. Fortunately there was an English translation projected above the stage. But as the show went on, the translation got more and more poor. During the third act it was more or less absent, which is why we eventually left before the show was over.
Beautiful operahouse. We saw the opera La Bohéme, had booked great seats in advance for a very modest price (about 10.000 HUF for 12th row). The interior of the opera house is very impressive!
