Amazing Buliding. A wonderful tour, well presented by the guide, though we were many, I would have liked more time, so that we could have learnt some more about the building and the people who perfomed there.

New Year's Eve and New Year's Day Opera and concert. We attended a Hungarian sung Die Fledermaus, with sur-titles in English on New Year's Eve, and a performance of Beethoven's 9th Symphony on New Years Day. The opera house is a beautiful example of fin-de-siecle architecture and decor. There are tours available daily. A must see.

The Bat. We visited the State Opera on our first day in Budapest. The building was magnificent. We ordered tickets from opear.hu with no difficulties. The Bat was in Hungarian; the first act had what seemed to be good texting in English. However during the second act the local audience laughed a lot and it seemed that the English texting lacked a lot of the dialogue.

A great opera house. We did the guided tour and admired the stunning architecture of the opera house. I especially remember the grand buffet and the smoking gallery with its wooden panelling and golden wallpaper. Being opera lovers we also visited a performance and enjoyed the atmosphere in the house.

Memorable evening. This is an amazing venue, with enough gilt to dazzle and cherubs wherever you look. We saw Nutcracker danced in the run up to Christmas and had a memorable evening, arriving in snow. Go up to the front bar (it was closed when we were there but you can still go in to look at the decor). tickets are cheap by our standards.
Most beautiful opera house. Went for New Years Night Concert, Beethoven's 9th. Was a wonderful experience. Felt like early 20th Century, music was fantastic.

A beautiful place to Visit. This opera house angered the Franz Josef. He had decreed that it had to be smaller than the one in Vienna, but he did not stress cost. So this opera house is more lavish and exceeded the costs of the Viennese one. Just beautiful. Go with a knowledgeable guide like we did.
Lovely Opera!. We went to see La Boheme. We found the Opera more tourist friendly than the one in Prague. Not so chaotic and the staff spoke English. Lovely show. Beautifully decorated for Christmas!

Awsome building, better than Vienna and maybe Paris.. We were taken here as part of a tour, shown around it by people who cared. The building wasn't supposed to excel Vienna State Opera House, but I am here to tell you after seeing that place with literally thousands of people crowded into the short period they allowed, I prefer Budapest.Lucky enough to have champagne to sip while we were serenaded by a soprano and tenor (may have helped our enjoyment.

Breathtaking!. We attended two events: an opera and our seats did not allow us to see much of anything, but we were warned before purchasing the $3 (yes, $3!!) tickets to hear The Bat by Strauss and the ballet The Nutcracker for $40 per ticket. The box seats are quaint and lovely. Just know beforehand if you will be listening or viewing so you're not disappointed. One tip: don't pay the price to tour the Opera House when you can enjoy an opera for as little as $3. Don't let the price fool you; it's world class and it's better to hear some of the opera and experiencing the confines with people in attendance versus being whisked through the turn-of-the-century gem with 100 others from a tour group. This may have been the highlight of my stay in Budapest! That's not easy to say because there are many great experiences to be had in this city.

Beautiful building. One of the most beautiful buildings of the city. Try to combine your visit with an opera or ballet performance. Book on-line is possible and in good prices. If you take balcony take only front places because else is difficult to enjoy.

Get a ticket!. We reserved the tickets before the trip and printed the tickets at home, really easy to buy online as there is English version of the website. The cast is really magnificent. Initially we thought of joining a guided tour of this magnificent building, but the ticket price is really a bargain comparing with those in Vienna, so why not enjoy an opera while you could appreciate the building as you like!
Must See!. Out of the two weeks I spent in Budapest, this stands out the most. The inside is beautiful. Had the opportunity to watch the Nutcracker as well.
The Nutcracker ballet @Christmas Day. We loved it, both adults and kids. Buying tickets on-line was easy and convinient. Unforgettable Christmas event!
Beautiful. One of the most beautiful buildings in the city. I din't have much time to go inside and watch opera.

Tour was good and we bought tickets for a show. Tour wasn't bad and guide spoke excellent english. Tours go at 2pm and 4pm and our group was very large. It was a great way to poke around the opera house and by the end we decided to pick up tickets to the Nutcracker the following afternoon. Worth it.

Fantastic experience. If you travel to Budapest, consider booking one night at the opera, it is amazing. The building by itself is a sight but also the experience of a classic performance in such an elegant scene is frustrating.
Worth the money. go for a 1 hour tour of the museum with nice history lessons included. Don't pay extra for the mini concert...

Beautiful Architecture. We attended La Boheme on Christmas Day 2012 and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. This was our first Opera and maybe we were too impressed, but I don't think so. We would highly recommend a trip to the State Opera House.
Performance at the Opera House. My wife and I were able to attend a performance by a famous Hungarian composer at the intimate, beautiful Opera House. The sound quality was excellent.

Nutcracker. Fantastic, wonderful setting and a great perfomance all round. I sat in a box above the music and the stage and that was a great place to see it all , better in a box then in the stalls and you get to see the orchestra too. at around £30 the evening was great value too, where else could you experince all this so well done at such a price ?

The heartof Budapest!. This is really a must do in Budapest! The building is wonderful on the inside, and there are lots of cheap tickets for less good seating places so ther is no excuse to not go... we went to see the Nutcracket, a baller, and though we didnt have full view I enjoyed it to the maximum... do it!!
Get your camera ready. We joined the 3pm tour and saw the 'mini' concert. The interior of the building is amazing and it definitely worths a visit.

Stunningly beautiful - worth the tour. Even though the tour itself was mediocre (the tourguide was a bit hard to understand, and a bit inpatient herding our group), it was well worth the money to see the inside of the Opera House. Stunningly beautiful! Please note that it costs extra to take photos inside. We also paid extra to see the opera singer perform a couple of songs, but to our disappointment (maybe we didn't see the fineprint), it was not on stage, it was in the adjacent parlor. Although his performance was good, it was a bit of a letdown, because we expected something a little different.

Beautiful!. Worth looking at just because its pretty! The tour groups are very large so if you not like crowds this is not for you! They charge extra for an opera singer performing 1 song in a parlor room. You just stand in a circle around him but it was still kinda fun! Figured we might as well. Happy travels

Charming venue which is worth the price of a tour ticket. We only toured the Opera house but it really is worth the price of the tour ticket. Excellent tour guide who knew her facts. We love history and we got lots of info about this splendid structure. Loved the architecture!
Great Opera House. Great palce to visit. It's a wonderful building. Guided tours are available aswell. It's located in a very nice area on Andrassy Avenue.

Spectacular. Breathtakingly beautiful. The scene of performances by the great composers and performers in history. We also saw opera performances in the Opera Houses of Vienna and Prague. As beautiful as they are, their interior is not as beautiful as that of the Budapest Opera House.
Fabulous!. This is a must see in Budapest. Outstanding lady guide who was outstanding, excellent English and had a great sense of humour. The opera house is beautiful and we really enjoyed our visit

It is so easy to book on line. Where apart from Budapest could you see a fantastic production of La Traviata, in a UNESCO World Heritage site building, sitting in row four of the stalls for only £37 a ticket! The music and singing were sublime in their own right but combined with the awe-inspiring decoration of the building and champagne during the interval at only £5 a glass, and it is an evening guaranteed to transport you to heaven!
Magnificent. This opera house is magnificent. Only wish we could have heard a performance. The gift shop has a nice selection of traditional Hungarian music available on CD.

My best memory of Budapest. Knowing we were going to be in Budapest for 4 nights, I look on the Internet to see what was on at the Opera House. There was only once choice -Don Pasquale with music by Rigoletto -a comic Opera I was not familiar with. I printed out a synopsis of the plot and took it along. Needn't have worried -although it was sung in Italian, with sub titles on the screen in Hungarian, we had no difficulty in following what was going on. The acting, singing and music were superb. I laughed and cried myself silly- I've never enjoyed an opera so much, and I've seen a few....And the setting -we sat at the front of a gold encrusted box-and it only cost £32!!! We'd pay at least double that in London. Also loved people watching in the intervals at the bar. Dress up if you can. It was the highlight of our trip, and we came out walking on air...

Opera House. We went to see La Boheme in the opera house, as it was very cheap and we wanted to do something different. This particular opera is in Italian (Puccini) and there was a screen which offered Hungarian subtitles. If you do not speak either, it may be harder to get the plot, but the music was nevertheless worth it.

Amazing experience.. We went to see The Nutcracker ballet on the 8th. of December. I purchased the tickets on line a couple of months earlier. The Opera House with the Xmas tree was lovely and the ballet superb. I highly recommend this venue. Just look at the Budapest tourist site for links. Booking a performance couldn't be easier but book at least two months ahead for good seats. Well worth it.

fab. if you are planning a trip to Budapest you just gotta go. The place is beautiful we saw the Nutcracker it was spectacular . There is a very grumpy cloak room lady but that just gave me the giggles
Verdi's Rigoletto. We saw that opera there and had some life-long memories. The inside is so beautiful because the gold is so bright that you can barely look at it even w/o lights on.

Made me enjoy the opera. Ok so I may have got carried away with Mulled Wine, Carols and Christmas trees, but this was a brilliant place to be at Christmas time. Looks spectacular and even our very cheap seats were pretty spectacular. Interval drinks also amazingly reasonable (although you don;t get long to drink them!)
Beautiful Opera House. The Opera House is a must see....a beautiful historic building with amazing ornate ceiling inside. Unfortunately we did not have time to take in a show.

Really worthwhile. Superb building, the tour was good with a great guide and we paid the small extra charge to attend the mini-concert (two arias) which was also superb. Well worth the money and an incredible place to see.

Everything you would expect to experience from this beautiful place. Unfortunately we only had time for the tour and mini-concert, not the full opera experience. Even so, we absolutely fell in love with the Opera House - truly atmospheric, and stunningly over-the-top with more gold, swags and velvet than you can imagine! Mini-concert was lovely

Amazing Inside and Out. This is one of the most stunning opera houses in the world, comparable to Vienna. You must attend a performance if you are in town or at the very least tour the gorgeous building. Show prices are extremely reasonable.

Beautiful reception. Certainly worth popping in to if your in a rush, the metro stop takes you right there!
We didnt have time for a show or tour (every day at 3pm and 4pm)

Opera house tour. It is a stunningly beautiful opera house but the tour felt like a bit of a rip-off. Not really worth it (costs about 12 euros), especially if you're already going to the opera for a performance. Tour was very short (really less than 35 minutes) and contained very little information. Only took you to the main auditorium, bar area, and smoking room -- all things you could see on your own at a performance. One cool part was getting to see the inside of the boxes, but that was about it.

Impressive and cozy!. My visit included the tour in English and the mini concert with an opera singer. If you don't speak English that's alright because you have several language options for the tour from Spanish to French, German, Japanese... You take a pick!The tour is good in general but there's little time to take pictures if you're in the English tour (which, usually, is one of the most popular). The guide talks and at the end of each talk in each room she just moved on to the next room and starts talking again... almost running from one room to another. It's understandable because a group of 15 or 20 people is difficult to control, specially with the little time they have as it's all very synchronized with the other languages tours. All tours happen at the same time and it looks like a dance of groups from room to room. I will not rate it as a 5 because of this... the most popular tours should start slightly early or should happen in other times so people could have more time to enjoy the rooms and be able to take some pictures without having to do it while the guide is talking. If you're listening to the guide and taking pictures at the same time is more likely you'll loose information and it's not polite or fair to the guide's work isn't it?Although we should have more time exploring the building I can understand how things are programmed this way... opera staff needs to prepare the main concert hall for the night's show, etc.Singers and dancers also need to practice but some revaluation of times should be done here.The mini concert does not happen in the main concert hall but in another room. It consists in one opera singer who sings a few popular opera songs all dressed up. It was quite nice to have that taster after the tour. It was just so refreshing and worth the £2 pounds more. So cheap!This taster ends with the singer choosing someone to dance. A very nice touch for the tourists indeed!One of the highlights of our trip and a must visit in Budapest. Don't miss it!
Pretty Building. My friend and I had this place on our list of things to do while in Budapest. It is worth a visit, the edifice is beautiful. We did not do the tour though.

Nutcracker 2012!. Just returned from the State Opera House in Budapest. Never really been to a ballet before but bought two tickets today for the Nutcracker and was blown away by the luxury, the beauty and splendour of the dancing, costuming and staging - and the orchestra was sublime - I will sleep tonight with visions of sugar plum fairies - we didn't do the tour, but being in the opera house for an actual performance was magic. If you are in Budapest, you MUST go to a performance. Any performance. Just go.

Traditional Opera House. A very traditional opera house in Budapest. The interior is lovely but VERY hot!!! The main concert hall was very lovely, very traditional (I guess I am used to Sydney). I did the guided tour which was good, but you kept running into tours in other languages which made it sometimes difficult to hear what your tour leader was saying. Don't bother paying for the photo ticket (not really worth it), or the concert at the end (two songs, a little dull).

Fascinating. We were taken by friends to see Rigoletto. An interesting performance although, as expected since the opera is sung in Italian, the surtitles were in Hungarian.The building is very impressive and worth visiting even if you do not go to a performance.

Great opera at budget prices. Lovely building, superbly decorated and maintained. Very good facilities, bar does not overcharge. Very good value for money compared with London. Opera was very well sung and played

do not miss it. certainly one of the most important operas in europe. even though the exterior needs repairing and restore,the inside is amazing,i was not lucky to attempt to some concert and enjoy the acoustic,but i enjoyed the most the tour and the story about this opera. worths definitely a visit and feel the luxury of the past season.

The exterior needs some tender loving care!. We visited the Opera House recently and while the interior is extravagantly sumptuous the exterior is in dire need of cleaning. It's often difficult to admire and appreciate the details on many of the beautiful buildings in Budapest because they are covered in years of dirt and grime. While I realise it's an expensive chore to clean these building, somewhere as important as the Opera House should be a priority.
Amazing architect and history. I'm not much into opera but a visit the the Opera house was an unforgettable experience. The artwork throughout is stunning and a small recital was an added bonus.

Europe's most beautiful!. We learned that it was cheaper to attend a performance than to pay for the tour. So that is what we did - for 20 Euro's we had box seats and were able to view the opera house on our own time. It blew away the Vienna opera house! Plus we were able to purchase them online and even print them out! Amazing!

Only seen from outside. I only saw the Opera House from outside, they did do tours at 3 and at 4 but I kept missing them, the building looked beautiful - at the top along the roof are lots if past composers, famous hungarian composers either side of the entrance, along with 2 half naked sphinx which placed in honour of the 1st opera ever played there

Spectacular opera house. Sweeping, curved staircases and ornamentation that seems to drip gold from the walls creates a background for reminiscent of days gone by and is a beautiful setting for performances. Tickets are extremely reasonable so if you go to a performance, get a box. They are deep, comfortable, and have room to hang coats and socialize at intermission.

Fabulous Building, wonderful programme. One of the most amazing theatre, opera buildings I have visited. definitely a must. There are guided visitings in the afternoon, but I would recommend to book for one of theirs wonderful choices. we have seen the Hungarian National Ballet presentation, Onegyn, spetacular! lovely bar, very reasonably priced, and very very elegant.

Go to the Opera.. The opera House is a spectacular piece of architecture. I saw Figaro while I was there for a fraction of what I paid at the Met and had better seats here than I could ever afford. If you never saw an opera go and enjoy one in Budapest.
Opera performance. We got tickets for Othello here at a very attractive rate. Dress code was modest - men in jeans, but mainly jacket and tie. Break after each act, with everyone dashing to the bar!

wonderful building and cheap seats. Just wanted to sample the atmosphere so managed to buy 3 for £1.50 each.These seats are restricted view but you you can see most of the stage if lean forward and they do have a large flat screen monitor with a full view of the stage but for £1.50 a seat to see and hear Verdis Rigoltto in does take some beating. We had read on the forum about the cheap seats but i asked at the box office they claimed to have no budjet tickets next to each other but we could sit elsewhere for £50--I declined as we only wanted to sample the evening so i tied the other box office in the opposite corner and had no trouble getting the cheap tickets. In fact there were at least 50 empty seats so the 1st box office in the opera house was trying it on. Great view of the operas house from our seats. We did leave after the 1st interval only because we didn't understand the language but really did enjoy the atmosphere.

Very good for Budapest, average compared to Vienna!. It is a nice and not too expensive experience. However the costumes, staging, set, singing is not up to major Opera level.. it is a beautiful building, it is cute, it is nice to see the locals dressed up. The singing can be ok to good, either the tenor or the bass is not quite the part, but the depth of singing is not there. It is low budget productions and even Teatr Wielki in Warsaw or the Prague Operas are a little better. However it is just 3 hours drive to Vienna - which is well worth whatever price you will pay.

The Opera is one of the most beautiful in Europe. The building is very nice, the Avenue, where you can find it, is in the downtown, and nice
The Opera has really good operas and ballets performances

Try to get a ticket.. A beautiful old Opera house, dont miss the pictures in the cieling, and the bar at the top. The price for a ticket is low and the performans very good, a lot of Bravos in the end.

Not to be missed. The tours run every day at 3pm and 4pm. Costs 2,900 HUF. Our tour was very informative. The building is magnificent and the interior is very plush. It is located on Andrassy Street.
Highly recommended.
Wonderful Don Pasquale. It was funny to see the surtitles in Hungarian, but that's to be expected. The opera house is dazzling and the company did a first rate job.
A Magnificent Building. The architecture of this building is fantastic. A must see when travelling to Budapest. Don't forget to take your camera!

To Opera House for a Ballet and a new experience.... Had absolutely no experience of the ballet. Booked tickets in advance as it seemed a good way to see the building and was almost as cheap as doing the tour. Really interesting experience and would recommend. I would advise some care when booking tickets as views in some of the boxes (if you do not get front row) are restricted - but this should be expected given age of building etc, but I really good expereince and much better value in Hungary than in UK!
Fantastik building. This area is very nice, i totally recommend this place if you are planning to go to Budapest, you should defiantely seeit.

Beautiful. Rather than booking a tour, which costs around 2800HUF, we booked tickets for a show. We were able to get a private box, with a great view of the opera for 500HUF each. It was a great way to experience the theatre and wander around taking pictures. BF and I didn't experience any rude staff, as was mentioned in a previous review.

Intimate elegant venue, good opera company. The old and very elegant opera house has spacious public spaces and a comfortable grand staircase. The whole interior, stalls and horseshoe boxes are smaller than most grand opera theatres lending an intimacy to the performance similar to that in some of the regency theatres in in the UK. One is never quite as far away from the stage as in most operas. The boxes are superb if you sit in the chairs in the front row. The opera is well supported by the state, resulting in amazingly low prices - for the top class ticket you can pay as little as HUF 6000 (£17 compare to Covent Garden's top price of £230). We heard Otello on a Sunday evening. It was a competent performance with a poorly directed first act in which the lead singers were disappointing; they seemed to warm up and improve significantly as the evening wore on. As long as you don't expect grand opera on the scale of Covent Garden, the Met, or La Scala you can enjoy a highly professional provincial opera in a beautiful building with an audience clearly supportive of their local opera. What may come as a disturbing surprise to anyone used to opera otherwise, is that the audience only applauds at the end of each act and remains silent throughout even when there is a bravado performance of a great aria. We found the silence somewhat distancing and felt that it was perhaps a strain on the singers who had to continue and not pause after a taxing effort, even where it is clear the music is composed to account for the expected applause. There were curtain calls after each act. The curtain was at 18.00 and the opera finished at 21.15 allowing ample time for dinner after the opera. They also have a ballet company but the ballet was sold out for the Saturday evening when we were there. The bar is comfortable and has a good selection of wines including Hungarian champagne. They also have open sandwiches and other snacks. Certainly a worthwhile, interesting and pleasurable way to spend an evening in Budapest.

Not worth your pennies. Tours of the opera house are at 3 and 4pm and are held in several different languages. Our group (the English group) was by far the largest. But instead of splitting our large group into two smaller groups (as is done in Vienna), we travelled around as one large happy family. They do make you wear booties while walking around, which causes a bit of a bottle neck while checking in for the tour. Our tour guide was quite informative and enthusiastic and seemed to be well versed in the venue. We did actually pay for the photo pass, but it seemed that everyone was taking photos regardless. This is not well enforced and I guess we were scammed into buying it. The opera house itself is small, and there were quite a few comparisons to Vienna. I think the tickets were a bit expensive for what it is, especially if you have already seen the Staatoper in Vienna. As we were leaving, we were verbally assailed by some staff member. I am not sure what we did or why we were so bothersome to her. All we were doing at the time was opening the door to leave the opera house. She said some angry sounding words in Hungarian and shot us the meanest face she could conjure. All in all, I would not recommend the tour, as the building is underwhelming, it is expensive for what it is, and you might run into the mean lady who says angry things in Hungarian at you while you leave.
Just gorgeous!. Such a beautiful interrior and exterrior design! Luxurious auditorium which expresses the hungarian history through the centuries. Should be definetely visited.

amazing building ......however..... be careful when booking seats in the 2nd row of all boxes as you will not see anything on stage unless you stand.Unfortunately like other theatres where the 2nd row of seats is raised these aren't.There is no warning of restricted view when booking unlike theatres in UK and Washington DC.
A lovely ballet experience ruined.

Well worth a visit. It was great to walk around such a lovely opera house. We only just made the last tour of the day, which is never a good idea, however despite the crowd and hot weather our guide was still enthusiastic and informative. Only sorry we did not have enough time in Budapest to spend an evenong at the Opera House.

Worth going inside. The building is disappointing from the outside - looks dirty and unkempt. But once inside it is beautiful.
We went on our last morning when most of the rooms were closed, wished we had gone sooner as there are tours with a short concert at 3pm and 4pm every day.
a very glamour experience!!. very nice the opera house a different experience with the hungurians very well dressed and the ballet we saw amazing!!

Beautiful place, good performance.. The building is beautiful both outside and inside.
The performance was very good and really worth to attend.
It would be better if there's also lyrics translation to English, there's only Hungarian translation.
Must see. Tours at 3 and 4 with groups divided by language. Really enjoyed the tour. Friendly guide and lovely opera house.

Bargain treat. We booked seats in "the gods" side balcony for £1.50 each (cheaper than a glass of wine from the bar.It was a restricred view of the stage (certainly no use for ballet) but clear sound and a great experience.
Beautiful. While we didn't go inside the Opera House, the outside was very beautiful. The paintings were very elegant and pretty. We took lots of pictures!

Golden gem. Magnificent setting, but a more intimate space for Mozart operas (which is what we saw when we visited). Strong musical performances, wonderful small orchestra. Seats not padded so don't think (for instance) the longer Wagner operas would be a good choice to see here.

Short tour. Beautiful building and knowledgeable guide made this a good, if short, experience; be prepared to queue for tickets and be in a large group. The area is worth exploring with lots of lovely places to eat, relax and people watch.
Onyegin!. Wonderful ballet, came home and had to read the story of this. Went to the upstairs at the Opera House, just drank in the whole atmosphere of the place! Ballet was wonderful

Saw Don Pasquale - great place. Venue is spectacular, performance incredible. Wish I new Italian or at least some Hungarian. We sat in one of the stalls or box seats. Little cramped but view was good. I don't think there were any bad seats. Have to see this place to believe its true beauty. Will be back to catch another performance!

Beautiful. We saw a ballet here. It was fantastic. However, our seats which were the second row of a box, had limited visibility and we had to stand for the entire performance. The tickets aren't expensive, but there weren't many seats left when we purchased our tickets. If you know you are going to be in Budapest, buy your tickets in advance and pay for some good seats.

Wonderful building. We went to see " The Marrige of Figaro " , and the performance was marvellous . The building itself is amazing . Our only complaint was that there was a huge queue at the bar , so we could not get a drink at the interval .

Stunning interior, superb acoustics and wonderful opera for a snip!. Externally, the State Opera House is a very grand and imposing building, from the front balcony of which Madonna performed in Evita. However, step inside to be greeted by a splendidly ornate vestibule and staircases boasting the finest materials that Hungary had to offer at the turn of the 19th century. Entering the auditorium reveals a further step-up in splendour - a beautifully 'La Scala Milan' style setting that must have used most of Hungary's supply of gilding (a little OTT for my plainer taste, but a must for lovers of substantial glitz and glamour). The admin staff from ticket office through to ushers couldn't have been more helpful.We were privileged to watch a performance of Donizetti's 'Don Pasquale', an opera with which we were unfamiliar upto that point. It doesn't have the pomp and grandeur of say Aida, Nabucco or Carmen but boy what a gem, containing some beautiful arias, duets and harmonous chorus section with a nice helping of humour. The cast were very impressive with nice performances particularly the acting of the lead and the voice of the soprano. As occasionally happens the male romantic lead was not the tallest person on stage and had a sweet voice of modest power; however, the very powerful soprano was able to show restraint during their especially beautiful love duet.Overall, amongst my operatic attendances (probably a dozen or so) this was probably the most enjoyable so far, providing a lovely performance in a great setting all for the ridiculous price of about £11ph in stalls seats! This was the final dress rehearsal which meant that prices ordinarily starting as low as £2 were reduced even further.
A lovely experience. Wish the libretto was available in English but the Opera wasbeautiful and the Opera House is a wonderful place to visit and feel a sense of history in...

Contents of purse stolen while touring the opera house. The Opera house is beautiful but be careful. My wife had her purse rifled while we were touring the building. She had it on her shoulder and it was secure. While the performer was singing an aria someone got into it and took all the contents. Wallet with all her money ( Euros, Forints, and Dollars ), Drivers license, our Passports, all credit cards and our debit card. I know the mistake that she made of carrying these items on her person but she did and it will not happen again. It was a nightmare reporting to the Credit Card companies, banks, American Embassy, even making a police report. The Opera House did not want to be involved so we had to walk to the police station to make a report, An interpreter was needed,so we waited over an hour after the two mile walk to the station. It cost us $270, which we had to borrow, to get temporary passports. It also cost us $129 for each local telephone call as Budapest does not have 1-800 or collect calls. If you are visiting, enjoy all the attractions and the people but be careful because you stand out. DO NOT CARRY PASSPORTS or too many credit cards. Keep cash in front pocket.Use the safe in the hotel.
Dont miss the opera in Budapest. This Opera House is a beautiful piece of architecture which you can enjoy by attending of their excellent opera performances at very reasonable cost
Worth a visit. Book a tour here, it is thoroughly worth it. The tour is carried out in a number of languages and the tour guides are very good. Book early though just in case it is fully booked.

Something for all the family. A fun tour, the guide was very pretty and the spiel quite irreverent, so the husband and kids were entranced. We took the mini-concert at the end option which was performed by a Bel Canto singer with a lovely voice, so I was thrilled.

Historical and Beautiful. This place is extremely beautiful. I haven't been to any other Opera but i'm happy to have gone to this one. You feel like royalty when you step into the building. For English tours, go around 3 and 4pm. Give yourself enough time to buy the tickets before the show. Also, be aware that you need to purchase extra tickets for picture taking. I don't know how strict they are because me and my girlfriend didn't get one but our tour guide didn't complain when we took pictures. The story behind the architecture makes you appreciate the building more so make sure you enjoy the tour. ENJOY!!!

Thrilling. As an added treat to being there, TAUCK TOURS, which was the tour I chose for the whole Danube River Boat Cruise, added the joy of having real opera singers entertain us on the grand staircase. That still vibrates in my memory.
Very nice. We enjoyed our visit and liked what we saw. It is a good copy after the Vienna Opera. We found the Vienna Opera a lot more impressive.

Anyegin- Premier in the Opera house. Hello, First of all i know so far my boyfriend posted his reviews but now i would like to writte more cultural experience to you guys. And As the latest experience was memoriable i think it s worth to share. So all in all Anyegin in the Opera house was absolutly Fantastic! I have never been a big fun of the Opera, but last week my friends invited me to watch the Anyegin Balett in the Opera house and i have to say i was impressed.3 hours with 2 breaks but the time was flying. The Opera on it s own is beautiful, so if notthing else thats worth for a look. After you see Balett with live music playing in front of the stage is just simply unbelivable. It doesnt matter if you being a turist or local i definetly recommend this. Only if you see this building is enough, but if you want to spend a nice night with your partner, trust me, Dont miss Anyegin. Love story with amasing music.

Even the best seats are modestly priced. We went to see a fabulous production of the ballet "Onegin". We could only get the 600HUF (less than £2) seats (all others sold out), from which we could only see about one third of the stage. That was a great deal even if you only went to see inside the Opera House, but we actually were able to stand further back, and had a great view. The best seats in the house were less than £50, which is a great deal by our standards. Use their website to book tickets. It was very easy, and we printed off bar coded tickets, which worked very well.

What an experience!. We saw the balett 'Onegin' and paid about 3 euros for the tickets! The performance was great and i would recomend paying a little bit more for balcony seats. The operahouse is impressive!!
Wonderful. We took the hour tour, and it was so worth it. Definitely also worth paying extra for taking photos during the tour. Beautiful on the inside and out.

ho-hum. The tour was expensive and nothing to write home about. However, the 5-minute mini-concert at the end (for a minimal extra cost) was simply spectacular. Our opera singer had to spring all over the Opera House to get the CD that played the music, but after two big gulping breaths, she sang a Puccini area beautifully and plucked a member of the audience out to dance with her. Beautiful in her blue satin dress and diamonds, she had a voice and style to match. Well worth it!
Wonderful. We only had the Tour and a very short experience of the Opera in the afternoon but would recommend it to everyone

A Must See. The State Opera House is a great building. A smaller version of its Habsburg cousin in Vienna, it is probably a better place to see a performance. Take one of the daily tours to get the full picture on the history and workings of the place. Be sure to pay the few extra Euros for the mini concert.

Opera and champagne on the terrace. We enjoyed Mozart's Marriage of Figaro (which he wrote in his apartment in Vienna, Mozart Haus) and splurged to drink champage on the terrace lounge during intermission. What a beautiful work of architecture and a most traditional way to enjoy one of Budapest's historical treasures.

Great evening out. My wife and I enjoyed a wonderful ballet at the opera house. We booked tickets on the day at 11am when the ticketing booth opens. It isnt the most pleasant experience as there is relatively little direction in terms of where exactly to book. However, we got some very reasonably priced tickets(just under $5/each) relatively quickly. We ran into some trouble of entirely our own making, but the management was incredibly helpful in sorting out the problem going well above and beyond what would be expected. The opera house itself is stunning and well worth the visit. I'd recommend buying tickets to see a performance rather then the tour as it is substantially cheaper and you get to enjoy a great evening out. Just make sure to check which ticketing booth is open on the day as there are booths on both the left and right side when you enter.
Beautiful!. Take the tour with the mini concert of you can't get tickets to a performance. Great hstory given by tour guides. The building is a work of art. Don't miss it.
Well worth a visit. Tours in English - in October - took place at 3pm and 4pm. The inside is beautiful and the 45 min tour gave us all the background hstory - and even included a mini concert!
Beautyful. Plan ahead and to see a performance. Wonderful art and decor. They ofer twice a day also a guided tour which is very informative. Note: you must pay extra take pictures inside.
a beautiful building. A nice building - the guided tour was interesting and not too long and not too short. Recommend the small opera performance too.
great to see. We booked tickets for the barber of seville and although we did not understand the language we thoroughly enjoyed the opera. The splendour of the opera house is well worth experiencing.

Gorgeous glamour from the old days. This opera house is one of the most beautiful I have seen. We saw the Barber of Seville, by Rossini. The seats are not very comfortable, but buying tickets on-line before our trips was simple to do, and operas are not as expensive as in the US. It was a fun production, with good acoustics and very minimalist set design.

Interesting tour. I've toured opera houses all over the world and enjoyed this one as well. Tours are offered in English at 3 pm and 4 pm and are 45 minutes long. It's rather small compared to other state opera houses, but it really highlights the contribution of Hungarian artists (among others). You have to pay extra if you want to take photos, and if you want to sit in on a "mini concert" after the tour.
Beautiful. Plan ahead and see a performance. Wonderful art and decor. The guided tour in very informative. Note: you must pay a feemto take pictures inside.
Took the tour. What a wonderful tour of this beautiful building. I took in a show and took the tour and it was the highlight of my stay. Loved everything about this place.

Breathtaking experience. A stunning building that in itself would be enough. A little on the furnace side of things in the middle of summer though. The performance, Lucia di Lammermoor was a great experience as well, the tenor being on the smaller side of average while the soprano playing the lead was absolutely fantastic. Even the intermission, sipping wine on the balcony, watching a glittering Budapest spread out below was magnificent. All in all a magical evening.

Splendour of the Opera!. What a magnificent opera house! Barber of Sevilla was an interesting and well though-out performance. The orchestra deserves recognition. Enjoyable. If there would be something to ask for even more it would be the seats (and the lack of english subtitles). But even they do not bother too much.
Unbelievably beautiful. Totally worth the visit. The most gorgeous opera house I've ever seen....nicer than Vienna or Paris. A must see.

Try to see an Opera or Ballet. Beautiful building and fantastic to watch The Karamazovs Ballet. A very special evening. Having drinks on the balcony and watching the city from above. Highly recommended!

First Opera Experience. Attended "The Barber of Seville" performance in the wonderful opera house in Budapest. Beautiful building from the outside but when you enter the auditorium, it just takes your breath away. Golden decorated boxes and not a bad seat in the house. Terrific experience. Dress code not strict, but take the opportunity to dress up.
Beautiful facility. Very nice tour. The building is beautiful inside and out. Ours included a singer signing a couple of arias.

Beautiful venue great acoustics. Last minute we purchased tickets to a piano concert. The seats were in a good location and the building was beautiful. Definitely a must to see a concert if you are a classical music fan.
Gleaming with gold!. Beautifull interior - make sure you check the time for guided tour before you headed. Reasonable fee, tour is available with many languages.
Not just for opera Lovers. Just what you'd expect of a top Opera venue. Lots of glitz & glamour & history. Just did a tour & I would love to attend an Opera there

Tour of Opera House. Unfortunately we weren't able to go to the opera there. But did take the tour of the opera house. It was very very interesting and beautiful. It is true when they say the opera house in Budapest is much nicer than in Vienna. Vienna Opera house is bigger but not as beautiful. We also paid a little extra to hear a opera singer at the end of the tour. It was well worth it and fun.

Piano concert surprise!. We didn't know we would be in town for LIszt's birthday celebration. Upon visiting the beautiful opera house, we found out that there was a piano recital that night so we bought tickets. The concert was just wonderful. The opera house is quite lovely.

The tour is a good way to see the beautiful opera house. English tours are at 3PM and 4PM daily. The tour guide was very sweet but difficult to understand. It is beautiful inside, and in our opinion, we thought it was more beautiful than the Vienna Opera House. The tour is 1 hour long and you get to sit in the theater and up in the box seats. The tour was less informative than we had hoped because of the guide's English. The "mini opera" at the end is about 2 Euros and we thought it was going to be in the main opera room. However, it was in the bar area. The singer had an amazing voice, and he sung two songs. The mini opera was worth the money but don't expect anything elaborate. Highly recommend you see this beautiful opera house.

Beautiful building!!. I went solo to see a contemporary ballet...the ballet was ok, but the building was spectacular!! I'd go early and get a drink before the performance so you can have a wonder round!!
Fantastic building. Book one of the daily tours to enjoy this wonderful building you can also enjoy a mini performance after the tour.

Great Tour. We showed up just in time to join the 3pm tour (signs said there was one at 3 and one at 4). This was worth it as we were able to walk through the entire building and see some areas that are not always open to the everyday visitor. Also we got to sit in one of the box seats while the history of the building was explained to us. We didn't pay for the mini-show and from the looks of it, we were pretty happy to have skipped that. We did pay the extra 500HUF to be able to take pictures but it seems that that wasn't a big concern for the guides as everyone was taking pictures. I'm not sure if that is how it is all the time but it made me question paying for it (even if it's only like $2.50). This building is a must stop at while visiting Budapest. The statues and everything that have gone into building it is just amazing.

Disappointment. Choose your seat with care.If you go in any of the side boxes you will not see anything unless you are prepared to either stand up or almost hang over the side. A very expensive exercise!!

Take the time to take a tour. The opera house tour is very worth while and takes around 45 minutes. Very informative and interesting. The mini concert though is pleasant but it is one man singing two songs only. Lines can be long for tickets so go a little early. Finish your visit with a coffee or drink at the famous Muvesc coffee house built in 1898.

Music in the Air. Unfortunately, we were pressed for time so could not take the tour but did appreciate the exterior and also the lobby of this beautiful building. It is gratifying to me as a professional musician to see such esteem and respect given to the arts.
This is Europe!. This stately architecture is one of the great reasons for an American to visit the old cities of Europe. The Opera House is worth many visits!

fantastic. we really enjoyed the opera
first time either of us had been ,thought i wouldnt like it only wnt because the litle ladty wanted to go, but to my suprise i rally got into it and am plnning to vist the opera again.

Prestige and Glamour. A beautiful building on the scale of the Vienna Opera house in both size and elegance. Tour takes you through the main public areas including the boxes but does not go back-stage at all. Spend a few extra euors and stay for the "mini-show" in the intermission area.

Great opera, beautiful house.... My wife and I attended Carmen last week. Had seen Aida in Bratislava and Boris at the Vienna State but I think we liked Carmen the most. The quality of singers and the beautiful interior of this opera house made it a very special occassion. Prices were very reasonable, as we paid $50/seat to sit 7 rows from the front. You might want to save a bit of money and sit in a booth along the side which I believe is slightly cheaper. The opera house was pretty much sold out so I'd recommend buying your tickets online. No additional fee if you purchase your tickets online and simply print them (which is different then the Prague State Opera, where tickets are sent to your hotel). I believe you can send $10 or less and still be able to appreciate the beauty of this grand building. Have a nice evening out at the opera.

Opulent for a reason. Our Tauck River Cruise received a tour of the Opera House which included a short private concert. What was most interesting was the history of this great ediface including the fact that the primary sponsor for the Opera House only visited it once and therefore his private viewing box went unused during his lifetime. His wife, the Empress, visited the Opera often but since she wasn't accompanied by her husband, she wasn't able to use his special box.

Regal. Didn't have time for a mini-Opera and the tickets were sold out for the evening show. So - make sure if there is one Opera that you'll ever see, its is in Budapest. Sheer Opulence mixed with powerful music.

WOW!!. The Opera House is truly beautiful, very rococco & gilded and with huge chandeliers. And the two productions we saw were also very good, especially the ballet "The Brothers Karamazov" - it actually brought me to tears.
jaw dropping. Beautiful opera house. amazing architecture. just a stunningly beautiful place. They don't make them like this anymore

Amazing!. This place is not only worth visiting to see what's inside, but one should definitely consider booking a ticket to see a show. The opera house itself is beautifully decorated, with "old-style" red carpets, gold etc. The prices are quite good compared to other European opera houses of this standard!

A great experience. My husband loves opera but I am not so keen so he booked Ballet - The Karamasovs with music by Rachmaninov. We put on the smartest clothes we had with us - not very smart and it was fine. Some people where dolled up to the nines but most where pretty casual - virtually no ties to be seen. The place is amazing. You are asked to leave your coat in the cloakroom. We were in the front row of the highest part near the centre which was a brilliant place to be and most inexpensive. No photos during the performance allowed. We enjoyed it all although we had no idea what the plot was about

Art. The building and the inside are wonderful (like a little Scala of Milan). But what is worth is to buy ticket online (when you are planning your trip) and enjoy high quality opera, ballet or classic music at an affordable price (compared to Opera Houses of others European Capitals).

Don't waste your money. We were very disappointed in our visit to the State Opera House. When buying our tickets we were not told you had to pay extra to take pictures and extra again to hear a 5 minute concert.
The tour guide could not have cared less about this.
The opera house itself is nothing special.
Visit to the Opera House. The beautiful archtecture, the atmosphere, the standard of performance. Don't expect a wide choice of interval snacks, if any.
Must see. Take the tour inside. the small concert is somewhat disappointing since it is in one of the corridors and not in the opera stage.

Architectural gem, with possibility.. If you are lucky with the cast, you can have a memorable experience. Beautiful gilt and red velvet interior reflecting a bygone age, but the comfort of even the best seats leaves something to be desired.

Wow, Wow, Wow!!! And more Wow!. I saw the Hyundai László Opera but before that had even started I was in awe of the building itself. It is opulence personified! The frescos, the gold and the marble (especially the stairs) make the inside a feast for your eyes!! Don't be put of by this though, it may be fit for a princess but it is not in the least bit stuffy. The audience on the whole wore smart/casual attire and some people were wearing jeans. I purchased the most expensive seats and it still was only around £40 each. Once inside I realised I'd almost pay £40 just to see the building! I would definitely recommend seeing an Opera here though rather than just going on a tour of the building it was fantastic! Despite the age of the building the stage area was fully modernised and equipped with moving platforms etc. The costumes, the music, the acting and even a bit of ballet was all fantastic! So go on immerse yourself in Hungarian culture and book tickets!! (I purchased mine online before going to Budapest.)

Carmen at the Hungarian State Opera House. We went to see Carmen last Friday - it was an amazing performance and a great way to see the Opera House. We arrived early and so could look around and take photos before the performance. The seats are amazing value for such high quality music. Do dress up - you won't feel out of place in smart clothes! A definite must for all music lovers.

An incredible venue, great performance. I was blown away by the beauty of this magnificent building. This is a true temple of art -- inside and out. Your fellow opera-goers will be well-dressed and well-behaved, so pack a nice suit or frock, switch off your phone, and be transported deep into the story. I saw Hunyadi László and despite not knowing any Hungarian, with the help of the surtitles, I followed everything. A great show with terrific singing. If you can get a ticket for a show here, any show, I would say it is highly worth it.

Stunning. My husband and I visited the Opera House to see Carmen. The building itself is so beautiful. Golden statues, cherubs painted on the ceiling. A large chandelier in the middle. The queens box is really neat. We were seated in a box in the front row-thank goodness! I don't know what I would have done if we were behind the woman behind me. I don't think I could have seen! The opera itself was wonderful, and when it ended we tried to get downstairs to take a picture. We barely had time before they turned out the lights and ushered us out. They were nice about it, but it would be nice to have some time to do that. They offer tours, but if you're seeing something it probably covers most of it. Priced very well too!

Gorgeous Architecture. unfortunately, we were unable to book for a concert, as it was completely sold out, but the building itself gives the Royal Opera House in London a run for its money!Just SIMPLY stunning

Laszlo Hunyadi . First opera we have seen, we did not think we would stay for it all but we did! English translation made it for us, was like subtitles above stage and enabled us to follow the story. 2 intervals also broke up the evening. We had isle seats in the top circle at the front which is a must so you can see but be aware the centre batch of seats have limited leg room. Overall we were really pleased we made the effort. One more point we were on a weekend break so did not take over smart clothes this was ok others were in jeans or casuals but the majority were in smart.
Interior is incredible. A working opera house and a work of art all in one. The interior is beautiful with gold leaf, paintings and dark wood everywhere.

A grand old opera. The informative tour gave a full view of the opulent opera house. Gold and glitz, very elegant. We could not, unfortunately, get tickets for a performance (and they were very pricey), but the tour was well worth it.

Exceptional. The building is absolutely georgeous! Its worth to go just because of that. We saw ballet one night and the Chinese opera another. I just loved the ballet. Hungarian artists, breathtaking!

What A Venue!. We took the tour and saw an absolutely beautiful opera house. We also enjoyed the mini concert at the end of the tour. In addition to the elegance of the facility, what interested me was the fact that tickets are comparatively inexpensive as compared with, say, Vienna.
beautiful. Well worth a visit to this lovely historic building. We love arthitecture and art and love visiting these historic buildings in the old cities.

beautiful building. We only managed to see the foyer and the exterior of the building and it looked wonderful, tours inside are at 3 and 4 pm and we did not manage to fit it into our schedule . A real shame as it looked wonderful. Maybe next time as there is so much to see in Budapest
Opera House Tour. Very poor value. English speaking group far too big. Totally disorganised. Our tour lasted all of 30 minutes max. Cost 3900 Ft approx. £12

Gorgeous!. Incredible architecture! Both the exterior and interior are gorgeous. Worth a long look. The area nearby is interesting, including the pedestrian area behind the Opera House which has great restaurants and shops.

Great history. Great history, great architectural details but the tour was quick and not very interesting. Most of the information that I know about the building I have picked up from my own reading with the exception of the gossip that the guide provided about the former queen of Hungary and her lover, the Prime Minister meeting at the Opera for their trysts (rolls eyes).
A must visit. Daily guided tours at 3 and 4 o'clock well worth the entrance fee, Absoultly stunning decor, and well informed guides

Old fashioned yet great fun to be there.. The architecture you either love or hate; we thought the coffee bar ceiling was amazing. The statues outside and other entrance places just seemed OTT as from a by gone era, but there is a great sense of the here and now from all those attending.

Very good tour!. We went on the tour of the Opera House in Sept 2012. Very informative and interesting tour with a mini concert at the end. The Oprea House is beautiful inside and our tour guide was great. You have to pay a little extra to take pictures and/or for the mini concert at the end. Although the mini concert was in the bar area of the Opera House it was still very good(2 songs from The Phantom of the Opera). Make sure to tell them when you a buying your ticket that you want to see the concert as several people in our tour group were not informed and missed out.

Saw both the Opera and Parliment. We didn't see the Vienna Opera House on the same tour because we took this tour. If you're in Budapest and have any interest in historical buildings, add this and the parliment to your list. We went through Vienna's sights and we were glad we spent the time to see both.
The most beautiful Opera House in the world. We have been to many beautiful opera houses, this one is the epitomy. The accoustics are also fabulous.
Carmen. Took my daughter to her first Opera. Opera house is beautiful inside and out. Excellent performance!
Worth a look inside. We took the tour. Our guide was not the best. She seemed flustered and her English was slightly hard to understand. Beautiful building however and nice to see.

Much more like the Tower of Babel than an actual, enjoyable, informative tour.. We decided to take the 3 P.M. tour of this large and magnificent Opera House on a rainy afternoon, and it was an unmitigated disaster.The Opera advertized that they gave such tours in four or five languages, and what we experienced were an enormous number of people—each linguistic group’s tour was very oversubscribed, way too large a crowd to be manageable and to work, perhaps 50 or 60 or more people in each of four or five groups, all crowded together for their simultaneous tours, and colliding with each other as each large group moved from site to site on crowded stairways, in corridors, and rooms, and all the while each tour guide was trying to make him or herself heard over the competing tour guides, and the sheer noise created by so many people moving at the same time through the same small portions of the Opera house’s echoing marble interior.Bottom line, discussing this disaster with many of the members of our Eastern European tour, who were also in our 3 P.M. English language Opera House tour group this afternoon, no one could really hear very much of anything the tour guide said; I do not blame the tour guides--for I expect that they would not have been able to be clearly heard, even if they had used bullhorns in these conditions, the blame falls, instead, on whoever organized things in this manner.The final straw was when our tour guide took our group up to the balcony seats—we never actually got to get to the ground floor to observe the stage—where a lucky few of us got to briefly sit and try to peer around to try to take in the interior of the hall and to see the stage below—those standing behind them in the box were out of luck--and all while the guides for the other tour groups had also brought their own groups to sit in different sections of the balcony seats, all the guides—in that large space with its great acoustics—giving their spiels at once—it was sheer bedlam, the Tower of Babel, and very disappointing. And there this very short tour--I suspect truncated due to these conditions--ended.The Opera House should be ashamed of the way they organized this supposed “tour.” They need to put a reasonable limit on tour group sizes and to stagger the times of the tours, so that each group will not interfere with the others, and so that each individual tour guide has a reasonable chance to be heard by those they are giving their tours to, without being interfered with by other tours going on nearby.

Stunning - A must Visit. The tour guides are great, informative, friendly and with great language skills. You have to buy a tour ticket, and an optional "photo" ticket if you want to take photo's and a "mini concert ticket" if you want to see an opera singer sing a couple of songs in the bar area. I regret that we visited outside of the Opera season and therefore didn't get to see a performance.

An Amazing Opera House. We went on June the 15th 2012 to watch the ballet "Snow White and the 7 Dwarfs". This place is amazing and the show was great. We bought our tickets online a month before leaving for the trip. We got amazing seats and the price was very good.

A wonderful experience, don't miss it!!. My wife and I saw Madame Butterfly. The opera was ok with Hungarian translation streamed above the stage (a hoot) and the orchestra was fine.But, the building and interior!! Magnificent. I am at a loss to explain how beautiful the environment is with all the guilding and exquisite restoration.Friends took a tour which they enjoyed, but a wonderful evening is to be had by attending a full opera.

Beautiful. We never made it to the interior tour - just too much to do in two weeks!! - but the outside is a marvel in itself. A couple were taking wedding pictures outside while we stood there. How fantastic!
Opera House. Visit worthwhile but pricey at 11.50 euros. We were disappointed to find the Opera is not performed during summer

An interesting Tour. I enjoyed the guided tour and the mini concert afterwards. I learned new things about the history of the Opera House, about the relationship between the structure of the building and social classes. It was very interesting. I enjoyed very much the mini concert afterwards which included two arias.

dissapointing. A rip off. Joined another large English spaeaking group and felt dragged along and jostled for space. Couldn't hear the guide above the sound of the other guides voices. Didn't think we saw everything available-nothing back stage or any of the boxes! and it was expensive for less than 1 hour.
Enjoyed the tour. We enjoyed the tour of the opera house. It included many rooms and it was highly decorated. We enjoyed the stories about the competition between Vienna and Budapest.

Tour was a tower of Babel. the opera house is gorgeous, but the tour was mobbed the day we were there with hundreds of people. The give the tour in 6 languages with various guides shouting over each other to be heard by their group, so it was pretty chaotic.
Opera House. An excellent one hour organised tour, that ended with a 10 minute performance of a couple of songs from La Traviata

Disorganised chaos spoilt the beauty and splendour of this magnificent building. Rarely have we been subjected to such a disappointing experience. We had stamped this as the highlight of our visit to Budapest and it was ruined within 10 minutes of the start by the chaos that ensued. Our group (english speaking) was split into three because it was so large - all language groups were sent into the main theatre at the same time because rehersals were due to start (if this was the case the tour should not have taken place - short changing the paying customer is not a solution !) We did not hear a word that was being said as the ambient noise level was so high. We were shunted out of this area pretty quickly into other little areas which we shared with other groups. It is fair to say we hardly heard a word said by our guide. We cut our losses, registered our disapproval with the management whose explanations were both dismissive and an insult to our intelligence. Regulating the size of groups that can be properly managed at times when rehersals are not scheduled to take place is relatively easy to organise and it is a sad reflection on the management of this magnificent building that this was not done.

Go to a performance, you will see more. The opera house is a gem. A really beautiful place. But if you want to see it then book a performance. The guided tour was a big disappointment. Vast crowds were shown around at the same time, so listening to the guide was near impossible with half a dozen other guides shouting in various languages at the same time. The group size should be limited and visits staggered.You don't get to see anything that you wouldn't see at a performance. No trips back stage or on stage.All in all an uncomfortable and rushed experience.

tosca. amazing venue, exquisite opera, great singers with impressive voices, wonderful audience.i booked tickets online on http://www.jegymester.hu/ and the service was great. I've been inside the Opera house, but never to the show. this time was the premiere of Tosca and it was wonderful. If you by any chance are you in the mood for opera, buy tickets and go, it's worth it!
quick tour but no performance. beautiful interior and excellent guide for the 1 hour tour of the interior. I wished that I had been there during the performance season.

Check out the ceilings!. The architecture and interior design are amazing. Check out the ceilings and the outside statues and driveway. Always handy to have a guidebook to tell you a little about the history of the place.

All that glitters. The opera house is well worth a visit. It is Paris on a smaller scale. Very intimate. The decor is sumptuous. The only down side was that several tours, different languages, were run at the same time and it was difficult to hear what was being said as well a bumping into the other tours . Pay the extra and stay on for the mini concert. A nice little treat

It is a must!. I just love old, historical buildings moreover culturals. This opera house is without a doubt one of the most famous and greatest all over the world. Beautiful frescoes by famous Hungarian artists ( e.g.: Károly Lotz) beautiful interiour and exteriour as well on the magnificent Andrássy Street (UNESCO WHS). The majority of the performances are excellent with world famous operasingers. Between the two performances you can drink a champagne on the terrace and looking down the World Heritage Sites.It can be a Mecca for culturelovers but for an outsider tourist as well. But please wear elegant clothes!!!
Most beautiful opera. Very nice tour inside opera, some interesting background info from young guide. Recommended stop. Photo shooting costs extra, bit strange with smartphones nowadays.
Opera House Visit. The tour guide spoke very good English, which is my language. We saw all the major areas of the building and learned the history. We also saw a short performance. Very nice.
beautiful. The opera house is really old Europe, and so well preserved. It was beautiful and stately, and the mini opera at the end was worth the $2.50!
budapest opera house. simply a must see for opulence and with a very interesting architectural history that your guide will discuss
Interesting tour. English guide had a lively commentary and the optional 2-song operatic performance at the end was fun

Beauty and grandeur add to the experience of magnificent music and performance.. Well worth a visit, even if you don't see an opera. This building is magnificent! It rivals the Paris Opera House for beauty and grandeur. The prices for performances will astound those who live in big cities in America. Pay and visit!!
Beautiful!. Great tour and beautiful decorations. I was very impressed by every detail on the walls, ceilings, and pillars. The workmanship is quite exquisite!

Absolutely beautiful. Take the tour of the Opera house if you have time. It is not very long - about an hour and it worth it. You will be shown around and told stories about the history of the Opera house. It is really beautiful. Unfortunately there were no operas on during the summer while we were there.
Smaller than Vienna Opera House but more beautiful!. Take a timed tour to experience this lovely opera house. Better yet, take in a concert if you are there during the season.

Beautiful Opera House. The Opera house is a must see building in Budapest. Easy access by metro; check the tour ours and by the ticket for a small amount more you can have a mini concert. The tours are offered by guides in different languages. The whole building is beautiful and charming. It's not as big as other opera houses but I think that makes it more charming. The tour was very good and we went not only to the concert hall but other rooms used for receptions too. The mini concert afterwards was a tenor singing two arias from popular operas. And since it's located on Andrassy avenue you can walk around afterwards.
Good architecture. Inside the space wa not big but had beautiful ceiling paintings with gold although w do not see any show but enjoyed the architecture of the building

Beautiful building. Must see in Budapest. I loved this tour. Gorgeous building. Wish it had been in season as would've booked to see an opera. But had the mini opera concert after the tour which was brilliant. This is a must do in Budapest. One of the best things we did whilst there.

Beautiful Opera House, but very short guided tour!. Guided tour takes only less than 30 minutes. We expected more for the price we paid. Opera house is very beautiful, but they do not show you anything in the back stage. We expected to see also how they prepare for a show in back stage. In overall worthy to visit.
Worth visiting it!. Beautiful builiding, I wish the had a better lighting inside where you could appreciate more the work on the walls, ceiling and floor. Anyways definitely worth visiting it.

Architectural Opulence. Tours start at 4:00 pm daily of this gorgeous visually rich opera house. Well worth any wait and a must-see when in Budapest. I would love to have seen an opera there although be forewarned: the seats are wooden and there is no translation available.

Worth the visit. Opulent and stunningly visual, the opera house is a must see. The visitors are split into language groups to ensure that the maximum benefit for the visitor is achieved. Our guide spoke excellent english and coped very well with all the questions asked of her. She was extremely passionate about the opera house

Buy the cheap seats!. Fabulous old building both for visiting and watching a show. You can buy cheap tickets (aound £2 each person!) and sit right up the gods where you still get a good view of the stage. Great if you want to experience the opera but not pay a fortune.

Jaw Dropping Beautiful. There are two tours a day, at 3 and 4pm, and they last about an hour. You line up for tickets (spend the small amount extra on the mini concert at the end) and then join the line with your particular language. From there you are transported back to the height of the Austro Hungarian Empire where a casual glance aroused dangerous passions and the fate of empires was determined over brandy and cigars. There is a story that the outside of the building could not be grander than the Opera House in Vienna and when the Emperor Franz Joseph came to the grand opening he was furious that though the exterior of the building was not as grandiose, the Budapest interior was far grander.Words alone cannot describe the splendor that awaits you. See for yourself.

Well Worth It. The Budapest Opera House is amazing and quite honestly better than the Vienna Opera House in which it was modeled after. Most of the old world feeling is kept within the Budapest Opera House whereas the Vienna Opera House seems to be more modernized. We did not see a performance here since we visited in August when the Opera takes their summer break, so we instead did the organized tour. It was very crowded and a little chaotic at first, so my advice is to buy your tickets early, but it worked out just fine. The staff was even accommodating enough to split our very large English speaking tour group into two groups. The focus of the tour is more on the magnificent rooms and you don't get to see the back of the stage like with the Vienna Opera House tour. But the grandeur of this building is something that can't be missed. Also, if you want to take pictures you have to pay extra for a bracelet to do so, however, many people in our group who did not pay the extra fee took pictures and our guide didn't seem to mind.

Disappointing. My review is for the tour. Unfortunately there were no performances on in August so I cannot comment on them but I amSure it would be a totally different experience to the tour!Firstly, I got my ticket. Which is advertised as including a mini concert. Only to later find out for that you need to pay extra, also you need to pay extra to be allowed to take photos! I was not offered these options when buying my ticket. Secondly it is over crowded so were shuffling along with pushing and shoving, can barely hear the speaker who is also talking too fast to rush us along. All in all a disappointing experience although unquestionably this is a beautiful opera house, in keeping with the exquisite architecture of Budapest.

Don't Bother. They take you thru as a large group with most of the time spent looking in the anciliary rooms. When you finally do get into the opera house itself, its your group and the others sitting in different parts with multipe speakers talking at the same time. It's noisy, no appreciation to be had of the acoustics of the place. There is a mini-concert offered in addition at extra cost which was a tenor singing in the bar area, accompanied on a ghetto-blaster boom box. The acoustics are terrible, its stand-up, a real disapointemnt. And the whole thing works out to about $15/person, not worth half that. A waste.
Great Splendor. Beautiful interior not to be missed. Nice guided tours on offer, but would be better to come for a real opera and enjoy the acoustics

A great way to spend an hour. The opera house is beautiful and the guided tour is excelllent. You can also be treated to a ten minute rendition by an opera singer. You can also stand where Madonna delivered one of her speeches in the film Evita!
Beautiful. Beautiful and exquisite site. Be sure to get there at least a half hour before the tour with enough cash to pay for the tour- they don't take charge cards and it is a popular spot.

Opera House - well worth doing the guided tour. Beautiful ornate building near the bottom of Andrassy Street. Good value guided tour which lasted about an hour - very interesting and informative and worth the money

See the place and mini concert. I was pleasantly surprised....a quick tour that seemed chaotic in getting started; however, off the English-speaking people went to see various parts of the opera house...and I paid the extra Euros to have a 5 minute concert with an Opera singer....WOW! she was amazing!

Beautiful but a tad expensive!. The building is extremely impressive and the tour is interesting; telling stories of the history of the building and the famous people who attended. Unfortunately there are only two tours a day and each of the tours are split up into their different languages. This means that at times there are possibly up to three groups in a room, each of which the history is being told in a different language. With the acoustics of the building, it makes it quite difficult to pay attention. My favourite part of the tour (which was an additional expense) was the mini concert which was sung by a lady with a very impressive voice. You can get an impression of what concerts would be like at this venue! I thought in total the price paid was a little steep considering: 1. Size of the group. 2. Additional cost of the mini concert 3. Additional cost to pay to take photos on your OWN camera.

Interesting Architecture. Since our hotel was right around the corner, we took in the tour and the English section was the most crowded. I agree that the photo ticket is a bit excessive so we had one person in our party take the pictures and we will share. We had gotten a discount since we had the Budapest card. The architecture was beautiful and tasteful. Lots of history here.
Magnificent. loved our personal opera star singing session. very interesting commentary and the guide was superb.

Small but Beautiful. We loved the Opera House in Budapest especially the ceiling paintings and wall decorations. Though smaller than it's famous counterpart in Vienna we thought it was far more beautiful. It is not to be missed.
Beautiful. Only found this on last day of holiday and liked what I saw. If ever went again would go to a performance.

Absolutely beautiful - only 2 tours a day, can get crowded. There are only 2 ours offered daily, 3pm and 4pm. So as you would imagine, they are pretty crowded. Also, it can be difficult to plan at being there at exactly those times.Tip: if you would like to take pictures...you need to buy a photo ticket. There were people taking pictures without the "bracelet"...so I don't know if it is necessary if you are good at not getting caught. I do feel that it is a bit ridiculous to have to pay for a photo ticket after you paid for the tour.
Worth a visit!. We visited the Opera House as part of our tour. I wondered what was so special about an opera house and then we stepped inside. It is beautiful and has a fascinating history.

A bit expensive!. Your average tour. Group somewhat on the large side (a reason for this peak season perhaps). Lasts about 30-45 mins.If I recall correctly it costs 2800 HUF (approx â¬9/10)...then they ask if you want to see the mini show (a super cheesy guy sings 2/3 songs), it's an additional 500HUF and then if you want to take photos while inside it's an additional 500HUF on top of that (the photograph taking wasn't policed on my visit). You receive wrist bands for the extras as proof of purchase.Our tour guide was just about average. She relayed many facts in an extremely boring manner and seemed quite jaded by tourists. It's a very beautiful building. Worth seeing, but I'm not sure worth 3800HUF if you go with all the added extras (approx the same price as a day in the baths).

Opera House Just Beautiful. This represents what old time architecture is all about. Heating underfloor system, background scenery rotations, beautiful designs all around and now opera goers have a place in outer room for smoking. Progress.

Guided Tour. Although slightly rushed, this tour gives a very good appreciation of the splendid interiors.
The optional mini operatic performance is well worth taking.

Definitely worth visiting.. The Hungarinan State Opera House is one of the most impressive buildings on the Pest side of the Danube. The tours are reasonable value and reveal some  elegant artworks, woodwork and tapestry displayed in the rooms surrounding the seating areas. The audience is bathed in light from a tremendous chandelier that's still maintained by traditional methods. There's also an opportunity to watch a show after the tour.
