A must see!. Even if you have no inclination at all towards classical music and opera you must check out this venue! We have been to opera all over the world but none compares to that in Hungary. The stage settings are amazing - the creative art director and team do the most amazing and imaginative job ever. The singers are incredible, world class and it is simply a joy to be present in the most fabulous building "old Europe" has ever seen! We have been to a few performances here and only one that was done in a rather contemporary design was a bit strange - the singing still was fabulous. It is inexpensive and I highly recommend it as a must see if you visit Hungary.

Stunning buliding, good wine, average ballet performance but can't complain for the £. We saw the Nutcracker in Jan 2012, having seen the Boston Ballet production Dec 2011 it was a little disappointing but as the tickets were a 1/3 of the price and the building interior at least 3 times as grand I feel it is a good compromise. Also the bar atmosphere was good with very reasonable wine for such a venue. Try and get tickets to anything it is not much more expensive than the price of admission to view the opera house.
Small but very nice!. We went here for a Traditional Dance show from Hungary. It was so beautiful inside and very well kept!

very interesting. Good tour with lots of interesting facts and anecdotes and history.
A classic opera house 'old world'. Enjoyed this much more than Vienna's opera house.

A setting that rivals the great houses in Paris and Vienna. Absolutely gorgeous building with all the dripping gold covered detailing found in the bigger Opera houses in Paris and Vienna. Relatively inexpensive tickets, and an appreciative audience
Worth to see.. Opera at low prices compared to other major cities. Do not remember seeing captions to understand singer`s lyrics.
Gold and more gold. Beautifully baroque interior but hard seats for a good production of Strauss, partly in Hungarian.

Old-fashioned grandeur. Exceptionally beautiful classic grand opera house bang in the centre of Budapest, with a regular repertoire of predominantly opera and some ballet, operettas and children's classics. For the European traveller seats in all parts of the house are affordable, and the quality of the programme exceptional. During the interval take advantage of the beautiful gilt bar serving Hungarian champagne and admire the views.
significant - go to a performance as not expense. didn't make a perfomance as it was New Year's eve & we were pushed for time, it would be worth it

Garnier's smaller sister.... Built in the Paris opera Garnier style, the house was actually constructed to compete with Vienna opera during the days of the Austrian-Hungarian double monarchy. The story is that emperor Franz Josef only visited one performance because the Hungarian builders had succeeded in making the house more beautiful than the Vienna State opera... so he never came back.Perhaps true - in any case this house is well worth seeing. Much smaller than both Vienna and Paris opera houses it has exquisite details and paintings - and good acoustics. And it's in great condition! It's cheap to see a performance (subsidized by the government), so if your'e into opera, do go. Or, if you just want to see the house, there are excellent guided tours most every day in several languages. Check online.
A summer opera season would be good. sadly, it was closed for the summer season. But an impressive building. Wonderful restaurant just beside it.

Spectacular Building and a Wonderful Evening at the Opera. I knew that the opera house was a must see when visiting Budapest. Why not try to get tickets for an opera. I was able to find a site on line and ordered 2 tickets for Puccini's "Manon Lescaut". The price of tickets were exceptionally inexpensive. What a wonderful evening. The building was a gem and the opera was delightful.

This place should not be missed. Seriously....if yo are ever in Budapest, you need to go to the opera house. Try and see a show, but if not, the building itself is amazing. It screams architecture. A must see!!
The Opera is gem.. Go to the Opera. The company and the building are gems.
very grand - performances excellent.. Amazing place to visit - just do it properly and go to watch a show and not do a guided tour!

Very beautiful building, but quality of all else leaves a lot to be desired.... A beautiful interior, a majestic exterior, an enviable location in the centre of Budapest. But... Only two working toilets for women -- thus leading to simply intolerable waits; only one girl serving behind the bar during the performance interval -- thus causing interminable queues; uncouth and uneducated behaviour from fellow patrons (not Hungarians, one must concede); simply miserable scenery (that looked as if it was cut from cardboard and painted by a class of seven-year-olds); poor stage direction; ZERO visibility of the stage from the topmost balcony in the side seats. Musically the opera I saw was sound.
unbelievable. I am so glad we took the the tour of the opera house. It is magnifient at every turn. You have to pay a small amount in order to take photos and it is well worth it to do so.
Must See. Very impressive building and interior. If you like classic music and Opera music in general, you have to visit it.
Beautiful detail in architecture. There wasn't enough time to see a show, but the inside of the opera house was quite beautiful. There is a small gift shop off to the left side.

Marvellous, a real treat!. We visited on two consecutive nights, and enjoyed both the symphonic concert and the opera enormously. Fantastic value for money at less than half the price you would pay in Rome or London for suberb standards of musicianship (so you just accept that the seats are rock hard - take a cushion, if necessary, I wish I had for the 4 hour opera!). I will be returning to Budapest for more such fantastic music. We were very lucky to get returned tickets on the spot this trip , but will use the online booking service to be certain of getting in next time.

A not-to-miss sight. The "Operahaz" is a very beautiful building -among many beautiful buildings in Budapest-, but you can best see its inside it if you go to a play (and of course you will enjoy the play as well). You can book tickets via internet for prices that start from 600 h ft (2 euros), which is a very clever idea (most museums & churches are much more expensive to visit). The truth is that if you buy the 2 euro ticket you won't be able to see a lot of the play, the 5 euro ticket is probably a better idea.
Opera House. To enter the Opera House without attending a formal performance there are guide tours but time vary day to day. Would advice checking in advance not to avoid disappointment

Stunning building; Stunning ballet. I think this is possibly the most beautiful building I have ever been in. We watched the Nutcracker Suite ballet which was mesmerising. Well worth a visit, and try and take in a performance!
A round of applause for the Nutcracker at Christmas time!. Stunning performance, magical decor and costumes. A real Christmas treat!
Amazing. What an amazing building. I saw the Nutcracker here and I just loved it.
Very good. The performance was great the building is beautiful.
Tosca. Fab and we were blinded by the diamonds from the ladies in the boxes!
Opulent. As you would imagine, this building is steeped in history and the interior illustrates that clearly. The guided tour was informative and delivered well by a guide who spoke excellent english
A lovely tour. A beautiful building. The guide was excellent although sometimes her speech was not clear enough and she dropped her voice. We enjoyed the tour.

Unbelievable value and experience. Got to Turandot by Puccini...admission ONE EURO 70cent....can you believe it...booked online at the opera house and enjoyed sitting in the gods...well up...but what a place...baroque gilt and balconies...huge cast and top quality singing...do it
Beautiful. But not open all the time and difficult to get tickets

Excellent performance of the Nutcracker Ballet. As advised by the many reviews, my wife and I booked via Internet seats to the 11 am Sunday Dec 4 performance at this very beautiful venue.We are avid ballet goers but this performance was so much higher in quality and the dancers all exhibited very high levels of technical skills.Really memorable and wonderful experience. We had very good seats at only HUF 6500 each. This translates to about EUR20. Surely very good value for such superior performers.

Add to your list of places to visit.. Very easy to get to. Even if you are not into opera or ballet is well worth a visit. Best seat in the house around £30 and unlike London programmes very cheap. If you dont want to go to a performance they do daily guided tours. It is a beautiful building.

First on our "to do" list when in Budapest. We actually chose our dates for our next trip to Budapest according to the HSOH program.It is outstanding quality, both for program and interpretations. Do not expect anything too avant-garde, though. It is rather conservative (or perhaps we could call it consensual). I strongly advise booking through the official Opera House website. It is extremely easy to navigate (after a few hesitations) and has an English translation (click on the "ticket" button and from there on, you are redirected to the venue plan). Seats are available a month ahead only and some dates are going very fast, leaving you with a very small choice of limited view side seats: the locals are keen music amators and the prices are incredibly low, even to local standards. Expect to pay around 50US$ at most for a central dress circle seat.At interlude, you can enjoy a glass on the large balcony overlooking Andrasy Avenue. There again, sandwiches and Tokay are of excellent quality. We attended three consecutive nights and regretted not having booked more.There are quite a few nearby restaurants for after concert dinner, which leaves you about half an hour to order before kitchens close. We so loved brasserie La Callas, just across the street, that we went there all three nights. It offers an "italo-hungarian" cooking and a very good selection of wines. It is an animate favorite amongst the locals. As stated before, we are planning our next hungarian trip based on the opera program and noticed that some periods would allow us to attend sixt nights without seeing the same concert twice.The only (slight) down side would be that the locals are such an enthusiastic public that they tend to applaud between scenes - and even after arias, which brutally pulls you back down to Earth and reality in the middle of the music.
Take the tour, but not the miniconcert at the end.. Luxurious concert hall, but no different from others elsewhere

amazing venue. We decided to see an Opera while in Budapest to get the atmosphere of a glamorous night out. The decor is truly stunning and prices very reasonable by English standards. Top price tickets in the front stalls were less than £40 and you can get last minte deals in the upper circles for just a few pounds if you don't mind heights. Dress as formally as you like, lots of people were wearing formal attire and it adds to the whole occasion.
Impressive building, very good show. We saw the nutcracker that evening. The building is impressive. We got very affordable tickets when booked online.

Beautiful music in beautiful surroundings. Attended a performance at the Opera and loved it! While enjoying the beautiful music you get to feast your eyes on the glorious surroundings - and at great prices. You can order the tickets online and print them from home. Be aware that it will be translated to Hungarian only.
Nice tour, good guide. But see a show instead!. It was nice, but it's cheaper to buy a ticket to a show so if you, try that!
Beautiful. Beautiful building. Great performances, both opera and ballet. Worth the trip. If you want to see the building don't pay the money for the tour. Just buy cheap tickets!
Don Giovani. My first time at the opera and it was beautiful. The building is magnificent. It really has to be seen to be believed. I liked the opera too but I have nothing to compare it too.

Tour is short and hard to hear. The concurrently run tours in six languages. I was in a large group of English speakers and when I was at the back of the pack (somebody has to be there!) I couldn't hear over the German and French tour guides.

Wonderful architecture and decor. Our flat in Budapest was a block away from the Opera House, so we passed it often enough to notice some interesting things. Like the fact that people/groups are rehearsing there during the day, so you may hear incredible music if you pass by. We took the afternoon tour, and it was worth the cost and the wait. The Austrians funded the construction of the opera house on the condition that it be smaller than the opera house in Vienna, so they made the inside incredibly ornate. Tiles, tapestries, paintings, different staircases and dining areas for different social classes, etc. You can see playbills and costumes from the 19th and early 20th centuries. Definitely worth the visit!
Worthwhile.. The Opera House is only open at certain times, unless you visit the opera but is greatly subsidized so easily affordable to experience decent opera.

Verdi's Requiem. Outstanding concert before a nearly full house. Magnificent interior. Book on line before going. We had seats 3 rows back from orchestra. Restaurant Calls next door for a meal or drink is also recommended
Beautiful!. We took the English speaking Tour at 3P in the afternoon and it is a beautiful site to see. Easily comparable to the Paris Opera House on the inside. Highly recommend!
Don Qiovanni. It was a quite heavy and long.The chair was not very comfortable
A Midsummer Night's Dream. Ridiculously cheap tickets to see the ballet. An amazing building! The ballet was fantastic and, as a previously non-ballet fan, I am now a convert.

Beautiful Building and Great Opera. We had never been to an opera but it is popular in Hungary so we decided to try an opera. The tickets were reasonably priced and you get to see the inside of the opera house, which is beautiful. It was also nice to see all the locals dressed up and enjoying themselves. I recommend going to a show instead of just doing a tour of the house.
Best opera. Magnificent building, great accoustics, very good performance (Don Giovani)
Beautiful building. we didn't enter, we hadn't enough time and their was an enterance fee which was quite expensive too so...but nice beautiful from the outside and nice entrancehall.
Opera for all. Spectacular building and wonderful performance. A bargain.
opera house. Looks a nice building from the outside although we didn't go in. we went to the nearby Museum to have a look into the Jewish cemetery...
Stunning interior. Only viewed the entrance hall but was very impressed. Not to be missed

Stunning Interiors and Amazing Experience. For about 100 USD, my husband and I scored a pair of great last-minute seats to a ballet performance of Tchaikovsky's Anna Karenina. The venue is absolutely stunning, and we enjoyed soaking in the ambiance from our red-velvet lined box seats. The ballet itself was very well performed, and the sets were charmingly intricate. This is a must-do!

Excellent opportunity to see Opera on a budget. At the last minute my husband and I decided to get tickets for the opera. The only tickets remaining were either around £300 or £3 for both of us. We went for the £3 option and weren't disappointed. The 'standing' seats still gave us a view of the stage and the performance was wonderful. The opera house is a beautiful building surrounded by high end shops if you fancy some pre-opera window shopping. Very easy to get to on the tube. Highly recommended.

Excellent Value, Excellent Production. majestic surroundings. Hungarian State OperaWe had a night a the opera when in Budapest this weekend and a wonderful,time was had. The production was Don Giovani and it was a season premier.Tickets for the opera in Budapest are remarkably good value and row 5 stalls costs around  £45. A word of advice about buying tickets. They sell out very fast and you need to book as soon as the sales open so check the web site in advance of any visit.Stall seats are good and the front row of any boxes. Be careful though of row 2 in boxes as the view is obscured. Be aware that operas are sung in original language and the subtitles will be in Hungarian. As a result you need to know the story in advance but the programme is in English which helps.The quality is superb and fr the price paid it was a bargain. I did however find it disconcerting hat the audience show their appreciation through a slow hand clap.....The seats offer a great view but are fiendishly uncomfortable and over 3.5 hours of Don Giovani it was hard on the posteria.The building is fabulous and is a gold leafed homage to former times. It is worth a visit on its own. Even if you are not an opera fan get cheap tickets for the top tier, enjoy what you can and leave....they are cheaper than a tour!!!!The bar was reasonable value but very busy and crowded. Sipping champagne in such surroundings however was wonderful.Dress is smart on the whole with lots of fur but few dinner suits. A lounge suit will suffice and dressing up is all part of the fun........have a great time.......and do go!!!!

Budapest Nov 2011. Lovely building. Went to watch Rigaletto. Only watched half of opera as not really my thing, but as tickets only cost £2.90 for 2 (cheaper than tour) we didnt mind. Was nice to see inside this lovely building and experience a taste of the opera.

Wonderful experience. We went there on 10/28/11 for Verdi's Requiem. It was a very powerful piece and hearing it in the beautiful opera house made it that much better. We paid only $6 for the seat and was very pleased with our choice. Make sure you choose center section and it is auditorium seating so you can still get a good view of the stage even if you are seated in the back rows. Afterwards, go eat at Ket Szerecsen or Klassz..both are close to the opera house and offer wonderful traditional cuisines.

Amazing opera house. A very unique and old building. Watching operas there makes you feel in the 18th century a part of the elite.I'm not a big opera fan, but seeing the building made me want to go to an opera performance, I enjoyed it so much that I returned 2 days later to see another one. The ticket prices are very affordable. We bought tickets day before the performance and had very good seats (row 2 and row 6 for 12000 huf a ticket).Highly suggested. The costumes are very pretty, the only downside is that the subtitles are in hungarian so make sure you read up on the opera, unless you speak Italian :)

Tour of the Opera House.. We love opera but decided against investing an evening of our short trip in a performance but took the tour instead.Glorious building reminiscent of Prague Opera House but I believe even grander.Pleasant guide pointed out architectural details and told history.Maybe a tad expensive, but otherwise very good.

Lovely day.. Lovely day at the opera. We went on Sunday at 11.00am. It was three hours so this time was perfect to go for cake and coffee after. The building is old but has a real taste of opulence. The opera 'Cinderella' was fantastic, two intervals and a nice wine/drinks bar.
An Icon of Budapest. Seriously impressive building/theatre. Put on the must do list.
Beautiful opera house. Prices are about one third or less of those to London's Covent Garden. Definitely a must on any trip to Budapest. Of course it is seasonal.

Very impressive interiors. We had booked online tickets for the ballet - Anna Karenina - at the State Opera House. Got there early and sipped coffee at Művész Kávéház as we admired the building from outside. Went in without trouble. We were not formally dressed. Both my husband and I had elements of denim in our clothing and both of us were constantly on the lookout for someone else dressed similarly. And we were not disappointed. Sighted quite a few! One annoying fact was that it was mandatory to hand in your coats and that too at a price! Didn't understand why you absolutely had to do that. Anyway, after stepping into the hall did we realise that this place was not famous for nothing. Amazing detailing in the architecture with very little repetition. Must-go.

Great Venue, Good Value. For those of us who only get to see an opera every couple of years, and then at enormous expense, the Hungarian Opera/Budapest is a real treat. Tickets are reasonable (the nosebleed seats are roughly $2.50), the venue is fabulous and intimate, and the performers quite good. Other reviewers have commented that it is necessary to 'dress up' - not so in late 2011. Any sort of 'basic black' will do; only one or two long dresses in evidence and only a few suits for men. We saw Rigoletto, which is of course in Italian, and the translation is in Hungarian! There are no programs with summaries so read the libretto before going. The only drawback is that the seats are very uncomfortable! Bring something soft to sit on.

Private recital. Finishing our 2-week cruise on the river at Budapest, our groups were taken on an interesting tour of the Opera House and given a private recital on the grand marble staircase. Very nice.
A Must See. We were able to see the ballet while in Budapest and the show was amazing. The inside of the opera house is stunning and something I'll never forget.

Beautiful building, but the tour is really not worth the money. If we had known that you could buy a ticket for the opera for less than the cost of the tour we would never have chosen it. The building is very beautiful but you don't need a tour guide to show it to you. It was very over-priced and didn't even last as long as advertised.You can wander around the Paris Opera for nothing and see almost as much. The 'mini-concert' which cost extra was very disappointing. We thought that at least it would be on the main stage, with perhaps a musician or two, but it was in one of the other rooms and was a single performer with a cd player!We would suggest going to the New York Cafe and having a nice coffee instead - equally lovely building and much cheaper
very beautiful place to go. When in Budapest you should have a night at the opera. It looks like the Vienna's.

Splendor in the city center. We saw a ballet here which was good but not excellent. The real attraction is the building itself. Worth the price of admission, which, by the way, was very reasonable. Opera, music and dance, in general, is very affordable in Budapest.
Beautiful building. Looks stunning at night! we went to see Cinderella there. Book your tickets EARLY online to get a decent choice!

Beautiful building, saw the Opera "Tosca". We enjoyed our experience seeng the opera "Tosca". My first opera and very glad I got to see the inside of this magnificent building. Didnt bother to take the tour, but the Opera was definitely worth it. We payed well to sit in the front center, but cheaper seats are available. One traveler we met on our trip was able to score tickets just passing by. I wish the subtitles were in English! but we were able to purchase the program for 500forint and understand the plot. i also enjoyed (but was somewhat confused by) the production of the curtain calls at every act and subsequent intermission. It is always interesting to experience another countries cultural events. I would return to this Opera House!
Culture and Class. Beautiful building and excellent knowledgable guides make this a very worthwhile visit for theatre lovers, with a taste of Opera from one of the company.
just beautiful. we went to see a ballet. The building is perfect. The ticket price was 1.5 euro and the view wasn;t good but the all ''project'' was perfect. the experience was unforgettable!!

Beautiful experience, but tour is overcrowded. Beautiful and very interesting tour full of history. I enjoyed the mini concert afterwards as well! The tour groups get a bit big though, as they provide 1 guide to 50 people which is annoying and hard to hear! There is lots of interest for the tour groups and it doesnt really matter when you book because it doesnt fill up (they just tack you on to the big group).
Poor!. Over sized groups, groups kept bumping into each other. Hard to hear guide with other groups moving around. Tour was advertised as 1 hour, it lasted a half hour!!!

translation in English. It is really a beautiful and huge building with a lot of GOLD. I succeed to buy a ticket and I really engjoyed the performance. 100 people were singing and dancing at the same time. English and German translation could be read over the stage, so I could also understand, what was going on.
Opera House. What a magnificent building. To get tickets for the opera is unbelievable value for money compared to most other European cities.

Wonderful. A beautiful building with an impressive programme of excellent quality. We would go again and again and again. Dislikes? The queue in the interval to buy a drink - maybe the interval could have been longer. Going out onto the balcony overlooking Andrassy ut with a glass of fizz was a treat.
a must visit. the tours go twice a day late afternoon, 3pm and 4pm, awesome so worth the a visit.

Stunning venue and an incredible performance. My wife and I saw Tosca at the Opera House last night. The theater is spectacular. We did not want the evening to end. If you are a lover of the arts you mustn't miss this magnificent venue

Beautiful Ballet & Opera Performances..... The opera house is over the top in decoration and worthy of attending a performance. My husband and I saw the Karamazov Brothers Ballet and Simon Boccanegra-the opera. Both performances were amazing. We sat in a private box for the ballet and near the orchestra for the opera. The tickets are very reasonably priced and exceptional value for the talent. We usually go to the MET in New York. The talent wasn't equal to the MET but it was close and a quarter of the price! We could even afford champagne and sandwiches during intermission! We had two wonderful evenings here. Even if you aren't a fan of opera, visit to appreciate the sheer beauty of this structure!

guided tour. we didn't have an evening spare to actually go to the opera (and to be really honest I'm not sure it would have been my thing) so when we turned up to have a look in the entrance hall and found there were tours at 3pm and 4pm, we booked on one. You get to see the main auditorium, the scenery being changed, the buffet and smoking areas for guests, and the staircases. Then you get to hear an opera singer for a few minutes. It was well worth doing and maybe next time I'd actually go to a performance!

Go to a performance. If you possibly can, get tickets for a performance here. The cheapest tickets actually cost less than the guided tours of the building, and the standard of the productions is very good. The building is rather smaller than some comparable European opera houses, but still very grand and glitzy and well worth seeing.

Opera house tour. We were very disappointed with our tour of the Opera House. The English speaking group was very large. Our guide had a very soft voice and we could not hear her presentation. There were many other groups speaking other languages that were speaking louder and distracted our group. There was not time to ask questions. I felt that I should have spent my money on going to an opera performance rather than this tour. A preformace would have cost less money. I was hoping that we could go back stage or tour other areas of the opera house that you would not normally get to see if one had attended a performance.

Skip the tour and buy cheap tickets. We went when an opera was on and booked online and bought the cheapest tickets which were 500 HUF (which equates to about £1.50). This was much cheaper than the tour and we just printed the tickets off at home and took the tickets with us. We didn't know which tickets to pick and booked two in the second row of a box. This meant that we walked up the full sweeping staircase from the front of the building seeing it in it's full glory. The view from these seats was awful (you would have had to stand up to see the stage though they did have one seat on steps which you could sit on) but luckily for us the seats in front weren't booked and so we got to sit at the front of the box. We aren't opera fans and didn't understand it and left after the first break, but we booked to go so we could see the inside of the opera house for a fraction of the tour price. It was lovely to sit there before the performance and admire the paintings and the sound was fantastic. Well worth the experience for the very small price
Pretty nice but expensive to tour. We did the tour. Its a fantastic building, but its not worth the steep price to do the tour.

Nice experience. The building is a must see on outside and the inside. Bought ticket the day before directly from the ticket window at the opera house for Saturday evening's performance. Ticket is affordable. The performance was great.Tip 1: Please dress appropriately when attending a performance. As a tourist, I did not pack a dress and all that goes with that. I found my [I'm female] outfit appropriate which was: black slacks, dress shoes, and a black beaded top. Tip 2: No intermission during the show. Tip 3: A note for Americans and westerners, the culture is to applaud or clap in unison.Tip 4: Select a seat that is front row of any tier, or center seats of any row.

Good - but very stuffy on a hot day. We visited the Opera House in June as part of a tour group in one of the scheduled afternoon slots for tours. It looks as though they schedule tours on a couple of afternoons each week.The opera house is very interesting and the guide was quite good. No restrictions on photos. The visit took about an hour all up. There were a lot of people in the building on the day we were there so there were some logistical challenges for the guides getting people in and out of different areas. The main opera theatre was quite impressive and some of the smaller rooms were also interesting – some ornate, some with impressive wood carving. Reading between the lines (or the story told by our guide), like a lot of Budapest's public buildings it was built cheap to look flash - but it is certainly in far better condition than most!It was hot outside and the building was very stuffy and a lot of people in our group were ready to quit early. Some needed to sit down and we were very glad of the complementary drink at the end. However, we were glad to have persevered for the mini opera performance by 2 very good singers (a tenor and a soprano) in the foyer stairwell for a couple of numbers.Extremely interesting, but we would have enjoyed it a lot more on a cooler day.

The place is absolutely gorgeous and the acoustics are fabulous. Try to see a performance. Don't cheap out on the seats as the views from the extreme sides of the balconies are obstructed according to some reviewers. If you can afford it go for the more expensive seats which are really not expensive by NY standards. We took the tour first and then purchased tickets for the evening performance. We saw Tosca and were seated dead center about 10 rows back. Perfect. The theater is so small that no seats are very far away.
See an opera in a beautiful setting. The setting is wonderful but you can't appreciate it as much as when you go to hear an opera itself.

Beautiful place - cheap tickets available but chose your seat carefully. We booked to see the ballet Romeo and Juliette.I did this online from home and it was really easy. The site is in English and you print your own tickets.We rejected the £1 tickets and upgraded to £3 tickets. The more expensive tickets were all sold out. We were at the very top of the house, in the front row nearest to the stage. The seats were dreadful. My husband had a theatre light immediatly in front of his seat totally obliterating his view. My seat was the second one in and I could only see most of the stage by leaning out. If you sit at the top the side sections (all rows) all have awful views. The middle section looked fine. If you sit in the top section you do have to enter by a side door and have a lot of steps to climb. You cannot enjoy the lovely main entrance. Again lower down unless you get the front row of the box I would avoid the side sections. It is a beautiful opera house and the experience was very worthwhile. We only stayed until the interval because the seats were so bad but we thought the money was well spent to enjoy the house at its best.

Looked good from the outside but........ We were only in Budapest for a couple of days and had planned to go to the Opera - only to discover that the opera season had finished so unfortunately, no opera for us. We walked there on our last day but were abruptly told by a rather surly chap, that it's only open for tours in the afternoon between 3 and 4 - so all we could do was admire the architecture from the outside and peep through a crack in the window, which revealed lots of gilt and red but nothing identifiable.Sorry, not much a review but just remember, visit in the afternoon or you'll be disappointed.

Very disappointing. I had really looked forward to seeing the opera house, but the tour was very poor. We were rushed around because there was a gay pride parade scheduled for that evening, and they were trying to close down Andrassy Ave apparently. It was definitely not worth the money.

Wonderful!. We had a great time at the Opera in Budapest. Our seats were terrible - we could barely see anything - but we didn't want to spend too much money. It was just amazing to be there and take in the surroundings and listen to the music. I would go again!
Worth the Walk!. This attraction is worth the walk. The outside architecture is incredible. However, there is a fee to enter and tour the inside.

Worth a visit - some very impressive rooms. Very pretty opera house with some nice halls and some impressive rooms. The tour was informative. The mini-concert was okay, not unmissable - just a single singer in a side-room singing along to a cd for a few minutes. You can also buy a pass to take photos, but I doubt they'd stop you from taking pictures without the small bracelet.Overall, I would recommend the tour, it was an enjoyable afternoon activity.

Beautiful building and amazing acoustic. Not to miss if you are visiting Budapest. A very well organized tour will take you inside the opera house and highly recommended. If possible, catch a show. It's very affordable. Tickets only cost £1- £47. The best acoustic in the world after La Scala.

Beautiful interior. We bought $5 tickets in advance to a performance of the symphony. We went inside the lobby & got a quick look around, but were then sent outside and around the corner to enter a side door to climb MANY stairs to get to our seats. This is not a handicapped friendly location! The music was wonderful and the interior of the opera house is breath-taking. I'd heartily recommend buying tickets in advance (it's very easy online). We enjoyed our visit very much.

A gorgeous jewel box of an opera house. History comes alive at this intimate theater. You can imagine the carriages bringing the 19th C aristocrats up the cobble stone ramp to the portico main entrance. As other reviewers have mentioned, the first row of the boxes are recommended, but compared to other famous opera houses around the world, anywhere you sit the tickets are inexpensive. We were lucky enough to get excellent seats for a performance of Parsifal on Good Friday. Try getting to the outside terrace during intermission. It's great for people watching both on the terrace and on the street below.

Fantastic!. Wonderful evening- world class singers, and beautiful environment. The house was packed. Lines at cloakroom and at bars during the interval are incredibly fast, but doors sdo not open until 30 mins before performance.

More beautiful than the Vienna State Opera House. What a pleasant surprise. Having only a short time (one day) in Budapest, I struggled with what to include for sightseeing. I'm so glad we went here.The architecture of the building is striking, and the interiors, unlike Vienna's, are still original. I took dozens of photos, and the small group tour size meant everyone could see/hear everything that was pointed out, and the guide's perfect english insured we all understood and could ask questions. We visited the Vienna State Opera House later in our vacation, and it simply couldn't compare to the beauty and detail of Budapest's.

Wonderful experience. Saw Cosi Fan Tutte. Fantastic performance and the opera house is small enough for it to feel 'intimate'. If you can afford it go for seats in the front row of the boxes - we were in the centre, 2nd floor, and the view was great. Tickets were bought online and cost 8900 HUF - about £27 each. If you sit in the back rows of the box you end up looking round people or standing up so it is worth the extra to sit in front. The cheaper seats up top and in the middle looked fine too but sides may give a restricted view. Some people commented on the price of drinks - we paid 500 HUF for cans of soft drinks. This is about £1.50. Anyway a night to remember - beautiful singing in a stunning building.

Fantastic 45-minute tour - FANTASTIC guides!. Greetings & Good Cheer,A must for any Budapest visit. The guides are knowledgeable and friendly. Price to value ratio = excellent. Opt for the "mini concert" at end of tour. It' short but a real treat. I had cause to communicate with the office staff prior to arrival, and believe me when I say, warm, friendly, and very enthusiastic about the positions and their beautiful opera house. Enjoy!Almost forgot: Cashiers are multi-lingual, friendly, and very nice.

Overpriced. Pushy tour guide.. We went on a tour as part the English group. OurTour guide was immensely pushy. Despite paying an extra 500HUF to take photographs our tour guide left us absolutely no time to tame the after she had finished her blurb. She even had the tenacity to "tell off" some Americans for taking photographs when the rest of the group were waiting for them. Not strictly true. More time to do this would have been appreciated. I would also have appreciated more timeIn the actual auditorium as I felt rushed on this. My partner and I joked that this is run by "cash cow tours!". At times there were 3 different groups in one room with three different languages being spoken everyone is trying to shout the loudest rather than sorting out their organisation. I missed a fair bit of what was said. I'm glad I got a discount off this with my Budapest card, but it still fails to represent value for money.

Beautiful Building; Hard to hear the tour guide at times. I really enjoyed touring the Hungarian Opera House. My husband and I went to both Budapest and Vienna, so we were able to tour the opera houses in both cities within a couple of days of one another to compare them. I liked both very much, as the buildings are extremely beautiful inside and out. The only issue with the tour is that they offer like 6 tours at once to accommodate multiple languages. The English tour is most crowded, maybe 40 people on our tour. So it was hard to hear him in our own group, but even more so with several different foreign languages talking over one another in basically the same space. The guide did the best he could, but I wish they could maybe offer an additional English tour to thin out the groups a little so that everyone could hear the history. Nevertheless, please take the tour (or see a show) - the building is well-worth seeing even if you cannot hear all of the details of its history.

Don't waste your money on the tour. Of all the tours we have ever taken in all the cities we have visited his one is amongst the worst. For the relatively high price of 2850 HUF (about $15) each you get to stand in a very hot line to buy tickets, get to stand in another line to enter into the foyer, and get to stand as a (language) group waiting for the tour guide(s) to show up about 10-15 minutes after the scheduled start time of the tour. The tour comprises sitting for about 5 minutes in the auditorium, being shepherded into and out of "Sissy's box", parlour and stairwell and the ante-room to the emporer's box. That's it. Most of the time is spent being herded around (all the tours in all the languages start at the same time) and crowd controlled as the various tour groups compete for space and their 30 seconds of peeking. Its also very hard to hear the tour guide (no microphone). Total time on the tour is 20 minutes - and then one is summarily ushered out into the street. Compared to other tours of other Opera Houses (Paris, Vienna...) this is by far the worst. Not worth the HUFs. Try and catch a performance instead.

Don't miss this ...... The building itself is wonderful - the prices are fantastic (buy your tickets online) - you won't get cheaper tickets to an Opera/Ballet anywhere else in Europe.This is an experience that will stay with you - isn't that what travel is all about....!I saw Bizet's Carmen - but really, it is the atmosphere, and the sense of history that you come away with.....I can't recommend it enough.

Breathtaking. We went to see the classic piece, Tosca, and it was nothing less than breathtaking. I have not seen any building that beautiful in my life (see photos attached).A local friend provided tickets for the front row in box no. 9 (first floor, very good view) and what a great performance and great sound. Engineers has classified the acoustics as the third best in Europe and that for an opera house that opened in 1884).If you are lucky as us and have the opportunity, this is a MUST!

Great performance in the State Opera - go if you can get tickets. hi All -we went to see the Ballet in the Opera house; its really nice and as a foreigner you do not rely on the language problem. We got tickets via our Hotel desk and paid about 30 euros for top tickets
Really good accoustic. Amazing interior, cheap tickets for the top floor. If you are lucky you spend only 3 Euros.
Worth seeing - beautiful interior. The outside is a bit dingy and need of cleaning, but the interior is beautiful. The guided tour was pretty good also.

Great opera, beautiful building. Got tickets to La Boheme on-line. The tickets are available for sale one month ahead of the performance online. Apparently everybody wanted to see the opera at Christmas time, so we were very lucky to get seats at all. The operahouse is beautiful, sort of smaller version of the great Paris Opera house, Opera Garnier with a grand stair case, and gallery too. All the marble and gilding, and poshy boxes. The Hungarian State operas performance of La Boheme in Dec 22 2009 was a very good one, great singing albeit occasionally singers really had to fight the orchestra from taking over. The sets were just wonderful, the view over Paris roofs made you believe you were actually there, the Latin Quarter scene was a vibrant one, and the winter scene at the toll gate, with all the trees and snow was so romantic and realistic at the same time, it was very beautiful. The set painters excelled in their job! Accoustics are good. The seats however, at the orchestea level were not very comfortable, they had very little stuffing on the wooden seats. But since the opera had two intermissions, this wasn't a problem. They had so manu bars in the grand gallery that there was virtually no waiting to get a drink or a sandwich, coffee etc. The prices, as in most operas, were on the high side. There is a place to leave your coat, and outerwear for a small charge. The ladies responsible are very nice and very efficient.Getting to the Opera is easy as it has it's own Metro station. Please note that the doors to the Opera do not open until 45 minutes ahead of the start, and you're not allowed in (to get your coat checked, and to your seat) until 30 minutes prior to performance begins.

Go see a show!. http://www.opera.hu/index_e.php?lang=en&module=main_engWe booked tickets to see the ballet (Taming of the Shrew) at the Opera House in Budapest, online (before our trip), We used the above site that takes you to a link site. The tickets are extremely cheap and are even cheaper than a tour of the opera house! We had a box seat, which had limited viewing. If you get a box seat, make sure you are on row 1 to ensure you can see the show!It is very grand inside as you would expect. The staff speak basic English and direct you to your seats. There is a bar in there that you can use in the interval - drinks are very expensive though and it gets very busy.The show was very good and well worth the whole £2 each that we paid!!!

Lovely building. Went to a performance of "The Karamazovs" in November 2009, which was a ballet. Now Ballet really isnt our thing, which is why we left at the half time interval, but the real reason for attending was to get a look at the building, which was lovely, whilst having an hour's rest after trudging the streets of Budapest all day!The tickets in the upper balcony only cost us 900huf each, so a lot cheaper than a tour of the building. A picture is attached so you know what kind of view to expect from up there. We could see all of the stage. The central chandelier is massive and weighs 3 tons apparently. Dont think id want to be sat directly under it, then again its been there for 125 years without incident thus far!Would have been wonderful if some more agreeable entertainment (purely from a personal point of view) had been on whilst we were in Budapest but for £3 each im not complaining too much.

Beautiful, opulent opera house--excellent tour. We did not see a show, but went on a 45 minute tour of this beautiful historic building. Tthere 2 tours each afternoon in about 5 or 6 different languages--you go to the sign for your language. The guides are very knowledgeable and enthusiastic. You see the theater, stage, Emperor's box and changing room, etc. Interesting and enlightning tour.

A wonderful visit. It can be cheaper to buy tickets for a performance, than to pay for the guided tour. My wife and i paid 1200 Huf (approx £4) each, and had centre seats in the front row of the balcony, and saw an excellent performance of " The Barber of Seville" One of the highlights of our visit to Budapest. It is easy to booked tickets on the State Opera House web site at home and print the tickets off.
Beautiful, well worth the tour. We enjoyed our hour tour of the opera house. Our English speaking guide was knowledgeable and provided both historical and humorous insites.

great experience! be sure to see a show.. I was there in June 2009. My friend and I attended a Aida performance and the Romeo and Juliet Ballet. For the Ballet we sat in the grand circle balcony in the yellow zone second row. Our tickets were £3 each. The view was uninterrupted and the cost was an exceptional deal. Just as a warning for those that are 5'9" and taller these rows are quite close and difficult to get your legs to fit comfortably. For all grand circle tickets you enter from the side of the building and do not go up the grand staircase of the opera house. For Aida we sat in the 400 HUF (£1.28) tickets of box 5 level two. The second row of seats in the boxes had absolutely no view. If I stood I was able to see 1/3 of the stage. The single pink 3800 HUF ticket in the box is actually a chair on a raised platform that has roughly a 2/3 stage view. However these box tickets allow for entry through the main entrance and you get to go up the grand staircase.I enjoyed both performances. I would definitely recommend attending a performance over taking a tour personally. We booked out tickets ahead of time.

Enjoy a performance for a very reasonable cost. The opera house is not only a lovely building and interior, but its performances are very reasonable. Seats start from 400 HUF (roughly £1.30), altho these seats have a very restricted view. We paid 1200 Huf (about £4 each) for seats at the back of the balcony with a good central view and the opera was lovely. Definitely worth doing this as the tours of the opra house are quite expensive in comparison. However be warned that the opera season stops in July and August. Still the opera house is definitely worth a visit just to see the building, and anyone can go into the buildling's main entrance!

Supplement the standard tour with a performance. The standard (English) tour of the Opera House was my biggest disappointment in Budapest...and it's still getting a "Very Good" rating. There's nothing really wrong with the tour; I just didn't find it worthwhile in and of itself.So, if I had the opera house to do over, I'd either:1. Walk into the lobby and absorb the interior from there and then walk around the exterior (the front and one of the sides) in order to appreciate the building's exterior. This superficial "tour" is free and it's not TOO much less involved than taking in the standard tour by itself.OR2. Take the standard tour and then see a performance sometime during your stay. This way, the small bits of dough that you get on the tour will have a chance to rise into a satisfying piece of bread.Again, there's really nothing wrong with the standard tour...I just didn't find it worthwhile by itself. So, I suggest staying either completely superficial (and self-guided & free) or supplement the standard tour with a performance. The latter option costs more time and money, but IMO that investment is necessary because the standard tour by itself gives you five or six tidbits of information that immediately deflate once you leave the building.

A must see. I would really recommend going to see an Opera whilst in Budapest. It is a great way to spend an evening and the building inside is beautiful. I have never seen an opera before but it was fantastic. I read in other reviews that you can get tickets from £1 & at the time I booked on-line they were from about £3.5. We opted for the £20 tickets & got a box right near the stage about 2 levels up (couldnt see the very far right of the stage but it didnt matter) - I am glad we paid the extra for the experience. If you have cheaper tickets you have to enter via the side entrace but I dont know at what the lowest price you can enter via the front is. If you are on a tight budget you really cant go wrong for a few quid! The opera house is easy to get to and the metro stops outside if you dont want to walk. There didnt seem to be a dress code as there were a few people in jeans and trainers, but I think it is nice to go looking a little bit smarter. Cameras are allowed inside just not during the performance!Read the story of your opera before you go otherwise you will not know what is happening! The singing is in Italian and the subsitles above the stage are in Hungarian. You can buy a simple programme for about HUF 350 if you forget!

Very nice. I've just been to Budapest and it is a very nice city. A very nice local law student, Ucey showed me quite a lot of the attractions of the city and this one was one of them. We were able to sneak into the building and see the interior. I recommend everyone to write him -- to get signed up for his tour! Ucey, double thumbs up! :)

Magnificent. Visited the Opera House in March 2009. We had no problem in obtaining the seats next to the Royal Box.We have paid £80 for two tickets from the Box Office.The quality of performance was fantastic. From the orchestra to the singers to the set. The building is magnificent. Highly recommended.

Fantastic experience so cheap!. A female friend and myself booked to see the ballet at the Opera House in Jan 2009 (Snow White). My friend is a fan of ballet and I am a fan of gorgeous buildings, so we thought it would be a good experience for us both. We booked online and could get a tickets for as little as £1 each, which is much cheaper than booking guided tours and is such a fantastic experience!It's a beautifully grand building and it was an amazing atmosphere to be a part of. The cheap £1 tickets are very high up and do compromise your view a little, but it's still a price you can't complain at. You have to use a side entrance to the building when using these cheaper tickets, so you don't get to see much of the grand interior until you're up the stairs to the bar and cloakroom. The more expensive tickets are still very affordable and let you use the main entrance to the building which is good if you want to have a nose at the grandeur! The price at the box office is exactly the same as the online price which is very reasonable.You have to use the cloakroom as they don't allow any coats or large bags into the actual theatre, but that costs around £1 also.The ballet itself was fantastic. Quite humourous and colourful, there was a large orchestra accompanying and I am told that the dancing was technically very good!Overall, it's a definite must-do when in Budapest. Even if you are only interested in looking inside the building itself. The price is so reasonable it shouldn't be missed!

Fantastic tour of the Opera House. I'd say this was one of the highlights of our trip, it is a truly beautiful building and has fascinating history. We had a small guide group of about 10 people with an excellent host who spoke good english. She was very humourous and gave us a quirky history of the building, you could tell she really loved her subject and was very knowledgeable on all aspects. She guided us through the history of the House, focusing more on the people, the kind of people who would afforded to visit the opera, how they would dress, how they would behave, how they used the stage, where different people would be seated etc. It was very interesting and I'd say it's a definate must on any trip to Budapest. The architecture itself is of course stunning and not to be missed.

Excellent value; shame about the surtitles. Just as everyone says, a stunning opera house, and the sense of history and tradition is everywhere - from the bust of Miklos Banffy on the grand stairway to the continuation of Mahler's tradition of playing the Leonore No3 overture before the final scene of Fidelio. This is where Matthew Barney filmed Cremaster 5! Fidelio was gloriously sung, and even more gloriously played (under the house conductor Janos Kovacs, not Fischer; this was a Sunday morning matinee) in a fascinating, though-provoking contemporary production (rather condescendingly, we'd expected old-school Eastern-bloc cardboard realism). And thrilling to get a box seat for £15. Booked online from the UK; excellent online box-office system and the e-tickets worked perfectly. Loved the range of chilled Tokays and lavish patisserie available in the interval. Surrounded by Budapest folk in furs and jewels, sipping wine and smoking, it felt like being back before 1914. A terrific experience. But...(and I know many opera lovers will disagree with this)...as opera fans in our 30s, we expect surtitles today, and in a major house in a major European capital we think it's reasonable to expect them in English as well as Hungarian, the more so as the programme book was available in English, Hungarian and German - leading us to expect this. But they were in Hungarian only. I mean no disrespect to the Hungarian language, but clearly an international audience is expected in Budapest, so it's strange that it wasn't catered for - especially in an opera as dependent as Fidelio on spoken dialogue. At the Geneva Grand Theatre, surtitles are trilingual, so it's perfectly do-able!  This was a serious disapointment; the lighting was too low to read the libretto we'd brought along and while I knew the opera well enough not to need a translation, my partner - hearing Fidelio for the first time - was left frustrated and confused. Hearing this, of all operas, for the first time, in one of the greatest opera houses in the world, shouldn't be a frustrating experience.

Gorgeous opera house but performances perhaps not for first time opera-goers. I think the Budapest opera house is one of the prettiest I've been to. It is smaller than some other European houses, but gorgeously baroque with a good deal of ornate detail. Ticket prices are very reasonable--so much so that I think, unless you are more a fan of architecture than opera, you should skip spending money on a tour and instead spend your money on a ticket to a performance. I saw Cosi Fan Tutte in Feb 2007 for under $10 and still had very good seats. At intermission the weather was just warm enough for us to enjoy a drink out on top of what I now know is called the "risalit" (under which carriages once dropped people off for a night out at the opera). From there you get a nice view of Andrassy Ut.For first time opera-goers, be aware that there are no English sub or supra titles available. There are only Hungarian supra-titles. So if you are uncomfortable not knowing what is being sung, I wouldn't suggest this as your first opera experience.

Saw "Cosi Fan Tutte" last June for $4!. We couldn't believe we could get tickets the day of the performance for just $4! That's 800HU/forints. It was almost sold out and the performance was magnificent. Balcony seats but still very good. You can tour the Opera House during the day so you can learn about the building's gorgeous architecture...very worthwhile.

Parsifal in Good Friday, how appropriate.. We went to Parsifal on Good Friday. It was well done, well sung and well played. No complaints at all. The audience was extremely happy with the performance and applauded and bravoed for longer than usual. We had great seats on the first floor with full view of the stage and the musicians. It is a beautiful building with an oldy-worldy feeling, paintings and big chandelier. We booked our seats on the internet and received them a week later by the post.Be warned though about the selection of operas in Easter. The themes are very appropriate for a 'catholic' Easter if you are happy with that.It means no comedy and no laughs but 'serious' works. Parsifal's religious, mysthical theme and length (3 acts, a bit more than 5 hours, starting at 5.00pm) can put off opera first-timers. There is also the question of language. Wagner's operas are of course in German. The simultaneous translation screen on top of the stage translates into...Magyar, of course! And the programme is very helpful..in Magyar, German and French. Have a look at the opera's summary in Wikipedia and then book your ticket, you will love it!

Disappointing production of Janufa. I agree with a previous reviewer that the Erkel seems to produce better productions than the Opera House. I saw Janacek's Janufa in March 2006 and it was a production disaster. The settings varied from ridiculous to non-existent. Lighting was poor. The acting unimpressive. Chubby tenors who are supposed to be handsome leading men don't seem very real to me and I do like some realism in the production. In contrast, at the Erkel I saw a sumptuous production of Puccini's Turandot. Costuming lighting, setting, acting . . . all were infinitely superior to the weak Opera House production of Janufa. I'll be seeing Janufa again at Glimmerglass Opera (NY) in a couple of months. I'm anticipating a handsome presentation typical of Glimmerglass with an emphasis on acting and action. But remember, you're making a big mistake if you don't experience a performance at the magnificent Budapest Opera House. I feel that it is much superior architecturally and in terms of decor to the Vienna Opera House.

Not as good as the Erkel!. We went to 4 operas in Budapest over 4 nights - two at the State Opera House (Mozart's Don Giovani & Shostakovich's Lady Macbeth) and two at the Erkel Theatre (Verdi's Rigoletto and Bellini's Norma). Despite the fact that the State Opera gets all the publicity, the operas staged at the Erkel were infinitely better - in terms of both singing and production. This was evident, too, in the audience response: desultry clapping at the State Opera, repeat curtain calls at the Erkel where the singing was as good as at Covent Garden or the Met. Although the surroundings at the Erkel are no where near as grand as at the State Opera, the seats are a lot more comfortable and there is more leg room! And we couldn't find a bar at stalls level during the interval in the State Opera (although there was one 4 flights up). And the Ekel wasn't overheated!

Opera House. Worth a visit! It is compulsory to join the tour and they offer different languages. You need to buy the tour ticket at their souvenir shop and need to be on time! The opera house is stunning in architecture as well as its acoustic.
